column12:
*June 1: The curfew was removed in Albania. Cars are allowed to move freely in all parts of the country.
*April 25: The duration of the “state of natural disaster” was prolonged by the government until June 23, 2020.

* All persons entering Albania from the COVID-19 affected areas are required to be mandatorily self-quarantined for a period of 14 days from the date of entry into the border.
*April 5: The Prime Minister announced that the daily period for going out to buy food will be extended to 90 min throughtout the week and citizens will be allowed to use their personal car.
*March 24: The PM decreed a 'state of natural disaster' across the country, a measure that suspends some basic rights and allows authorities to seize private properties or raid homes if deemed necessary (the PM can maintain these measure for up to 30 days before calling a vote in Parliament to extend them).

* Government deployed troops to enforce a 40-hour curfew as self-isolation has not been thoroughly implemented by citizens.

* Albania implemented a 16-hour curfew: individuals are only permitted to shop and go to work from 5:00 to 13:00, after which security forces will enforce the curfew.

* March 19: pedestrians can only be outside at limited hours. Walking on the streets accompanied by other people is banned.
column14:
* June 15: Albania opened air borders with Greece.

* June 1: Public transportation remains closed.

* June 1: Albania opened land borders with all neighbouring countries.

* April 27: Taxi services are now allowed for a maximum of two passengers from the same family per car.
*April 5: The Prime Minister announced that the government will begin to impose sever penalties (e. g. imprisonment) for those who do not obey the measures.

* March 29: The Ministry of Europe and Foreign Affairs started repatriation operations for Albanian citizens.

* March 15: The government adopted an emergency law that allows people to be fined for various breaches of measures to contain the spread of the coronavirus.

* Public and private transportation are suspended except for ambulances, vehicles performing public service functions and those transporting goods, accompanied with an authorisation by state police.

* March 15: all land access to Albania is closed to all passengers by bus, minibus and car.

* Albania's land border will remain open only for the transport of goods.

* Air and sea transport services with Italy have been suspended.

* Maritime borders with Greece are closed as well (except for freight vessels).

* Internal circulation by private cars between regions was also restricted.
column16:
* June 1: Kindergartens and day-care facilities reopened in Albania.

* June 1: Schools are only open for high school graduates taking university admission exams.

* April 28: The Minister of Education, announced that schools will reopen in September 2020. Students in the 1st to the 11th grade will continue to attend online classes from home until May 29, 2020.
'
* March 9: Educational institutions are closed.
column18:
* June 1: Mass gatherings, weddings, public hearings and other kind of gathering remain banned.

* June 1: Indoor bars and restaurants, swimming pools, theatres, cinemas and nightclubs remain closed.
'
* March 15: As part of the emergency law adopted by the government, fine of 5 million LEK (40 000 euros) for organising social, cultural or political gathering.
column20:
* June 10: Beaches are opened for all tourists. A licensing authority is in charge to make sure that all beach areas fulfill the required conditions.

* June 1: Beaches are opened for hotels only.

* May 18: Individual sports training are allowed in open areas.

* May 18: Museums, art galleries and archaeological sites are opened.

* May 18: Bars and restaurants resumed activities only on the exterior of their facilities.

* May 11: Driving schools, hairdressers, barbershops, dental clinics and stores in shopping malls were allowed to resume activity.

* April 27: New wave of businesses was able to resume their activities, enabling 27 589 employees to return to work. These include different types of stores such as clothing stores, shoe and leather goods shops, furniture and household items stores, florist shops, lighting, electronic and telecommunications equipment stores.

* April 20: The government allowed economic activity to resume for 600 sectors such as agriculture and animal husbandry, food production, mining and textile industry as well as the fishing sector.
column22: * March 19: 10 billion LEK (80 million euros) are provided to companies that have difficulties in paying employee salaries, through the instrument of a sovereign guarantee
column25:
*April 1: The Prime Minister announced that the doctors, nurses and health workers on the front line will receive an additional 1 000 EUR payment. The supporting personnel (including ambulance drivers) will benefit from an additional payment of 500 EUR (this measure is applicable during the COVID-19 crisis).

* March 15: As part of the emergency law adopted by the government, private hospitals that refuse to offer their capacities when required can be fined up to 5 million LEK (40 000 euros)

* 2.5 billion LEK (20 million euros) for the fight against the virus, are made available to the Ministry of Health for medical equipment and materials or support of medical staff.
column28:
* The government promised it will pay the salaries of about 60 000 employees of small businesses or self-employed people, which will cost about 1.57 billion leks (13 million euros).

* April 13: The Prime Minister announced an extended aid package that will support 100 000 employees in small businesses, which have been affected during the weeks of restricted movements; 66 000 employees in large businesses that have been affected during these weeks in their workplaces; 10 000 employees in the tourism sector. As of April 20, 176 000 families will receive a direct payment of 40 000 LEK (323 euros).
'
* The government will temporarily double monthly social benefits for about 70 000 very poor families at a cost of 340 million leks (about 2.8 million euros).

* 6.5 billion LEK (52 million euros) allocated for the most immediate needs to the most disadvantaged part of the population, to small businesses and for potential unemployment due to the fight against the virus.
column31: Information not available
column34: Information not available
column37: * The government will reschedule, in the second half of 2020 and onwards, the profit tax for all businesses up to the range of 2-14 million LEK (16 000 to 113 000 euros) turnover. There will be a postponement of balance sheet submission for a period up to 1 June 2020 for businesses submitting balance sheets to NBC online or directly.
column40: Information not available
column43: Information not available
column46:
* May 28: The Central Bank of Albania announced the temporary suspension of the payment of loan instalments for all categories of customers, for an additional period, from 1 June to 31 August 2020. It also suspended temporarily the creation of reserve funds for real estates obtained instead of the payment of loans until December 2020.

* May 28: Banks can restructure current loan agreements in order to find adequate solutions depending on borrowers' solvency until 31 December 2020 without additional provisioning costs and without deteriorating the status of the borrowers. The current regulation and requirements related to the restructuring of loans will be in place for one more year until January 2022.

* The Bank of Albania suspended dividend distribution for 2019 and 2020 for banks until the end of June in order to boost capital and support lending during this period. The Bank of Albania also halved the salaries of its supervisory board and top management for the duration of the pandemic.

* March 25: the Central Bank of Albania decided to further ease the monetary policy stance and the monetary and financial conditions in Albania, by (a) reducing the policy rate from 1% to 0.5%; (b) reducing the interest rate for the overnight lending facility from 1.9% to 0.9%; (c) maintaining the interest rate for the overnight deposit facility unchanged at 0.1%.
column47: Information not available
column48:
* Extension of the deadline of payment of loans to enterprises and households that may face difficulties during this period due to the coronavirus COVID-19.

* March, 19: The government will permanently erase late payment interests for active debtors who are current energy consumers, family or small business, with a financial effect of up to 15 billion LEK (121 million euros). The measure will benefit to 21 124 subsribers.
column54:
* The Council of Ministers decided that the salary of the Prime Minister, the government cabinet and the deputies will be halved for a period of three months, while the Presidency offered to voluntarily give up 50% of their salary.

* The supervisory board and top management of the Central Bank of Albania had their salaries halved for the duration of the pandemic.
column55:

column12:
* September 2: Access to beaches, public swimming pools, and all naval clubs is prohibited through October 15, 2020.

* August 9: Angola extends the State of Public Calamity until September 8th. According to the second phase of the Public Calamity regime, women with children under 12 years of age must return to work from August 15 to perform 50 % of the working period, in person.

* August 9: The physical exercises in public space can be performed from 5 to 8pm, individually or with a group of five people. During the physical activity the wearing of the mask is not required. Regarding the gymnasiums, which are still closed in Luanda, those who violate this ban will pay a fine ranging from 10 to 15 thousand kwanzas.

* July 14: The Angolan government has instituted a mandatory 14-day quarantine for anyone entering the country, regardless of citizenship. The Government of Angola has set up multiple quarantine sites throughout the country, including two just outside of the capital city of Luanda. Upon arrival in Luanda, travelers may choose between staying at one of several government-approved hotel quarantine locations (at personal expense) or a government-run quarantine center.

* July 9: Public transportation can operate until 6:00 p.m. only (at 75%of passenger capacity). The use of face masks is lifted only while walking or exercising outside during the approved hours of 5:30 to 7:30 and 17:00 to 19:00.

* May 25: Angola replaced the state of emergency with the state of public calamity setting the tone for a gradual resumption of regular life disrupted by the COVID-19 pandemic in the country.

* May 8: Government of Angola approved the third period of state of emergency for another 15 days, starting on May 11.

* April 24: The sanitary restrictions have been lifted in 17 out 18 provinces and people are now able to move to other provinces for commerce and business, excluding to and from Luanda.
*April 24: Angola authorities extend state of emergency until May 10.
*April 10: Angola extends state of emergency for two weeks, between 11 and 25 April.

* March 26: the government announced a 15-day state of emergency that may be extended automatically. The measures include restrictions on movement within national territory. Citizens are only allowed to leave their home places to buy essential goods and services.
column14:
* August 9: The Angolan Government has extended the hours of operation of public and private urban and interurban public passenger transport, from 5 am to 10 pm. In the province of Luanda the occupation capacity remains up to 50% and in other provinces it increases to 75%. Regarding the motor-taxi service, it is stated that they operate between 6 a.m. and 10 p.m., being mandatory the use of a face mask for the passenger and driver. Violation of the rule will result in a fine ranging from 5,000 to 10,000 kwanzas (about USD 17 to USD 25.5].

* August 9: The country's national borders remain closed. Only nationals and foreign residents can return to the national territory, foreign citizens to their respective countries and official trips. The entry into the national territory is subject to the completion of RT-PCR pre-boarding test 72 hours before the trip.
*July 27: The Ministry of Transport, in a joint action with the Government of Luanda, increased the number of public buses to 220 as a measure to improve road traffic in the capital of the country during the pandemic. Passenger capacity is at 50% and public transport is available from 5am to 6pm.

* July 14: Land borders remain closed for all but commercial transport, and the areas within the quarantine districts (Luanda Province and the municipality of Cazengo, in the Province of Cuanza Norte) are closed to overland personal travel or domestic passenger flights through August 9, 2020.

* July 9: Angola remains closed to commercial flights.

* June 17: Angola remains closed to passenger flights, however, the government has announced that commercial flights may resume June 30. Land borders remain closed for all but commercial transport and Luanda Province remains closed to overland personal travel or domestic passenger flights.

* All borders have been closed.

* March 20: the government closes the country's air, land, and sea borders for 15 days. Future updates will depend on the progress of the pandemic.

* March 18: Passengers and airline crew travelling from China (People's Rep.), France, Iran, Italy, Korea (Rep.), Portugal or Spain are not allowed land in Angola. Residents, airline crew and nationals of Angola who travel from these countries are allowed to land, but they are quarantined.
column16:
* September 2: Schools remain closed. It is permitted to hold classes virtually only, and not in person.
*April 01: Given the closure of schools, the Angolan Ministry of Education has been offering teleclasses, broadcast by the Angolan Public Television (TPA), as a resource to maintain students training.

* March 24: closure of schools and universities.
column18: * March 26: the government announces restrictions of gatherings with more than 50 people.
column20:
* July 9: Angola continues to operate under a “State of Calamity.” However, restaurants, which were previously allowed to remain open for onsite dining until 10:30 p.m. (at no more than 50 percent capacity), now must close at 4:00 p.m. (note: restaurants remain open until 10:00 pm for take-away services only). Beaches, pools, and marinas remain closed, as do movie theaters, libraries, and media centers.

* May 27: public services reopen with 50% of the workforce, from June 8 with 75% and from June 29 there will reach a 100%. In Luanda, it will be 75% on June 29 and the entire workforce on July 13. Trade in goods and services in general returns to work, between 07:00 and 19:00. The establishments must ensure the mandatory use of the mask. Industrial, farming and fishing activities will also be retaken, with mandatory use of masks by workers and physical distance. In civil construction, there will be a first phase from May 26, for urgent and strategic public works, and a second phase, from June 8. Restaurants can already open in Angola, but only to serve lunches.
*March 26: all commercial establishments are shut down, except those providing essential services
- such as banks, telecommunications, press services and markets. "Informal street markets” are prohibited.
column22:
* April 6: As part of the announced package of measures to tackle coronavirus, Angola reduces ministerial departments from 28 to 21, merges institutes and national directorates, freezes the recruitment of new civil servants, introduces exemptions on customs duties and VAT payments, and forbids the export of medical equipment.
* Additional health care spending to mitigate corona virus, estimated at US$40 million, was announced. Tax exemptions on humanitarian aid and donations were granted. Some delays on filing taxes for selected imports were granted.
* March 25: The Government is working on a package of measures to fight the coronavirus outbreak in the country and its economic fallout
column25:
* August 21: The regional molecular virology laboratory, located in Benguela General Hospital, started to perform the first tests for diagnosis of Sars cov2. The laboratory will work with six senior technicians and has the capacity to test 279 samples per day for the diagnosis. Huila's virology laboratory, set up at Lubango Central Hospital, has also began diagnosing. It is the third province to carry out tests for the diagnosis of Covid-19, along with Luanda and Benguela.

* August 4: According to the Secretary of State for Public Health, a laboratory with a capacity to conduct one thousand COVID-19 tests a day will open in northeastern Lunda Norte next September, to serve the country's three eastern provinces (Lunda Sul, Lunda Norte and Moxico). In addition, three other laboratories will be established in the provinces of Luanda, Huambo (centre) and Uije (north) to carry out six thousand tests a day. The Angolan State has spent five million US dollars to purchase the equipment.
*June 3: A field hospital for COVID-19 patients with six hundred beds, of which 140 are reserved for intensive care, was inaugurated in the Luanda-Bengo Special Economic Zone. When the second phase of the project is completed, within a month, the hospital will have capacity for 1,000 patients.
*June 1: The authorities have purchased about 380 tons of biosecurity material from China, including 50 thousand test kits.
*April 28: The daily testing capacity has been increased from 90 to 300 tests.

* April 16: a caravan of public health specialists left Luanda for the regions. The initiative is receiving technical and financial support from the WHO.

* Additional 260 Cuban doctors arrived in Angola and are expected to be allocated country wide.

* April 7: Due to the increase of confirmed cases, the Health Ministry announced the application of the civil requisition law, requiring retired health care professionals to report to service and reinforce the health sector.

* April 6: 350 health professionals were recruited among retired people and unemployed technicians by the Angolan Order of Nurses (ORDENFA) in Lunda Sul. This measure aims at strengthening the treatment of quarantined people and the hospital services in the province.

* April 6: Angola ensures free distribution of water.

column46:
*April 18: To mitigate risks of shortages of essential goods, which are predominantly imported, the BNA instructed banks to provide credit in local currency to assist importers.
* April 3: BNA announced that the minimum allocation of credit to priorities products would increase from 2 percent to 2.5 percent of the commercial banks net assets.
* March 31: The central bank announced the following measures:

* A liquidity line with a maximum value of KZ 100 billion will be established for the acquisition of government securities held by non-financial corporations;

* The interest rate on the liquidity absorption facility, with a seven-day maturity, has been reduced from 10% to 7%;

* Bank reserves will be used to extend credit to 54 producers in the agriculture, fisheries, and industry sectors that fall under the Prodesi export diversification programme;

* Restrictions to the import of basic foods and medicines are relaxed;

* From April 1, oil companies and the National Oil and Gas Agency (ANPG) will be allowed to use the Bloomberg terminal for the sale of foreign currency to commercial banks.

* March 30: financial institutions that carry out credit operations are now allowed to grant their clients a moratorium of 60 days for servicing the debt
- measure with a duration of two months.

* March 27: the central bank (BNA) announced the equivalent of 0.5 percent of GDP to be provided as liquidity support to banks and created a liquidity line of US$186 million for the purchase of government securities from non-financial corporations.
column47: Information not available
column54: Information not available

column12: The government has ordered complete confinement of the population from 20 March until 20 September. Police is controlling the streets and non-compliance with measures is prosecuted as criminal offence. From 7 June until 20 September, the strict confinement only applies to a zone comprising the city and province of Buenos Aires and other provinces, where new Covid cases are concentrated. In other provinces social distancing measures are in place. Since 27 April, provincial governments have the authority to decide on exemptions to the national quarantine, if certain epidemiological criteria are fulfilled, but certain activities remain closed nation-wide (such as school classes, public events, shopping malls, restaurants and bars, recreational and touristic activities, and interregional public transport). Women and members of the LGBT community are explicitly exempt from the quarantine in case they need to report charges due to domestic violence.
column14: All borders are entirely closed from 27 March until 20 September.
column16: All schools and universities closed as of March 16. Online schooling platforms were introduced.
column18: All shops and public spaces are closed from March 20 until 20 September.
column20: All shops and public spaces are closed from 20 March until 20 September, only supermarkets, small groceries shops, hardware stores and pharmacies, certain parts of public administration as well as essential production and services activities remain open. As of 3 April, the following additional activities are excluded from the mandatory quarantine: distribution of construction materials, mining, forestry, manufacturing of wood, furniture, leather as well as agricultural or construction machines, imports and exports of already produced items, nuclear fuel production, maintenance and desinfection services, as well as a minimum service of banks and savings and credit cooperatives. Notary services are excluded as of 8 April, and repair services for cars, personal care services, and home delivery of IT and office equipment as of 11 April. As of 6 April, a specific certificate is necessary for all workers and other individuals allowed to leave their household during the confinement. As of 20 April, retail activities through online platforms, doctor visits, and payment service centres are exempted from the quarantine. In many provinces, authorities have started to lift containment measures gradually since 27 April and many economic activities have been allowed to resume. From 7 June until 20 September, the strict confinement measures only apply to a zone comprising the city and province of Buenos Aires and other provinces, where new Covid cases are concentrated. From 31 August, construction and open-air restaurants and bars have been allowed to resume activities in the City of Buenos Aires.
column22: Public investment will be boosted by around 0.5% of GDP (USD 1.5 bn or 100 billion Pesos), mainly in road infrastructure, housing and school construction as well as infrastructure for tourism. Public credit subsidies for private housing construction will be reinstated and extended, providing opportunities to refurbish homes during confinement, with a focus on domestically produced materials. A specific infrastructure programme with resources of 29 Billion Pesos focuses on social housing as well as gas, electricity and sanitary infrastructure in disadvantaged neighbourhoods. Other measures to mitigate the economic costs of the crisis for households and businesses are detailed below.
column25: Twelve new emergency hospitals have been constructed. The government is cooperating with domestic equipment producers and laboratories to increase their supply and has started decentralised testing throughout the country as of 28 March. It has purchased 200,000 reagents for large-scale testing activities and the health system disposes of 8500 Intensive Care Units, which are supposed to be increased to 10,000. All workers in the health sector will receive a monthly bonus of 75 USD from April until July 2020. Prices for personal care, drugs and medical products have been fixed until 30 August at their levels observed 6 March. Exports of medical equipment necessary for the treatment of COVID infected patients require prior authorisation from the government. As of 1 April, imports of medical supplies and vaccines are exempted from import duties until the end of the emergency situation. Social security contributions and some taxes for companies providing healthcare-related services are reduced during the health emergency situation. The goverment has improved the access to online consultations with doctors, in particular for disadvantaged individuals. In August, the government has announced the joint production with Mexico of a potential vaccine developed by Oxford University, estimated to be ready for distribution during the 1H-2021.
column28:
- Households that live from informal activities, self-employment or domestic work and have suffered income losses will receive a one-off bonus of USD 150 in April, May and June.

- Conditional cash transfers to poor families are boosted by a one-off bonus of USD 50.

- Retirees and non-contributory pension beneficiaries with minimum pensions will obtain a USD 50 one-off bonus, while other benefits will be topped up to the new level of the regular minimum pension after including the bonus.

- Employers are not allowed to fire workers during a period of 180 days (as of 1 April), if the reason is related to the confinement measures or an unfair cause. They are required to pay at least 75% of the salaries of confined private sector workers, who could not continue working from home. For firms that have been strongly affected by the lock down, the state pays up to 50% of the original wage in April, May, June, July and August (find more details under firm support measures).

- People aged 60 and above, pregnant women and people in risk groups are dispensed from working and cannot face any negative consequences as a result (employers are required to continue paying the full wage).

- Unemployment insurance protection has been reinforced raising benefits for workers dismissed without a fair cause during the lockdown. The duration of unemployment benefits has been extended to 31 December for all unemployed workers, with a coverage of 70% of the original benefit in case of expiration of the original benefit duration.

- Public food programmes are expanded.

- All workers in the health sector will receive a monthly bonus of 75 USD from April until July.

- Workers in the security and public defense sector receive a one-off bonus of USD 75 in April.

- On 29 April, all households included in the conditional cash-transfer programme receive a one-off in-kind bonus of 62 USD or 93 USD (if more than one child), which is payed out through a specific credit card only usable for food purchases.

- Disadvantaged families that suffered the loss of a family member due to Covid-19 receive a one off bonus of 210 USD.
column31:
In sectors particularly affected by the lockdown social security contributions and payroll taxes for employers due in April, May, June, July and August are reduced by 95% or postponed for 2 months. A specific committee has been created to establish objective criteria for accessing these benefits (6 April).

- Social security contributions and some taxes for companies providing healthcare-related services are reduced during the health emergency situation.
column34:
- In sectors particularly affected by the lockdown the government will pay part of the salaries. A specific committee has been created to establish objective criteria for accessing these benefits (6 April). For affected firms, the government will pay for each worker 50% of the monthly wage in April, May, June, July, and August, at least one and maximum two minimum wages per worker. For particularly hard hit firms in the health services, tourism, culture and leasure services sectors, the wage support scheme will last until December 2020.

- Firms carrying out interregional transport services will receive a one of bonus totalling 500 Million Pesos.

- Family businesses engaged in local agricultural production are supported by 100 Million Pesos.
column37:
- Households' installments of credits granted by the Social Security Agency corresponding to April, May, June, July and August have been cancelled.

- Refunds for domestic taxes paid during the production process for exporting firms are accelerated.

- In sectors particularly affected by the lockdown social security contributions and payroll taxes for employers due in April, May, June, July and August are reduced by 95% or postponed for 2 months.

- Payments of taxes, social security contributions as well as export taxes and import duties can be split and paid using up to six monthly quotas.

- Due payments for taxes and social security cobtributions have been postponed for SMEs to 31 August. Due payments for export taxes have been postponed for SMEs until 30 September.
column40:
- Public and private banks will support private companies with working capital for up to 180 days. This measure targets firms most affected by the lockdown, especially small and medium size enterprises. Rates will be around half of current inflation, with an estimated fiscal cost of around 0.33% of GDP. Part of these credits will be directed to companies producing foodstuff, medicaments and hygienic articles as well as equipment necessary for teleworking. To protect banks, soft-credit lines will be guaranteed by the State through a Public Credit Guarantee Fund which has received additional resources from the government.

- The public sector provides loans of up to 2300 USD with zero interest rates to self-employed workers whose revenues have strongly decreased due to the crisis. The amount of the loan is equivalent to the average monthly revenue of the self-employed and paid out over three months (with repayment in twelve quotas starting after 6 months). The total fiscal cost of the measure amounts to around 11 billion Pesos and loan guarantees of 26 billion Pesos have been provided by the government. Since August, repayment of new loans for self-employed workers in the culture services sector starts after 12 months.
column43: Public credit guarantees for bank lending to micro, small and medium enterprises (SMEs) affected by the emergency situation have been reinforced.
column46: Monetary policy has been loosened considerably with policy rates decreasing by 25 percentage points since January and strong increases in the monetary base in March, April and May.
column47: Bank lending has been encouraged through lower reserve requirements for bank lending to households or SMEs, limits to bank holdings of Central Bank papers, and temporary easing of bank provisioning needs and of bank loan classification rules (i.e. extra 60 days to be classified as non-performing).
column48:
- Until 31 December, access to electricity, gas, water as well as phone lines, TV and internet will not be suspended for households unable to pay up to six monthly bills since March 2020. Utility prices are frozen at their March levels until 31 December. All price increases for the provision of phone line, TV and internet announced by providing firms from 31 July until 31 December 2020 are suspended.

- All rent contracts are automatically prolonged until 30 September, rents are fixed at their March levels and tenants cannot be forced to leave apartments due to non-payment of rents (as of 29 March).

- Until 30 September, payments for mortgage loans related to the first residence are fixed at their March levels and foreclosures are suspended.

- Until 31 December, banks are not allowed to close accounts due to bounced checks and charging commissions for the use of automatic cash machines are prohibited.

- As of 1 April, road toll collection is suspended until the end of the emergency situation. From 29 May, only workers in health and public security services sectors are exempted from road tolls, for others road toll collection has been resumed.

- Prices for food, personal care, drugs and medical products have been fixed until 30 August at their levels observed 6 March. Local mayors have the authority to conduct inspections and enforce the price controls as of 8 April.

- A program offering zero interest rates for the purchase of a wide range of products, such as food, medicaments and medical equipment, personal care and cleaning products, home appliances, wearing apparel and shoes, among others, using credit cards and up to 18 quotas was extended until 30 August.
column51:
- Until 31 December, access to electricity, gas, water as well as phone lines and internet will not be suspended for SMEs unable to pay up to six monthly bills since March 2020. Utility prices are frozen at their March levels until 31 December. All price increases for the provision of phone line, TV and internet announced by providing firms from 31 July until 31 December 2020 are suspended.

- Until 31 December, a stay on both bank account closures due to bounced checks and credit denial to companies with payroll tax arrears helps securing acess to banking services for affected companies.
column54: Information not available

column12: There are vast differences in the stringency of confinement rules across Australian states and territories. While most states are in an advanced stage of reopening, whereby public gatherings are allowed and most industries have restarted operations, the State of Victoria announced a state of disaster on 2 August to curb a resurgence in COVID-19 cases.  New restrictions in Victoria will last a period of six weeks (until Sunday 13 September) and will mean that residents of the state's capital, Melbourne, will be subject to a curfew whereby they must not leave their residence from 8pm to 5am unless it is for essential health, care or safety reasons. Non-essential retail businesses in Melbourne, administration and some manufacturing activity will be halted. Residents in Melbourne will only be permitted to leave their home for one of four reasons: i) one person per household will be allowed to leave once per day to purchase food and necessary supplies from businesses within a five kilometre radius of the home, ii) two people may exercise together for up to one hour within a five kilometre radius of home, iii) for care and health care, iv) travelling to work. Outside of Melbourne, the rest of the state has also increased restrictions, although the four reasons for leaving home are less strictly defined and the extent of industry shutdowns will be more modest.
column14: Only Australian citizens, residents and immediate family members can travel to Australia. From 9pm AEDT 20 March 2020, only Australian citizens, residents and immediate family members can travel to Australia. All travellers to Australia are required to self-isolate for 14 days. From 28 March, all travellers arriving in Australia will be required to undertake their mandatory 14 day self-isolation at designated facilities. On 24 March, it was announced that Australians are not allowed to take a return trip overseas, unless in exceptional circumstances (in mid-June, the ban was extended and will now run until 17 September). Cruise ships from foreign ports have been banned. Interstate travel is heavily curtailed, with some states such as Western Australia keeping state borders closed and most states banning or heavily restricting entry from Victorian residents. Tasmania had planned to reopen interstate borders to travellers from South Australia, Western Australia and Northern Territory on 7 August, but this planned reopening has now been pushed back to 31 August.
column16: Primary school and high school students have returned to face to face learning in most states. In some states and territories, university and adult education students are still being urged to work from home where possible. In the State of Victoria, the heightened restrictions announced on 2 August mean that all schools in the state have now moved to remote learning. Schools remain open for vulnerable children and the children of essential workers. Kindergartens and early childhood centres in metropolitan Melbourne are only open for vulnerable children and children whose parents are essential workers.
column18: Depending on the jurisdiction, the maximum permitted size of gatherings varies. In most states, restaurants, museums, galleries, playgrounds, places of worship, pools and gyms are open, albeit with slightly altered operations to allow for physical distancing and stricter hygiene standards. Sportig stadiums in several states have been opened to a limited number of spectators. Consistent with tighter confinement measures in Victoria announced on 2 August, gatherings in Victoria are not permitted.
column20: Most economic activities are now permitted in Australia other than those activities that bring many people together (e.g. entertainment and culture). However, non-essential retail businesses in Melbourne, administration and some manufacturing activity have been shutdown due to stricter restrictions announced by the Victorian government on 2 August.
column22: Total direct spending by Commonwealth Government of A$155bn (7.8% of GDP) and by State Governments of around A$36.9bn (1.5% of GDP).
column24: Total direct spending by Commonwealth and State Governments amounts to approximately A$164bn.
column25:
On 11 March, the Government committed an additional A$2.4 billion to support the health system to manage any further outbreak in Australia. The package provided support across primary care, aged care, hospitals, research and the National Medical Stockpile, along with a national communication campaign. The package also provided funding to ensure Australia had sufficient personal protective equipment and medicines in addition to infection control training and programs for health and aged care workers.
On 15 March 2020, the Prime Minister announced that health services had moved into the 'Targeted Action' stage of the Australian Health Sector Emergency Response Plan for Novel Coronavirus (COVID-19). This included moving resources within hospitals to priority areas, establishing fever clinics which specialise in COVID-19, cancelling non-urgent elective surgeries to free up capacity in public hospitals and adapting hospital resources (i.e. rooms and equipment) for use in priority areas, such as Intensive Care Units.
On 29 March, the Prime Minister announced an additional A$1.1 billion in funding for mental health services, domestic violence support, Medicare assistance for people at home (including through telehealth services) and emergency food relief.
On 31 March, the Government announced a partnership with private health providers for their infrastructure, essential equipment, supplies, workforce and additional resources to be made available to the public health system. In return, the government would ensure the viability of these enterprises. In essence, this agreement will integrate the private and public health systems in the event that capacity in the public system is strained.
On 26 April, the government launched the new voluntary app, COVIDSafe. It is intended that the app will help with tracking and tracing COVID-19 infections.
On 27 April, the first phase in reinstating elective surgeries commenced. Since then, there has been further reintroduction of elective surgery across states and territories.
column28:
On 30 March, the Commonwealth Government announced a planned wage subsidy to businesses (A$69bn or 3½% of GDP) to encourage them to keep workers in jobs. A “JobKeeper Payment” of A$1,500 per fortnight per eligible employee is being paid to businesses under the condition that every eligible employee receives at least A$1,500 per fortnight from the business. The Jobkeeper Payment covers full-time and part-time employees, as well as employees stood down ahead of the commencement of the scheme, casual employees who have been employed for at least 12 months and the self-employed. Eligible businesses are those with a turnover of less than A$1 billion that can demonstrate a 30% decline in turnover relative to a comparable month one year ago (firms with turnover of greater than A$1 billion must demonstrate at least a 50% reduction in turnover).
On 21 July 2020, the Government announced it will extend the JobKeeper Payment until 28 March 2021 (it was previously slated to expire at the end of September 2020) and is targeting support to those businesses who continue to be significantly impacted by the COVID-19. The rate of payments will be reduce from a flat A$1,500 per fortnight per employee to A$1,200 for full-time workers and A$750 for part-time workers, until 3 January. After that, payments will be reduced to A$1,000 and A$650 respectively until the programme finishes at end-March 2021. To remain eligible for the JobKeeper Programme, firms will have to demonstrate that they have met the revenue threshold (a decline of at least 30% compared to year-ago levels for most firms) in the previous two quarters for the Q4 2020 payments, and the previous three quarters for the Q1 2021 payments. The Treasury estimates that the number of employees receiving the payments will fall from around 3½ million to 1.4 million in Q4 2020 and 1 million in Q1 2021. The extension to the payment is estimated to cost A$16.6 billion.
There has been a temporary expansion of eligibility for income support payments (the JobSeeker Programme) and the establishment of a new, time-limited Coronavirus supplement to be paid at a rate of A$550 per fortnight until the end of September 2020. This will be paid to both existing and new recipients of various government benefits. On 21 July, the government announced that the supplementary payment will be extended to the end of December 2020, but that the size of the payment will be reduced to A$250 per fortnight. New arrangements for the supplement are expected to cost A$3.8 billion.
Social security and veteran and other income support recipients and eligible concession card holders can receive up to two separate cash payments of $750 (those who do not receive the Coronavirus supplement payment will receive the second cash payment of A$750).
The government has also announced some relaxation of the partner income test for employees applying for unemployment benefits and the Coronavirus Supplement of A$550 per fortnight. An individual can now receive these benefits as long as their partner earns less than A$79,762 per annum (the threshold was previously less than A$48k).
On August 3, in response to a rise in COVID-19 cases and tighter confinement measures announced in Victoria, the Federal Government announced $1,500 "disaster payment" for workers who are required to self-isolate because of coronavirus but do not have leave entitlements.
On April 2, a subsidy to childcare providers was announced, conditional on them staying open and not charging families for care. The Commonwealth Government will pay 50 per cent of the sector's fee revenue up to the existing hourly rate cap. The funding will apply from 6 April based on the number of children who were in care during the fortnight leading into 2 March, whether or not they are attending services. The existing arrangements will end in mid-July and be replaced by a three month A$708 million support package to the childcare sector. Families will return to paying for childcare, with the reintroduction of the Child Care Subsidy, but the criteria for families impacted by the economic downturn will be loosened.
Some labour market regulations have also been temporarily relaxed for the duration of the crisis. Across a large range of work types (103 of the 121 modern awards), employees will receive two weeks of unpaid pandemic leave. The covered employees will also be allowed to take double the duration of annual leave at half pay. There have also been changes to three specific awards that cover about 2 million workers, those related to restaurants, hospitality and the clerks award. These changes will allow an individual worker who was performing one type of duty in one type of classification perform another type of duty in another type of classification.
column31: New Commonwealth Government measures include support for business investment, including by increasing the threshold for assets eligible for instant tax write-off and expanding access to this regime to larger firms (with annual turnover of <500 million AUD up from <50 million AUD), as well as through new accelerated depreciation measures. Measures have also been implemented to support business cash flows (including through payments to SMEs that employ workers to help finance payments of salaries and wages plus wage subsidies to SMEs to support them in retaining apprentices and trainees).
column34: Information not available
column37:
On 12 March, the Australian Taxation Office announced a range of measures to allow firms that are affected by the pandemic to defer payment of tax liabilities for up to 4 months without incurring interests or penalties for late payment (incl. for income taxes, goods and services tax (GST), excises and fringe benefits tax). These have been complemented with measures to accelerate tax refunds, notably of excess input-GST credits.
The government has also announced the HomeBuilder programme to support residential construction activity in the second half of 2020. The programme will provide all eligible owner-occupiers with a grant of A$25,000 to build a new home or substantially renovate an existing home. Construction must be contracted to commence within three months of the contract date. Applicants are subject to eligibility criteria, including caps on household income and the price of a new home or renovation. The program is expected to provide around 27,000 grants at a total cost of around $680 million.
column40: Information not available
column43: Under a new Coronavirus SME Guarantee Scheme, the Government is guaranteeing 50 per cent of new loans issued by eligible lenders to SMEs. The total lending capacity of the facility is A$40bn (2% of GDP). Loans written until 30 June 2021 will be eligible. Under a plan put forward by the banking industry, businesses with up to A$10mn in total loan facilities will be able to defer their loan repayments for six months.
column46:
The central bank cash rate was cut by 25 basis points on 3 March. Then, on 19 March, the central bank announced additional measures including 1) A reduction in the cash rate target to 0.25 per cent (from 0.5 per cent); 2) A target for the yield on 3-year Australian Government bonds of around 0.25 per cent; 3) the introduction of a A$90bn (4.5% of GDP) term funding facility for the banking system, with particular support for credit to small and medium-sized businesses; 4) Exchange Settlement Balances at the Reserve Bank will be remunerated at a rate of 10 basis points, rather than zero as would have been the case under previous arrangements.
The government will also allocate AUD15bn (0.7% of GDP) to the Australian Office of Financial Management to invest in wholesale funding markets used by smaller lenders.
On 1 September, the central bank increased the size of the term funding facility to A$200 (10% of GDP) and extended the duration of this lending programme until the end of June 2021.
column47: On 19 March, the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority announced that it would tolerate bank capital levels that were below benchmark capital targets as long as institutions demonstrate that they can meet their various minimum capital requirements. On 20 March, the central bank announced that it would establish a temporary reciprocal currency swap arrangement with the US Federal Reserve for the provision of US dollar liquidity.
column48: The government will also allow the unemployed and some workers and sole traders adversely affected by COVID-19 to access up to $10,000 of their superannuation in 2019-20 and a further $10,000 in 2020-21. Eligible individuals will be able to apply for the scheme until 31 December 2020. Minimum superannuation drawdown requirements have also been reduced and social security deeming rates (the rate of income beneficiaries are assumed to be earning from financial investments) have also been reduced.
column51: On 7 April, the government introduced a mandatory code of conduct in relation to commercial tenancies. The Code imposes a set of good faith leasing principles for application to commercial tenancies (including retail, office and industrial) in circumstances where the tenant has annual turnover up to A$50 million and is eligible for the government's JobKeeper programme. The Code includes rent reductions that are proportional to the tenant's decline in turnover, in order to ensure that the burden is shared between landlords and tenants. On 9 April, Commonwealth and State governments agreed to a nationally consistent approach to hardship support across the essential services for households and small businesses. The principles for dealing with entities in financial stress are i) offering flexible payment options to all households and small businesses in financial stress; ii) Not disconnecting restricting supply/services to those in financial stress; iii) Deferring debt recovery proceedings and credit default listing; iv) Waiving late fees and interest charges on debt; and v) minimising planned outages for critical works, and provide as much notice as possible to assist households and businesses during any outage.
column54: The Commonwealth and State and Territory governments are joint funding the $1billion JobTrainer Fund, which aims to provide an additional 340,700 training places to help school leavers and job seekers access short and long training courses.

column12: As of May 1, the lockdown in Austria ended. The government instructs residents to keep the necessary physical distance. Wearing a mask in public transport and public space (e.g. shops) is mandatory. Restaurants and hotels returned to business in mid-May and end of May respectively.
column14: Borders are open for entry from the European union (except Bulgaria, UK, Portugal, Romania and Sweden).
column16: Schools re-opened from May 15 on. Schools were reopened first for graduating classes, then subsequently for other students as well, conditional that the virus is still relatively contained. Since May 29, all students have been back to their classes. All students are automatically progressed to the next school year, i.e. staying down has been suspended for this school year.
column18: "Large" public events will remain forbidden, at least until August, 31.
column20:
* From April 3 on, authorities allow to order and pick up take-a-way food from restaurants, though guests are still prohibited from eating on the premises.

* On April 6, authorities have announced a gradual lift of the lockdown.
o From April 14 on, small shops (< 400m2), small handicraft businesses, hardware stores and garden centers are allowed to open for business.
o All other shops, including hairdressers, may open from May 1 onwards.
o Restaurants, bars and hotels remain closed, at least until the end of April.
o Public events remain prohibited at least until end of June.
o Schools and universities remain closed until mid-May.
column22:
* A budget envelope of currently EUR 50 billion (10% of GDP including credit guarantees and tax deferrals) is gradually implemented and operationalized. Austrian authorities have signaled to mobilize additional help if needed.

* The budget envelope consists of the following items, which are already implemented or soon to be implemented:
o Emergency funds for hard-hit industries which provides direct liquidity provisions and subsidies for running costs (EUR 15 billion).
o Credit guarantees (up to EUR 9 billion).
o Tax deferrals (up to EUR 10 billion) for personal income and corporate income taxes. Taxes can be deferred until end of September. Deferrals of social security contributions are possible for the months February to April.
o A compartment of EUR 4 billion including funds for short-time working, as well as EUR 1 billion for hardship cases across freelancers, family enterprises and sole proprietorships and funds to finance increased costs of caretaking.


* Further EUR 36 million are disbursed through an emergency-call for research by the Austrian Research Promotion Agency (FFG) to incentivize eligible research on Covid-19 by Austrian firms.

* Moreover, the government has spent around EUR 13 million on medical supplies and EUR 10 million to support the care-taking system.

* The funds for the short-time working scheme have been increased twice and currently stand at around EUR 10 billion.

* In mid-May, authorities announced a recovery package for the hospitality sector of around EUR 500 million. Further recovery measures are currently planned.
\
column25:
Results of the second testing based of a representative sample of Austrians were disclosed on May 5. The tests during this second phase were conducted between April, 21 and April, 24. The resulting prevalence rate was less than 0.15%, significantly earlier than in the first phase (around 1%). The second phase also included seroprevalence tests of people living in high risk regions, showing that around 4.7% of Austrians in these regions developed antibodies against COVID-19.

The government has started testing representative samples of Austrians for infection with Covid-19. A first test with 2,197 Austrians suggested a rather low rate of infection (around 1% of total population). Further testing with larger samples are planned in the near future.

Wearing masks is mandatory in open spaces and public transport. Vulnerable people have to work from home.
column28:
* All workers (private and public sector) can be requested to use all remaining leave days from last year and to deplete any over-time hours.

* Short-time working (EUR 5 billion): The Public Employment Service Austria (AMS) takes over the salary of all workers (except public service) including apprentices of min. 10% up to 90% of the working time according to collective bargaining agreements up to a certain threshold (100% for apprentices). This threshold depends on gross salary and is 90% for salaries below EUR 1,700, 85% for salaries below EUR 2,685 and 80% for salaries below EUR 5,370; apprentices will be compensated in full. Any application to the short-time working scheme will be handled within 48h. The employer's share of social security contributions is covered as well.

* The Ministry of Finance will take over one third of labour costs for workers who have to take care of children up to an age of 14 due to closed schools or kindergartens.

* Short-time working is limited to three months with the possibility to reapply for another three months.
column31: Information not available
column34:
Swift support measures (up to EUR 4 billion)

* Self-employed and micro-sized enterprises (< 10 employees) are supported by EUR 2 billion.

* A single entity can tap up to EUR 6,000 within three months.

Credit guarantees (of up to EUR 9 billion)

* Around EUR 2 billion is provided through an export credit scheme and intends to cover up to 15 % of operating costs of exporting companies.

* General liquidity provisions are granted by the Austria Wirtschaftsservice Gesellschaft (aws), a federal development and financing bank.

* The aws supports firms of all sizes in all industries except the tourism sector, which is covered by the public Tourism bank. The funds for general liquidity provisions by the public Tourism bank will be stepped up to EUR 1 billion (from EUR 100 million).

* Self-employed can tap the credit guarantees as well.

* The aws covers only credits necessary to preserve liquidity but does not cover debt restructurings.

* The minister of Finance has been entitled to increase the guarantee envelope with a sunset clause of three months.

Emergency assistance (EUR 15 billion)

* The emergency assistance intends to support industries hit hard by the coronavirus crisis and will provide direct liquidity provisions and subsidies for operating costs.

* Part of this emergency assistance is devoted to “hardship” cases across self-employed and micro-sized firms. Under certain conditions, they can get subsidies of up to EUR 6,000 for three months per entity. These subsidies have not to be paid back.

* More details are expected to be disclosed in the week after Easter.
column37: Tax deferrals (up to EUR 10 billion) for personal income and corporate income taxes. Taxes can be deferred until end of September. Deferrals of social security contributions are possible for the months February to April.

* A single entity can tap up to EUR 6,000 within three months.

column46: Information not available
column47: The ECB has committed to “do everything necessary within its mandate” to support the economy through this shock. To preserve bank lending and liquidity, the ECB will temporarily conduct additional longer-term refinancing operations (LTROs) and lower the interest rate applied in targeted longer-term refinancing operations (TLTRO III). On the supervisory front, the ECB has temporarily lowered bank capital requirements and introduced flexibility regarding the treatment of non-performing loans. Furthermore, the ECB has expanded its asset purchase programme by an overall EUR 870 billion (7.3% of euro area GDP) until the end of 2020, while opening the door to freeing its self-imposed limits. More details and additional measures are presented in the EU note.
column54: Information not available

column12: As of June 8, citizens are free to move inside the country, respecting the health recommendations. There remain some restrictions (e.g. group meetings are limited to a maximum of 10 people).
column14: Non-essential travel outside Belgium has been prohibited since March 18. Belgium lifted border restrictions on all movements within the European Union, the Schengen area and the United Kingdom on June 15. People returning to Belgium from certain countries/areas are subject to a self-quarantine of 14 days, except for those travel for compelling reasons such as frontier workers.
column16: Classes and activities resume in kindergartens and primary education subjet to certain conditions. Classes and activities may resume in secondary education under strict organisational conditions. Higher education and adult education institutions may resume their classes and activities in accordance with the guidelines from the Communities and the additional measures provided by the federal government.
column18: Public places such as museums and libraries are open. Mass events such as festivals are not allowed before August 31.
column20: Non-essential shops and retail outlets were closed on March 18, which applied until May 11 for most. "Contact professions" (e.g. hair-dressers) were allowed to re-open on May 18. The hospitality industry was allowed to open on June 8. A number of activities associated with a large public gathering (e.g. cinemas and theatres, reception rooms) were allowed to re-open on July 1, but mass events are not allowed yet. The limit on the number of people allowed was reduced from 200 to 100 for indoor events and from 400 to for outdoor events on July 29. They need to respect a number of obligations. Firms in industry and business-to-business sectors were closed on March 18, unless they could organise telework or they could ensure social distancing, which applied until May 4. They continue to be encouraged to organise telework. If social distancing cannot be respected, they will follow a series of health recommendations, such as wearing a mask.
column22:
* All payment deadlines for personal income tax, corporate income tax, VAT and withholding tax are automatically extended by two months.
'These measures were first announced on 6 March, then strengthened on 20 March.
column24:
EUR 8
- 10 billion (measures at the federal level), excluding public loan guarantees.
column25: The federal government provides additional resources to grant a cash advance to hospitals, which will be regulated taking account of exceptional costs and loss of revenues (around EUR 1 billion, 0.2% of GDP). It was announced on March 20.
column28:
* Include Covid-19 as a reason for temporary unemployment due to force majeure.

* Companies affected by a decline in their sales for fear of contagion may grant their employees temporary unemployment for economic reasons.

* For those on temporary unemployment, benefits were raised from 65% to 70% of gross wages, supplemented by a lump-sum benefit of EUR 5.63 per day for those who are on temporary unemployment.

* The payment of mortgages/credits and premiums for fire insurance and outstanding balance insurance for families, viable firms and the self-employed can be deferred until end September 2020 without charging any fee.

* The self-employed are also entitled to “bridging right” (replacement income) of EUR 1 291.69 per month (EUR 1 614.10, if they have dependent family members) if they are forced to stop their activity. These measures were first announced on March 6, then strengthened on March 20.
* The extension of temporary unemployment is prolonged until 31 August 2020 (possibly until 31 December 2020 for industries in difficulty).
* The extension of the "bridge right" (replacement income) for the self-employed is prolonged until 31 August 2020 (until 31 December 2020 for industries in difficulty).
* The introduction of "consumption voucher" of EUR 300, which can be granted by employers for the purchase of goods and services in the worst affected industries (e.g. hospitality industry) and is 100% deductible and tax-free.
* Additional income support of EUR 50 per month for the beneficiaries of the guaranteed minimum income (RIS), the beneficiaries of the income guarantee for the elderly (IGO/GRAPA) and people with disabilities for the next six months. These measures were adopted by the 'Inner Cabinet extended to the 10 parties supporting the Federal Government' on June 6.
* The creation of a special Corona unemployment scheme, which consists of a transition from temporary unemployment due to force majeure to regular economic unemployment. This 'transitional' economic unemployment can be used if the company experiences a 10% drop in turnover. This measure was adopted by the 'Inner Cabinet extended to the 10 parties supporting the Federal Government' on June 12.
column31:
* 'VAT will be reduced to 6% (except for alcoholic beverages) in the hospitality industry until 31 December 2020.
* The withholding tax on the benefits for those on temporary unemployment can be partially exempted for the next three months. These measures were adopted by the 'Inner Cabinet extended to the 10 parties supporting the Federal Government' on June 6.
* A new Covid-19 tax shelter system, which is temporary, until the end of the year for all SMEs affected by the crisis.
* An increased investment deduction (25%) for investments made between mid-March and end-December. These measures were adopted by the 'Inner Cabinet extended to the 10 parties supporting the Federal Government' on June 12.
column34:
* Brussels: EUR 110 million to support companies (These include one-off premium of EUR 4 000 for all companies affected by the emergency measures and that are required to close, liquidity support to companies etc.).

* Wallonia: EUR 350 million fund to help firms, health and social industries and local authorities (These include EUR 5 000 for companies that have been shut down or cannot work and retail (EUR 2 500 if they are partially closed), liquidity support to companies, etc.).
* Flanders: Different measures to support firms (These include interruption premium of EUR 4 000 for all companies or shops that must stop their activities; EUR 100 million of guarantees for firms and the self-employed, etc.).
column37:
* The payment of social security contributions for H1/2020 is postponed until mid-December for employers and the self-employed.
'
* All payment deadlines for personal income tax, corporate income tax, VAT and withholding tax are automatically extended by two months.

* Additional flexibility in payment of tax arrears for businesses in distress, including new postponement and repayment plan.

* Reduction of social security contribution for the self-employed who considers their income is lower than the amount used to calculate their contribution.
These measures were first announced on March 6, then strengthened on March 20.
* Reduction of tax for advance payments in H2/2020, which applies only for firms which do not pay dividends for the rest of this year and are not linked to tax havens. '
* Reduction of tax in the art and entertainment sector for the expenditure during the next twelve months. These measures were adopted in Parliament on 20 May.
column40: Information not available
column43: * A guarantee scheme by the federal government and the financial sector was set up (total EUR 50 billion, worth 10.6% of GDP), guaranteeing all new credits and credit lines with a maximum term of 12 months (excluding refinancing credits) provided until 30 September 2020. This was announced on 22 March.
column46: Information not available
column47: The National Bank of Belgium announced the decision to reduce the counter-cyclical buffer to zero, releasing approximately EUR 1 billion worth of capital available to Belgian banks to expand lending. It was announced on March 11.  A ban on short-selling stocks has been introduced since March 18, which expired on May 18.
column48: The payment of mortgages/credits and premiums for fire insurance and outstanding balance insurance for families, viable firms and the self-employed can be deferred until end September 2020 without charging any fee. It was announced on March 22.                                            The payment of consumer credit can be postponed for three months, which can be renewed once for another three months. It was adopted in Parliament on 20 May.
column51: The payment of mortgages/credits and premiums for fire insurance and outstanding balance insurance for families, viable firms and the self-employed can be deferred until end September 2020 without charging any fee. It was announced on March 22.
column54: * Flexibility in the performance of federal public contracts. Accelerated payment period for public procurement service providers.

column12:
*May 11: Countrywide obligation to wear masks.
*May 11: Lifting of the “Cordon sanitaire” around Cotonou, Abomey-Calavi, Allada, Ouidah, Tori-Bossito, Kpomassè, Toffo, Zè, Sô-Ava, Aguégués, Sèmè-Podji, Porto-Novo, Akpro-Missérété, Adjara, and Atchoukpa.
*April 13: Extension of “Cordon sanitaire” set up around the following agglomerations: Cotonou, Abomey-Calavi, Allada, Ouidah, Tori-Bossito, Kpomassè, Toffo, Zè, Sô-Ava, Aguégués, Sèmè-Podji, Porto-Novo, Akpro-Missérété, Adjara, and Atchoukpa, until April 27.
*April 7: Obligation to wear a mask in the agglomerations which have been cordoned off, starting April 8.
*March 27: “Cordon sanitaire” set up around the following agglomerations: Cotonou, Abomey-Calavi, Allada, Ouidah, Sèmè-Podji, Porto-Novo, So-Ava, Aguégués, Akpro-Missérété, and Adjarra, starting March 30.
*March 23: Quarantine for vulnerable persons and people over 60 years old.
*March 18: Systematic and compulsory quarantine for all people arriving to Benin by air.
column14:
*May 12: Mandatory COVID-19 testing of all airline passengers arriving in Benin. Tests will be done at passenger expense; fees are XOF 100,000 (approximately USD165), payable in cash only, and airlines may require advance payment as a condition of boarding. The Government of Benin said it will hold passengers' passports until testing and isolation requirements are met to ensure compliance. Passengers will be required to self-isolate for at least 48 hours until all results have been confirmed negative, and may be subject to additional testing after 15 days.
*March 18: Limitations on entering/exiting the country via land borders.
*March 18: Restriction on the issuance of visas and limitations on movement across land borders; suspension of official missions abroad.
column16:
*May 11: Launch of E-learning platform (distance learning courses) to enable university students to follow courses online.
*Re-opening of schools (except for kindergartens and universities), starting May 11.
*March 23: Closure of schools and universities for the Easter break starting March 30.
column18:
*June 2: Resuming of public transportation.
*June 2: Re-opening of the places of worship (mosques, churches, temples), subject to strict adherence to the social-distancing protocols.
*April 3: Closure of all places of worship in the affected zones, extended to the entire country from April 3 to April 19.
*March 18: Social distancing and sanitary controls are mandatory in some public places (banks, supermarkets, bars, restaurants).
*March 18: Suspension of all demonstrations and all other non-essential events of a sporting, cultural, religious, political and festive nature, including pilgrimage to Mecca preparations.
column20: *June 2: Re-opening of bars, subject to strict adherence to the social-distancing protocols.
column22:
*The authorities' have developed an ambitious response plan to Covid-19 pandemic, which aims at raising healthcare spending, granting cash transfers to vulnerable households, and providing support to impact businesses. The cost of this plan for 2020 has been set a XOF 150 billion (1.7% of GDP).
*March 31: Fundraising initiative managed by the Ministry of Finance for voluntary contributions.
*March 17: Mitigation and prevention measures amount to XOF10 billion (US$17 million or 0.1% GDP).
column25:
*The authorities have prepared, with the support of the WHO and Word Bank, prevention and mitigation plan in order to buy the necessary equipment. The response consists on an increase in health spending by XOF 60 million (equivalent to 0.7% of GDP, or US$ 100 million), to cover the cost of purchasing medical equipment, the construction of temporary centres to care for people who are sick, and quarantine arrangements for at-risk populations.
*April 23: The authorities announced the installation of laboratories in each of Benin's 12 departments and started a nationwide screening program.

* March 21: The Central Bank of West African States (BCEAO) introduced measures to promote the use of electronic payments.
*March 18: The State provides pharmacies, supermarkets and other structures with a stock of protective masks. The price is regulated to ensure accessibility to all citizens.
column28: *The response plan to Covid-10 includes a total of XOF 50 billion to help the most vulnerable segments of the population though various forms of cash transfer.
column31:
*June 10: The stimulus package includes:

- the suspension of penalties, surcharges, default interest and other costs of proceedings for late payment of taxes, until 30 June 2020. It concerns: value added tax (VAT), withholding on salaries (IRPP/TS), withholding on rents (IRPP/RF), advance payments on income tax (AIB), tax instalments and the balance on income tax (IRPP and IS), contributions to patents and licenses, the professional tax (TPS).

- the exemption of motor vehicle tax for public passenger transport activities.

*The response plan to Covid-19 includes a XOF 40 billion to support struggling businesses through targeted and temporary tax exemptions and a relaxation of certain payment rules
column34: *June 10: The authorities announced XOF 74 billion (USD 124 million) stimulus package to support formal enterprises, craftsmen and small service trades in the informal sector, in addition to the most vulnerable segments of the population. Measures include in the package are expected to cover 70% of the gross salary of all formal sector employees over the period of 3 months. It provides a full coverage of electricity cost for 3 months for hotels and travel agencies (in addition to a general subsidy, applied to all citizens, on electricity and water tariffs).
column37: *June 10: The stimulus package includes a penalty waiver for late filing of income tax and financial statements.
column40: *June 10: The stimulus package includes a XOF 30 billion (USD 51.3 million) subsidy fund to support a XOF 100 billion (USD 171.2 million) zero rate financing line provided through banking and microfinance institutions.
column43: Information not available
column46:
*June 22: The Monetary Policy Committee cut by 50 basis points the ceiling and the floor of the monetary policy corridor, to 4 and 2% respectively.

*The Central Bank of West African States (BCEAO) launched a special 3-month refinancing window at a fixed rate of 2.5% for limited amounts of 3-month “Covid-19 T-bills” to be issued by each UEMOA sovereign to help meet funding needs.

*March 25: The West African Development Bank (BOAD) decided to grant the West African Economic and Monetary Union (UEMOA) member countries XOF120 billion in concessional loans (XOF15 billion per country) to be disbursed immediately; such loans are softened through the interest subsidy mechanism replenished by the Central Bank of West African States (BCEAO) and the UEMOA Commission for XOF25 billion and XOF15 billion, respectively.

*March 23: The Central Bank of West African States (BCEAO) has raised liquidity made available to banks, allowing average refinancing rates to remain relatively close to the floor of the monetary policy corridor of 2.5%. This was followed by the adoption of a full allotment strategy at a fixed rate of 2.5% thereby allowing banks to satisfy their liquidity needs fully at a lower rate (about 25 basis points lower than before the crisis).
column47: *March 21: The Central Bank of West African States (BCEAO) announced the: i) extension of the collateral framework to access central bank refinancing to include bank loans to prequalified 1700 private companies; ii) set up a framework inviting banks to accommodate demands from firms with repayment difficulties.
column54:
*June 28: Since March 31, Benin received more than XOF 2.6 billion in financial donations and thousands of medical materials and equipment, from the States, public institutions, private donors and international organisations.

*May 15: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) Executive Board has approved an immediate disbursement of US$ 125.1 million to Benin to address the urgent financing needs stemming spread of COVID-19 and to mitigate its economic and social impacts.

*April 28: World Bank has approved USD273 million in International Development Association (IDA) financing for Togo, Benin, Burkina Faso and Niger to facilitate access to services for vulnerable people (especially women and the poorest segments of society), through the West Africa Unique Identification for Regional Integration and Inclusion (WURI) Program.

*April 28: The World Bank has approved USD 10.4 million additional financing from the International Development Association (IDA) to support Benin's efforts to fight Covid-19 and help the country respond to public health emergency.
