column12:
State-level (Bosnia and Herzegovina)


* The Government has abolished the state of emergency and has introduced deconfinement measures.

* As of end of June, Bosnia and Herzegovina has seen a recent resurgence of infections with the number of positivecases increasing within the entire territory of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
column14:
State-level (Bosnia and Herzegovina)


* June 1: Borders were reopened for neighbouring countries (Croatia, Montenegro and Serbia). Citizens from other countries can enter only for business reasons upon an official invitation from a legal entity and a negative Covid-19 certificate, not older than 48 hours.


* June 1: International airports in Sarajevo, Banja Luka, Mostar and Tuzla are reopened for commercial traffic.
column16:
Entity-level (Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina)


* May 18: Kindergartens have reopened for the majority of cantons. Schools remain closed until the end of the school year.

Entity-level (Republika Srpska):


* May 11: Kindergartens have reopened. Schools remain closed until the end of the school year.
column18:
Entity-level (Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina)


* May 14: Indoor public gatherings are alowed provided 10 square meters per person are ensured.

Entity-level (Republika Srpska):


* June 22: Public gatherings are alowed.
column20:
Entity-level (Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina)


* May 11: All business activities can operate within normal working hours and all commercial establishment and activities has been reoopened.

Entity-level (Republika Srpska)


* May 11: All business activities can operate within normal working hours. Cafes, restaurants, kindergartens, hair salons, gyms and private dental clinics have been reopened.
column22: Information not available
column25:
State-level (Bosnia and Herzegovina)


* March 24: The Council of Ministers introduced a tax exemption on equipment and resources granted by both domestic and international entities for the needs of prevention, containing and termination of the epidemics caused by COVID-19. These are face masks, gloves, disinfection means, and protection suits for medical staff, respirators and other necessary equipment.

Entity-level (Federation of Bosnia and Herzgovina & Republika Srpska)


* The two entity governments have allocated around KM 50 million (0.15 percent of GDP) for dealing with COVID-19, including purchasing medical equipment and supplies: (i) Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina will transfer KM 30 million (0.1 % of GDP) to hospitals; (ii) Republika Srpska announced the health fund will cover health care costs for all patients.
column28:
Entity-level (Federation of Bosnia and Herzgovina)


* The Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina plans to cover minimal salary contributions to all employees in the real sector (from March until one month after the end of the state of emergency) in the amount of BAM 245 (~EUR 120) per month per employee.

Entity-level (Republika Srpska)


* Republika Srpska has covered full salaray contributions in March and minimal salary contributions in April. Republika Srpska will cover taxes for those subjects that were most affected by the crisis, including merchants, caterers, and small entrepreneurs. BAM 58 million or around EUR 29 million from the Solidarity Fund is dedicated to cover the minimal salary, contributions and taxes for around 70 000 employees in April.

* Police officers who have worked for at least 3 weeks in the period from 15 March to 15 April would receive a cash grant of about EUR 500.

* June 22: The Steering Committee of the Solidarity Fund announced the distribution of BAM 30 million (~ EUR 15 million) as an assistance to local communities in the Republika Srpska to help repair the damage caused by the COVID-19 pandemic.
column31: Information not available
column34:
Entity-level (Federation of Bosnia and Herzgovina)

*The FBiH Development Bank established of a Stabilisation fund for stabilising the economy, with initial reserves of up to BAM 80 million (~EUR 40 million).

*7 April: The Government announced the allocation for a total of BAM 7 million (~EUR 3.5 million) to the Federal Civil Protection Administration and the Federal Civil Protection Headquarters.

Entity-level (Republika Srpska)


* The Republika Srpska's Ministry of Agriculture has also allocated BAM 2.2 million (~EUR 1.1 million) in loans to encourage agricultural output for small producers.

* June 15: Citizens will benefit from a 100 BAM (around 50 EUR) voucher that can be used to co-finance accommodation costs at any destination in the RS, provided that the stay lasts a minimum of 3 nights. The Government plans to distribute 20 000 vouchers in the first phase and two times 15 000 in the second and the third phases. Depending on the demand, additional vouchers might be allocated.
column37:
Entity-level (Federation of Bosnia and Herzgovina)


* The obligation to make advanced payments on corporate income tax for businesses and self-employers is abolished.

* Lease amounts were decreased by 50% for business premises managed by the FBiH Office of Joint Affairs.

Entity-level (Republika Srpska)


* Corporate income tax liabilities in RS are postponed until 30 June.

* All borrowers from the Investment and Development Bank of RS are granted a three month repayment moratorium.
column40: Information not available
column43:
Entity-level (Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina)


* The Government announced the first injection of funds (BAM 100 million or around EUR 50 million) to provide guarantees to commercial banks for loans destined to companies whose activities are characterised as those in the strategic development sectors.

'Entity-level (Republika Srpska)


* The Investment and Development Bank dedicated a credit line to local businesses (craftsmen, entrepreneurs and SMEs). Together with the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development and the Guarantee Fund of the RS, BAM 50 million (~EUR 25 million) will be provided as a guarantee for loans (ranging from BAM 5 000 or around EUR 2500 to BAM 500 000 or around EUR 250 000), which business entities will be able to obtain through commercial banks.
column46:
Entity-level (Federation of Bosnia and Herzgovina & Republika Srpska)


* Banking Agencies of both entities instructed banks to approve certain measures to support clients who are found to have aggravated circumstances for loan repayments due to COVID-19. These measures comprise: a moratorium until at least the end of the state of emergency, a grace period of up to 6 months, and approval of an additional amount to overcome liquidity difficulties. Banking *Agencies have instructed banks to track clients and exposure portfolios affected by COVID-19.

* Banks are also encouraged to consider additional customer relief, including reviewing current fees for services and avoiding charging fees to handle exposure modifications. All banks were ordered not to pay dividends or bonuses.

* 9 April: A decree that determines the margins for certain product

Entity-level (Republika Srpska)

*2 April: A decree on price controls regulating margin limits for all
goods and products specified in the Decree
column51:
State-level (Bosnia and Herzegovina)


* May 23: The Council of Ministers of Bosnia and Herzegovina adopted a Decision on a preferential treatment for domestic companies in calls for public tenders, which will be implemented for a year starting from 1 June 2020. According to the Decision, when calculating bid prices the contracting authority is obliged to reduce the prices of domestic bids by a preferential domestic factor of 30% in all public procurement procedures.

Entity-level (Federation of Bosnia and Herzgovina)


* Federal Banking Agency stated that banks and non-depositary financial institutions can approve special measures for clients: a moratorium, a grace period of up to 6 months, granting of an additional amount of exposure to overcome liquidity difficulties
*26 March: Adoption of a decision to decreasing the lease amount (i.e. rent) for 50%, for business premises managed by the Office for joint affairs of FBiH authorities and bodies

Entity-level (Republika Srpska)


* 20 March: All borrowers from IRB-managed funds have been granted a three-month repayment moratorium
20 March: Banks can approve to clients special measures: a moratorium at least until the end of extraordinary situation, a grace period of up to 6 months, granting of an additional amount of exposure to overcome liquidity difficulties; a similar decision has been adopted for microcredit organizations
column54:
Entity-level (Federation of Bosnia and Herzgovina)


* June 19: The Government adopted the Programme of Economic Stabilisation of FBiH 2020-2021, with the following key objectives: preservation of jobs, fiscal stability, supporting exports, further reform of state-owned enterprises, macro-economic stability, strengthening the health and social protection sectors, improving the business environment and increasing the economic competitiveness. The measures that will support the realisation of these goals are fiscal policy measures, active employment measures and the financial ones through the Guarantee Fund

column12: Lockdown measures imposed by local authorities have been relaxed.
column14: Entry by air been been authorised for foreign residents as of July 27. Land borders remain largely closed for non-residents, for now until September 26. Citizens and residents are allowed to enter by air and across land borders.
column16: Schools remain closed but local authorities are currently making plans for schools to re-open, with significant local variation. There are warnings that schools in São Paulo may not re-open at all during 2020.
column18: Most restrictions imposed by local governments have been eased.
column20: Most restrictions imposed by local governments have been eased.
column22: A state of emergency declaration by Congress exempts the government from meeting 2020 fiscal target. Additional spending exceeding 6% of GDP has been decided. The areas of social protection and health have seen significant additional spending.
column25:
An additional 0.4% of GDP have been assigned to the public healthcare system, in addition to transfers to state and municipal governments who bear the main responsibility for public healthcare. Taxes and import duties on goods used by hospitals have been zeroed and import procedures eased. Field hospitals are being built and efforts are underway to procure respirators and augment ICU capacity. The Health Ministry opened 5,800 vacancies for doctors. Resident doctors will receive a 20% bonus, worth USD 130.
Telemedicine services have been allowed. Physicians can make consultations online and issue electronically signed medical reports or prescriptions.
column28: Informal workers and the unemployed have received, over 3 months, a temporary new benefit of USD 120 per month (USD 240 for single mothers) provided that they earn less than half a minimum wage and are not covered by other social benefits except Bolsa Família. This benefit has been extended for another two months, and is now expected to continue until the end of the year at half its initial level, and with some additional eligibility restrictions. Additional spending on the conditional cash transfer programme Bolsa Familia has reduced waiting lines for programme enrolment and expanded the number of beneficiaries. Formal workers and their employers can benefit from a new short-time work scheme with public income support from unemployment insurance. Benefit levels are 80% of earnings for those earning 1 minimum wage and capped at 1.8 minimum wages. All benefits are pro-rated for the reduction of working hours of the worker, which can be 25%, 50%, 70% or 100% in the case of suspension. The estimated fiscal cost is around 0.7% of GDP. Withdrawals from individual unemployment insurance accounts have been made possible. School meals may be distributed directly to families of public school students while schools are closed. The disbursement of some social transfers has been brought forward.
column31: Import taxes and the industrial tax IPI have been zeroed for medical and emergency-related products. Mandatory employer contributions to semi-public training institutions have been halved for three months. A tax on bank loans is suspended for three months. Air navigation tariffs have been postponed by 6 months and airport concession fees have been postponed.
column34: Formal workers and their employers can benefit from a new short-time work scheme with public income support from unemployment insurance. These reduces wages to be paid by businesses. Since the bulk of this benefit is paid directly to workers, it is counted under 2.C.
column37: Some tax liabilities, especially for SMEs, have been deferred for three months.
column40: The national development bank BNDES has announced new credit lines to companies with a loan volume of 0.6% of GDP. Other public banks are increasing their loan volumes. One public bank has delayed interest liabilities for airlines for up to four months.
column43: For SMEs, an emergency credit line has been opened to cover 2 months of wages for employees earning up to 2 minimum wages. This is a loan over 36 months, with a grace period of 6 months, and a nominal interest rate below current inflation. Payments are directly disbursed into workers' accounts, but firms are liable for the debt. 85% of the credit risk is borne by the federal government
column46: The policy rate Selic was cut on four occasions, by 50 bps on 18/3 to 3.75% by 75 bps on 06/5, to 3.00%, by 75 bps to 2.25% on 17/6 and by 25 bps to 2.00 on 7/8.
column47: The Central Bank is injecting liquidity worth 17% of GDP, to be implemented through lower reserve and capital requirements and special liquidity lines for banks. The Central Bank undertook repo operations to support the value of the currency. A USD 60 billion swap line with the US Federal Reserve will help Brazil manage pressures on its currency.
column48: 9 million low-income families will be exempt from paying their energy bills up to BRL 150 per month, for 3 months (announced on 8/4).
column51: Airlines have been granted 12 months to reimburse customers for cancelled flights.
column54: Administrative procedures for medical imports and raw materials have been eased. Administrative procedures for loan renegotiations have been eased. Firms can get temporary exemptions from labour regulations to incentivate reduced hours rather than outright dismissals in the formal labour market. Further flexibility for firms will come from extended use of the bank of hours and the possibility to anticipate annual leave.
column55: Presidency, Ministry of the Economy, press articles. https://www.gov.br/casacivil/pt-br/assuntos/noticias/2020/marco/ ; https://www.gov.br/planalto/pt-br/acompanhe-o-planalto/noticias/2020/03 ; http://www.economia.gov.br/noticias/2020/marco/confira-as-medidas-tomadas-pelo-ministerio-da-economia-em-funcao-do-covid-19-coronavirus

column12: State of emergency lifted on 13 May. Replaced by epidemic emergency until 14 June with most preventative measures still in place. Later extended until July 15 in response to growth in coronavirus cases. On 15 June, wearing of a mask or face covering was made compulsory on public transport, in pharmacies and medical establishments. From 23 June, a mask or face covering is required to be worn at all indoor public venues.
column14: On June 1, Bulgaria made exempt from a 14-day quarantine people coming from several EU countries, and a few non-EU countries. The mandatory 14-day quarantine on entry to Bulgaria is applicable for people coming from the UK, Sweden, Belgium, Portugal, and all non-EU countries except Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina and Montenegro, Iceland, Norway, Switzerland, Lichtenstein, San Marino, Andorra, Monaco, and Vatican City. On May 22, Bulgaria lifted the entry ban on citizens of EU member states, the United Kingdom, Schengen visa zone member countries (including the Republic of San Marino, the Principality of Andorra, the Principality of Monaco and the Vatican City State), the Republic of Serbia and the Republic of North Macedonia. Bulgaria remains closed to other non-EU nationals.
column16: On May 22, Kindergartens and daycares were re-opened. Universities, schools and daycare services remain closed.
column18:
Cultural and entertainment events, including theatres, concerts and stage performances allowed from 1 June. Venues/cultural centers can use 30% of indoor capacity and maximum 50% of outdoor capacity. Maximum capacity of use of cultural venues (community/cultural centers, youth/children centers, school halls, recreational clubs, etc.) not more than 20 people for group activities, minimum 4 square metres per person. First
- and second-tier football matches were allowed to take place from 5 June, with a restriction of 30% crowd capacity. Public parks opened on 13 May. On 11 May, indoor museums, galleries, libraries and cinemas opened with distancing measures in place.
column20: On 1 June, bars and restaurants fully opened, including those in shopping centres. Shopping centres, gyms, entertainment and gaming halls, indoor children's and sports facilities had already been opened over 13-22 May. Nightclubs remain closed until end of pandemic emergency (June 14).
column22: Budget measures amount to about BGN 1.5 billion (1.3% of GDP). The 60:40 measure is the most important tool (around BGN 1 billion) designed to support businesses in the crisis. The budget measures were part of the package approved under the Law on the amendment of the 2020 State Budget Act (approved by partliament on April 6). In addition, there has been a reprogramming of resources from EU funds to programmes to support individuals and enterprises directly affected by the crisis amounting to BGN 870 million. There also has been a BGN 700 million capital increase of the Bulgarian Development Bank, and a package of Government-supported financial instruments in the form of liquidity provision/guarantees (BGN 4.5 billion). This brings the overall stimulus package to around 5.8% of 2019 GDP.
column25: Doctors and nurses working in the frontline will receive an additional payment of BGN 1000 a month (EUR 510) (announced on 15 March). The additional remuneration of medical and non-medical staff involved in the treatment of COVID 19 patients is estimated to BGN 60 million (EUR 30.6 million).
column28: Under the 60:40 salary support scheme, the government pays 60% of salaries for employees facing being laid off, with employers paying the remaining 40%. The state also covers 60% of the social security and healthcare contributions, rather than the employers and employees covering such contributions in full. This covers companies (i) engaged in retail (with the exception of car or motorcycle dealerships), land and air transportation, hotels, restaurants and bars, cinemas, tourist operators and trade fair organisers, private kindergartens, artistic and other cultural activities, sports and other recreational activities; and (ii) companies that have experienced a 20 per cent fall in sales in March 2020, compared to the same month of 2019. Firms need to retain all their staff to qualify. Expenditure is estimated to reach BGN 1 billion (EUR 510 million). Employers were able to apply for the scheme with the Employment Agency on 31 March (with decision to take up to 7 days and then compensation within 5 days). An amendment on 30 May establishes that  employers must pay remuneration to employees that is not less than the amount of the employees' social insurance income in January 2020. Initially, the scheme was set to be in place until the end of the State of Emergency and was then extended to 30 June. The Government is considering plans for the continuation of this type programme beyond July.
column31: Information not available
column34: Information not available
column37: Certain taxes and fees due to government have been delayed, including the deadline for submission of the annual income tax return and for payment of the tax assessed has been extended until end-June firms/sole traders involved in commerce and farmers who pay tax under this regime.
column40: Information not available
column43:
A government-backed package of financial instruments has been put in place to the amount of BGN 4.5 billion. (i) The capital of the Bulgarian Development Bank (BDB) was increased by BGN 700 million of which BGN 500 million will be used to issue portfolio guarantees (with 80% coverage of loan principal) to commercial banks to enable them to provide more flexible business unsecured loans for a specified period under certain conditions and individual case-by-case assessment. This was part of the package approved under the Law on the amendment of the 2020 State Budget Act (approved by partliament on April 6). The guarantees period is 5 years. The amount of loans is up to BGN 300,000 provided by commercial banks, the volume of the program is BGN 2 billion and is accessible to all business sectors in all regions of Bulgaria. Eligible borrowers are micro as well as small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in accordance with the SME Law. It is expected that sectors most affected by the crisis will benefit from the instrument, mainly trade, transport, hotels and restaurant, logistics, also export-orient companies and others. The grace period for payment of interest and principal is up to 36 months. Application deadline for the program is by the end of 2020. The eligibility criteria are:


- Decrease in turnover starting the first quarter of 2020 compared to the first quarter of 2019 (based on the financial statements of the company);

- Existence of receivables from customers that have not been received / amounts not paid to suppliers after 01.03.2020 (based on the financial statements of the company);

- Discontinued import supplies required for the enterprise's activity
- after 01.01.2020, cancelled export contracts (based on certificates and documents submitted by the company);

- Sickness and self-isolation of employees, overall reduction in the number of employees, closed production facilities and offices (based on certificates and documents provided by the company).
The remaining BGN 200 mln will guarantee interest-free consumer loans with the amount of BGN 1500
- 4500. The maximum amount of BGN 4500 could be drawn at one time or in three tranches of BGN 1500 each. If a smaller amount of the loan is initially allowed, it can be annexed subsequently in order to reach the amount of BGN 4500. So far 12 commercial banks have declared interest in participating in this measure. The lending decisions under those programs will depend on the banks and remain market-based. No fees, commissions or penalties will be due for the loans.
(ii) The Government also activated financial instruments with a public resource through the Fund Manager (the Fund of funds). The main role of the Fund is to implement financial instruments in Bulgaria via facilities using EU funds and private resources. The financial instruments financed from the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESIFs) are specialised funding schemes where the Fund of Funds provides financing, via financial intermediaries and banks, in the form of guarantees, loans and equity investments to various target groups of final recipients. In the current exceptional circumstances, the Fund is focusing efforts on several main areas:

- Loans to provide liquidy support to SMEs
- One of the measures is a guarantee product that provides liquidity support to small and medium-sized enterprises operating in various sectors, including those most affected by the crisis, such as tourism, transport, wholesale and retail trade, etc. The Fund of Funds will provide banks with guarantees totalling to BGN 170 million that will back up new loans of up to BGN 850 million in terms of one year. The amount of financing is up to BGN 3.6 million, mainly for working capital, with the possibility of providing long-term investment loans up to a maximum of ten years. The goal is to enable such lending without any additional administrative burden for the loan applicants. In addition, an extended grace period for the principal amounts is envisaged.


- Micro loans programme
- this measure provides support to self-employed individuals and small start-ups having a very short business track record, if any, including those set up by vulnerable groups (people with disabilities, young people aged 29 or less, people who have been unemployed for more than 6 months). This is a facility for granting concessional loans, including without any collateral, to target groups of final recipients who usually have no access to bank financing due to a lack of credit history. The aim of the instrument is to retain employment levels by supporting small businesses, including those run by self-employed persons. The amount available for this measure totals BGN 24 mln, with the possibility of supplying additional funds, should the facility be exhausted rapidly. The loans are extended via financial intermediaries that have capacity and branch networks in all of the 28 districts of Bulgaria. Eligible undertakings could receive up to BGN 50 000 leva in working capital loans funds and investments under more favourable conditions and at interest terms below market rates.


- Funds for private equity in start-ups and innovative companies -this measure is in the field of venture equity investments in start-ups and innovative businesses, and amounts to BGN 150 million This instrument is designed to support companies that have the potential to contribute in the rapid economic recovery after the crisis, especially in key areas of innovation and digitalization, as well as make investments in high tech such as bio and nanotechnology, mechatronics, green technology and IT, pharmaceuticals, fintech, where such investments can bring added value. Considering that start-ups and fast-growing companies are facing so far unpredictable challenges, the Fund of Funds is focusing its efforts mainly on accelerating investments and providing more favourable conditions. The amount of investment varies over a wide range according to the stage of development of the companies. The average value is BGN 800 thousand in the form of equity investments, i.e. investments in the capital of the companies or convertible debt in return for which the investor is entitled to acquire participation in the capital of the company under certain conditions.


- Funds for urban development
- the Fund will continue to finance municipal and other projects aimed at improving the urban environment, with a facility amounting to BGN 418 million available through its urban development funds. This financial instrument is targeted at 39 Bulgarian municipalities and public and private urban development projects. This support is for infrastructure projects, cultural centers and tourist objects with national and global importance, development of economic zones which is key for the economy in times of crisis, given the lack of financing alternatives on the market. It is envisaged to further ease the conditions in the direction of greater guarantee coverage, as well as for projects and companies in the most affected sectors of the crisis such as tourism and transport. The amount of financing can reach up to BGN 40 million and is mainly aimed at investments, with the possibility of providing also working capital financing.
column46: There is a currency board in place since July 1997 that fixes the national currency to the euro. The ECB and the BNB put in place a swap line of EUR 2 billion to be put in place until end-2020 to provide euro liquidity (announced 22 April 2020).
column47: The Bulgarian National Bank (BNB) is taking measures aimed at both preserving the stability of the banking system and strengthening its flexibility to reduce the adverse effects on households and companies from the restrictions caused by the pandemic (announced on 19 March). The key measures include an increase in banking system liquidity with BGN 7 billion or 5.9% of 2019 GDP by reducing commercial banks' foreign exposures, full capitalisation of profits in the banking system (BGN 1.6 billion), and the cancellation of the counter-cyclical capital buffer increase planned for 2020 and 2021 (totalling 0.6% of 2019 GDP). BNB package of measures in relation to the COVID 19 pandemic amounts to total BGN 9.3 billion.

column12:
*May 11: Countrywide obligation to wear masks.
*May 11: Lifting of the “Cordon sanitaire” around Cotonou, Abomey-Calavi, Allada, Ouidah, Tori-Bossito, Kpomassè, Toffo, Zè, Sô-Ava, Aguégués, Sèmè-Podji, Porto-Novo, Akpro-Missérété, Adjara, and Atchoukpa.
*April 13: Extension of “Cordon sanitaire” set up around the following agglomerations: Cotonou, Abomey-Calavi, Allada, Ouidah, Tori-Bossito, Kpomassè, Toffo, Zè, Sô-Ava, Aguégués, Sèmè-Podji, Porto-Novo, Akpro-Missérété, Adjara, and Atchoukpa, until April 27.
*April 7: Obligation to wear a mask in the agglomerations which have been cordoned off, starting April 8.
*March 27: “Cordon sanitaire” set up around the following agglomerations: Cotonou, Abomey-Calavi, Allada, Ouidah, Sèmè-Podji, Porto-Novo, So-Ava, Aguégués, Akpro-Missérété, and Adjarra, starting March 30.
*March 23: Quarantine for vulnerable persons and people over 60 years old.
*March 18: Systematic and compulsory quarantine for all people arriving to Benin by air.
column14:
*May 4: Lifting of the ban on travel between cities.
*April 20: Ban on travel between cities.
*March 20: Closure of Ouagadougou and Bobo-Dioulasso airports from March 21 (except domestic and military flights and cargo), for 2 renewable weeks.
*March 20: Closure of land and rail borders from March 21 (except freight), for 2 renewable weeks.
*March 20: Suspension of biometric enrolment and of special operations of issuance of national identity cards.
column16: *March 14: Closure of schools and universities, starting March 16, extended on March 26 for two weeks.
column18:
*May 2: Re-opening of mosques.
*April 2: Prolongation of the closure of catholic churches.
*March 20: Ban on gatherings of more than 50 people; restrictions on opening of markets, restaurants, cinemas, and other entertainment centres; recommendations to follow basic protective measures and social distancing.
*March 19: Suspension of all religious ceremonies and closure of places of worship, starting March 20.
*March 19: Restrictions of marriage celebrations in Ouagadougou, starting March 19.
*Suspension of National Assembly plenary sessions, starting March 16.
column20:
*April 29: Reopening of 27 markets and yaars in Ouagadougou.
*April 19: Reopening of Ouagadougou central market, starting April 20.
*March 23: Closure of markets and yaars in Ouagadougou, starting March 25
column22:
*June 17: The Cabinet has approved the draft revised 2020 budget, which seeks to address the socio-economic impacts of COVID-19.

*April 27: Heads of states of the West-Africa Economic and Monetary Union (UEMOA) declared a temporary suspension of the UEMOA growth and stability Pact setting six convergence criteria, including the 3% of GDP fiscal deficit rule, to help member-countries cope with the fallout of the Covid-19 pandemic. This temporary suspension will allow member-countries to raise their overall fiscal deficit temporarily and use the additional external support provided by donors in response to the Covid-19 crisis.

*April 16: The President of Faso decided to waive his salary for 6 months to contribute to the COVID-19 Pandemic Response Support Fund, with the Prime Minister, Ministers of State and Ministers giving up 4, 2 and 1 month's salary respectively, starting in April.

*April 2: Acquisition of agricultural inputs and livestock feed amounting to XOF30 billion.

*April 2: Revision of the 2020 budget to address the socio-economic impacts of the outbreak, requiring the mobilisation of nearly XOF394 billion (4.45% of GDP) that includes the global health response plan amounting to about XOF178 billion.
column25:
*June 23: The government received a first batch of 185 ambulances out of a total of 300 acquired.

*June 17: An emergency response plan for the health sector has been prepared: it focuses on strengthening human and technical capacities of public hospitals, increasing available hospital beds, expanding testing capacities and purchasing medical supplies to facilitate the implementation of hygiene measures. The plan will be regularly updated to reflect local and global development.

*April 2: Allocation of XOF15 billion to finance the research on infectious diseases and the production of medicines.

*March 21: The Central Bank for West African States (BCEAO) announced measures to promote the use of electronic payments.

*March 20: Setting up of a Scientific Council to the President in order to monitor and guide the measures to be taken against the pandemic.
column28:
*June 17: The Cabinet's approval of the draft revised 2020 budget take into consideration the following measures:

- donating food and providing assistance to households and local small businesses
-supporting the water and electricity bills, including though cancelation, of the most vulnerable social groups;
-securing adequate stocks of consumer products and strengthening surveillance of prices.

*April 2: The amended finance law provides:

- the payment of the water bills of the social bracket, and the free consumption at the standpipes;

- the payment of electricity bills for the social strata using 3-amp single-phase connections;

- the reduction of electricity bills by 50% for the social strata using 5 and 10 amp single-phase connections;

- cancellation of penalties on SONABEL and ONEA bills;

- a 50% reduction in the cost of solar kits under the Solar Home System project for vulnerable households;

- the reactivation of SONAGESS' pilot shops;

- the securing of stocks of consumer goods, in consultation with the action of the supply chain and the reinforced economic control of prices on the national territory.

*April 2: The amended finance law provides, under closed markets and yaars, for the period April-June 2020:

- the suspension of rents

- suspension of the rights of place;

- the payment of water and electricity bills;

- coverage of security costs;

- the donation of food to vulnerable people of the closed markets and yaars thought their apexes;

- free parking for taxis.
column31:
*June 17: The Cabinet's approval of the draft revised 2020 budget take into consideration the following measures:

- lowering import duties and VAT for hygiene and healthcare goods and services critical to tackle COVID-19, and for tourism businesses;

- lowering other selected tax rates;
-lowering the licensing fee for companies in the transportation and tourism sector;
-suspending on-site tax inspection operations.

*April 2: The amended finance law provides:

- automatic reduction of penalties and fines due;

- suspension of on-site tax controls;

- exemption of contribution from micro-enterprises of the informal sector;

- exemption from VAT on the sale of products used in the fight against the coronavirus;

- exemption from taxes and customs duties on pharmaceutical products, medical supplies and equipment;

- postponement of the deadline for payment of the vehicle tax to the end of June 2020;

- delivery of tax certificates to companies not in compliance with their tax obligation until June 2020;

- suspension of the Employers' Apprenticeship Tax (TPA) on salaries, in favour of companies in the transport and hotel sectors;

- reduced taxes on an exceptional basis;

- suspension of proceedings for the recovery of tax debts and the collection of the minimum lump sum; the application of a reduced VAT rate of 10%; the reduction of 25% of the patent in favour of the companies working in the sector of passenger transport, hotels, restaurants and tourism;

- the abolition of charges and taxes imposed on the organization of cultural activities.
column34:
*April 2: The amended finance law provides:

- Establishment of an economic recovery fund for companies amounting to XOF100 billion;
-establishment of a solidarity fund benefitting the informal sector (including women) amounting to XOF5 billion.
column37:
*June 17: The Cabinet's approval of the draft revised 2020 budget take into consideration the following measures: delaying tax payments, and waiving late payment fines and penalties

*April 2: The amended finance law provides the cancellation of penalties for delays in the execution of public contracts at the level of the central State and local authorities.

column46:
*The Central Bank for West African States (BCEAO) has launched a special 3-month refinancing window at a fixed rate of 2.5% for limited amounts of 3-month “Covid-19 T-Bills” to be issued by each UEMOA sovereign to help meet funding needs related to the current pandemic.

*March 25: The West African Development Bank (BOAD) decided to grant the West African Economic and Monetary Union (UEMOA) member countries XOF120 billion in concessional loans (XOF15 billion per country) to be disbursed immediately; such loans are softened through the interest subsidy mechanism replenished by the Central Bank of West African States (BCEAO) and the UEMOA Commission for XOF25 billion and XOF15 billion, respectively.

*March 23: The Central Bank for West African States (BCEAO) has raised liquidity made available to banks at its weekly and monthly auctions of March 23, allowing average refinancing rates to remain relatively close to the floor of the monetary policy corridor of 2.5%. This was followed by the adoption of a full allotment strategy at a fixed rate of 2.5% thereby allowing banks to satisfy their liquidity needs fully at a lower rate.
column47: *March 21: The BCEAO announced: i) an extension of the collateral framework to access central bank loans to prequalified 1.700 private companies; ii) a framework inviting banks to accommodate demands from firms with COVID-19-related repayment difficulties to postpone for a 3 month renewable period debt service falling due, without the need to classify such postponed claims as NPL.
column54:
*April 30: World Bank has approved USD21.15 million in financing, of which 50% credit from the International Development Association (IDA) to help Burkina Faso's respond to the Covid-19 pandemic (Burkina Faso Covid-19 Preparedness and Response Project).

*April 28: World Bank has approved USD273 million in International Development Association (IDA) financing for Togo, Benin, Burkina Faso and Niger to facilitate access to services for vulnerable people (especially women and the poorest segments of society), through the West Africa Unique Identification for Regional Integration and Inclusion (WURI) Program.

*April 15: A disbursement of USD115.3 million from IMF in order to help finance health, social and macroeconomic stabilisation measures, address urgent balance of payments needs and catalyse additional support from the international community.

*April 2: Decree granting, on an exceptional basis, total remission of sentences to 1207 inmates.

column12:
*March 16: Côte d'Ivoire announced a compulsory quarantine for all suspected cases.
*March 23: The government introduced a curfew from 9pm to 5am, declared the state of emergency and started to progressively contain citizens from the mostly affected geographical areas.
*April 9: Obligation to wear masks, particularly in Grand Abidjan.
*April 9: Mandatory confinement for at-risk populations, especially the elderly and those suffering from chronic conditions.

* April, 29: Extension of the state of emergency declared on 23 March 2020 across the country for a further period from 1 to 15 May 2020.

* May, 7: In Abidjan, the curfew is relaxed, from 11:00 p.m. to 4:00 a.m, until at least may 15

* May, 7: President Ouattara announced, from May, 8, the easing of all restrictions across the country, except in Abidjan: end of curfew, reopening of schools, restaurants, maquis (popular bars), bars, theatres, etc.

* May, 14: End of the curfew in Grand Abidjan, starting from May 15

* May 14: Extension of the State of Emergency until May 31

* June, 11: The Conseil de la sécurité Nationale decided, until Tuesday 30 June 2020: to maintain the state of emergency; The National Security Council also decided to strengthen the control of the obligation to wear masks, in particular through community awareness and law enforcement, due to the non-application by the majority of barrier measures and physical distancing.

* July, 30: The state of emergency remains in place until 31 August.

* July, 30: The Conseil de la Sécurité Nationale decided to resume gatherings in Côte d'Ivoire, upon authorization by prefects and with the health authorities.
column14:
* March 16: Ban of all international travels, except for humanitarian aid purpose.

* March 20: Border closure, beginning March 22.

* March 23: Displacements between Abidjan and the rest of the country are constrained and require a special authorization; humanitarian corridors are created in order to help communities in urgent need of assistance; commuting is restricted.

* April 9: Reduction of non-essential travel; reduction in the number of passengers in public transit and in personal vehicles.

* June 10: creation of 42 health control posts at points of entry into the territory to strengthen national health security

* June, 11: The National Security Council decided, until Tuesday 30 June 2020, to maintain the closure of land, air and sea borders; and to maintain systematic health checks of all persons coming from outside the country.

* July, 31: land and sea borders remain closed until further notice
column16:
*March 16: Closure of schools and universities, extended until May 17.

* May, 7: Reopening of schools, except in Grand Abidjan

* May, 14: Schools in Grand Abidjan may reopen on May 25
column18:
* March 16: Ban on gatherings of more than 50 people.

* March 16: Social distancing in all public places; closure of nightclubs, bars, theatres and other recreational facilities; suspension of sporting and recreation events.

* March, 19: All religious services are suspended.

* March 23: Closure of restaurants.

* May, 7: From May, 8, reopening of bars, restaurants, theatres across the country, except in Grand Abidjan

* May, 7: easing of the restriction on the assembly of persons from 50 to 200 persons, with the obligation to respect distancing measures (across the country).

* May, 14: Starting from May 15 reopening of bars and maquis in Grand Abidjan

* May, 15 : bars, nightclubs, cinemas remain closed until May 31

* June, 11: The National Security Council decided, until Tuesday 30 June 2020, to maintain the closure of bars, nightclubs, cinemas and places of entertainment, to maintain the isolation of Grand Abidjan and to reinforce control at entrances/exits; to maintain the ban on population gatherings beyond 200 people within the country; to maintain the ban on population gatherings in Abidjan, whose maximum allowed is now reduced from 200 to 50 people

* July 30: The Conseil de la Sécurité Nationale authorized the reopening of bars, nightclubs, cinemas and entertainment venues. This relief measure is, however, accompanied by the obligation to comply with barrier measures, including hand washing, the wearing of masks and physical distancing.
column20: *April 9: Effective implementation of teleworking.
column22: * Mach 31: The authorities adopted a package of economic measures (Plan de soutien social, économique et humanitaire), that includes the creation of 3 support funds, the first consists of XOF1 billion for large companies, the second of XOF200 billion for SMEs, and the third of XOF100 billion for the informal sector
column25:
* March 16: Opening of complementary sites equipped with care facilities in Abidjan, Abengourou, Aboisso, Bondoukou, Bouaké, Bouna, Daloa, Gagnoa, Korhogo, Man, Odienne, San Pedro and Yamoussoukro; free diagnosis and management of all suspect and confirmed cases.

* March 23: Increased support to pharmaceutical industries, laboratories and diagnostic facilities throughout the country; call centre dedicated to COVID-19 and an "alert and monitoring system" are put in place.

* March 23: An emergency response plan of XOF 96 billion was announced (0,3% GDP) to provide free care for those with infection and to equip intensive care units; epidemiological and biological surveillance (virus testing, creation of a free call centre, equipping laboratories) was strengthened, and research on the virus was financed.

* Tax exemption on health equipment, materials and other health inputs relevant to the fight against COVID-19.

* June, 11 : requisition of additional hosting capacity in Grand Abidjan, in order to isolate patients suffering from asymptomatic or mild forms
column28:
*A support fund (Fonds Spécial de Solidarité COVID-19) for vulnerable households became operational on March, 23, for a total cost of XOF 13.3 billion. It consists in electronic cash transfers.

* April 15: Eviction procedures for tenants are suspended between April 1 and June 30. Rent increase are also suspended during this period.

* As of June 10, A total of 72,498 beneficiaries, representing 40.9% of the target of 177,198 vulnerable households targeted by the transitional phase, benefited from FSS support
column31: * May, 6: cancellation of the late penalties to be paid by holders of public contracts, from 06 April to 06 July 2020, in order to help companies to safeguard their production tool and jobs.
column34:
*April 9: Creation of two funds: a Support Fund for Large Enterprises (XOF100 billion) and a Support Fund for SMEs (XOF150 billion).
*April, 9: Creation of a specific fund to support informal sector enterprises affected by the crisis for an amount of XOF100 billion.

* April, 15: The National Pandemic Health Response Plan includes financial support for the agricultural sector (cashew nut, cotton seed oil, hevea, oil palm, cocoa and coffee) of XOF 250 billion. The operationalization of this emergency programme will consist in public transfers, in particular, price and income support and the provision of goods and services, including fertilizer subsidies and seed distribution.

column46:
*March 25: The West African Development Bank (BOAD) decided to grant the UEMOA member countries XOF 120 billion in concessional loans (XOF 15 billion per country) to be disbursed immediately. These loans benefit from an interest subsidy mechanism financed by the BCEAO and the UEMOA Commission with XOF 25 billion and XOF 15 billion, respectively.
*March 23: The Central Bank of West African States (BCEAO) increases liquidity available to banks at its weekly and monthly auctions and allows average refinancing rates to remain relatively close to the floor of the monetary policy corridor of 2.5%.
*March 30: Adoption of a full allotment strategy at a fixed rate of 2.5%, thereby allowing banks to satisfy their liquidity needs fully at a lower rate.
column47: *March 21: The BCEAO has announced: i) an extension of the collateral framework to access central bank refinancing to include bank loans of 1 700 prequalified private companies; ii) a framework inviting banks to accommodate demands from firms with Covid19-related repayment difficulties by postponing debt service falling due for a 3 month renewable period, without the need to classify such postponed claims as NPL.
column48: * March, 31 : Electricity bills relief for one million vulnerable households (months of April and May) and deferred payments for the other households.
column51: * May, 6 : The Council has adopted an ordinance that cancels the late penalties to be paid by holders of public contracts and other State orders, from 06 April to 06 July 2020, in order to help companies to safeguard the production tool and jobs.

column12:
Canada's containment measures came into force from mid to late March. Provinces and territories, as well as the federal government, played a key role. States of emergency and other measures, brought school closure, regulation on social distancing, operational restrictions on various types of businesses, and strong public health advice for people to remain at home.

Provinces and territories are beginning to lift containment measures. Among the four most populous provinces, Quebec's reopening schedule commenced on the 4 May and Alberta's on the 14 May. Ontario and British Columbia have critera-based reopening schedules.
column14: Tight international travel restrictions remain in place, including a ban on all but essential border crossing with the United States (these mesasures were first introduced 18 March).
column16: Most schools remain closed.
column18: Tight restrictions on events remain across provinces and territories.
column20: Obligatory shutdown rules have varied across provinces and territories. Mainly it is  only essential activities that have been allowed to continue operating.
column22:
The main components of federal-government fiscal support were announced as follows:
March 12. Announcement of an initial package of economic measures that includes: improved insurance sickness benefits, additional funding for health care.
March 18. Follow-up package comprising further financial assistance to households and businesses.
March 25. Announcment of Canada Emergency Relief Benefit to support individuals (CERB). Also announcement of switch to a larger wage subsidy (the Canada Emergency Wage Subsidty, CEWS).
column24: Estimated value of measures with direct budgetary impact (including additional healthcare spending and an estimate of provincial spending), CAD 256 billion according to Economic and Fiscal Snapshot, July 2020
column25: Additional budgetary allocations for health care have included funds for medial research, increased health spending transfers to provinces and territories and spending on protective equipment.
column28:
The main measure taken to support individual incomes (in fiscal terms) is the Canada Emergency Response Benefit (CERB). This benefit pays CAD 2 000 per month (for up to four months) to those who have lost income due to COVID-19. Expenditure on the benefit accounts for a substantial share of total outlays to combat the crisis. The application system began operating on 6th April and was extended to more groups, including seasonal workers, on 15 April. On 16 June the maximum payout duration was increased from 16 to 24 weeks and on August 20 it was expanded to 28 weeks. The latest extension implies payouts will start coming to an end in October.

Phase-out of CERB is to be accompanied by a widening of support through other channels. Policy announcements in August 2020 include increase in support via Employment Insurance (lightening of contribution requirements, a minimum benefit and coverage period) and three new benefits. The latter target, the self employed, those unable to work due to illness or quarantine, and those unable to work due to caring duties.

Other measures include:
o Boost to the GST refundable credit that targets lower income households (every adult who qualifies will receive up to $300 with $150 for every child).
o More supportive sickness-insurance benefit, measures include waiving the one-week benefit waiting period for sickness-insurance pay out.
o Immediate financial assistance to those losing their jobs because of business closure, including self-employed and part-time workers unable to collect regular employment-insurance benefits.
o Wider welfare support that includes, temporary boost to the Canada Child Benefit, a doubling of the Reaching Home Program that provides funding for the homeless, establishment of a new fund to help Indigenous communities and a six-month moratorium on repayment of student loans.
o Help for those accessing pensions savings. To help retirees avoid realising losses on savings due to stock-market falls and other developments, the minimum required withdrawals from Registered Retirement Income Funds have been reduced by 25%.
o A nationwide top-up scheme for low-wage essential workers (for instance, low-earning hospital workers) (announced April 15).
o The Canada Student Service Grant, students will receive grants of $1,000 to $5,000 to support the costs of postsecondary education in the fall, with the amount of each grant dependent on the time the recipient devotes to volunteer work (announced April, launched June 25).
column31: Information not available
column34:
The largest support scheme for business (in terms of fiscal spending) is the Canada Emergency Wage Subsidy (CEWS) that provides up to 75% wage subsidy for up to 3 months, retroactively to March 15. CEWS was opened for applications on 27 April. CEWS has been extended twice, on the 15 May it was extended to end August 2020, on the 13 July it was extended to mid-December. Other developments include:

* A widening of the scope of CEWS (announced 17 July), notably the rule that businesses must have a at least 30% revenue loss was replaced by a gradation of benefit to income loss, thus providing access to the program for businesses with smaller losses.


Other support has included:
Extension of the Work Sharing program from 38 to 76 weeks.
column37: Tax payment deferrals regarding corporate-income tax, sales tax remittance and customs duty payments (no interest or penalitiess will apply). For instance, individuals will not have to file their tax returns until June 1 and can defer any payments until after August 31.
column40:
The Business Credit Availability Program (BCAP) (valued at CAD 81 billion) includes the Small and Medium-sized Enterprise Loan and Guarantee program (loan support up to CAD 6.25 million) and the Canada Emergency Commercial Business Account (loans up to CAD 40 000 for small business and not-for-profits). On August 31 the CEBA progarmme was extended by two months ( to end of October).

Large Employer Emergency Lending Facility (LEEFF), bridging financing to businesses with revenues above CAD 300 billion (announced 11 May, open to applications 20 May).

Other lending support includes: the Canada Emergency Commercial Rent Assistance program, support for commercial property owners who commit to lowering or foregoing small-business rents; lending support to agriculture sector.
column43: The Business Credit Availability Program (BCAP) includes a loan guarantee support.
column46:
Key annoncements of monetary and liquidity support include:
"April 15. Bank of Canada announces further support through the purchase of government bonds and treasury bills, an additional corporate-bond purchases and enhancement of the term repo facility.
April 15. Department of Finance announces relief for federally regulated pension plan sponsors. The relief comprises moratorium on solvency payment requirements for defined benefit plans.
March 27. Bank of Canada cuts policy rate from 0.75% to 0.25%, and announces:

* The establishment of the Commercial Paper Purchase Program (CPPP) that aims to alleviate strains in short-term funding markets and thereby support business funding.

* That the Bank will begin acquiring Government of Canada securities in the secondary market. Purchases will begin with a minimum of $5 billion per week, across the yield curve.
'March 18. Bank of Canada urges retailers to continue accepting cash as means of payment
March 17. Six largest retail banks announce mortgage-payment deferment facilities.
column47: March 17 Six largest retail banks announce mortgage-payment deferment facilities.

*May 29: Approval of the Deconfination Plan.
*May 13: Extension of the state of emergency for the island of Santiago through May 29.

* May 1: the state of emergency has been extended through May 14 for Boa Vista and Santiago. For the other islands
- São Vicente, Santo Antão, São Nicolau, Sal, Maio, Fogo, and Brava
- some restrictions on businesses and public areas remain under the “State of Calamity” designation.
*April 24: All individuals outside their home are required to wear a facemask.

* April 16: the Government of Cabo Verde extended the State of Emergency for the islands of Boa Vista, Santiago, and Sao Vicente until May 2, 2020. The State of Emergency was extended for the islands of Santo Antão, São Nicolau, Sal, Maio, Fogo, and Brava until April 26, 2020.
*March 28: The government announced a 20-day state of emergency.
*March 20: The government decided to quarantine the Boa Vista island until April 4.
column14:
*June 30: Resuming of the inter-islands air links, including Santiago.
*May 11: Resuming of maritime connections for passenger transport with Boa Vista.
*May 11: Resuming of limited maritime passenger transportation between some islands (with the exception of Santiago and Boa Vista).
*March 26: Suspension of flights and maritime connections between islands, except for sanitary reasons, emergency situations and essential services, such as maritime connections for the transport of goods and for the normal supply of the market by commercial and fishing boats.
*March 22: Mandatory quarantine for all travellers.
*March 18: Installation of body temperature scans in airports; preparation of quarantine areas in hospitals; suspension of flights from affected countries [Europe, United States, Brazil, Senegal and Nigeria], as well as maritime traffic (with a few exceptions).

*March 26: Closure of schools until April 17.
*March 18: the Government declared school holidays from March 23 to April 13.
column18:
*June 18: Museums start activities in compliance with all imposed health requirements.
*June 6: Lifting of the limitation of the opening hours of restaurants, fixed until 9pm, starting June 1, throughout the national territory.
*May 15: Re-opening of services, companies and organizations, public and private, with the exception of those representing a greater risk of personal contact to contagious and that are not services and essential activities during the state of emergency.
*March 28: Closure of all non-essential services and companies (excluding production, processing, distribution activities and the sale and supply of food, hygiene and cleaning products or other essential goods; groceries, bakeries, market supplies; supply of fuel and gas; production and supply of water and electricity; restaurant delivery services between 10 a.m. and 9 p.m.).
*March 26: Local markets of agri-food products must operate with a small number of sellers; ban on selling products in the street.
column20:
*March 28: Closure of all non-essential services and companies (excluding production, processing, distribution activities and the sale and supply of food, hygiene and cleaning products or other essential goods; groceries, bakeries, market supplies; supply of fuel and gas; production and supply of water and electricity; restaurant delivery services between 10 a.m. and 9 p.m.).

*May 13: The government provides more than CVE 25 000 for domestic workers.

*For the most vulnerable, mitigating measures are estimated at CVE 2.2 billion (1.2% of GDP). They comprise: i) income compensation to provide financial support to individuals operating in the informal sector; ii) social inclusion emergency measures for vulnerable people without income; iii) social inclusion income, with support from the World Bank; iv) support to microfinance institutions to support interest-free loans to vulnerable households and; v) care for the elderly with food assistance and other financial support.

*The Government will provide more than CVE 25,000 for the Solidarity Income (RSO), for the benefit of 2540 people who are in the informal sector, who do domestic work and who are not registered in the social security system.

*Late March: The authorities adopted social protection measures amounting to US$ 3.7 million.

*May 22: The Government reinforces the Program to promote Micro Entrepreneurship.

*March 24: The authorities have taken measures to support the private sector including loan guarantees of up to 50% for large companies in all sectors (CVE1 billion, about 9 million euros); up to 80% for companies in the tourism and transport sectors (CVE1 billion, about 9 million euros); up to 100% for SMEs in all sectors (CVE300 million, 2.7 million euros) and for micro-enterprises in all sectors (CVE700 million, about 6.7 million euros).

column46: *Late March: The central bank decided to loosen the monetary policy stance and to increase liquidity in the banking system. Key measures included a reduction in rates as follows: the policy rate by 125 basis points to 0.25%, the minimum reserve requirements from 13 to 10%, and the overnight deposit rate by 5 basis points to 0.05%; and the setting up at the central bank of a long-term lending instruments for banks.
column47: *The Bank of Cape Verte (BCV) implemented the reduction in capital adequacy ratio and provision for banks depending on requests by borrowers to place a moratorium or forbearance on loan repayment for 3 months.
column54:

*Prorogation of the curfew to June 23.

*May 10: 15 days prison and a fine of XAF 2000 for any person apprehended without a mask
*Obligation to wear masks, starting May 7.
*April 25: Declaration of the state of health emergency for 21 days.
*April 15: Curfew reduced from 8pm to 5am in the provinces of Logone Occidental, Logone Oriental, Mayo-Kebbi Est, the city of N'Djamena, Mandelia, Logone-Gana, N'Djamena-Farah and Guitté, extended for 2 weeks, starting April 15.

column14:

*May 7: Ban on entrance/exit of people in all provincial capitals and in the city of N'Djamena, starting May 8, for a period of two weeks (with the exception of people inside the areas that are under curfew and for vehicles transporting goods and foodstuffs).
*March 17: Closure of airports (except cargo), starting March 19.
*March 16: Closure of borders with CAR and Sudan.
*March 16: Strict restrictions on movement outside refugee camps.
*March 8: Test and quarantine for all people coming from high-risk countries [China, South Korea, Iran, Italy and France]; systematic health checks at national borders.

*March 20: Closure of the places of worship.
*March 17: Ban on gatherings of more than 50 people, starting March 19.

*March 23: Closure of non-essential businesses throughout the country.

column22: *April 14: The authorities have decided on a package of fiscal measures to help households and businesses weather the shock.
column25:
*May 15: Health system measures include:

- distribution for free of face masks to the population;

- Approval of a financial bonus for health workers; the family of workers who have died of COVID-19 will remain payed their usual wages until all kids are above 18 years old.

- Purchase of medical equipment and medicine, as well as 5 mobile testing labs.

*May 15: A Health Crisis Management Committee (CGCS) has been set up to coordinate the medical response to COVID-19 (the National Coordination for Health Response).

*April 14: The package of fiscal measures decided by the authorities also include the simplification of the import process for food and necessity items, including health equipment and tax exemptions for these items. Additionally, the authorities are in the process of hiring additional health workers (+1600) and will set up a solidarity fund for the vulnerable population amounting to XAF100 billion.

*April 14: Implementation of the contingency plan against COVID-19. The financing is going to exceed the estimated XAF 15 billion (0.3% of non-oil GDP) to XAF 31 billion (0.6% of non-oil GDP).

*March 16: Implementation under a national contingency plan with an estimated cost of XAF 15 billion in fiscal measures, including:

- training of medical and technical staff;

- purchase of necessary medical equipment;

- construction of 7 health centres in remote areas;

- construction of 3 mobile hospitals;

- secure management of entry points.
column28:
*May 20: Distribution of food supplies to low income households.

*April 14: The package of measures decided by the authorities include:

- the temporary suspension of payments of electricity and water bills for the lifeline consumption;

- establishment of a food distribution program (0.5% of non-oil GDP), with a minimum budget of XAF 25 billion to reinforce the stocks of the National Food Security Office (ONASA);

- payment of all death benefits due to deceased civil and military agents, indemnities and ancillary wages owed to retirees and payment of medical expenses for civilian agents and defence and security forces (0.1% of non-oil GDP);

- a solidarity fund for vulnerable population amounting to XAF 100 billion.
column31: *April 14: The package of fiscal measures includes: for the SMEs, the authorities will, among other things, reduce by 50% the business license fees and the presumptive tax for 2020. Tax breaks such as carryforward losses and delays in tax payments will also be examined on a case-by-case basis.
column34:
*April 14: The package of measures decided by the authorities include:

- the establishment of a Youth Entrepreneurship Fund (0.6% of non-oil GDP);

- the clearance of domestic arears of about XAF 110 billion owed to suppliers;

- a subsidy planned to the agricultural sector (0.3% of non-oil GDP) ;

- the simplification of the import process for food and necessity items, including health equipment, and tax exemptions for these items.

*March 25: The Central African Banking Commission (COBAC) informed banks that they can use their capital conservation buffers of 2.5% to absorb pandemic-related losses but requested that a restrictive policy with regard to dividend distribution be adopted.

column12: The country is under curfew between 10pm and 5am. Some areas are fully locked down. People aged 75 or older must stay at home and the government issued a recommendation to stay at home to everyone.
column14: Borders are open to nationals and residents only, subject to a 14-day mandatory quarantine upon arrival.
column16: Schools and universities are closed (starting on March 16). Winter holidays were brought forward.
column18: Events of more than 50 people are banned from March 16. Public venues as well as restaurants, bars, and the like are closed.
column20: Information not available
column22: The Government of Chile announced several measures in response to the pandemic. First, the government has ensured fiscal resources for detection and treatment of the virus. Second, policy measures have been geared towards supporting household incomes, especially for the most vulnerable, and protecting employment. Third, a broad set of measures point towards injecting liquidity to the economy, thereby facilitating access to working capital, especially for SMEs. A national agreement achieved between the the government and political parties leads to a new emergency plan to support the economy for the forthcoming two years. Its main pillars are: i) protecting households' income and well-being, with a new emergency family plan, a new solidarity fund at the municipal level, a new health fund, and some improvements to the employment protection law and unemployment insurance scheme ii) a reactivation plan for the economy and the labour market, which includes a public investment plan, hiring subsidies, easing the financing of SMEs, promoting private investment, new teleworking measures, facilitating access to credit and supporting public companies iii) the creation of a new US $12,000 million fund to finance the recovery plan, to be financed partly by sovereign wealth funds.
column25:
- A national campaign was launched to inform the public of prevention measures and detection.


- As of April 1, the coordination of the public and private network was handed over to the Undersecretary of Healthcare Networks. This means that the Ministry of Health took control of the management of public and private infrastructure to face this emergency.


- Testing for people covered by the National Health Fund is free (subject to a prescription). Price for people covered by private insurers is capped. Between March and May, the daily capacity of PCR tests was almost quadrupled.


- Hospital capacity will be reinforced by speeding up the completion of five new hospitals and other facilities, such as a field hospital, 6 health care posts, a navy ship and a new field hospital with a capacity of 3 thousand beds in a convention center, among others.


- Between March and June, ICU beds with mechanical fans will be doubled.


- Bed capacity for people who must be quarantined will be increased. The government announced on May 17 the expansion of the existing network of Health Residences nationwide to accommodate people in need, with special concern and priority for the elderly.


- Elective surgeries will be postponed in cases where delay does not imply a significant health risk.


- The National Health Procurement Agency will accelerate the delivery of personal protection equipment for emergency services and primary health care staff.


- Workers that have been in contact with confirmed cases are granted a sick-leave.


- The Ministry of Health authorized the performance of synchronous care in 11 medical specialties. While the Health Alert is in force, these medical consultations may be carried out remotely in the same terms as face-to-face care, through information technology and telecommunications between a patient and a doctor who are in different geographical locations and who they can interact with each other in real time.


- The government instructed health insurance institutions to deliver medications at home to patients diagnosed with any of the 85 pathologies guaranteed by the state, without this implying an additional cost. The measure aims to prevent the displacement of these patients to obtain the dispensing of their prescriptions.


- To cope with the effects of the pandemic and the confinement in the mental health of the population, the government announced on May 17 the Healthy-Mind program. This program will strengthen the public and private offer of mental health and will include a digital platform for consultation, support and recommendations on this matter.
column28:
- The 19th of April the government gave a cash transfer (Bono Covid) for the poorest families (2 million households).


- The 14th of May the government enacted a bill for a second transfer, covering people from the 60% poorest population and without formal work (about 4.9 million people). This will be provided for a period of three months.


- The 17th of May the government announced the delivery of 2.5 million family baskets with food and essential elements for middle-class and vulnerable families in this emergency due to problems in supplying themselves.


- The law for job protection, covering 4.5 million formal workers, has now come into force, which allows the temporary suspension of employees´ functions in the company when the employee must remain at home without the possibility of teleworking. In these cases, the contractual relationship and all corresponding employment rights will be maintained (except the salary), but the employee will be paid from the unemployment insurance under more flexible eligibility criteria. As long as this exceptional situation continues, the employer will maintain the obligation to pay the employee's social security and health contributions. The law also prohibits the distribution of dividends by firms using this new framework.


- Other measures include the payment deferral of electricity bills, suspension of peak hour charge for electricity bills and the postponement of the otherwise mandatory annual vehicle inspection and circulation permit.
-The 5th of June, a support program for the middle class has been announced and which comprises four pillars: i) a credit for the middle class and self-employed (Crédito Covid) at 0% interest rate and which will potentially benefit 600 000 workers ii) the postponement of mortgage payments of mortgages up to 6 months and with state guarantee ii) the extension of rent subsidy to the middle class for households who experienced a fall in income of more than 30% iv) the expansion of the credit for higher education
column31: Information not available
column34: Information not available
column37:
- Deferral of the payment of Property Tax to be due in April, with 0% interest rate. Applicable to individual owners of real state with fiscal value lower than CLP$ 133,000,000 (aprox. US$ 160,000). The payment delayed shall be paid along with the 3 next installments to be due in June, September and November 2020.


- Flexibility measures for tax debts payments of low income individuals (flexible payment agreements, with no interest nor penalties).

-Accelerated income tax refund for self-employed (in April 2020 instead of May 2020).


- Advanced income tax refund for self-employed of amounts withheld in January and February 2020 (rate of 10.75%).


- Suspension of mandatory monthly provisional payments on account of CIT for the next 3 months. This measure should benefit 700,000 businesses.


- Deferral of VAT payments for the next 3 months. Applicable to businesses with sales of less than UF 350,000 (aprox. US$ 12 million). They will be able to pay the VAT in 6 to 12 monthly installments (depending on their size) at a 0% interest rate. This measure should benefit 240,000 businesses.


- Accelerated income tax refund for SMEs (in April 2020 instead of May 2020). This measure should benefit 500,000 SMEs.


- Postponement from April to July 2020 of the payment of CIT for SMEs. The CIT return shall be submitted in April (as usual). This measure should benefit 140,000 SMEs.


- Deferral of the payment of Property Tax to be due in April 2020, with 0% interest rate. Applicable to businesses with sales lower than UF 350,000 (aprox. US$12 million). The payment delayed shall be paid along with the 3 next installments to be due in June, September and November 2020.


- Deferral of the payment of Property Tax to be due in April 2020, with 0% interest rate. Applicable to businesses with sales lower than UF 350,000 (aprox. US$ 12 million). The payment delayed shall be paid along with the 3 next installments to be due in June, September and November 2020.


- Temporary reduction from 0.8% to 0% of the stamp tax rate on all loans/credit transactions for 6 months. This measure will benefit businesses and individuals.
column40: Information not available
column43:
The Financial Market Commission unveiled a package of measures to facilitate the flow of credit to businesses and households, which includes: (i) special treatment in the establishment of provisions for deferred loans; (ii) use of mortgage guarantees to safeguard SME loans; (iii) adjustments in the treatment of assets received as payment and margins in derivative transactions; and (iv) start of a review of the timetable for the implementation of Basel III standards.


- A new law eases access to government-backed guarantee for loans to firms with annual income of up to US$ 34 million. If fully used, loans granted through this scheme would represent 10% of GDP.


- The 17th of May the government announced a state guarantee fund to deliver liquidity to SMEs through non-bank financial institutions.
column46: On March 16 the Central Bank cut the interest rate by 0.75 points to 1%, then to 0.5% on March 31. Moreover, the following measures have also been enacted: (i) introduction of a new Funding Facility for banks Conditional on them increasing credit (FCIC); (ii) inclusion of high-rated commercial loans as collateral for FCIC operations; (iii) inclusion of corporate securities as collateral for the Central Bank's liquidity operations; (iv) initiation of a program for purchase of bank bonds (up to US$8 billion); (v) initiation of a program for purchase of central bank bond; (vi) expansion of the program for providing liquidity in pesos and US$ through repo operations and swaps up to US$4 billion and US$4.5 billion in NDF; (vii) expansion of eligible currencies for RR in foreign currencies; (viii) flexibility of CB regulations for bank liquidity; and (ix) extension until January 9, 2021 the window for possible resumption of FX sales and NDF operations that was opened in November 2019.
column47: A draft bill sent to Congress on June 5 allows pension funds to invest in debt instruments issued by large firms, subject to certain conditions.
column48:
Reducing workers' exposure to Covid-19 in the workplace:
A massive campaign of vaccination against seasonal flu started on 16 March. Employers are responsible for protecting the health and safety of employees at work. They are required to implement preventative measures to ensure employees are not exposed to conditions that could be harmful to their health or safety while working.

Income support to sick workers and their families:
Unemployment insurance extended to those who are sick and unable to work from home, without termination of contractual link.

Income support to quarantined workers who cannot work from home:
Workers in quarantine (infected or those who had a close contact with an infected person) are entitled to paid sick leave.

Helping workers that are self-employed:
A Covid-19 Law project was announced that ensures that self-employed workers can access an unemployment insurance fund.

Helping firms and workers to adjust working time and preserve jobs:
The unemployment insurance fund can also be used to compensate the reduction in earnings due to reduced working hours. Additionally, the law prohibits benefitted firms to fire workers that have their contracts suspended and to distribute earnings to its shareholders.

Changes to dismissal regulation:
The law for job protection bans the dismissal of workers using force majeure clauses related to Covid-19, during a period of six months or during the state of emergency.

Helping workers to work from home:
A Covid-19 Law project was approved through which workers that work from home will be able to access the same benefits as workers that do not work remotely.
column51:
Economic plan involves resources of more than US$ 17 billion, 6.9% of GDP, to help small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), as well as large companies face and overcome this crisis. A new capitalization plan of Banco Estado for US$ 500 million to grant more credits and the extension of state guarantees for loans, reinforced with additional US$ 3,000 million the 8th of April will help leverage over US$ 25 billion in credits. Tax relief with suspension of second quarter provisional monthly payments (PPM). Postponement of VAT payment for companies with sales under CLP$ 10 billion. Early income tax refund, postponement of income tax to July.

In early April, the government paid all pending payments to suppliers. Future invoices will be paid in 30 days.
column54: On the 31st of July, the government announced US$4500 M in public investment, employment (employment subsidies and skills formation), SMEs support and to speed up permits process.
column55:
Government links for more details: https://www.gob.cl/coronavirus/

Fiscal measures: https://www.dipres.gob.cl/598/articles-201476_Informe_PDF.pdf (page 34)

column12: The country has started a total lockdown on the 24th of March nationally, while in Bogotá, the capital, started on the 21st of March. Confinement has been extended till 1 of August. From the 1 of June many activities are allowed to start under strinct sanitary protocols.
