* The "Pa 'Ti" programme was launched, targeting freelance business workers. A monthly transitional transfer of 5,000 pesos will be provided to their bank accounts. The identification of the beneficiaries was made through a database of people in this condition and who have loans with the formal financial system [announced on May 17].
column31: * Urgent facilities will be granted, to make the payment of advance commitments of the entire productive sector more flexible, in three installments immediately after the emergency period.
column34:
* FASE (Employee Solidarity Assistance Fund) continues to support companies to keep jobs. This fund will pay DOP 8500 of the salaries for those formal workers that had to stop working.

* The govt. announced the constitution of a Guarantee and Financing Fund to benefit Micro and Small Businesses (MIPYMES), through an agreement with the Central Bank, the Superintendency of Banks and the Association of Commercial Banks of the Dominican Republic [announced on May 17].
column37: * Payment of the annual income tax (to be done in April by certain companies) was divided into 4 payments. The DGII will temporarily stop applying the rate of the Advance Price Agreements to the hotel sector [since March 17].
column40: Information not available
column43: Information not available
column46:
* Around DOP 12 000 million (of the total expenditure of DOP 32 062.5 million for this crisis) will come from a loan from the Central Bank to the Government, in response to the national emergency situation declared by the National Congress.

* The central bank reduced (1) the Monetary Policy Rate from 4.5% to 3.5%, (2) the interest rate of the permanent liquidity expansion facility (from 6% to 4.5%), and (3) the interest rate on short-term interest-bearing deposits at the central bank (from 3% to 2.5%). The central bank also implemented liquidity provision measures for the financial system, both in national (more than DOP 52 billion) and foreign currency. In addition, the special regulatory treatment measures for the financial system would allow readjustment of the payment schedule of bank debtors if necessary, without additional regulatory costs arising from this action [announced on March 16].
column47: Information not available
column51: * The Ministry of Agriculture initiates a commercial assistance plan for sensitive sectors of the agricultural economy such as chicken, cheese, and vegetable production. A grocery purchase and distribution program is being coordinated with producer organizations [since April 15].
column54:
* The Emergency and Health Management Committee is created to attend to the emergency generated by COVID-19 [from Aprlil 1]

* The Economic Affairs and Employment Commission, the Social Affairs Commission and the High Level Commission (in charge of co-ordination) are created to deal with the emergency [since March 19].
column55:
Ministerio de Salud, Comunicados de Prensa (https://www.msp.gob.do/web/?page_id=3371)
Presidencia, Comunicados de Prensa (https://presidencia.gob.do/noticias)

column12: * August 26: The National Emergency Operations Committee (COE) defined new parameters for the reopening and the mayor of Quito announced a move to lower confinement requirements starting June 3.
column14:
* June 1: Ecuador approved resumption of commercial flight operations with limited flight capacity.
All arriving passengers are required to have the results of a PCR COVID test from within the last seven (7) days prior to arrival in Ecuador.
column16: * July 17: Closure of all schools and universities remains in force, but classes will be delivered online.
column18: * June 3: The National Emergency Operations Committee (COE) defined new parameters for the reopening using a "traffic light" system to indicate the number of cases in a region.
column20: * June 30: In Quito, starting June 3: Productive activities will be reactivated "as long as they respect biosafety protocols" in person with 50% of the staff. The reopening of commercial premises may operate with 30% of customer capacity.        In the rest of the country, “yellow confinement level” means: The curfew will apply from 21:00 to 5:00. Public transportation will circulate without restriction of license plates, urban transportation will circulate at 50% capacity. Restaurants and cafes may reopen at 30% capacity. In the rest of the country, "green confinement level" means: curfew from 00:00 to 05:00. Public transport may circulate without restrictions, while urban transport will work at 50% capacity. Inter-cantonal transport may operate between cantons with the same traffic light colour.
column22:
* April 14: declaration to allow all relevant aspects for the operation of the economy to be agreed between the interested parties, in order to preserve jobs and sources of those jobs to the maximum: for instance, to avoid layoffs, new salaries and different working hours may be agreed; as well as extensions of terms and grace periods for debts.
*April 10: Creation of the National Account for Humanitarian Assistance, where both the public and private sector contribute to support the response to the crisis. In particular: 1) firms with more than USD 1mn of utilities will contribute 5% of that utility in three monthly payments; 2) workers earning more than USD500 a month will have a progressive contribution, according to their salary, for the next nine months.

* Civil servants will contribute with a percentage of their salary, with higher-level officials contributing 50% of their salaries
* March 30: Refinancing of debt of decentralised governments (GADs) through Ecuador's development bank (Banco de Desarrollo del Ecuador) to postpone payments and free up resources to support the emergency at the regional level.
column25:
*May 8: CAF has approved a loan for USD 50 million to strengthen the capacity of the health system to respond to the health emergency. '
* Reduction of tariffs for the imports of medicines and other crisis-related medical inputs.

* From 1st March to April 2nd, USD 298 million have been disbursed to support the health sector (remunerations, equipments and payments)
column28:
* March 19: On March 19th, further measures were announced to support the population and businesses, such as deferral of payroll contributions, exceptional cash transfer amounting to USD120 to 400 thousand poor families, later extended to 950 thousands families, distribution of food baskets, and a financing of USD50 million in credit lines for small
- and medium-size businesses.
column31: * March 19: On April 16th, President Moreno sent two urgent economic laws to the National Assembly First, an "Organic Law of Humanitarian Support to Combat the Health Crisis of COVID-19" which seeks to collect tax revenues from two main sources, an additional tax of 5 percent on the profits of the companies that have earned more than USD1 million in 2019, and a progressive income tax for people whose monthly salary is greater than USD500. Those special contributions will be managed by an extra-budgetary fund with the sole purpose of supporting the health and economic crisis. The proposed law also includes changes to labor regulations that seek to make labor contract more flexible.
column34: * March 19: The "Organic Law for the Regulation of Public Finances" project seeks to establish fiscal rules for the expenses of the non-financial public sector institutions and improve the use, control and evaluation of public resources.
column37:
* The government has approved a six-month extension for the income tax declaration for SMEs and for the VAT incurred in the months of April, May and June. The government is also granting flexibility to enterprises in the repayment of tax liabilities.

* Social security contributions postponed 90 days (i.e. contributions for April, May and June) for voluntary affiliates and those without a relation of dependency and for microenterprises.
column40:
* April 12: the National Financial Corporation (CFN) will create a long-term credit line at interest rates not exceeding 2% to sustain jobs, with an initial contribution of USD 500 million from the companies' contribution to the humanitarian trust that plans to create the Regime

* USD 50 million have been made available in credit lines for small
- and medium-size businesses.
column43: Information not available
column46:
* March 29: Selling of gold by the Central Bank, to obtain liquidity (USD 300 million)

* March 24: Announcement of extraordinary deferrals of credit obligations, including those from public banks, and a requirement for additional generic provisioning on banks' gross lending portfolio during 2020.
column47: Information not available
column48:
*May 8: CAF has approved a USD 350 million loan for financial support for the economic program of the National Government to contain the social and economic emergency. '
* Deferral of payment of interests on current credits, mainly those contracted though Ecuador's development bank (Banco de Desarrollo del Ecuador) and CFN Ecuador and for clients of the "Economia Popular y Solidaria".

* For mortgages, clients who are in default may restructure or refinance their obligations up to 18 months grace and 30 years term.
column51: * 12-month deferral in payments of utilities for the months of April, May and June for selected small enterprises with no interests or associated charges.
column54: Information not available

column12:
* March 17: Egypt placed over 300 families under quarantine in a Delta village to stem the spread of the new coronavirus.


* March 25: A night-time curfew between 8pm and 6am local time has been introduced.

*The government has also reduced by half the number of public sector employees coming to work.

*April 28: a Presidential decree published in the Official Gazette declared the state of emergency across the country for three months starting April 28.

*May 10: Due to the steady number of positive cases in Egypt, the Ministry of Health announced that it will continue to implement its curfew during Ramadan.

*May 14: The Ministry of Health published a three-stage plan outlining the required procedures for the gradual reopening of the economy.


* June 27: The night-time curfew in place since March 25 is fully lifted as of June 27 announced Hany Younes, the Prime Minister's Media Advisor.
column14:
* July 1: reopening of select tourist destinations to international charter flights. EgyptAir will resume flights to more than 29 international destinations.


* June 23: Prime Minister Mostafa Madbouli announced that starting on June 27 public transportation will operate between 4 a.m. and midnight.

*All borders are closed, remaining open for cargo only. Domestic and international flights are also suspended and airports are closed.
column16:
* March 15: All schools, universities, and colleges have been closed.

* March 24: The closure of schools was extended (two extra weeks).

*The Ministry of Education and Technical Education (MOETE) announced steps to implement distance learning and assessment during school suspension. MOETE extended the access to the Egyptian Knowledge Bank (EKB) to students, providing content by grade level and subject (kindergarten through secondary education). Content is available in both Arabic and English to all students, parents and teachers.

*March 19: Egypt announced it had contracted with the online learning provider Edmodo to deliver remote instruction to the country's entire K-12 student body.
column18:
* March 24: The government has closed churches, mosques and their attachments. It also cancelled cultural events and touristic trips, and banned religious prayers in public gatherings as well as other large public gatherings.

*May 4: Hotels are allowed to operate at 25% capacity until June 2020 and at 50% capacity thereafter.

*June 23: Prime Minister Mostafa Madbouli announced that starting on June 27: 1) worship places will be open for daily prayers but main prayers like Friday prayers and masses will be banned; 2) toilets and ceremonial halls at worship places will be closed.
column20:
* June 23: Prime Minister Mostafa Madbouli announced a bundle of measures aimed at co-existing with COVID-19 that went into effect on June 27: 1) restaurants and cafes will resume work with 25 percent capacity; 2) shisha will still be banned; 3) stores will close at 9 p.m. while restaurants and cafes will close at 10 p.m. and 4) cinemas, theatres, and entertainment venues will operate with 25 percent capacity.

* June 16: The Minister of Tourism and Antiquities, Khaled El-Anani, confirmed the reopening of some of eight of Egypt's most significant archaeological sites in July. These are the Pyramids of Giza and their surrounding areas, the Egyptian Museum in Tahrir, the Citadel of Salah El-Din, the temples in Karnak and Luxor, Hurghada Museum, Abu Simbel temples and the Temple of Philae in Aswan.
*The government has closed all malls, gyms, sporting clubs, in-dining restaurants and cafes. Supermarkets, bakeries and pharmacies remain open.
column22:
* March 22: President Al-Sisi announced the allocation of 100 billion EGP (USD 6.4 billion equivalent to 2% of GDP) to fund a comprehensive plan to combat the coronavirus. Half of the budget is allocated to the tourism sector while the rest will support poor families and the stock market through a stock purchase programme by the Egyptian Central Bank (USD 1.3 billion).

*The government also introduced a six-month extension for credit repayments targeting all individuals and businesses, and the cancellation of the ATM withdrawal fees.

*The cost of transactions in the EGX will be reduced from 0.15% to 0.125% and from 0.15% to 0.05% for non-residents and Egyptian residents, respectively. All spot transactions on EGX will be exempt from stamp duty.

*The Ministry of Finance lifted the Administrative detention for taxpayers in return for payment of 10% of the tax due and to settle the outstanding tax due through the Dispute Resolution Committee. The Egyptian Tax Authority has also lifted the means of payment to allow cash or cheque payment of taxes due for fiscal year 2019/2020.
column25:
* The authorities have taken a host of precautionary measures to improve testing as well as to limit the community spread of the virus, including setting up testing centres, temporarily closing places of worship, temporarily halting all air travel, and encouraging civil servants to work from home in non-essential sectors. The central bank and the government are actively implementing measures to contain economic implications of the epidemic.


* March 24: The government recently has announced 1 billion EGP (USD 63.5 million) in extra funding for its health services and applied various measures to increase the country's capacity to absorb the sudden increase of critical patients that the outbreak might bring.


* March 25: WHO delegation concludes COVID-19 technical mission to Egypt, as a result of which alternative mechanisms for testing patients were identified through the establishment of 27 laboratories across the country and additional 4 university laboratories.
column28:
* March 22: The government announces that pensioners will get five overdue bonuses (amounting to 80% of the basic salary), as well as a 14% annual bonus as of the fiscal year 2020/2021.

*The Ministry of Workforce has allocated EGP 50 million (USD 2.9 million) for irregular workers, including women, who lost their job due to the coronavirus. Around 300,000 beneficiaries will receive EGP 500 (around USD 32) in cash.

*The government increased payments to women community leaders in rural areas from EGP 350 to EGP 900 per month to ensure gender equity.

*Expansion of the Takaful and Karama social protection programmes to an additional 60,000 households, where women already represent 88% of the programmes' beneficiaries.

*Annual salary increase of 7-12 % for government employees starting from June 30, 2020. Total cost of EGP 31 billion (USD 1.8 billion).
column31:
*The price of natural gas and electricity has been reduced for industrial use. Natural gas for industrial use will be priced at USD 4.50 for mmbtu (one million British thermal units), down from USD 5.50, while electricity for heavy industry will be priced at 0.10 EGP (USD 0.0064) per kilowatt hour, down from 1.10 EGP. The price of electricity for other industries will be kept stable for three to five years. The government also postponed repayment of loans for SMEs.

*Capital gains tax has been postponed until further notice.

*The Ministry of Finance lifted the Administrative detention for taxpayers in return for payment of 10% of the tax due and to settle the outstanding tax due through the Dispute Resolution Committee. The ETA has also lifted the means of payment to allow cash or cheque payment of taxes due for FY 2019/2020.

*The stamp duty on transactions in the EGX are reduced from 0.15 percent to 0.125% and from 0.15% to 0.05% for non-residents and Egyptian residents, respectively. All spot transactions on EGX are exempt from stamp duty.

*Personal income tax: introducing a progressive system instead of the current credit system, where income is subject to progressive income tax rates between 2.5% to 25% with additional rules applied to individuals who earn a higher income.

*The Export Subsidy Fund will pay out the entire EGP 1 billion in arrears in March and April 2020, plus 10% in cash payments to exporters in June 2020.

*The withholding tax on dividends paid by listed companies in EGX will be reduced from 10% to 5%.
column34: Information not available
column37:
*Extended extension of the suspension from the taxation of Capital Gains on securities listed on the EGX for Egyptian residents until 1 January 2022 which was originally due to expire in 17 May 2020. The exemption from the taxation of Capital Gains on securities listed on the EGX for non-residents will be permanent.

*The moratorium on the tax law on agricultural land has been extended for 2 years.

*Three months extension for the payment of property taxes for companies in the industrial and tourism sector. The property taxes shall be payable in monthly instalments over the following six months.

*Extension of the individuals' annual tax return filing deadline to 16 April instead of 31 March. Exemption of the tax returns online filing subscription fee for the use of the Egyptian Tax Authority online filing portal.

*The Agricultural Land Tax Act is suspended for two years.
column40: Information not available
column43: Information not available
column46:
*March 26: The Egypt`s Central Bank cut interest rates to historic lows, reducing the overnight deposit rate by 300 basis points to 9.25% and the lending rate to 10.25%. The preferential interest rate on loans to SMEs, industry, tourism and housing for low-income and middle-class families, has been reduced from 10% to 8%.

*March 29: The Central Bank announced a series of new limits on cash withdrawals and deposits to avoid overcrowding, in particular during payroll and pension disbursement. A daily limit of 10,000 Egyptian pounds (around 630 USD) for individuals and 50,000 (around 3180 USD) for businesses is applied until further notice, while fees on electronic transactions have been lifted for six months to encourage people to rely on electronic payment methods and bank transfers instead of using cash.

*The limit for electronic payments via mobile phones has been raised to EGP 30,000/day and EGP 100,000/month for individuals, and to EGP 40,000/day and EGP 200,000/per week for corporations.

*A new debt relief initiative for individuals at risk of default has also been announced. It will waive marginal interest on debt under EGP 1 million if customers make a 50% payment.

*The Egyptian Central Bank has also launched an EGP 20 billion stock-purchase program.
column47: Information not available
column51:
*The Central Bank introduced credit lines for tourism enterprises to facilitate paying of salaries and financial dues for suppliers. Such credit lines can be paid over a maximum of two years with a six-month grace period.

*The Financial Regulatory Agency (FRA) announced a set of measures to aid micro-finance activity, including introducing free financial services for regular clients, postponing 50% of payments with no penalty, and reducing the administrative fees for current finances.

*The FRA extended deadline for the EGX listed companies to submit their financial statements for 4Q 2019 to 15 June 2020 (original deadline 30 April). The FRA requested mortgage lenders, factoring and leasing companies to grant six-month grace period upon request by clients.

*The National Bank of Egypt and Bank Misr announced a one-year deposit program with a 15% interest rate.

*Meetings of Board of Directors: On 18 March 2020, the General Authority for Investment and Free Zones (GAFI) issued Decree No. 160 to temporarily allow virtual attendance of general assembly meetings for companies governed by the provisions of Law No. 159 of 1981 and Law No. 72 of 2017.

*Free Zones: On 16 April 2020, GAFI issued Decree No. 187 to allow industrial companies operating in Free Zones to produce facemasks and protective supplies using existing production lines for a period of six months.

*On 9 April 2020, GAFI issued Decree No. 175 to increase export allowance to the local market of industrial companies located in Free Zones from 20% to 50% for a period of six months. Companies can also sell up to 20% or more of their raw materials and accessories to the local market with special approval from the Head of the Free Zone and the Head of Free Zones Sector. The deadline for submission of financial statements has also been extended for three months.

*Investment Zones: On 22 April 2020, GAFI issued Decree No. 192 to facilitate approval of new projects inside the Zones and allow companies engaged in manufacturing of medical supplies, pharmaceuticals, and food commodity to change or add business activity immediately upon a notification for a period of six months. New projects are also granted a temporary six-month licence to operate without having to comply with the normal procedures if the production lines have been already installed.

*April 21: The House of Representatives amended two articles of the real estate and property tax Law (196/2008) to relieve businesses of the real estate tax provided that these lands are used in industrial and production activities. Upon a report submitted by the Finance Ministry, the Cabinet will decide whether industries using their affiliated lands in industrial, strategic and service activities are eligible for real estate tax exemptions.
column54:
*March 18: Brokerage firms are allowed by the EGX to receive orders via e-mail or mobile text messages.

*March 29: The Egypt for Information Dissemination Company (EGID), a subsidiary of EGX, developed an electronic voting system called (E-Magles) enabling board members of a listed company to vote remotely.

*March 30: The EGX developed electronic trading support systems allowing remote access to several platforms, including customer coding, electronic membership system, financial solvency, and OMNI accounts.

*The Egyptian government has undertaken important efforts to integrate the specific needs of women in its COVID-19 response plan. The National Council for Women (NCW) will be part, along with other state institutions, of the committee in charge of designing additional tailored measures to mitigate the impact of the crisis on informal sector workers. Its recent policy brief outlines the pillars of Egypt's response to women's situation during the outbreak, including immediate and medium-term policy suggestions to mainstream the needs of women in health, social protection and economic measures. It also recently launched a policy tracker to monitor the policy measures taken by the government to respond to women's needs in the context of the COVID-19 outbreak.

column12:
*7 July: Phase 1 of the phased reopening of the economy is extended until 21 July.
*16 June: Quarantine lifted. Economic activities subject to phased reopening. Citizens encouraged to remain at home unless necessary.

* 13 June: End of compulsory quarantine due to the laws governing the quarantine having been overturned by the Constitutional court. Voluntary quarantine requested of all citizens.
*4 June: Quarantine extended (on 2 June) until 15 June but is relaxed for construction workers and the functioning of distribution channels for construction materials for work to mitigate the impact of tropical storm Amanda and for functioning of producers and distributors of plastic products.
*31 May: Quarantine remains in force until 6 June but is relaxed following the damage caused by tropical storm Amanda. The State of Emergency is declared for 15 days due to tropical storm Amanda. Mobility restrictions are lifted for 5 days for those needing to carry out repairs in their homes.
*7 May : "Special quarantine" in force for 15 days, with further restrictions on movement. Extended until 6 June on 20 May and until 15 June on 2 June. People can only leave their home twice per week on designated days (rotating on the basis of national ID number), travel between municipalities heavily restricted to work reasons or purchase of food or medecine if not available in the municipality. Movement restrictions also apply to municipalities within the San Salvador metropolitan area

* March 14: State of Emergency declared, extended for 15 days on April 13 and for 17 days on April 29. State of Emrgenency is due to lapse on 16 May. Certain Constitutional rights temporarily restricted by law for 30 days.

* All non-essential public sector workers and all workers over 60, and all working pregnant women are to stay at home with remuneration since March 16

* March 21: the government issued a nationwide stay-at-home order and closed all non-essential businesses. The first 30-day period was extended for a further 15 days on 30 March (Executive Decree No. 14), a further 15 days on 13 April and a further 17 days on April 29. As part of these provisions, people can leave their house twice a week along to make essential purchases, those violating the order can be placed in quarantine facilities, vehicles violating the order can be seized for disinfection, and Ministry of Health staff can carry out in site inspections.

* April 13: For businesses allowed to operate, specific distancing measures are specified including distance, handwashing, availability of hand sanitizer and wearing of facial masks.
column14:
* 16 June: passenger flights allowed only for repatriation and humanitarian flights

* Since January 31: Progressive prohibition to entry from China, Korea, Italy, Iran, France, Germany and Spain.

* March 11: All borders are closed to passenger traffic and no foreign nationals are allowed to enter the country. Salvadorans returning have to undergo 30 days of quarantine in dedicated centres.

* Public transport operates at reduced capacity and under specific sanitary measures (face masks, availability of alcohol gel, disinfection)

* Specific areas put under temporary lockdown (72-hour lockdown in Puerto La Libertad 17-20 April)

* 7 May : no travel allowed between municipalities except for those allowed to work and to procure food or medecine if not available in the home municipality
column16: * March 11: Closure of schools, universities
column18: * Closure of restaurants, public events, public places and tourism facilities and activities
column20:
* 6 July: First phase of gradual reopening of the economy extended until 21 July.
*16 June: First phase of gradual reopening of the economy (planned until 7 July): On top of essential activities, industrial activities in food and drink, cleaning and hygiene products, textile and apparel, metal mechanic, electronics, auto parts, as well as construction, energy, vehicle service and repair, air transport for cargo import and export, maritime ports for cargo and logistics services, shopping malls (for pick-up in parking lots only), food delivery and take-away, business services by phone or online, accounting and professional services for commerce and industry, print shops, online and telephone sales, medical services, veterinary services and barber and beauty shops by appointment, merchandise transport, private trasport (with restrictions), public sector (in activities linked with commerce and industry), teaching and administrative personnel in education centres. Remote working is encouraged.

* 4 June: Closure of economic activities except for essential activities. Hardware stores, manufacturers of beds and matterasses, distributors of plastic products and construction workers are allowed to operate following tropical storm Amanda. Public transport is not allowed to operate (except to transport health professionals since 9 May). Are otherwise allowed: food and medecines delivery (not take-away); medical and paramedical services (excluding cosmetic industry); private transport; agriculture, agrifood and its value chain, including husbandry, fishing and distribution chains (production of nonperishable foods is restricted to essential foods in a positive list), merchandise transport for the goods whose production is allowed; call centres if linked to essential services (medical and pharmaceutical, food distribution, airline assistance, insurance, utilities, telecommunications, banking and financial services); bakeries (excluding chains and franchises), agricultural inputs; production of cleaning and higene products, pharmaceutical, packaging; utilities; fuel production; construction and civil engineering (only for publicly mandated works and for mitigation of the impact of tropical storm Amanda); press and media; funeral homes; support to airline operation (including maintenance).

* 31 May: Closure of economic activities except for essential activities. Hardware stores, manufacturers of beds and matterasses are allowed to operate following tropical storm Amanda. Public transport is not allowed to operate (except to transport health professionals since 9 May). Are allowed: food and medecines delivery (not take-away); medical and paramedical services (excluding cosmetic industry); private transport; agriculture, agrifood and its value chain, including husbandry, fishing and distribution chains (production of nonperishable foods is restricted to essential foods in a positive list), merchendise transport for the goods whose production is allowed; call centres if linked to essential services (medical and pharmaceutical, food distribution, airline assistance, insurance, utilities, telecommunications, banking and financial services); bakeries (excluding chains and franchises), agricultural inputs; production of cleaning and higene products, pharmaceutical, packaging; utilities; fuel production; construction and civil engineering (only for publicly mandated works); press and media; funeral homes; support to airline operation (including maintenance).

* 7 May: Closure renewed with increased restrictions: public transport is not allowed to operate (except to transport health professionals since 9 May). Are allowed: food and medecines delivery (not take-away); medical and paramedical services (excluding cosmetic industry); private transport; agriculture, agrifood and its value chain, including husbandry, fishing and distribution chains (production of nonperishable foods is restricted to essential foods in a positive list), merchendise transport for the goods whose production is allowed; call centres if linked to essential services (medical and pharmaceutical, food distribution, airline assistance, insurance, utilities, telecommunications, banking and financial services); bakeries (excluding chains and franchises), agricultural inputs; production of cleaning and higene products, pharmaceutical, packaging; utilities; fuel production; construction and civil engineering (only for publicly mandated works); press and media; funeral homes; support to airline operation (including maintenance).

* 13 April: Closure renewed. The following are permitted to operate: public transport, merchandise transport (for essential products and or international trade), restaurants (delivery), food distribution, water distribution, medical and paramedical services, call centres if linked to essential services (medical and pharmaceutical, food distribution, airline assistance, insurance, utilities, telecommunications, banking and financial services), food processing (except non-essential foods) and their distribution chains, production of cleaning and higene products, pharmaceutical, packaging, agriculture and agri-food (including husbandry, fishing and distribution chains), agricultural input production, textile and apparel (only if for the production of inputs to PPE equipment and other inputs to the health system), bakeries, administrative and shipment activities in exporting firms, administrative areas of investing firms (with explicit authorisation), financial services can operate at 50% of capacity unless they are invovled in channelling cash transfers to the public.
Automobile repair shops can work to serve demand from authorised public sector entities, utility and insurance companies. Hardware stores operate at a maximium 30% of capacity and only serve demand from authorised entities involved in the response to the pandemic.
Operating firms are to respect procection measures (availability of hand sanitizer, personal distancing, regular handwhashing includinga fter contact with bills, face masks).

* 21 March: Closure of most business places except for essential activities and activities linked to the fight against the pandemic.
column22:
* May 7: Approval has been granted by Parliament to borrow additional 1 000 million USD (3.7% of GDP) to finance a further package of economic measures including 600 million USD for a trust fund to foster job retention and economic recovery and 400 million USD to honor public expenditure commitments.

* March 26: Approval has been granted by Parliament to borrow 2 000 million USD (7.4% of GDP) to finance a package of measures to respond to the emergency. A specific Fund for Emergency, Recovery and Economic Reconstruction will organise the disbursement of these funds, of which 30% are to be implemented by local (municipal) government

* March 26: Suspension of the Fiscal Responsibility Law until the end of the State of Emergency.
column25:
* June 21: A new hospital wing was inaugurated in San Salvador with 400 intensive care units (adding to the around 150 operational intensive care beds). Two further stages are in construction, bringing the total to 1 000 ICUs and 1 000 acute care beds. Total expenditure in the new hospital is estimated to 75 million USD. Other major refurbishements in hospitals have been carried out worth around 35 million USD. The Ministry of Public Health has received until end of May 35.4 million USD in additional funding for purchasing inputs and equipment.

* May 7 : Face mask wearing is compulsory for those allowed to circulate.

* March 13: a State of Emergency has been declared. A broad package of measures have been announced. They include increasing resources for the health sector to facilitate the acquisition of medical equipment, the construction and improvement of hospital facilities, enlarging testing capacity and providing liquidity to the hospital network.

* A temporary hospital is being built in the facilities of the Conference Centre in San Salvador, with the aim to house 300 intensive care units and 1000 hospital beds (announced cost: 70 million USD).

* 800 hotel rooms have been habilitated as care facilities to confine COVID-19 cases not requiring hospital care.

* As of 8 April: 105 quarantine ("contention") centres have been habilitated to house persons undergoing compulsory quarantine (e.g.: those arriving from outside the country).
column28:
* 14 May: Distribution of food baskets begins, targeting 1.7 million households, objective raised to 3.4 million households (5 June), with estimated unit cost USD 56 each.

* 23 April 2020 (announcement): 50 million USD per month for the purchase of food baskets to be distributed to Salvadoran households

* USD 300 subsidy targeted to households not receiving a salary during confinement and consuming less than 250 kW of electricity per month (estimated to reach 1.5 million households at a cost of 450 million USD or 1.7% of GDP)

* USD 150 salary bonuses for all employees of the Ministry of Health and other public institutions involved in treatment and containment of COVID-19 (not included in cost estimate)
column31: * 3-month exemption from the special tourism tax (5%) for companies operating in the tourism industry.
column34:
* 7 May 2020: Subsidy for employees of MSMEs covering 50% of wages for up to two months (with a ceiling of 500 USD per worker and 45 000 USD per firm over two months) for firms with up to 100 employees and turnover up to 7 million USD (140 million USD)

* Financial relief to micro and SMEs with difficulties with their credit for a period of 3 months, including credit lines to cover salary payments.

* Investment funds worth 50 million USD to be targeted to MSMEs

* 80 million USD investment are to be channelled to the agriculture sector and toward food security
(assistance for credit difficulties not included in the estimated value)
column37:
* 14 May 2020: 2-month deferral of personal and income tax (up to 30 june). Penalties and interest for those having missed the previously stipulated deadline are waived. Large contributors can have payment extended over 4 instalments with a 30% down payment, medium-sized firms can have payment extended over 7 instalments with 10% down payment.

* 3-month extension for income tax payments for all individuals and firms with tax payments lower than USD 10 000, for those operating in the tourism sector with tax payments lower than US$ 25,000, and for firms in electricity generation, transmission and distribution, fixed and mobile telephony, cable television, and internet provision. Those eligible for deferral are also eligible to pay in eigth monthly instalments.
column40:
* 4 June 2020: The law governing the Development Bank of El Salvador (BANDESAL) is reformed, allowing BANDESAL to lend directly to firms, from 1 July. BANDESAL is expected to grow by 1600 million USD in capital and to offer 300 million USD in credit in addition to the planned credit for formal and informal firms affected by the pandemic.
*7 May 2020: Credit programme for formal firms (registered as employers with social security) offering credit at capped interest rates (3%) with 1 year grace period, managed by development bank BANDESAL (360 million USD)
*7 May 2020: Credit programme to finance working capital for informal firms with credit history or credit ratings (100 million USD)
column43: * Credit guarantees of 50% announced for a value of up to 100 million USD to be provided through BANDESAL (Announcement)
column46: Information not available
column47:
* Key measures include:
(i) lowering banks' reserve requirements by 25 percent of newly issued loans;
(ii) amending provisioning for NPLs through freezing credit ratings;
(iii) imposing a temporary moratorium on credit risk ratings;
(iv) temporarily relaxing lending conditions through a grace period for loan repayments
column48:
* The payment of rent, mortgages, consumer credit, credit card and vehicle credit instalments is deferred for 3 months for individuals affected by the pandemic.

* The payment of utility bills is deferred for 3 months

* Electronic purchases by individuals sourced in the United States up to 200 USD in value are exempt from import duty.
column51:
* The payment of rent, mortgages, consumer credit, credit card and vehicle credit instalments is deferred for 3 months for companies affected by the pandemic.

* The payment of utility bills is deferred for 3 months
column54:
* Reduction in gasoline prices

* Price controls (maximum prices) imposed on a number of basic foodstuffs and hygiene products.
column55:
* National bulletin published measures (https://imprentanacional.gob.sv/compilacion-de-decretos-de-emergencia-por-covid-19/)

* Official information site for COVID-19: (https://covid19.gob.sv/)

column12:
*April 22 : The 21-day lockdown announced on the 2nd of April, has now been further extended indefinitely. All but indispensable activities including security tax, food production and processing, manufacturing, construction, grocery stores, pharmacies and banks will be closed. All government institutions have stopped their routine services to focus on key security tasks.
* The government has asked locals to limit non-essential movement and avoid public transportation unless for emergencies and announced that stringent legal measures will be taken on all individuals and commercial enterprises that engage in hoarding and speculative price hikes.
column14:
*June 6: 259 Eritrean nationals who were stranded in the country have now been repatriated to their respective 16 countries of residence, with Charter Flights. The Foreign Ministry and other relevant bodies within GoE arranged the repatriations.

* The government discouraged nationals who live overseas from returning to Eritrea.

* Ban on local public transport, intercity buses, and private cars.

* March 25: All passenger flights in and out of country have now been suspended for 21 days and Asmara International Airport is now closed.
column16: *June 28: the Government announced the partial reopening of schools, with the aim to open all schools by end of July 2020. Schools will re-open during the summer (local rainy season) to complete curricula before the beginning of the new academic year.
column18: * The government has prohibited public gatherings, sports and cultural events that assemble a crowd of more than 10 people; closed cinemas and nightclubs; mandated social distancing in commercial units and centres.
column20: *All economic activities have been suspended, excep from major producive and service sectors including manufacturing,food processing construction and trucking sectors. Food production services, grocery shops, pharmacieis and banks continue to operate
column22: Information not available
column25:
* June 23: Due to rise in awareness around vaccinations and expansion of health insitutions, the regular vaccination programmes have increase and reached over 95% and the rates of communicable diseases has declined over the past 5 months. Health facilities in the region are also better equipped with refrigerators, increasing their storage capacities.
*June 3: the extensive random testing pilot launched in Asmara has now been completed. The tests covered 4659 households, and one patient was diagnosed positive. The next round of testing will take place in border towns and villages surrounding Asmara, with plans to expand the tests to wider regions.
*May 24: The President of Eritrea addressed the country's 29th independence day celebrations, and laid out a road map of the government's approach in tackling the spread of COVID-19:

* Strengthening long term capacities and strategies for prevention of the virus spread;

* To develop a mechanism for testing that initially starts with a sample and base-line data but whose scope will ultimately be extended to cover all citizens inside the country as well as abroad and that will include periodic monitoring;

* Enforcing strict modalities of control for the movement of people
- normative or irregular
- to and from the country;

* To develop effective and professional human capital above and beyond other factors;

* To upgrade our capabilities in the manufacturing of drugs. medical equipment and facilities;

* To foster and enhance technical cooperation with various foreign institutions and experts.
*May 17: the government launched the first phase of random extensive testing, started from several parts of the capital Asmara. The tests will be carried out in towns and villages surrounding Asmara and to all front-line health workers in the MoH and other relevant institutions.
column28:
*Date TBC: landlords agreed to waive rents for tenants
*Date TBC: The government banned lay offs and postponned payments of utility bills
column31: Information not available
column34: Information not available
column37: Information not available
column40: Information not available
column43: Information not available
column46: Information not available
column47: Information not available
column54: Information not available

column12:
State of emergency declared from 13 March to 17 May 2020 (extended from 1 May on 24 April).

From 25 March to 18 June, a 2+2 rule was implemented. People were only allowed to move alone or in pairs in public and should keep at least 2 meters distance to other people. From 19 June, replaced with a requirement for people to disperse and keep a safe distance.

For two municipalities Saaremaa and Muhumaa (islands), lockdown and closures of shops were introduced from 28 March to 27 April.

Exit strategy from confinement measures approved on 27 April. Easing of restrictions started from 2 May.
column14:
Border controls introduced from 17 March. Restrictions on border crossings with Finland, Latvia and Lithuania lifted from 14 May. People entering from abroad are recommended to quarantine for two weeks (does not apply to commuters).

Restrictions on movement imposed on the islands of Hiiumaa, Saaremaa, Muhumaa, Vormsi, Kihnu and Ruhnu from 14 March to 7 May.
column16:
All schools, universities and educational institutions required to close and switch to remote teaching from 16 March to 14 May. Re-opening from 15 May, activities only allowed for groups of up to 10 people.

Closure of childcare facilities decided by local governments.
column18:
All public gatherings prohibited from 13 March. From 1 June, public meetings of maximum 50 people allowed indoors and 100 outdoors (2+2 rule still in place).

Cultural activities (concerts, museums etc.) and sport competitions prohibited from 13 March to 10 May.

Visiting ban imposed for hospitals, welfare institutions and detention facilities from 13 March. From 1 June, allowed with restrictions.
column20:
All nightclubs and cinemas forced to close from 13 March. Gradual re-opening with restrictions from 1 June.

All sports clubs, gyms and children´s play rooms closed from 14 March to 31 May. Re-opening with restrictions.

All shopping centres was forced to close from 25 March to 10 May, except for stores providing basic necessities (groceries, pharmacies, banks etc.). Restaurants and bars had to close at 10 PM until 1 June.

Alcohol sale prohibited in bars, restaurants and hotels from 10 PM to 10 AM (from 17 March to 31 May). This was an extension of a similar prohibition permanently in place for shops. The purpose was to limit alcohol abuse, which could overburden health system and police during the state of emergency.
column22:
An economic package containing state guarantees, loans, income support and tax measures was presented on 19 March.

Additional resources to be allocated to the health sector announced on 25 March.

Local governments will receive around EUR 100 million in additional support for investment and an additional EUR 30 million to cover additional costs related to the coronavirus (announced 2 April).

Reconstruction of apartment buildings and private houses will be supported by EUR 100 million through the state-owned financial institution KredEx (announced 2 April).

A supplementary budget was adopted on 2 April, adding additional economic measures and bringing total initiatives related to the crisis to EUR 1.15 billion (4.1% of GDP).
column25:
The government is allocating the health system at least EUR 200 million over three months to cover the extraordinary costs of coronavirus (announced 25 March). Additional EUR 20 million has been earmarked for purchase of personal protective equipment, respirators and testing capabilities.

An increase in shifts, the opening of separate COVID-19 wards, and extraordinary salary increases for frontline staff in health care institutions are foreseen.
column28:
Job retention scheme introduced, available for two months between March and May, administered through the Unemployment Insurance Fund (announced 19 March). Extended and revised to June on 21 May. Qualifying employers will receive wage subsidies covering 70% of employees' average salary over the last 12 months, with a maximum of EUR 1 000 per month. Available for companies with at least 30% decline in turnover, who does not have work for 30% of its employees and who have reduced employees' salaries by at least 30% (or to the minimum wage). Employees will receive the 70% reimbursement or max EUR 1 000 per month, plus at least EUR 150 paid by the employer. For June, a 50% decline in turnover is required and reimbursement in reduced to 50% with a maximum of EUR 800 per month.
All taxes and allowances to be paid by the Unemployment Insurance Fund and the employer. Expected fiscal costs EUR 250 million + EUR 36 million for June.

Paid sick leave (announced 19 March). The government will ensure sick pay to the employee for the first three days of sick leave for all sick leave certificates from March to May (normally unpaid). Expected fiscal costs EUR 7 million.

Support to self-employed (announced 19 March). The government will pay the advance payment of social tax for self-employed persons for the first quarter of 2020. Estimated fiscal costs EUR 3.3 million.
column31:
Suspension of pension contributions (announced 19 March). The government's payments to the second pillar pension system have been temporarily suspended until September 2021. This will increase revenue by the employers' 4% contributions that are part of the social tax. Exceptions apply for people born from 1942 to 1960, who will continue to receive regular contributions until Nov 2020. From Oct 2020, individuals are free to decide if they will continue to contribute or not (2% of gross remuneration). For those continuing contributions, the government will compensate for reduction and increase contribution to 6% from 2023. Estimated to improve fiscal revenue by EUR 142 million in 2020.

Interest on corporate tax debt reduced (announced 19 March). Interest on corporate tax debt is suspended during the state of emergency (March-April), and afterwards reduced from 0.06% to 0.03% per day. Estimated fiscal costs EUR 7 million.

Excise duty rate reductions (announced 2 April). From 1 May to 30 April 2022, excise duty rates on diesel, natural gas and electricity will be lowered. Estimated fiscal costs EUR 77 million.
column34: Compensation to organisers of cancelled events (announced 19 March). The government will reimburse up to EUR 3 million of the direct costs of cultural and sporting events scheduled between March and April. Estimated costs EUR 25 million.
column37: Deferral of corporate income tax payments without penalty for a longer period (announced 19 March).
column40:
The state-owned financial institution KredEx will provide loans to businesses affected by the covid-19 crisis (announced 19 March, revised 18 June):

- Operating loans to overcome liquidity problems, including payment of bank loans, are provided (EUR 500 million). The maximum loan amount is EUR 5 million per company with 4% interest per annum.

- Investment loans to take advantage of the new business opportunities created by the spread of coronavirus, and other new business opportunities are made available (EUR 50 million). The maximum loan amount is EUR 5 million per company with 4% interest per annum.
Expected losses included in budget amounts to around EUR 55 million.

The Rural Development Foundation will provide additional financial measures for rural and agricultural businesses (announced 19 March):

- loan guarantees (EUR 50 million)

- operating loans (EUR 100 million)

- land capital (EUR 50 million).
Expected losses included in budget amounts to around EUR 17 million.
column43: The government will provide loan guarantees for bank loans already issued in order to allow for repayment schedule adjustments (announced 19 March). The maximum guarantee amount is EUR 5 million per company and EUR 1 000 million loan guarantees in total. Expected losses of around EUR 100 million included in budget.
column46: The Nordic Investment Bank (NIB) and the Estonian state signed a loan agreement of EUR 750 million to finance the economic measures to mitigate the effects of the coronavirus on 27 March. The repayment deadline for the loan is in the year 2035.
column47: The central bank lowered the systemic risk buffer requirement applicable for all commercial banks from 1% to 0% from 1 May (announced 25 March). This will free up capital of EUR 110 million.
column54: Information not available

column12:
*June 12: The Tigray Regional state has rejected the House of Federations (HoF) decision "to extend the regional and federal parliament mandates until the COVID-19 is declared not a threat to public health". The regional council announced that it will go ahead with the election plans, which will be held before the end of Ethiopian year (September 11, 2020). Further, the Council also extended the regional State of Emergency by two and half months, despite the COVID-19 five-month state of emergency order in place at the federal level.
*June 8: Ethiopian PM addressed the parliament and touched on various issues related to COVID-19 and supported the decision not to halt EA flights to China and other countries. He also defended the Government's decision not to enforce strict lockdowns, and claimed measures to contain the virus should be based on local realities.
*April 24: The northern (Tigray) region of Ethiopia has eased the State of Emergency and lockdown measures. Under the new conditions civil servants will be returning to work and movements within the region will be allowed. Other activities will be allowed under strict social distancing measures (i.e only take-away services will be allowed for restaurants and bars).
*The region also implemented a 14 day mandatory quarantine for any passengers arriving via the regional airpot and land.
column14:
*July 13: Ethiopian Airlines, resumed flights to 40 destinations, after suspending 80 flight routes at the beginning of the lockdown measures.
*June 19: Ethiopia started to relax some of its preventative measures for COVID-19, the quarantine period for travellers from abroad has been shortened from 14 to 7 days. Travellers must have certificates for COVID-19 negative, which must be issued 72 hours before their arrival to Ethiopia. Those without certificates will be put in mandatory quarantine of 7 days, and additional 7 days of isolation at home. Additionally, families are now allowed to hold funerals for relatives with a limit of maximum 15 persons.
*March 23: The authorities have closed borders.
column16: *March 16: Schools have been shut down.
column18:
*August 27: Ethiopia COVID-19 State of Emergency Inquiry Board has recommended to release prisoners who qualify for pardon, in order to reduce the spread of the virus. Following the political unrests in June 2020, over 9000 persons were detained, and public spaces such as schools, town halls and warehouses were converted into detention facilities, raising concerns of increased spread of the pandemic. The request has been submitted to the executive bodies of the House of the Peoples' representatives.


*June 29: Ethiopia's Government COVID-19 statistics updates have been interrupted due to the internet blackout in the country. The last updates from national sources such as Ethiopia's Health Ministry and the Public Health Institute, took place on June 29. The WHO Regional Office for Africa continues to report figures on its social media account, which the Organisation collects from verified sources.
*June 10: General elections meant to reconstitute a new parliament and originally to take place on August 29 have been postponed until international health institutions have deemed the threat from coronavirus to be over. By the same token, Ethiopia's upper parliamentary chamber, the House of Federation (HoF), has approved an extension to the mandate of Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed's parliament as well as regional parliaments and councils.
*May 7: The regional government of Tigray region (TPLF) vows to go ahead with elections despite the national elections being postponed from August 2020.
*Public gatherings are prohibited.
*April 1: The National Electoral Board postponed the parliamentary elections of 29 August 2020.
*Some schools
- below seventh grade
- have started broadcasting teaching via radio.
column20: *March 23: The authorities have shut down nightclubs and entertainment outlets.
column22:
*June 11: Finance ministers of East Africa are expected to present their up to date budget for the new financial year starting from July the 1. The reading of the regional budget is normally a joint exercise among member countries. It is expected that COVID-19 has put extra pressure on government budgets, due to reduction in fiscal revenues and deterioration of economic outlook. East African fiscal finances are expected to have bigger deficits than what was expected few months ago and public debt is expected to increase at faster rate. However, authorities are expected to carefully monitor their budgets to avoid deficit, and allocate fiscal resources where necessary, including health care, and social support sectors.
*May 29: A supplementary budget of USD 1.43 billion has been approved by the parliament, for the fiscal year 2019/20. The budget aims to support humanitarian and medical assistance and to reduce the economic ramification of Covid19, for the estimated 30 million people who are considered to be in need of government assistance. The budget will be funded by a mix of loans from internal and external sources.
*March 23: the Prime Minister announced the aid package announced earlier on would be increased to Br 5 billion (US$154 million or 0.15 percent of GDP) but details on the precise modalities of the assistance are not yet available. *Early March: Ethiopia initially announced a Br 300 million package to bolster healthcare spending.
*April 3: The GOE announced the Multi-Sectoral Preparedness and Response Plan, to be implemented over 3 months. The USD1.64 billion plan aims to support various economic sectors and population groups including: USD 635M for distribution of food to vulnerable population groups who are not covered by the national social protection programme; USD 430M to be allocated on health care response under assumed worst case scenario COVID-19 cases of over 100 000 cases of COVID 19, especially in urban areas; USD282M for provision of emergency shelter and non-food items; and USD 293M will be allocated to agriculture, nutrition , and protection of vulnerable groups such as refugees and site management support.
column25:
*August 2: Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed announced the launch of the massive COVID-19 Prevention and Testing Campaign Ethiopia that will begin on 3 August. According to the campaign programme, the country will test 200,000 people for the virus in the next two weeks. Depending on the campaign's results, authorities will decide on whether to resume in-person schooling.
*May 27: A field hospital is being constructed on the outskirt of Addis Ababa and is expected to start operating in the next 10 days. The field hospital will be used as training centre for emergency medical response teams.
*April 25: Ethiopia launched a door-to-door testing across the country, and expanded its daily testing capacity to 4000 corona virus samples per day, with 20 labs operating nationwide. Door-to-door testing started in Addis Ababa on 13 April.
*April 13: Launch of the door-to-door temperature screening in 117 districts of the capital city. Addis Ababa city also launched its school feed programme with 1200 food banks (30,000 youth volunteers will be mobilised to deliver this programme).
column28: *April 30: The government is actively considering the expansion of the urban Protection Safety Net Programme to 16 additional cities over the next two months. This will be done in cooperation with the World Bank and is estimated to cost USD 134 million.                                                                                                                 *April 8: Ethiopian government prohibits lay-offs of workers under the State of Emergency

column37:
*April 30: The Council of Ministries approved new economic measures to support firms. The measures include tax fogiveness for firms with tax debt prio to 2014/15; tax amnesty on interest and penalties for taxes prior 2015/2016-2018/2019; and relief from personal income tax for 4 months, for firms who have stopped operating due to Covid
- 19 but continue to pay their employees' salaries.

column14: On March 17, EU Member States agreed to restrict non-essential travel to the European Union for an initial period of 30 days. The Commission subsequently recommended to extend restrictions three times, until 30 June. Exceptions mainly cover EU and British citizens, long-time residents, cross-border commuters, health care workers and workers delivering goods. Movement of goods is not to be affected. On June 11, the Commission proposed a coordinated lifting of restrictions from 1 July, starting with a common list of third countries selected together by Member States.  For the remaining third countries, the Commission proposed to enlarge the categories of permitted travellers to include, for instance, international students. On 30 June, the Council of the EU recommended that, as from 1 July, member states start lifting restrictions for residents of a list of third countries, with the list to be regularly reviewed.
column16: Information not available
column18: Information not available
column20: Information not available
column22:
* The EUR 37 billion Coronavirus Response Investment Initiative (CRII; proposed on 13 March, in force since 1 April) will accelerate the implementation of cohesion policy (total country allocations for the 2014-2020 period remain unchanged). Member States will not have to pay back to the EU budget unspent pre-financing received from structural funds (about EUR 8 billion). Instead, they will be able to use it as national co-financing for the next tranches of their structural fund allocations (about EUR 29 billion). Investment for fostering the crisis response capacities in public health services and some financing of working capital in SMEs will become eligible.

* The Coronavirus Response Investment Initiative Plus (CRII+), proposed on 2 April and in force since 24 April, complements the CRII by further enhancing flexibility in the use of cohesion funds. This enhanced flexibility is inter alia provided through transfer possibilities across the three cohesion policy funds (the European Regional Development Fund, European Social Fund and Cohesion Fund), transfers between the different categories of regions (e.g. less vs more developed), flexibility regarding thematic concentration, the possibility for a 100% EU co-financing rate for the accounting year 2020-2021, and simplified procedural steps.

* Maximum flexibility will be deployed in the application of the Stability and Growth Pact by activating for the first time (on 23 March) the general escape clause in case of a severe economic downturn for the euro area or EU as a whole.

* The scope of the EU Solidarity Fund has been extended to cover major public health emergencies and possible advance payments from this Fund have been increased (proposal on 13 March, in force since 1 April). Up to EUR 800 million is available in 2020.

* At the request of Member States, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund could be mobilised to support dismissed workers and those self-employed (up to EUR 179 million available in 2020)

* EUR 1 billion has been provided as a guarantee to the European Investment Fund (part of the EIB group) to support SME financing (announced on 13 March, implemented on 6 April).

* On 9 April, EU finance ministers decided to establish Pandemic Crisis Support credit lines within the framework of the European Stability Mechanism (ESM). Access granted will be 2% of the respective country's GDP as of end-2019, as a benchmark (about €240 billion in total). The credit line will be available until the COVID 19 crisis is over. The only requirement to access the credit line is that euro area Member States requesting support would commit to use this credit line to finance direct and indirect healthcare, cure and prevention related costs due to the COVID 19 crisis. On 8 May, the Eurogroup agreed on further details: requests for Pandemic Crisis Support may be made until end-2022 (with the possibility to adjust this deadline) and the ensuing loans to countries will have a maximum average maturity of 10 years and favourable pricing modalities. On May 15, the Board of Governors of the ESM approved the establishment of Pandemic Crisis Support.


* The Commission intends to allow State aid for struggling businesses. In particular, the Commission considers that the impact of the COVID-19 outbreak is causing a serious disturbance to the entire EU economy (Article 107(3)(b) of the Treaty). In this context, the Commission adopted on 19 March a Temporary Framework to enable Member States to use the full flexibility foreseen under State aid rules. This Framework was extended on 3 April, 8 May and 29 June to cover additional types of aid. It will be in place until end-2020 (for recapitalisation measures, until end of June 2021).

* The European Investment Bank (EIB) Group announced on 16 March a plan (currently being deployed) to mobilize up to EUR 40 billion of financing to alleviate liquidity and working capital constraints for SMEs and mid-caps. This comprises dedicated guarantee schemes to banks based on existing programmes, dedicated liquidity lines to banks, and dedicated asset-backed securities (ABS) purchasing programmes to allow banks to transfer risk on portfolios of SME loans.

* In addition to the above plan, EU finance ministers endorsed on 9 April an EIB proposal to create a EUR 25 billion guarantee fund, which will support up to EUR 200 billion of financing for companies (especially SMEs) throughout the EU. The scheme will be implemented by the EIB Group, in close partnership with national promotional banks and other financial intermediaries. By guaranteeing parts of loan portfolios, operations under the guarantee fund will free up capital for the financial intermediaries involved to make further financing available for SMEs and mid-caps. On 26 May, the Board of Directors of the EIB agreed on the structure and business model of this new
Pan-European Guarantee Fund. The fund will initially approve operations until end-2021 (a deadline which can be extended), and at least 65% of the financing will go to SMEs.

* The Commission presented on 2 April a proposal for a new European instrument for temporary Support to mitigate Unemployment Risks in an Emergency (SURE). SURE support will take the form of loans granted on favourable terms from the EU to Member States, to help them cover the costs directly related to the creation or extension of national short-time work schemes, and other similar measures for the self-employed, in the context of the current crisis. EUR 100 billion (0.7% of 2019 EU27 GDP) will be available for this instrument (with no pre-allocated national envelopes), backed by EUR 25 billion of guarantees committed by Member States to the EU budget. SURE will have a temporary nature: its duration and scope are limited to tackling the consequences of the coronavirus pandemic. An instrument along these lines was endorsed by EU finance ministers on 9 April. On May 20, a Regulation establishing SURE entered into force. Countries will be able to use loans also in support of some health-related measures, esp. in the workplace. SURE will become available once all Member States have provided the required guarantees proportionally to gross national income, and will remain available until end-2022 (with the possibility to adjust this deadline).

* On 27 May the European Commission presented its proposal of a recovery plan of EUR 750 billion (about 5.5% of EU27 2019 GDP). This plan, named Next Generation EU, is embedded within the 2021-27 EU budget, strengthening some of the previously proposed budget programmes and creating new instruments. It envisages 3 strands of support over the next 4 years (2021-2024):
1. Support to Member States with investments and reforms

- A new Recovery and Resilience Facility to help finance investment and reforms in line with the priorities of the European Semester (EUR 560 billion, of which EUR 310 billion in grants and EUR 250 billion in loans)

- A new REACT-EU initiative, providing a top-up to current cohesion policy programmes, to be spent until 2022 (EUR 50 billion)

- A reinforcement of the Just Transition Fund, which will support the transition to climate neutrality (EUR 30 billion)

- A reinforcement of the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EUR 15 billion)
2. Kick-starting the EU economy by incentivising private investments

- A new Solvency Support Instrument, aiming to mobilise private resources to support viable firms in the sectors, regions and countries most affected (EUR 26 billion of guarantees)

- A reinforcement of InvestEU, the main EU investment programme, including a new Strategic Investment Facility to generate investments in boosting the resilience of strategic sectors and key value chains in the internal market (EUR 30.3 billion of guarantees)
3. Addressing the lessons of the crisis

- New or reinforced programmes in the areas of health, R&D, civil protection and external action, including humanitarian aid (EUR 38.7 billion)
Overall, the plan envisages EUR 250 billion of loans, about EUR 50 billion of guarantees and almost EUR 450 billion of grants, with a focus on the sectors and regions most severely affected by the pandemic. The plan will be financed through borrowing by the Commission on financial markets, which entails temporarily increasing the Own Resources ceiling (the maximum amount of funds that the EU can request from Member States to cover its financial obligations) by 0.6% of EU gross national income. However, this acts like a guarantee, and should not entail actual additional disbursements by Member States over 2021-27 (in this period, even the borrowing costs for the grant component of the Plan will be paid by the EU budget). Repayment will take place through future EU budgets between 2028 and 2058. This will entail increased contributions by Member States and/or new own resources, which could be related to carbon emissions or include a digital tax. The Commission will present detailed proposals of additional own resources at a later stage.
On 21 July, the European Council reached an agreement on a modified version of the plan. The amounts for the different strands of support have become:

- Recovery and Resilience Facility: EUR 672.5 billion, of which EUR 312.5 billion in grants and EUR 360 billion in loans

- REACT-EU: EUR 47.5 billion

- Just Transition Fund: EUR 10 billion

- European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development: EUR 7.5 billion

- Solvency Support Instrument: dropped

- InvestEU: EUR 5.6 billion

- R&D and civil protection programmes: EUR 6.9 billion
While preserving the EUR 750 million total, grants have been reduced from about EUR 450 billion to about EUR 385 billion, and more than half of this reduction has fallen on programmes directly managed by the Commission and for which there are no national envelopes (such as Horizon Europe, an R&D programme). The guarantees component has been very strongly downsized, and the loans component has increased.
As regards the Recovery and Resilience Facility, 70% of the grants will be committed in 2021 and 2022 according to the cross-country allocation key proposed by the Commission (based on population, GDP per capita and unemployment), and the remaining 30% in 2023 according to a somewhat modified key (replacing the 2015-2019 unemployment criterion by the GDP fall in 2020 and the cumulative GDP fall over 2020-21). Preliminary estimates point to a relatively small impact of this modification, with about half of the grants still expected to go to southern European countries (Greece, Italy, Portugal and Spain). As for oversight of the national use of funds under the Recovery and Resilience Facility, the July agreement gives a role to the Economic and Financial Committee (a preparatory body of the Council of the EU) and, in some cases, to the European Council itself.
column25:
* The Commission has been pursuing joint public procurements of protective equipment, which reinforces member states' negotiating position towards the industry.

* On 19 March, the Commission decided to create a European civil protection stockpile of medical equipment such as ventilators and protective masks. Member states wishing to host the stockpile will procure the equipment, financed with a 90% Commission grant. The initial EU budget of the stockpile was EUR 50 million, subsequently increased to EUR 80 million. Distribution of the equipment will be managed at EU level.

* On 2 April, the Commission presented a legislative proposal (in force since 15 April) to activate and extend the scope of the Emergency Support Instrument, with EUR 3 billion from the EU budget to directly purchase or procure emergency support on behalf of Member States, financially support and co-ordinate pressing needs such as the transportation of medical equipment and of patients in cross-border regions, and support the construction of mobile field hospitals.
