column46:
* The ECB took several measures to support bank lending and liquidity throughout the euro area:
o 12 March: lowering the interest rate applied in targeted longer-term refinancing operations (TLTRO III) during the period from June 2020 to June 2021 (25 basis points below the average rate applied in the Eurosystem's main refinancing operations).
o 12 March: conducting additional longer-term refinancing operations (LTROs) temporarily (with an interest rate equal to the average rate on the deposit facility, -0.50% currently).
o 18 March, further detailed on 7 April: easing collateral standards to give easier access to ECB liquidity, by adjusting the main risk parameters of the collateral framework. These measures, due to remain in place until September 2021, include expanding the use of credit claims as collateral, reducing collateral valuation haircuts and taking a number of other temporary steps, such as a waiver to accept Greek sovereign debt instruments as collateral.
o 22 April: adopting temporary measures, due to remain in place until September 2021, to mitigate the effect on collateral availability of possible rating downgrades. More specifically, the ECB will grandfather the eligibility of marketable assets and the issuers of such assets that fulfilled minimum credit quality requirements on 7 April 2020 in the event of downgrades, as long as the ratings remain at or above BB.
o 30 April: reducing further the interest rate applied in targeted longer-term refinancing operations (TLTRO III) until June 2021, to 50 basis points below the average rate on the main refinancing operations.
o 30 April: conducting a new series of non-targeted pandemic emergency longer-term refinancing operations (PELTROs). These will consist of seven additional refinancing operations commencing in May 2020 and maturing in a staggered sequence between July and September 2021. They will be carried out as fixed rate tender procedures with full allotment, with an interest rate that is 25 basis points below the average rate on the main refinancing operations.

* The ECB also took measures to reinforce the asset purchase programme (APP):
o 12 March: adding a temporary envelope of additional net asset purchases of €120 billion until the end of the year.
o 18 March: furthermore, launching a new temporary asset purchase programme of private and public sector securities (Pandemic Emergency Purchase Programme, PEPP) with an overall envelope of EUR 750 billion until the end of 2020. Together, both envelopes amount to 7.3% of euro area GDP. Some self-imposed purchase limits will not apply to the PEPP.
o 18 March: expanding the range of eligible assets under the corporate sector purchase programme (CSPP) to non-financial commercial paper.
o 4 June: increasing the envelope for the Pandemic Emergency Purchase Programme (PEPP) by EUR 600 billion to a total of EUR 1350 billion, and extending the horizon for net purchases under the PEPP to at least the end of June 2021. Furthermore, the maturing principal payments from PEPP purchases will be reinvested until at least the end of 2022.
column47:
* Major banks (i.e. those directly supervised by the ECB) will be allowed to operate temporarily below the level of capital defined by the Pillar 2 Guidance (P2G), the capital conservation buffer (CCB) and the liquidity coverage ratio (LCR). The ECB considers that these temporary measures will be enhanced by the appropriate relaxation of the countercyclical capital buffer (CCyB) by the national macroprudential authorities (12 March). In addition, the ECB has introduced supervisory flexibility regarding the treatment of non-performing loans (NPLs), in particular to allow banks to fully benefit from public guarantees and moratoriums. Flexibility will also extend to banks' implementation of NPL reduction strategies (20 March). Furthermore, the ECB has asked banks not to pay dividends until at least 1 October 2020 (27 March), and announced a temporary reduction in capital requirements for market risk (16 April). On 28 July, the ECB extended its recommendation to banks not to pay dividends and not to buy back shares until 1 January 2021 and asked them to be extremely moderate with regard to variable remuneration. The ECB also clarified that it will give enough time for banks to replenish their capital and liquidity buffers, with the exact timeline to be decided following the 2021 EU-wide stress test and on a case-by-case basis.

* On 28 April, the European Commission proposed a number of changes to the Capital Requirements Regulation (Regulation (EU) 575/2013) to provide temporary capital relief to banks. Changes, in force since 27 June, include inter alia extending by 2 years the current transitional arrangements for mitigating the impact of IFRS 9 provisions on regulatory capital, a later date of application of the leverage ratio buffer for global systemically important institutions, a more favourable treatment of publicly guaranteed loans under the NPL prudential backstop (the minimum loss coverage requirement for non-performing loans), and advancing the date of application of capital reduction factors in respect of certain loans to SMEs or in support of infrastructure investments.

* On 24 July, the European Commission adopted a Capital Markets Recovery Package, proposing targeted changes to capital market rules (Prospectus Regulation, MiFID II and securitisation rules). Amendments to the Prospectus Regulation envisage the temporary creation of new type of short-form prospectus (the “EU Recovery Prospectus”), applicable under certain conditions, to make it easier for issuers to quickly raise capital. Amendments to the Markets in Financial Instruments Directive (MiFID II) include inter alia steps to reduce administrative burdens for experienced investors in their business-to-business relationships. Changes to securitisation rules (Securitisation Regulation, Capital Requirements Regulation) aim to facilitate the use of securitisation to support the recovery by enabling banks to expand their lending. The Commission proposes to create a specific framework for simple, transparent and standardised on-balance-sheet securitisation that would benefit from a preferential prudential treatment and to facilitate the securitisation of non-performing exposures.
column54: Information not available

column12: The Finnish government declared a state of emergency on 16 March and instructed persons aged over 70 to refrain from contact with other persons to the extent possible. Visits to nursing home were banned. On 27 March, the Uusimaa region was quarantined from the rest of the country for three weeks, with exceptions for essential commuting and other work-related travel. On 15 April, the government lifted the quarantine in the Uusimaa region. The government started phasing out the restrictions gradually on 1 June. On 15 June, the state of emergency was lifted. On 23 June, the recommendation for persons aged over 70 was lifted.
column14: From 19 March, passenger traffic has been restricted at the Finnish external borders, but Finnish citizens are allowed to return home. Those returning should undertake a mandatory two-week quarantine. From 27 March, all individuals are screened at airport arrivals and those experiencing symptoms are tested. On 27 March, travel restrictions to and from the Uusimaa region was imposed. On 15 April, the travel ban in and out of the Uusimaa region was lifted. On 14 May, the statutory restrictions on border traffic is lifted in cross-border traffic across the Schengen internal borders, allowing employment or commission-related commuting and other essential traffic. On 15 June, the border was opend to Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Denmark, Norway and Iceland, waiving a mandatory 14-day quarantine upon arrival from these countries.On 13 July, the government adopted the decision to remove travel restrictions for countries where fewer than eight coronavirus cases have been diagnosed per 100,000 persons within the last 14 days, allowing quarantine-free travels between17 European countries and essential travels between 11 non-European countries .On 23 July,  travel restrictions to Austria, Slovenia and Switzerland as well as Algeria and Australia were reinstated due to surge in cases in these countries, while non-essential travels to 9 non-European countries including China, Japan and South Korea were allowed without quarantine.
column16: On 18 March, schools and universities were shut down. This did not apply to nurseries and day-care centres, but parents were advised to keep their children at home. On 14 May, primary and lower secondary schools reopened. General upper secondary schools, vocational schools, higher education institutions and liberal education were also allowed to start providing contact teaching on that date, although the government recommends that they continue distance teaching until the end of the semester.
column18: On 19 March, some public services (e.g. museums) were closed. On 16 March, public gatherings of more than 10 people were banned.  Visiting elderly homes as well as care homes was forbidden. On 1 June, public events and public meetings organised indoors and outdoors with a maximum of 50 persons were allowed. Larger private events, such as private parties or private meetings are allowed but advised against by the government. Public events and public meetings of more than 50 and a maximum of 500 persons in indoor and enclosed outdoor spaces can be organised on the condition that the organisers are able to control the number of attendees and limit close contact between them. On 1 Aug, gatherings over 500 people were permitted if they comply with the guidelines of the Finnish Institute for Health and Welfare and the Ministry of Education and Culture.
column20: On 16 March, businesses aside essential services, such as grocery stores and pharmacies were advised by the government to close.  On 4 April, cafés and restaurants were shut down except for takeaway services until 31 May 2020. On 1 June, restaurants and cafes throughout the country reopened to customers with certain restrictions. Non-essential businesses were no longer advised to close but teleworking was still encouraged. On 1 August the recommendation for teleworking was lifted.
column22:
The government announced fiscal measures totalling around EUR 24.5 billion (10% of GDP), EUR 9.2 billion of which (4% of GDP) will increase the budget deficit, mostly in 2020. Key spending areas were: (1) strengthening the capacity of the health sector and authorities to respond better to the COVID-19 crisis; (2) supporting household income, for instance through temporary extension of the coverage of unemployment benefits, a wider application of temporary layoff scheme, as well as direct income supports to parents of small children on unpaid leave; (3) supporting firms, including large-scale credit guarantee, business subsidies and compensation of business costs targeted to firms in sectors hit hardest by the COVID crisis, namely the hospitality sector; (4) fiscal stimulus for the economic recovery including investment in greener transportation and housing infrastructure. Revenue-side measures included deferral of corporate income taxes and VAT, as well as temporary reduction of pension contributions.
The government announced its first fiscal package amounting to about EUR 15 billion (largely credit guarantee) on 20 March, and followed up with several supplementary budgets to finance new support measures. The fourth supplementary budget submitted on 2 June amounted to EUR 5.5 billion and included a wide range of spending to boost aggregate demand and potential economic growth.
column25:
On 20 March, the government allocated in its supplementary budget about EUR 50 million to finance additional expenses by health authorities to counter the coronavirus. A raft of emergency measures was adopted to safeguard medicines and medical supplies. The sale of medical supplies and pharmaceuticals used in the public health-care system was restricted and municipalities were temporarily waived the obligation to provide timely non-emergency care. Local governments have increased health spending, at least 25% of which to be covered by the central government.
On 8 April, the government allocated in its second supplementary budget EUR 600 million for the purchase of protective and other equipment and medicines through the National Emergency Supply Agency.
column28:
The government annonced on 20 March that it will temporarily extend the right to unemployment allowance to entrepreneurs and self-employed, irrespective of type of business. Furthermore, the five days waiting period for the earning-related and basic unemployment benefits as well as the labour market subsidy is temporarily removed. In order to preserve jobs, measures to facilitate temporary layoff are put in place by amending the Employment Contract Acts. The notice period for layoffs is shortened to five days and so is the duration of co-operation negotiations. Employees on a fixed-term contract may be laid off as well. At the same time, the re-employment obligation foremployees dismissed for financial or production-related reasons between 1 April and 30 June is extended to a period of nine months.
On 8 April, the government allocated EUR 1.4 billion in its second supplementary budget to finance the additional expenditure associated with the above decisions on unemployment benefits. It also allocated EUR 94 million in its second supplementary budget to a temporary income support of EUR 723 monthly for parents absent from work with no pay while caring children under 10 at home following the recommendations or restrictions by the government. The support is also available to persons arriving in Finland from abroad who have been placed in quarantine-like conditions and are therefore away from work without pay.
On 2 June, the government announced that the extension of the right to unemployment benefits is to be continued until the end of 2020.
column31: On 20 March, it was announced that pension contribution in the private sector will be reduced temporarily by 2.6% (between 1 June and 31 December 2020). The reduction will be financed by the EMU buffer fund of the employment pension scheme. The buffer fund will be augmented later by raising the pension contributions for the period 2022-2025.
column34:
On 20 March, the government announced that EUR 200 million business supports are to be disbursed by Business Finland and Centers for Economic Development, Transport and the Environment. An addtional fund of EUR 0.5 million was allocated to the Talousapu financial assistance service offering business advisory services to entrepreneurs.
On 26 March, the government announced that EUR 1 billion business subsidies targeted to SMEs and microenterprises are to be disbursed by Business Finland and Centers for Economic Development, Transport and the Environment.
On 6 May, the government announced a support scheme for restaurants and cafés that compensates up to 15% of decrease in sales and provides a subsidy of EUR 1 000 per re-hiring of each laid off employee with a limit of 800 employees.
On 14 May, the government announced a new form of support that covers the business costs up to EUR 500 000 for two months, for firms that (1) belong to sectors where turnover in April 2020 has decreased by at least 10% compared to March-June 2019, and (2) experienced more than 30% decrease in turnover during April and May 2020 compared to March-June 2019.
column37:
Firms in financial difficulties can request a payment arrangement for their corporate income tax that extends payment deadline up to 24 months. They can also request changes in prepayments of their corporate income tax without interim financial statements or other written clarifications. Deadlines for corporate income tax filing can also be extended upon request witha justified reason, such as illness. The interest rate for late payment for taxes due from 1 March 2020 is reduced from 7% to to 4%. Penalties for late filing of value added tax (VAT) returns may be waived if a justified reason can be demonstrated, such as illness. Employers and self-employed individuals can extend, upon request, the payment period for pension contributions between 20 March 2020 and 30 June 2020 by an additional 3 months without incurring penalty interests.
On 8 April, the government reckoned in its second supplementary budget that these tax measures would results in a deferral of EUR 766 million corporate income tax revenue and EUR 571 million VAT revenue to 2021.
column40:
On 8 April, the government allocated EUR 150 million in its second supplementary budget for Tesi (Finnish Industry Investment Ltd) to set up a new stabilisation programme, which invests in firms facing sudden and temporary liquidity difficulties.
On 8 May, the government allocated EUR 700 million in its third supplementary budget for share acquisitions in state ownership steering.
On 2 June, the government proposed in its fourth supplementary budget an additional funding of EUR 250 million for Tesi (Finnish Industry Investment Ltd).
column43:
On 20 March, the government announced that business finance, mostly through loan guarantees, by Finnvera, the state's financing and export credit company, was expanded by EUR 10 billion. The government also increased its coverage of Finnvera's credit and guarantee losses from 50% to 80% to allow Finnvera to take bigger risks. The government also granted up to EUR 600 million of state gurantee to Finnair.
On 8 April, the government allocated in its second supplementary budget EUR 300 million increase in Business Finland's loan and guarantees of up to EUR 600 million for shipping companies to operate and maintain cargo transport essential to the security of supply.
On 8 May, the government proposed in its third supplementary budget to grant a state guarantee of maximum loan principal of EUR 800 million to the Employment Fund and another EUR 800 million to an European instrument for temporary supports for mitigating unemployment risks and the European Investment Bank.
column46:
The ECB has committed to “do everything necessary within its mandate” to support the economy through this shock. To preserve bank lending and liquidity, the ECB will temporarily conduct additional longer-term refinancing operations (LTROs) and lower the interest rate applied in targeted longer-term refinancing operations (TLTRO III).
Furthermore, the ECB has expanded its asset purchase programme by an overall EUR 870 billion (7.3% of euro area GDP) until the end of 2020. This mainly consists of the EUR 750 billion Pandemic Emergency Purchase Programme, to which some of the ECB self-imposed limits for asset purchases will not apply.
column47: The ECB has temporarily lowered bank capital requirements and introduced flexibility regarding the treatment of non-performing loans for institutions directly under its supervision (Nordea Bank Plc, OP Group and MuniFin). On 17 March FIN-FSA decided to decrease all main solvency requirements by approximately 1.0% with bank variations, which FIN-FSA reckons would increase Finnish credit institutions lending capacity by EUR 30 billion.On 27 March FIN-FSA and ECB strongly advised banks to refrain from distributing dividends until October 2020, in order to ensure that the decreased solvency requirements and new public aid is channeled to lending.
column54: Information not available

column12: As of 15 June, the authorities authorised the conditional reopening of cafés and restaurants in the whole France, except in Guyana and Mayotte where confinement measures remain in place. The ban on public or private gatherings of more than 10 people was lifted on 13 June. As of 20 July, the authorities made mandatory the wearing of masks in all public closed places.
column14: As of July 1st, the EU re-opened its borders to 15 non-EU countries and all travelling restrictions to and from these countries were lifted. The list is to be updated every two weeks.
column16: Physical sites for pre-schools, primary and middle schools fully reopened on 22 June. Yet, some schools with cases have to remain closed.
column18: As of 15 June, the authorities authorised the conditional reopening of cafés and restaurants in the whole France, except in Guyana and Mayotte. The ban on public or private gatherings of more than 10 people was lifted on 13 June. Yet, large cultural and sports events (above 5,000 participants) are banned until September.
column20: As of 22 June, cinemas and casinos may reopen under strengthened sanitary conditions. As of 15 June, the authorities also authorised the conditional reopening of cafés and restaurants in the whole France, except in Guyana and Mayotte. Large cultural and sports events (above 5,000 participants) are banned until September.
column22:
- Joint actions/coordination: joint actions are being taken between national and regional authorities to manage the crisis as part of the new Economic Council 'Etats-Régions', including to set-up regional Task Forces together with development banks (BPI), to accelerate support measures for businesses enterprises.

- The costs of the fiscal package for households and firms, as well as the healthcare sector, are officially estimated (as of 3 April) at around EUR 16.5 billion, ie 0.7% of 2019 GDP. The main fiscal costs are the short-time work scheme (EUR 8.5 billion), health measures (EUR 4.5 billion) and the solidarity fund (EUR 1.5 billion) for the self-employed and smallest firms

- The postponement of social and fiscal deadlines and the early reimbursements of tax credits will reach EUR 48.5 billion (2.0% of 2019 GDP)

- Implementation of an exceptional State guarantee mechanism for new liquidity loans granted by credit institutions between 16 March and 31 December 2020 to companies registered in France (within the limit of EUR 300 billion). Specific guarantees for export insurance and credit insurance could also reach EUR 12 billion.
column25:
- Financial support has been provided to the healthcare system: EUR 260 million (0.01% of GDP) for hospitals have been allocated out of unspent reserves in the 2019 budget. Payments of EUR 3.5 billion (0.14% of GDP) from the 2020 allocation have been brought forward (April instead of May)

- EUR 4.5 billion of additional funds for the purchase of equipment and other health expenses

- Creation of an additional emergency fund of EUR 50 million for research on Covid-19

- Overtime caps for health care professionals in hospitals have been removed, lifting the cap of 15 hours per month (i.e., 180 hours per year),

- Reduced regulatory barriers to the use of telemedicine, such as easing restrictions on reimbursement of consultations done by telephone or videoconference, which currently limit its use

- State requisition of protective masks stocks and future production to support in priority hospitals, town medicine and nurses

- Immediate postponement of non-urgent surgeries

- Mobilization of taxis and hotels for medical staff

- Allowed pharmacists to make their hydro alcoholic solutions and regulated their prices, as well as overtook the national stock and production of protective masks.

- A military health service hospital has been deployed in Alsace

- The military is helping move patients from the most affected regions to reduce local capacity needs.
column28:
- Increased sick leave reimbursements for affected workers, as well as those facing school closures.

- Relaxation of the conditions for the firms to grant an exceptional purchasing power bonus

- Extension of social rights (minimum welfare benefits, benefits for disabled people)

- Extension of unemployment benefits

- A "solidarity fund" will support income for the self-employed and entrepreneurs (see also firm-specific measures)

- Postponement of part of the unemployment insurance reform (around EUR 0.5 billion)

- Additional transfer to the poorest households.
column31: Tax exemptions for bonuses in "essential" sectors. These bonuses can reach 1000 euros or 2000 euros in case of firm-level agreement.
column34:
- Implementation of a €4bn fund to support the cash flow of start-ups

- setting-up a “solidarity fund” with a lump-sum compensation corresponding to the loss of turnover over one year (up to €1500) for very small businesses (turnover under €1 million and annual taxable profit under €60,000), the self-employed, micro-entrepreneurs and liberal professions suffering a very sharp drop in turnover (loss of 70% of turnover over one year in March 2020) or subject to administrative closure. Additional flat-rate aid of €2000 for businesses with at least 1 employee threatened with bankruptcy.
column37:
Broad-based support measures including:

- postponing the payments of social security contributions and taxes, and a on case-by-case basis granting exemptions

- Early repayment of corporate tax claims refundable in 2020 and accelerated processing of VAT credit claims

- Cancellation of late fees for State and local authorities procurement contracts. The government has allowed companies to declare the epidemic as a cause of “force majeure” if it prevented them fulfilling their public procurement contracts.

- Removal of the ceiling for advances paid by the State on public contracts
column40:
- State-guaranteed treasury loan of up to 25% of annual turnover or 2 years of payroll for newly created or innovative companies. No repayment will be required in the first year; the company may choose to amortize the loan over a maximum period of five years.

- Temporary increase in state-ownership for some firms facing exceptional difficulties (up to EUR 20 billion).
column43:
-Scheme enabling the State to guarantee EUR 300 billion in cash loans. The guarantee may cover 70 to 90% of the amount of the loan, depending on the size of the company

- Activation of public reinsurance on outstanding credit insurance up to EUR 10 billion, which will help companies to keep the credit insurance cover they need in order to maintain their activity

- Setting up of reinsurance for short-term export credits with the "Cap Francexport" public reinsurance scheme, launched in October 2018, will be extended to support French exporters. The cap on outstanding amounts reinsured by the State has been doubled to EUR 5 billion, and eligibility has been extended to more destination countries.
column46: Information not available
column47:
The French High Council for Financial Stability has deciced to fully release banks' countercyclical capital buffer on 18 March.
There is wider access to Banque de France refinancing for SMEs.
column51:
- For very small firms and SMEs, water, gas or electricity bills and rents will be postponed for the time of the crisis.

- The authorities encourage conflict mediation with a free, fast and reactive mediation service by a mediator within 7 days for any dispute to the implementation of a contract between private parties, even if tacit, or public procurement

- The authorities created of a crisis unit for inter-company credit;

- The authorities mobilised credit mediation to support SMEs thanks to a public scheme to help any company that is experiencing difficulties with one or more financial institutions
column54: Reduction of the notice period for the imposition or modification of paid leave days

column12:
*June 10: Extension of the state of emergency for a further 21 days.
*May 19: Extension of the state of emergency for a further 21 days. Emergency regulations previously instated will also continue for the next 21 days in line with the state of public health emergency.
*March 27: Declaration of a state of emergency, extended on April 4 for 45 days.
column14:
*March 23: Closure of airspace (except medical and cargo flights) and land borders between the Gambia and Senegal for 21 days (except for essential services such as movements of security and medical personnel, and transportation of food and medical supplies).
*March 20: Suspension of flights from 13 countries and mandatory quarantine for all people travelling from 47 affected countries.
column16: * March 17: Closure of schools and universities for 21 days.
column18:
*June 4: Re-opening of the mosques, starting June 5, and of the churches, starting June 7.
*March 27: Closure of places of worship.
*March 27: Ban on gatherings of more than 10 people; restrictions on public transport [all public transport shall carry half of the total number of passengers they are allowed to transport by law].
*March 27: Recommendations to follow good hygiene practices and social distancing protocols.
*March 17: Ban on public gatherings.
*March 18: Suspension of National Assembly sessions.
column20:
*June 5: Re-opening of markets and ship, under hygiene and social distancing guidelines.
*March 27: Suspension and reduction of non-essential activities and services.
*March 27: Closure of non-essential food outlets in all markets and shopping areas, bars, cafeterias, cinemas, and other entertainment centres.
*March 27: Freeze prices of all essential commodities to prevent hoarding [and ration essential food and non-food commodities].
column22:
*March 27: Reallocation of D500 million Dalasi (0.6% of GDP) from the current budget to the Ministry of Health and other relevant public entities for containment measures to prevent and control the spread of the COVID-19 outbreak.

*Mid March: The authorities prepared a US$9 million (0.5% of GDP) COVID-19 action plan.
column25: Information not available
column28: *The government has launched a student relief fund to support Gambian students abroad and a GMD 734 million (USD14.5 million) nation-wide food distribution program to benefit 84% of the households. These actions are subject to enhanced oversight by the National Assembly.
column31:
*The authorities are working on a relief package for the municipal councils and the tourism sector.
*April 23: 2019 tax returns for the retail and services sectors have been deferred form the first quarter of 2020 to the second quarter.
column34: * 2000 tons of fertilizer will be distributed to support the needs of farmers. This action is subject to enhanced oversight by the National Assembly.
column37: *April 1: The Gambian Revenue Authority has extended, by two months that expired at end-May, the filing of the 2019 annual tax return and the payment of final 2019 tax, as well as for the filing of the first quarter 2020 declaration and the payment of the first quarter instalment. It has also revised down its annual revenue target about 2.2% of GDP.
column40: Information not available
column43: Information not available
column46:
*Further measures are under consideration to provide emergency liquidity support, together with increased intensity and frequency of supervision to address any financial stability concerns. The CBG successfully completed a remote IMF safeguard assessment mission, which found good progress made by the CBG since the last assessment in 2017. The CBG in consultation with MoFEA will be looking to implement the recommendations in the near terms.

*The domestic financial conditions have tightened with the average yield on the most used 364-days T-bills increasing to 11.4% (400 bps higher than at end
- 2019) in late May, before declining in mid-June to about 10.09% (259 bps higher than end-2019).
*May 28: Encourage by the drop in headline inflation from 7.7% at end-2019 to 5.6% in April 2020, the Central Bank (CBG) during its monetary policy committee meeting, reduced the monetary policy rate by 2 % points to 10% resulting in a cumulative reduction of 2.5 % points since end-2019. The Bank also reduced the reserve requirement from 15 to 13%, thus, releasing close to D600 million (USD14 million, 0.7% of GDP) liquidity to the banks.

*To ease liquidity conditions the Central Bank reduced its monetary policy rate by 50 basis points at end-February 2020 to 12% and increased its standing deposit facility rate by the same margin to 3%. The Central Bank is also actively monitoring the situation, communicating with commercial banks, and ready to respond to inflationary pressures.
column47: Information not available
column54:
*April 24: 121 prisoners pardoned in the spirit of decongesting the prisons and allow for social distancing.

*End of April: The European Commission provided Euro 9 million support.

*April 15: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) Executive Board approved a USD21.3 million for The Gambia under the Rapid Credit Facility (RCF). The financing will help the country meet its urgent balance-of-payment (BOP) need as well as support the authorities' efforts to contain the spread of Covid-19 and limit its adverse economic and social impacts. The RCF support supplements earlier financing from the IMF, on March 23.

*DATE?: Donor agencies, including the UNDP, WFP, FAO, UNICEF, UNFP AND UNICEF, have focused financial assistance (about US$1.5 million cumulatively) to strengthen social assistance support for programs aimed at vulnerable groups impacted by COVID-19 by improving communication, safeguarding nutrition and ensuring food security.

*April 2: The World Bank approved a US$10 million grant to the COVID-19 Response and Preparedness Project to enhance case detection, tracing, prevention, social distancing communication and the provision of equipment to isolation and treatment centres. The Word bank is accelerating the rollout of its Social Safety Net project to help mitigate the impact of COVID-19 on the most vulnerable population.

*March 23: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) Executive Board approved a USD47.1 million Extended Credit Facility (ECF) arrangement for The Gambia. The ECF
- supported program aims to anchor macroeconomic stability and progress on structural reforms achieved under the 2019 Staff Monitored Program and would provide a framework to assist the authorities in develop and implementing effective policy responses to address the Covid-19 challenge.

column12: 27 August, minumum €50 fines introduced for failure to wear masks in shops and public transport.
column14:
- Travel restrictions apply for a large number of countries, with unrestricted entry only for residents of EU, schengen or specific low-risk countries

- 14 day quarantine requirement for travel from high risk areas within the EU, including Spain and Paris
column16: August: Classes resumed from the start of the school year, which varies by region, with reduced mixing between classes and targeted quarantine where there are cases detected.
column18:
- 27 August: Cancellation of large public events extended until 31 December

- The states have agreed on a cap of new cases at the municipal level, above which stricter lockdown measures have to be reintroduced. This cap is 50 new cases per 100.000 inhabitants over the previous seven days.
column20:
- Restrictions on most activities in compliance with hygiene measures have been lifted again by individual states. Restrictions remain on nightclubs or conventions.

- The states have agreed that the re-opening will be subject to an “emergency brake", where the occurrence of more than 50 new infections per 100.000 inhabitants over 7 days at the municipal level will require state governments to re-impose containment measures.
column22:
- 3 June: An additional recovery package has been agreed on of roughly EUR 130 bn (3.8% of GDP) for the years 2020 and 2021, which will render a second supplementary budget for 2020 necessary. The included measures provide short-term consumption incentives and increase resources to address longer-term investment needs into digitalisation and greening the economy.

- 23 March: The clause for exceptional circumstances in the debt break was triggered on March 25. This allows debt financing of a supplementary budget of EUR 156 billion (4.5% of GDP) to cover response measures and an estimated reduction in revenues of EUR 33.5 billion (1% of GDP).
column25:
- As part of the 3 June recovery package, further support to health authorities in the technical and digital upgrading of equipment and strengthening their possibilities for personnel recruitment is planned. The Federal Government is setting up a "Hospitals of the Future Programme", which promotes necessary investments by hospitals.

- 23 March: Agreement of federal level and Länder to expand hospital capacities for COVID by e.g. postponing elective treatments. Additional funding for hospitals will be provided to balance losses due to rescheduled surgeries and to increase ICU capacity. Federal government will provide EUR 2.8 billion in 2020, additional funding will come from health insurance.

- 13 March: The budget committee provided additional EUR 800 million for protective equipment, equipment for intensive care and research on vaccines. Previously, around EUR 350 million were already agreed on for protective equipment and the WHO.

- 13 March: Additional central procurement of special equipment on federal level, in addition to procurement of hospitals and private practices
- participation in EU joint procurement.

- 13 March: Derogation for the provision and use of biocidal products (Biocide Ordinance) allows pharmacists to produce and place on the market hand disinfectants.

- 13 March: Sick leave by telephone for up to 14 days for patients with minor illnesses.
column28:
- 25 August: More generous short-time work arrangements extended for up to 24 months, to the end of 2021, at an estimated cost of €10 billion

- As part of the 3 June recovery package, families will receive a one-off payment of EUR 300 per child in 2020.

- 23 April: For individuals receiving unemployment benefits, the length of entitlement will be increased by three months if the entitlement would otherwise end between May and December 2020.
column31:
- 3 June: The VAT rate will be lowered temporarily until the end of the year from 19% to 16% and from 7% to 5% (reduced VAT rate).

- 23 April: The government announced that the reduced VAT rate of 7% will apply for restaurants for 12 months starting on July 1.
column34:
- As part of the 3 June recovery package, direct support to self-employed and small businesses with fewer than 10 employees has been extended for the period June-August 2020. The government will reimburse between 50%-70% of their fixed operating costs up to EUR 15 000. Payments of more than EUR 15 000 are possible in exceptional cases.

- On April 23, the government decided to increase the replacement rate of lost net earnings to 70% for childless workers and to 77% for workers with children from the fourth month of short-time work onwards if they have reduced their working time by at least 50%. In the seventh month, payments are increased further to 80% and 87% respectively.
'
- 23 March: Direct support to self-employed and small businesses with fewer than 10 employees of up to EUR 15 000 per firm (total of EUR 50 billion foreseen).

- 13 March: Short-time working scheme (Kurzarbeit): The government temporarily eased access to the “short-time” work scheme as was the case during the financial crisis. Firms can request support for their workers under this scheme if 10% of their workforce is affected by cuts in working hours as opposed to one third under the usual regulation. In addition to compensating 60% of the difference in monthly net earnings due to reduced hours, the labour agency will now also cover 100% of social-security contributions for the lost work hours. This is an increase compared to the financial crisis, where only 50% of social-security contributions were subsidised and employers had to cover the other half.
column37:
- As part of the 3 June recovery package, the due date for import sale tax will be shifted to the 26th of each following months to increase liquidity for firms.

- 3 June: The loss carry-back for the years 2020 and 2021 will be extended to EUR 10 million.

- 3 June: Degressive depreciation will be possible for the years 2020 and 2021.
'
- 23 April: Loss carry-back for the 2020 tax year which will allow taxpayers to carry back their 2020 tax losses against advance tax payments from the previous year.

- 13 March: The labour agency will cover 100% of social-security contributions for lost hours of short-time workers. This is an increase compared to the financial crisis, where only 50% of social-security contributions were subsidised and employers had to cover the other half.

- 13 March: Tax deferrals are possible and tax prepayments can be adapted to expected lower income in 2020. Enforcement measures and penalty surcharges will be paused in 2020 if the enterprise is hit hard.
column40:
- As announced on April 6, firms will be able to apply for immediate loans through the KfW with 100% government guarantee worth up to 25% of 2019 revenue, capped at EUR 500 000 and EUR 800 000 for firms with 10 to 50 employees and those with more than 50 employees, respectively. Screening will be eased and based on past profitability only, conditions comprise an interest rate of 3% and a maturity of ten years. Loans can be converted to regular KfW loans over time following usual risk screening measures by banks.
'
- In line with a EU decision from March 27, export guarantees will temporarily be extended to cover EU countries and some OECD countries.

- 23 March: An Economic Stabilisation Fund for larger companies with 250 employees or more. The fund will provide EUR 100 billion for recapitalisation, EUR 400 billion of guarantees for corporate liabilities, and a credit authorisation for EUR 100 billion to the KfW for refinancing purposes.

- 23 March: EUR 2 billion for co-investment in start-ups through the KfW bringing forward a first tranche of an already planned future fund of EUR 10 billion.

- 13 March: Providing liquidity to affected firms through programs of the KfW with unlimited credit. Firm size limitations for liquidity support will be adjusted upwards. Risk taken by the government will increase.
column43:
- April 6: Firms will be able to apply for immediate loans through the KfW with 100% government guarantee worth up to 25% of 2019 revenue, capped at EUR 500 000 and EUR 800 000 for firms with 10 to 50 employees and those with more than 50 employees, respectively.

- In line with a EU decision from March 27, export guarantees will temporarily be extended to cover EU countries and some OECD countries.

- 23 March: An Economic Stabilisation Fund for larger companies with 250 employees or more. The fund will provide EUR 400 billion of guarantees for corporate liabilities.

- 13 March: The volume of guarantees provided by guarantee banks will be doubled to €2.5 billion.
column46: Information not available
column47:
- 1 April: The national designated authority BaFin reduced the countercyclical capital buffer for banks from 0.25 % to 0 %.

- 25 March: A three-month payment moratorium on consumer loans established before March 15th is granted until June 30th 2020 if the debtor is financially affected by the COVID-19 crisis.
column48: 25 March: For private or commercial tenants facing income losses, the landlords' right to terminate tenancies due to rent arrears is restricted between April 1 and June 30, 2020.
column51: 25 August: Suspension of the obligation to file for insolvency extended for a further 3 months until the end of 2020
column54: Information not available

column12:
*April 26: Obligation to wear masks (initially Greater Accra region, extended to all public places).
*April 19: Lifting of the partial lockdown of the Greater Accra Metropolitan Area and Kasoa, and the Greater Kumasi Metropolitan Area and its contiguous districts, starting April 20.
*March 28: Partial lockdown (restriction on movement) for the Greater Accra Metropolitan Area and the Greater Kumasi Metropolitan Area for a period of 2 weeks subject to review, starting March 30.
column14:
*March 21: Closure of airspaces and land and sea borders, starting March 22, extended on April 4 from April 5 until April 19.
*March 19: Suspension of all passport services by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Regional Integration.
*March 15: Ban on entry to those coming from a country that has recorded at least 200 cases, except for nationals, starting March 16; mandatory quarantine for any Ghanaian citizen who has been to a country that has recorded at least 200 cases.
*March 10: Suspension of all international official travels by public officials until further notice.
column16:
*June 2: Re-opening of tertiary schools and universities for final year students, starting June 15; level SHS will return June 22; JHS will return June 29.
*March 15: Closure of schools and universities.
column18:
*June 5: Public gatherings (conferences, weddings, burials, non-contact sport and political activities) with a limited number of 100 participants are now allowed.
*June 5: Re-opening of places of worship (churches and mosques): the services and prayers can take place with 100 congregants at a time and for only one hour; wearing of masks and social-distancing rules are mandatory.
*May 10: Extension of the ban on public gatherings, including religious activities, festivals and funerals until the end of May.
*March 21: Closure of all beaches by the Ghana Tourism Authority.
*March 15: Suspension of public events and gatherings including: conferences, workshops, funerals (except private burials not exceeding 25 in attendance), festivals, political rallies, religious activities in churches and mosques; social distancing in workplaces, for 4 weeks.
*March 6: Recommendations to follow good hygiene practices and social distancing protocols.
column20: * March 15: Increased hygiene conditions in marketplaces, public transport, shopping malls, restaurants nightclubs, hotels, drinking spots.
column22:
*March 28: Extension of tax filing date from April to June; 2% reduction of interest rates by banks, starting April 1; granting principal repayments 6 month moratorium to entities in the airline and hospitality industries.
*The government plans cutting spending in goods and services, transfers, and capital investment, for a total of at least GHS1.1 billion (0.3% of GDP).
To reduce the financing needs, the government will draw US$218 million from the stabilization fund, and will borrow up to GHS10 billion from the Bank of Ghana.
*March 11: The government committed USD100 million to support preparedness and response plan.
column25:
*April 26: A major investment in healthcare infrastructure was announced, including the construction or upgrade of 100 district and regional hospitals.
*March 28: Cost of fund transfers decreased for mobile money in order to encourage the use of mobile money rather than cash for hygiene reasons (sending up to GHS100 for free and 100% to 300% increase in the daily transaction limits for mobile money transactions).
*March 11: Ghanaian Cedi equivalent to US$100 million to support preparedness and response plan from the government to fund expansion of infrastructure, purchase of materials and equipment, and public education; earmarking of additional funds for test kits, pharmaceuticals, equipment and hospital beds.
column28: * March 28: A COVID-19 National Trust Fund to support vulnerable populations through contributions and donations from the public.
column31: Information not available
column34: Information not available
column37: Information not available
column40:
*May 19: The government launched the GHS 1 billion Coronavirus Alleviation Programme Business Support Scheme.
*The government committed US$210 million under its Coronavirus Alleviation Programme to the promotion of selected industries (e.g. pharmaceutical sector supplying COVID-19 drugs and equipment), the support of SMEs and employment, and the creation of guarantees and first-loss instruments.
column43: *The government has also agreed with the investors to postpone interest payments on non-marketable domestic bonds held by public institutions to fund the financial sector clean-up for about GHS1.2 billion (0.3% of GDP).
column46:
*May 15: The Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) kept the policy rate unchanged and announced a new bond purchasing program to provide emergency financing to the government in light of a higher projected fiscal financing gap. A 10-year bond with a face value of GHS 5.5 billion (1.4% of GDP) has been purchased, and the MPC indicated that future purchases may increase up to GHS 10 billion. The MPC also announced relief measures for small depositary institutions and a USD 1 billion repop agreement with the US Federal Reserve under its FIMA facility.
*March 18: The Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) reduced the interest rate from 16% to 14.5%. Other measures include: lowering reserve requirements from 10% to 8% to provide liquidity support to critical sectors, lowering the capital conservation buffer from 3% to 1.5%; revising provision and classification rules for specific loan categories and steps to facilitate and lower the cost of mobile payments; continuing to monitor the economic impact of COVID-19, holding emergency meetings if necessary.
column47: Information not available
column54:
*April 15: A disbursement of USD 1 billion from IMF.
*April 2: The World Bank is providing US$100 million to Ghana. This USD 100 million will be made available to the government and the people of Ghana as short, medium and long-term support.

column12:
From 18 May, movement allowed to travel outside the prefecture of the residence on the mainland as well as to the the islands of Crete and Evia only.
From May 4, movements for prescribed purposes are permitted without a self-signed authorisation form. Permitted include visiting parks and beaches.
From March 23 to May 4, only movements for prescribed purposes are permitted (essential employment, food shopping, health). Individuals must sign a form declaring the purposes of their movements.
14-day home restriction on anyone entering Greece
column14:
15 June: Entry permitted for residents of EU states. EU external borders remain closed. Arrivals for 'high risk' regions must undergo a COVID-19 test while other arrivals are tested randomly. Flights to UK remain suspended. External border to reopen 1 July.,
'From May 18, travel allowed outside the prefecture of the residence on the mainland as well as to the the islands of Crete and Evia only. Traveling to other islands is still allowed for permanent residents, business owners and workers provided they carry documents proving the necessity of traveling.
23 March: Suspends all fligths with UK and connections with Turkey, except for good transport and residents of Greece.
18 March: External borders closed to all non-EU nationals except in exceptional cases. Turkey closes land border with Greece at Karaaga and Ipsala.
16 March: 14-day home quarabntine introduced for all arrivals. Border closed with Albania and North Macedonia, except for transport of good and for residents of Greece. Cruise ships banned from docking. Ferry services to Italy suspended.
9 March: Suspension of flights to northern Italy and Spain
column16:
1 June: Nursery schools, kindergartens and primary schools may reopen
18 May: All other grades of secondary education resumed classes and private tuition and foreign language centres re-open.
11 May: Senior high schools reopen. Classes were divided into two groups with a maximum of 15 pupils in each group and groups attend classes on alternating days. Younger grades to follow later.
10 March: Schools and universities closed.
column18:
From May 18: Outdoors archelogical sites reopened, including the Acropolis, ancient Olympia. Some other museums and cultural sites can reopen. Large gatherings, such as festivals, concerts or sporting events with spectators, remain closed.
From May 16: Organised beaches are reopened, with restrictions on activities, services, density and number of entries.
From March 23, only movements for prescribed purposes are permitted (essential employment, food shopping, health).
Froim March 18: Restaurants, coffee shops, hair salons, malls and beaches and resorts closed. Olympic-related events cancelled. Tourism effectively shut down through closure of hotels.
column20:
15 June: seasonal hotels and tourist accommodations, fitness facilities, museums, rehabilitation centers for disabled people, therapeutic baths, spas, hamams and saunas, recreation and thematic parks, remaining facilities for entertainment and recreation, and prostitution facilities may reopen.
'8 June: Bars, internet cafes, night clubs, entertainment facilities with live music, shops and gambling may open.
6 June: Indoor areas of restaurants may open. Food and drinks may be sold at outoor events. 1 June, All cafes and restaurants will be allowed to re-open, but only with outdoor seating and certain distances between chairs and tables. Shopping malls, year-round hotels and summer movie theatres will also begin operation, with strict social distancing rules. Staff members will have to wear masks and gloves.
May 4: Wider variety of shops may open, including haidressers. Restaurants and bars may serve take-away. Sanitary restrictions apply.
March 23: Additional movement restrictions
Restaurants, coffee shops, hair salons, malls and beaches and resorts closed from Wednesday 18 March. Tourism effectively shut down through closure of hotels.
column22:
Split roughly equally between workers and businesses. Businesses in heavily affected sectors will see a mix of loans and grants. Targeted tax holidays for both affected individuals and businesses. No blanket payment moratorium.

- No calculation of late payment interest or surcharges for tax liabilities/payments suspended.

- Immediate refund of debts due from the Tax Administration to taxpayers for amounts up to EUR 30,000.
EUR 6.8 bn (2% of GDP), including EUR 5 bn financed through budget and EUR 1.8 bn from European Special Fund.
column24: EUR 6.8 bn (2% of GDP), including EUR 5 bn financed through budget and EUR 1.8 bn from European Special Fund.
column25:
EUR 200 m for health system, EUR 75 for hiring 2000 health workers in addition to 950 doctors and nurses already hired. Funding to contract private hospitals and laboratories to provide facilities. All manufacturing activities for the production of antiseptics by industrial and craft enterprises for the Ministry of Health are zero-rated. Reduction of VAT rate from 24% to 6% until the end of 2020 for certain goods necessary for the protection against COVID-19 including protective masks and gloves, antiseptic products, wipes and relevant products, soap and other products used for personal hygiene purposes, and ethyl alcohol if used as a raw material for the production of antiseptics.
18 March: A total of 108,000 public servants working in hospitals, National Emergency Aid Centre, National Organisation of Public Health and Civil Protection will receive an (extraordinary) Easter bonus.
column28:
14 April: PM announces one-off allowance of EUR 400 for 155000 long-term unemployed.
For private sector employees whose labour contract has been suspended, the fraction of their Easter bonus that corresponds to the period of suspension will be covered by the state budget.
20 March: Firms can reduce their employees' work time to a minimum of 2 weeks per month, for at least 50% of all employees within a firm, on the condition that they do not dismiss any workers. The measure can be applied for up to 6 months.
EUR 600 training voucher for liberal professionals. 180000 estimated beneficaries.
19 March: Extension of the regular unemployment benefit payment, as well as extension of the long-term unemployment benefit and the unemployment benefit to freelancers and self-employed workers, for two months.
Special leave scheme 25% funded by the state, for parents of children younger than 15 who are not in school.
11 March: Allowance of 800 euros for self employed, freelancers, individual businesses (520 000 indiviiduals) and employers of up to 20 employees (90 000 individuals) and affected by the coronavirus crisis based on specific NACE codes
Allowance of 800 euros for employees of firms affected by the coronavirus crisis, whose labour contracts have been suspended based on specific NACE codes, covering 1.7 million private sector workers (81% of private sector employees). These amounts apply from mid-March to the end of April, with EUR 533 will be granted for May.
Introduction of special purpose leave only for workers with children attending to schools (while schools are closed), the cost of which will be shared between the state, the firm and the employee.
column31:
24 March: 25% reduction in tax and social security contribution obligations (excluding VAT), if paid on time, for employees of halted firms as well as for self-employed, freelancers and firms affected by the coronavirus crisis. This measure applies to all those eligible to deferral in tax debt payments and SSC payments:
18 March: VAT reduction to 6%, from 24%, for sanitary products (masks, gloves etc) (negligible cost).
11 March: The SSCs of employees (of firms affected by the coronavirus crisis, whose labour contracts have been suspended) and self-employed (considered as employees) affected by the coronavirus crisis based on specific NACE codes will be covered by the state.
column34:
30 March: Economic support in the form of a training voucher of EUR 600 for six scientific sectors (economists/accountants, engineers, lawyers, doctors, teachers and researchers, 180,390 beneficiaries).
30 March: Support of the primary sector of the economy with EUR 150 million to the Ministry of Rural Development and Food.
30 March: Interest payments on performing loans of corporates affected by the coronavirus crisis for April, May and June will be paid by the state conditional to firms maintaining their employment levles.
column37:
26 March; 3-month extension of the deadline for the payment of scheduled instalments of tax and contribution debts, due on March 31 and subsequent months. These payments will start as of 1 June 2020.
18 March: Immediate repayment of all pending tax refund claims up to 30,000 euros that are under audit. The measures refers to tax refunds for CIT and VAT and has no fiscal impact.
11 March: 1) Suspension of VAT and other tax obligations' payments that were due between March 11
- April 30 until August 31 for businesses, self-employed persons and sole proprietorships affected by the coronavirus crisis based on specific NACE codes.
2) Suspension of SSC payments due by the end-March until October 31 for businesses, self-employed persons and sole proprietorships affected by the coronavirus crisis based on specific NACE codes. Suspended payments will be paid in 4 installments of equal amount without interest and surcharges.
column40:
April 3: A scheme for the support of the economy through the issuance of guarantees by the Hellenic Development Bank has been approved under the E.U. temporary framework for state aid. The scheme will partially guarantee eligible working capital loans, with the total exposure of the Hellenic Development Bank capped at 40% of the volume of loans issued by a financial intermediary. Solvent SMEs will receive grants of up to EUR 800 000 per company to cover interest on fixed-maturity loans, bonds, or overdrafts. The total size of the scheme will amount to EUR 2 billion.

18 March: A refundable advance payment will be provided to businesses affected by the crisis and whose loans are performing, on the basis of turnover reduction or other factors. The advance will be a fraction of loss in turnover and can over five years following a one-year grace period and at a low interest rate (EUR 2 billion).
column43: Information not available
column46: The ECB has committed to “do everything necessary within its mandate” to support the economy through this shock. To preserve bank lending and liquidity, the ECB will temporarily conduct additional longer-term refinancing operations (LTROs) and lower the interest rate applied in targeted longer-term refinancing operations (TLTRO III). Furthermore, the ECB has expanded its asset purchase programme by an overall EUR 870 billion (7.3% of euro area GDP) until the end of 2020, while opening the door to freeing its self-imposed limits. Greece's government bonds are included as eligible assets for this programme.
column47: On the supervisory front, the ECB has temporarily lowered bank capital requirements and introduced flexibility regarding the treatment of non-performing loans.
column48: 18 March: A 40% reduction in rent for primary residence,, for March and April, for employees of firms affected by the coronavirus crisis based on specific NACE codes.
column51:
18 March: 1) A 40% reduction in rent for commercial premises, for March and April, for firms affected by the coronavirus crisis based on specific NACE codes.
2) Suspension of loan repayments (for the principal amount) until September for firms affected by the coronavirus crisis. This measure was agreed by Greek banks
column54: Information not available

column12: *August 26: Guatemalan government implemented a nation-wide tiered system of health alerts July 27, which provides updated information on levels of health risk by locality throughout Guatemala, in an effort to prepare for the country's gradual re-opening. The Guatemalan government's mandatory curfew remains in effect, running 9:00 p.m. each evening through 4:00 a.m. the following day.  As of August 1, the Executive Branch and its dependencies have a different work schedule, working between 7:00 a.m. to 3:00 p.m. and, Private sector entities that do not have established hours must carry out their activities from 9:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m.. The government began implementing a differentiated re-opening of the economy based on municipalities' performance on pre-established indicators through an alert board system of four colors (red, orange, yellow, and green).
column14:
*August 26: TThe Guatemalan government is currently barring entry to most non-Guatemalans (with specific exceptions for accredited diplomatic personnel, health and security personnel, and exceptional cases as designated by the Guatemalan government)
- by its land, sea, and air borders.? Airport operations and routine commercial flights out of Guatemala have been suspended.
column16:
* May, 5: Schools continue to be closed throughout the national education system with no scheduled date to reopen.
* March, 25: The Program to study at home “Aprendo en Casa” is launched. This way, children can continue with education. Teachers receive guidelines through email.
column18:
*August 26: Based on the tiered alert system, the following restrictions are in place in Guatemala City:

Open-air markets must maintain 1.5 meters of distance between patrons and ensure the proper use of masks. Individuals over the age of 60 are prohibited from shopping at open-air markets.

Supermarkets and enclosed stores must maintain four meters of distance between patrons and ensure the proper use of masks. Individuals over the age of 60 are prohibited from shopping at supermarkets and enclosed stores.

Malls and commercial centers may open to provide support to online shopping and parking lot delivery services. Restaurants, food courts and gathering spaces must remain closed. Commercial centers must arrange a special schedule to accommodate patrons over the age of 60.

Groups of ten or larger are not permitted. High risk individuals and individuals over the age of 60 are not permitted to enter.

Gyms, concert venues, movie theaters, pools, bars and public parks must remain closed.
column20: *August 26: All public and private businesses must maintain four meters of distance between employees at all time. Public sector offices will operate from 7 a.m. to 3 p.m. Private sector businesses are recommended to operate from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.
column22: * June 15: Three fiscal packages, totaling around 3.4% of GDP. 1) US$250 million IADB Budget Support loan 2) US$200 million World Bank Disaster Risk Management loan 3) issuance of treasury bonds and the use of emergency budgetary reserves (about US$60 million). The fiscal response is now focused on two programs: i) stepping up healthcare resources (0.2% of GDP) and ii) providing support to different sectors in the economy through cash transfers (1.2% of GDP), salary subsidies (0.3% of GDP) and funding to SMEs (0.6% of GDP).  As part of its financing strategy, Guatemala has raised from international markets US$1,200 million on April 21st (third LatAm sovereign issuer since the onset of the COVID crisis alongside Panama and Peru). This covers over one third of the intended issuance this year by the sovereign domestically and internationally.
column25: * June 15: Focus on stepping up healthcare resources (0.2% of GDP). A facility for coronavirus patients (financed through a US$1 million grant from the Central American Bank of Economic Integration) will add 3,000 beds to the existing capacity (350 beds).
column28:
* June 15: current plan focuses on 1) increasing the coverage and amount of electricity subsidies, and 2) fostering low income housing. As part of its financing strategy.
* March, 25: Fines, administrative expenses or interest imposed due to delays in the fee payment to educational centres are banned.

* April, 3: 2 million families will be benefit from Q1000 a month for a period of three months. 300 000 workers unable to work during the emergency will benefited from the equivalent of USD 9 a day.

* April, 3: A working capital credit fund is created to finance working capital directly or through financial mechanisms with attractive conditions to preserve productive capacity.
column31: * March, 23: The Board of Directors of the Institute for Workers' Recreation, the Technical Institute for Productivity, and the National Institute of Social Security will defer the employer's fees for three months in order to support SMEs. *June 15: As part of the National Emergency and Economic Recovery Plan, additional targeted measures to support the economy were enacted: i) streamlining tax credit refunds to exporters (freeing up to 0.2% of GDP) iii) waiving taxes on medical supplies
column34: Information not available
column37: * June 15: As part of the National Emergency and Economic Recovery Plan, additional targeted measures to support the economy were enacted: deferring income tax payments and social security contributions (one quarter),
column40: Information not available
column43: * April, 2: Individual and SME loans will be granted through credits from local banks.
column46:
* March, 18: Banco de Guatemala has lowered its policy rate by 75 basis points to 2 percent since March 18 and stands ready to secure liquidity provision facilities, including by acting as lender of last resort. To support the financial sector, the Monetary Board has temporarily eased (180-day period) credit risk management regulations to enable loan restructuring, loan payment moratoriums, and the use of generic provisions.

* March, 18: An Economic Recovery Plan is presented to the legislative.

* April, 2: Hoarding, speculation, shortages or refusal to sell products will be penalized. *June 24: Monetary Board cut its policy rate by an additional 25 basis points to 1.75 percent, in response to the detrimental impact on domestic growth from weaker global conditions than initially foreseen.
column47: Information not available
column48: * April 24:  Banco de Guatemala granted a special loan to the government for GTQ 11 billion (about USD 1.5 billion). Resources will be used for vulnerable population and strengthen resources for the COVID-19 emergency (first tranche of the loan for GTQ 3.5 billion, USD 470 million).
column54: Information not available

column12:
*June 16: Lifting of the curfew across the country, with the exception of Conakry, Coyah and Dubreka (from 11pm to 5am).
*June 16: Extension of the state of emergency until July 15.
*May 15: Curfew from 10pm to 5am in the greater Conakry region (Conakry, Coyah and Dubréka); lifting of the curfew in the rest of the country.
*April 13: Obligation to wear masks starting April 18.
*March 31: Curfew from 9pm to 5am.
*March 26: Declaration of a state of emergency for one month, starting March 26. Renewed on May 15 for another month.
column14:
*May 25: Guinea requires all travellers to provide proof of a COVID-19 test result and upon arrival, to undergo another test and a mandatory 14-day quarantine. Foreign national must undergo a 14-day quarantine prior to their travel.
*March 26: Closure of land borders (excepting transport of goods) for 30 days.
*March 26: Restrictions on the transportation of goods.
*March 26: Restrictions on public transport.
*March 26: Ban on travel to countries with more than 50 cases.
*March 23: Closure of Conakry airport to non-essential flights.
*March 19: Suspension of commercial flights for countries with more than 30 cases (except cargo and humanitarian flights); suspension of visa issuance; suspension of official missions in affected countries, starting March 21 for 30 days.
*March 19: Increased sanitary measures at all border points.
column16:
*June 15: Re-opening of universities and school-classes preparing for official examinations on June 29.
*March 26: Closure of schools and universities for at least 14 days.
column18:
*June 15: Re-opening of the places of worship in the prefectures without new cases for 30 consecutive days, starting June 22.
*May 15: Partial lifting on the ban of gatherings, from more than 30 people.
*March 26: Social distancing and restricted access to public places (markets, restaurants, banks); ban on gatherings of more than 20 people; suspension of sport and cultural events and religious ceremonies.
*March 26: Suspension of all international conferences.
*March 19: Increased sanitary measures in public places (markets, places of worship).
*March 19: Ban on public gatherings without adequate sanitary measures.
column20: *March 26: Closure of bars, cinemas, theatres and other entertainment centres for at least 14 days.
column22: *April 6: A COVID-19 economic response plan has been announced to strengthen infrastructure in the health sector, protecting the most vulnerable and supporting the private sector, notably SMEs. Authorities estimate the cost of the Plan at about USD 328 million (2.3% of GDP). Key measures include the introduction of temporary exonerations on taxes, social contributions and payments of utilities for firms in the most affected sectors; the implementation of labour-intensive public works, provision of cash transfers, a waiver on the payment of utilities for the most vulnerable. The authorities are contemplating additional support measures to some agricultural commodity chain such as cashew, pineapple and potatoes.
column25: *Preparation of a National Emergency and Response Plan, with the support of international development partners, with the following key measures: strengthening surveillance at ports of entry; reinforcing capacity for COVID-19 detection; increasing the number of quarantine centres; expanding treatment facilities and acquiring medical equipment; conducting a communication campaign. The implementation cost of the National Emergency Plan is estimated at US$47 million (0.3% of GDP).

column46:
*April 16: As announced in April 6 COVID-19 economic response plan, the Central Bank of the Republic of Guinea (BCRG) unveiled some support measures:

- The policy rate and reserve requirement ratio were both reduced by 100 basis points to 11 and 15% respectively.

- The BCRG allows banks, for the duration of the pandemic, to count against their reserve credit provided to SMEs, businesses in the services sector affected (hotels, restaurants and transport), and major importers of food and pharmaceutical products. T

- The central bank also announced a program of liquidity injection, including a window for the provision of long-term liquidity.
column47:
*April 16: The Central Bank of the Republic of Guinea (BCRG) announced measures to mitigate prudential requirements, including:

- lowering the liquidity coverage ratio from 100 to 80%;

- suspending the NPL classification for businesses and individuals impacted by the pandemic and the provisioning of such loans;

- relaxing the limits on foreign exchange positions (from 20 to 25% of capital for the next positions, and 10 to 12.5% for the position in each currency;

- dividend payments have been suspended while financial institutions are required to limit technical assistance fees paid to their parent companies to the strict minimum;

- financial institutions have been granted a 3-month postponement of the payment of supervision
- related fees as well as contributions to the deposit insurance scheme;

- insurance companies are to postpone the payment of premia falling due during the pandemic and to suspend policies at the request of customers;

- identification requirements of e-money accounts have been eased and companied are encouraged to reduce e-money transfer fees.

column12:
*June 26: Lifting of the curfew.
*June 26: Extension of the state of emergency though July 25.
*June 11: Extension of the state of emergency through June 25.
*May 26: Extension of the state of emergency through June 10.
*May 12: Extension of the state of emergency through May 26.
*May 15: Absolute night-time curfew between 8pm and 6am, in addition to the movement restrictions according to which necessary purchases can only be made between 7am and 2pm.
*Obligation to wear masks in public places and public transports.
*April 29: Extension of the window during which persons are allowed to leave their residence to go shopping from 7am and 2pm.
*April 27: Curfew applies throughout the day with one exception between 7am and noon. During this time it is allowed to go shopping.

* April 12: The state of emergency was extended until 29 April.
*March 28: The government announced a 15-day state of emergency.
column14:
* May 27: entry and exit into Guinea-Bissau permitted only with the presentation of a certificate of negative COVID-19 status. Prohibition of interregional travel. Extension of circulation hours (time permitted to undertake essential shopping outside of the home) to between 7:00 am and 6:00 pm.

* April 06: closure of all borders and permission to circulate in the streets only between 7:00 am and 11:00 am.
*March 25: Suspension of public transport.*March 17: Closure of land borders and ban on all flights landing at Osvaldo Viera International Airport, starting on March 18.
column16: *March 27: Closure of schools.
column18:
* May 27: No more than five people may gather without social distancing and no more than ten people may attend a funeral.
*March 16: Suspension of religious ceremonies, traditional fairs and ban on public gatherings.
column20:
*May 27: Sit-down service not permitted at restaurants; take-away service only.
*Restriction and/or closure of markets and commercial sites.
*March 16: Closure of bars and nightclubs; ban on selling products in the street.
column22: Information not available
column25:
*The government has increased monthly health expenditure by XOF 222 million (USD 0.4 million) to purchase medicine, food, services and equipment for hospitals.
*March 21: The Central Bank for West African States (BCEAO) has introduced measures to promote the use of electronic payments.
*March 20: The Government has created a multi-sectoral committee that will work with the WHO.
*Emergency health measures of XOF 485 million (USD 0.8 million or 0.06% of GDP) have been spent to supply the Ministries of Health, Home Affairs and Defence. These were focused on upgrading the main national hospital, and providing medicines, food, and medical equipment. The authorities are seeking support from multilateral donors to finance additional expenses.
column28: *The government has provided some assistance to households. XOF 525 million  (US$ 0.9 million or 0.06 percent of GDP) are used to distribute 20.000 bags of rice and 10.000 bags of sugar throughout the country. The authorities are seeking international financial support to complement its assistance program.
column31: Information not available
column34: Information not available

column40: Information not available
column43: Information not available
column46:
*June 22 : The Monetary Policy Committee cut by 50 basis points the ceiling and the floor of the monetary policy corridor, to 4 and 2% respectively.
*The Central Bank for West African States (BCEAO) has launched a special 3-month refinancing window at a fixed rate of 2.5% for limited amounts of 3-month “Covid-19 T-Bills” to be issued by each WAEMU (UEMOA) sovereign to help meet immediate funding needs related to the current pandemic. The amount of such special T-Bills issued by Guinea Bissau amounted to 4.5% of GDP.
*March 25: The West African Development Bank (BOAD) decided to grant to the WAEMU (UEMOA) members countries XOF 120 billion in concessional loans (XOF 15 billion per country) to be disbursed immediately; such loans are softened though the interest subsidy mechanism replenished by BCEAO and the WAEMU Commission for XOF 25 billion and XOF 15 billion, respectively.
*March 23: The Central Bank of West African States (BCEAO) first raised the liquidity made available to banks at its weekly and monthly auctions of March 23, allowing average refinancing rates to remain relatively close to the floor of the monetary policy corridor of 2.5%. This was followed, starting with the weekly refinancing auction of March 30, by the adoption of a full allotment strategy at a fixed rate of 2.5% thereby allowing banks to satisfy their liquidity needs fully at a lower rate.
column47:
*The WAEMU (UEMOA) authorities have extended by one year the five-year period initiated in 2018 for the transition to Basle II/III bank prudential requirements. In particular, the regulatory capital adequacy ratio will remain unchanged at end-2020 from its 2019 level of 9.5%, before gradually increasing to 11.5% by 2030 instead of 2022 initially planned.
*March 21: The Central Bank of West African States (BCEAO) has announced: i) an extension of the collateral framework to access central bank refinancing to include bank loans to prequalified 1,700 private companies; ii) the setting up a framework with the banking system to support firms with repayment difficulties.
column54: *March 28: The international community has decided to support the contingency plan presented by the authorities, a plan budgeted at just over USD 16 million.
