column12: On 18 June, the Hungarian parliament revoked the state of emergency that had been declared in mid-March due to COVID-19. Some restrictions remain in place, including travel restrictions. People are required to wear a face mask in stores and on public transport.
column14: Hungary will close all borders as of 1 September. Foreign citizens cannot enter Hungary, with some exceptions, including business travel, cross-border commutes, transit and diplomatic visits. Hungarians returning from abroad must show two negative coronavirus tests 48 hours apart in the previous 5 days, or they must quarantine for 14 days.
column16:
- Primary and secondary schools reopened on 2 June to provide for child care. Digital education will continue until 15 June, the end of the semester.

- Universities and colleges can re-open again on 4 May (in Budapest on 18 May).
column18: All public events and gatherings with more than 500 people remain banned.
column20: On 18 June, the Hungarian parliament revoked the state of emergency that had been declared in Hungary in mid-March due to COVID-19. Some restrictions remain in place. People working in restaurants and bars are required to wear a facemask. Facemasks are also obligatory when entering stores. Music and dance events are permitted if the total number of those present, including staff, does not exceed 500.
column22: The government announced additional fiscal spending of around 4.5% of GDP. This includes temporary tax cuts in the order of HUF 515 billion (1.1% of GDP), additional funding for the health sector of HUF 180 billion (0.4% of GDP), HUF 1200 billion (2.6% of GDP) wage subsidies for furloughed workers and additional income support. In addition, the government will bring forward the planned 2-percentage point cut to employers' social contributions from October to July (HUF 180 billion or 0.4% of GDP), and pay a one-off bonus for health workers in November 2020.
column25:
- On 23 April, the government ordered pubic hospitals to free up 50% of bed capacity for a potential renewed surge in the number of COVID-19 patients.

- On 4 April, the government announced a HUF 663 billion (1.4% of GDP) Epidemic Prevention Fund to cover additional health spending, including a 20% wage increase for health care professionals in November 2020. About HUF 180 billion (0.39% of GDP) will be new spending, but most funding will be redirected from other budgetary items, and around 91 billion will be raised through new bank and retail levies and from municipalities' vehicle tax. In addition, a small financing part comes from the financing of political parties.

- Export restrictions were introduced for certain medical products.

- The government has released additional funding of EUR 630 million to the health sector for purchasing protective equipment, a container hospital and other prepatory measures.

- Several central hospitals and four major hospitals outside Budapest have been prepared to receive new cases.

- Administrative procedures for the use and supply of medical products have been simplified.
column28:
- On 18 May, the government announced additional HUF 80 billion for the wage subsidy scheme to support job creation. The duration of the wage subsidy will be extended to 6 months, while employers have to commit to keep their employees for another 3 months.

- The uptake of the new job retention scheme has increased since the end of April, but remains low. As of 8 May, the job retention scheme provided funding for around 4,000 companies covering 54,000 furloughed workers (1% of all employees). SMEs and sectors related to the automotive industry benefit mostly. 60% of workers covered work in SMEs, and 62% of furloughed workers are employed in the processing industry and in trade and repair of motor vehicles. Only 9% of furloughed workers work in heavily affected tourism and hospitality sectors. By 18 May, uptake stood at 90,000 workers in 6,800 companies, with HUF 15 billion being paid out. 8,300 employees received a wage subsidy for R&D workers with a total paid out of HUF 6 billion.
'
- On 15 April, the government announced a 40% payroll subsidy (up to HUF 318 920) for engineering and R&D workers for 3 months. As of 8 May, the scheme covered 5,892 furloughed workers (0.1% of total employment). Every second beneficiary works in the IT service industry, and scientific and technical services.

- All maternity leave benefits are prolonged until the end of the state of emergency (15 April).

- On 6 April, the prime minister announced a temporary job retention programme, where the state assumes 70% of wage costs of furloughed workers for up to 3 months for companies that lost 15-75% of their revenues as a result of the Covid-19 epidemic. Funding is conditional on the company retaining its workers. While previously a cap of HUF 75 000 per worker applied, the wage cap was raised to twice the minimum wage on 16 April. This translates into HUF 112,418 in case of a 75% work reduction and HUF 22,495 in case of a 15% work reduction. Wage costs of part-time workers and employees on lease are not covered. Smaller firms benefit from a streamlined application procedure. Firms that operate in sectors for 'the operation of national economic interest' are eligable, which creates some regulatory ambiguity, and firms can apply only once.

- The government estimates the costs of the two wage subsidy schemes at around HUF 615 billion (1.32% of GDP) in 2020. Against this target, only HUF 12.9 billion were spend or allocated to firms as of 8 May, including HUF 8.7 billion for furloughed workers and HUF 4.2 billion for R&D workers.

- The government also announced a protection programme for families and pensioners (6 April), including a one-off payment for pensioners and an allowance for large families at an estimated cost of HUF 125 bn (0.25% of GDP)

- The government also announced the reinstatement of the 13th month of pension, adding a week of pension over four years starting in Feb 2021 (HUF 235 billion).

- Sick leave pay for all workers during the epidemic from the first day onwards will be covered by Health Insurance Institute at an estimated cost of HUF 60 bn (0.13% of GDP).

- Monthly basic income for self-employed workers and farmers at estimated cost of HUF 105 bn (0.23% of GDP)

- Allowances for special working conditions of public employees (HUF 245 bn or 0.53% of GDP)
column31:
- The government introduced a new financial sector ley on 1 May, which is expected to raise HUF 55 billion in 2020. Banks are charged 0.19 percent of their 2020 tax base. The levy will be due on 10 June, 10 September, and 10 December 2020.

- A new retail tax of 2.5% is charged on retailers with annual revenues above HUF 100 billion, including global online retailers. Businesses with net revenues of under HUF 500 million are exempted. Retailers with annual revenues between HUF 500 million and HUF 30 billion are charged 0.1% of their revenues, and those with revenues between HUF 30 billion and HUF 100 billion 0.4%. The government expects to raise HUF 36 billion.

- Revenues from the financial sector and retail levies will be used to cover spending by the HUF 663 billion Epidemic Prevention Fund.

- In addition, HUF 34 billion of local governments' revenues stemming from car taxes and 50% of subsidies for political parties (HUF 1.2 billion) will be redirected to fund spending under the Epidemic Prevention Funds.

- Reduction in the VAT rate for new dwellings to 5% (17 April).

- Companies in affected sectors can apply for a tax reduction of up to HUF 5 million (15 April).

- Starting in July 2020, the social security contribution will be cut from 17.5% to 15.5% (HUF 180 billion) (15 April).

- Small enterprises will benefit from a reduction of the Small Companies Special Tax Regime rate (KIVA) from 12% to 11% from 2021. An estimated 50,000 enterprises may be eligible (15 April).

- 17 and 23 March: Temporarily suspension of employers' social security contributions in most affected economic sectors, such as tourism, hospitality, the entertainment industry and passenger transport until 30 June. Employees' social security contributions, including pension contributions, have been temporary reduced to the level of the health care contribution until 30 June (17 March and 23 March). Numbers of potential beneficiaries vary and cost are estimated between HUF 37 billion, assuming 163,000 people work in affected sectors (administrative sources), and HUF 178 billion, assuming 500,000 workers are covered at the minimum wage for three months (tourism sector representatives).

- Suspension of the tourism development contribution fee (HUF 9 billion) and the advertisement tax (17 March).

- Selected businesses, including in health social care services and other strongly affected activities, covering 81 000 small enterprises have been exempted from the special lump sum tax on small enterprises (“KATA”) until end-June at an estimated cost of HUF 2.1 billion (17 March).

- The media tax payable by media service providers has been temporarily suspended.
column34:
- The government announced HUF 920 billion (0.9% of GDP) in investment subsidies under the Economy Protection Action Plan that aims at restarting the economy.

- This includes HUF 310 billion of non-refundable grants and HUF 110 billion of 0% loans made available for firms that benefit from the wage support program.

- Grants of HUF 21 billion are available for SMEs in the manufacturing sector.

- About HUF 50 billion of subsidies to support investment in new technologies by SMEs: Between HUF 5 and 153.5 million per firm, up to 70% of the total eligible costs of new machinery and equipment and attached to the number of staff. Businesses can receive HUF 1.5 million per employee between 1 and 9 staff, HUF 1 million between 10 and 49 staff, and HUF 500,000 between 50 and 249 staff, provided that they retain 90 percent of their employees. The government made available an additional 169 billion HUF of investment subsidies for SMEs in manufacturing and service sectors that were hard hit by the COVID-19 crisis (i.e. experienced a decline of at least 25% in sales revenue or orders).

- Firms in the agricultural and food sectors will receive 25 billion of grants, and renovation and construction will be subsidised in the tourism sector by an additional 180 billion.

- Large firms benefit from HUF 40 billion investment subsidies in 2020.

- Purchases of electric cars and vehicles will be subsidised by up to 55% of the purchase price.
column37:
- The government will bring forward the planned 2-percentage point cut to employers' social contributions from October to July (HUF 180 billion or 0.4% of GDP)

- KATA arrears before 1 March will only be payable when the state of emergency ends.

- Enforcement measures arising from tax arrears have been suspended.

- Deferral of tax and financial returns until 30 September 2020.

- VAT refunds are accelerated to 30 days.
column40:
- Eligable firms can access HUN 2000 billion in subsidised emergency credit lines an interest rate of 0.1% of the Hungarian Development Bank (MFB) (6 April). On 7 May, the sum was raised to HUF 2500 billion, with a 90% government guarantee. HUN 439 billion in credit lines are available through the MFB Crisis Loan programme, the MFB Competitiveness Loan Programme, and the SME Technology Loan Programme (6 April).

- The MFB Crisis Loan programme provides small
- and medium sized enterprises loans between HUF 1 million and HUF 150 million at a 2.5% annual interest rate.

- The MFB Competitiveness Loan programme offers loans for large companies and finances major investments, loan refinancing, and acquisitions.

- The SME Technology Loan Programme provides loans for SMEs at 0% interest rate.

- HUF 371 billion are allocated to four capital programmes that target start-ups, SMEs and real-estate, including the SME Rescue Capital and the Startup Rescue Capital Programme.

- Short-term loans to businesses have been extended to 30 June.

- Széchenyi Job Retention Loans: Firms can apply for a 2-year Job Maintenance Loan that will carry a 0.1% interest rate to cover nine-months worth of their payroll. It provides a grace period for interest payments until 31 December 2020, and the repayment of the principal will only have to start after 9 months

- Széchenyi Investment Loans finance investment with a term of 6 to 10 years at an interest rate is 0.5% and a grace period for interest payments until the end of 2020. The principal only needs to be repaid after 24 months.

- Széchenyi Liquidity Loans are working capital loan with a term of 3 years at a fixed interest rate at 0.2% that can be used up to HUF 250 million. A grace periods for interest and principal repayments applies until the end of 2020.
column43:
- Eligible firms can access HUF 2500 billion in emergency credit lines of the Hungarian Development Bank with a 90% government guarantee (7 May).

- HUF 525 billion of these guarantees are reserved for the protection of domestic industries from foreign takeovers.
column46:
- On 4 May, the central bank announced a new government securities purchase programme and a new mortgage bond purchasing programme that targets securities with a maturity exceeding 3 years. Initially, HUF 1,000 billion (2.1% of GDP) are made available for government securities and HUF 300 billion (0.6% of GDP) for mortgage bonds.

- On 20 April, the central bank also announced the Funding for Growth Scheme Go! with HUF 1,000 billion (2.1% of GDP). Together with other lending schemes for banks, this provides a total of HUF 1,500 billion (3.2% of GDP) of lending source for SMEs. The new Scheme will provide refinancing loans to credit institutions at a zero interest rate, and interest to be paid by SMEs will continue to be maximum 2.5 percent. In addition, the length of refinancing loans will be set at 20 years, while the maximum amount of loan will be HUF 20 billion. The loan repayment moratorium was extended to loan repayments within the Funding for Growth Scheme.

- On 7 April, the central bank raised the overnight and one-week collateralised lending rates to 1.85%, while leaving the base rate and one-week deposit rate unchanged at 0.9% and the overnight deposit rate unchanged at -0.05%. The one-week rate will deviate from the base rate upward or downward within the interest rate corridor.

- On 1 April, the central bank introduced a new one-week deposit tender with a rate of 0.9%, significantly above the 0.05% overnight deposit facility, to stem the depreciation of the forint. By 2 April, the central bank provided HUF 655 billion liquidity through tenders.

- On 18 March, the government adopted a loan repayment moratorium for all households and corporate loans up to 31 December 2020. The Hungarian Banking Association estimates interest costs at HUF 450 billion (19 March).

- The central bank also announced a new long-term collateralised lending facility to provide liquidity for government securities markets and mortgage markets. On 7 May, the central bank provided HUF 80 billion (0.2% of GDP) liquidity to banks through collateralised loans, including HUF 20 billion of loans with 3-year maturity, and HUF 60 billion of loans with 5-year maturity, both at a fixed interest rate of 0.9%.
column47: On 1 April, the central bank announced an easing of capital buffers of systematically relevant credit institutions.
column48:
- The government covers 95% of tuition fees for online distance education, training and re-training (15 April).

- The government introduced a 0% interest-bearing loan up to HUF 1 200 000 for adult learning and a HUF 500,000 student loan scheme with a 0% interest rate for university students (15 April).

- Estimated cost of training and education programmes is HUF 65 billion for the period 2020-2022.
column51:
- Rental fees are frozen in the hardest hit sectors. Moreover, evictions and confiscations have been suspended. Since 7 May, landlords cannot end rental contracts without the approval of tenants until the end of the state of emergency.

- From 1 May, retailers cannot unilaterally reduce the supplier purchase price of agricultural and food products.
column54:
- Mergers of companies in strategic sectors will require approval by the Hungarian Innovation and Technology Minister (18 June). Notification of foreign investment is required if the foreign investor acquires at least 10% of stakes, or if ownership held by foreigner investors exceeds 25 per cent. It applies to the following sectors: chemical sector, communications, energy, finance, insurance, trade, transport, and tourism.

- Establishment of a Special Economic Zone (SEZ) in Göd (17 April). Reduction of the investment threshold necessary to create a SEZ to EUR 14, from previously EUR 282 million. Tax revenues from within SEZ will be transferred from the municipality to county government, and country governments can use up to 3% of investment funding as overhead costs.

- Employment regulations have been temporarily amended to allow for teleworking, home office, and different or flexible work hours, while also authorising employers to take the necessary measures in order to inspect the health of employees. Employers and employees may separately agree to other conditions (17 March).

- The government launched a new online business portal for business.

- Administrative procedures for the use and supply of medical products have been simplified.

column14: Arrivals from all countries allowed. Arrivals can either undergo a test and, if negative, can enter the country, or they must self-quarantine for 14 days
column16: Since 4 May secondary schools and universities are open with a maximum of 50 people per class.
column18: Gatherings above 500 people prohibited.
column20: Most restrictions removed
column22: Government announced third phase of support to households and firms
column25: Health professionals working at the front get a one-off bonus
column28: Extension of the short-term work scheme to 31 August (formerly 1 June), with government paying up to 75% of furloughed workers. Additional child benefit on June 1. Several other measures  to support vulnerable groups
column31: Municipalities receive additional grants and can reimburse VAT for construction projects.
column34: Companies whose revenues declined by more than 75% can apply for support of up to 633'000 ISK per month for three months.
column37: Tax deferrals until end 2021.
column40: Non-indexed loans at the Central Bank's key rate (currently 1%) is available to companies subsidised through this package
column43: State guarantee for bridge loans
column46: Key policy rate lowered from 2.75% to 2.25 on March 11, to 1.75% on March 18 and to 1% on May 20.
column47: Countercyclical capital buffer on financial institutions reduced from 2% to 0% and the deposit institutions average reserve requirement from 1% to 0%.
column48: Households can withdraw pension savings up to 12m krona during 15 months

column12:
1 August: Unlock 3 Guidelines open up more activities outside Containment Zones (where strict enforcement of lockdown is prolonged until 31 August), in particular i) restrictions on movement of individuals during night (night curfew) have been removed; ii) Yoga institutes and gymnasiums will be allowed to open from 5 August; vii) The use of Aarogya Setu mobile application will continue to be encouraged.









Ministry of Home Affairs


MHA issues Unlock 3 Guidelines, opens up more activities outside Containment Zones

Strict enforcement of lockdown in Containment Zones till 31st August 2020



Posted On:29 JUL 2020 7:23PM by PIB Delhi



New MHA guidelines

Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA) issued new guidelines today, for opening up of more activities in areas outside the Containment Zones. In Unlock 3, which will come into effect from August 1, 2020, the process of phased re-opening of activities has been extended further. The new guidelines, issued today, are based on feedback received from States and UTs, and extensive consultations held with related Central Ministries and Departments.

Salient features of the new guidelines
*Restrictions on movement of individuals during night (Night curfew) have been removed.
*Yoga institutes and gymnasiums will be allowed to open from August 5, 2020. In this regard, Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) will be issued by the Ministry of Health & Family Welfare (MoHFW) for ensuring social distancing and to contain the spread of COVID-19.
*Independence Day functions will be allowed with social distancing and by following other health protocols, e.g., wearing of masks etc. In this regard instructions issued by MHA on 21.07.2020 shall be followed.
*After extensive consultation with States and UTs, it has been decided that schools, colleges and coaching institutions will remain closed till August 31, 2020.
*International air travel of passengers has been permitted in a limited manner under the Vande Bharat mission. Further opening up will take place in a calibrated manner.
*All activities, except the following, shall be permitted outside containment zones:
i.Metro Rail.
ii.Cinema halls, swimming pools, entertainment parks, theatres, bars, auditoriums, assembly halls and similar places.
iii.Social/ political/ sports/ entertainment/ academic/ cultural/ religious functions and other large congregations.

Dates for opening of these will be decided separately, based on the assessment of the situation.
*Lockdown shall continue to be implemented strictly in the Containment Zones till 31 August, 2020. Containment Zones are required to be carefully demarcated by the State/ UT Governments with a view to contain the spread of COVID-19, after taking into consideration the guidelines issued by MOHFW. Within the containment zones, strict perimeter control shall be maintained and only essential activities allowed.
*These Containment Zones will be notified on the websites of the respective District Collectors and by the States/ UTs and information will also be shared with MOHFW.
*Activities in the Containment Zones shall be monitored strictly by State and UT authorities, and the guidelines relating to containment measure in these zones shall be strictly implemented.
*MOHFW will monitor the proper delineation of Containment Zones and implementation of the containment measures.

States to decide on activities outside Containment Zones

States and UTs, based on their assessment of the situation, may prohibit certain activities outside the Containment zones, or impose such restrictions as deemed necessary. However, there shall be no restriction on inter-State and intra-State movement of persons and goods. No separate permission/ approval/ e-permit will be required for such movements.

National Directives for COVID-19 management

National Directives for COVID-19 management shall continue to be followed throughout the country, with a view to ensure social distancing. Shops will need to maintain adequate physical distancing among customers. MHA will monitor the effective implementation of National Directives.

Protection for vulnerable persons

Vulnerable persons, i.e., persons above 65 years of age, persons with co-morbidities, pregnant women, and children below the age of 10 years, are advised to stay at home, except for meeting essential requirements and for health purposes.

Use of Aarogya Setu

The use of Aarogya Setu mobile application will continue to be encouraged.

Click here to see MHA Order & Guidelines

*****

NW/RK/PK/SS/DDD






(Release ID: 1642115) Visitor Counter : 7076







Read this release in: Tamil, Urdu, Hindi, Marathi, Manipuri, Assamese, Bengali, Gujarati, Odia, Telugu


















































Unlock 3 Guidelines, issued on 29 July and effective 1 August, open up more activities outside Containment Zones (where strict enforcement of lockdown is prolonged until 31 August), in particular i) restrictions on movement of individuals during night (night curfew) have been removed; ii) Yoga institutes and gymnasiums will be allowed to open from 5 August; iii) Independence Day functions will be allowed with social distancing and by following other health protocols, e.g. wearing of masks etc; iv) schools, colleges and coaching institutions will remain closed till 31 August; v) international air travel of passengers has been permitted in a limited manner under the Vande Bharat mission; vi) Metro Rail, Cinema halls, swimming pools, entertainment parks, theatres, bars, auditoriums, assembly halls and social/ political/ sports/ entertainment/ academic/ cultural/ religious functions and other large congregations remain prohibited; vii) The use of Aarogya Setu mobile application will continue to be encouraged.

column12: Large-scale social restrictions are being rolled out. As of 8 June, the two largest cities (Jakarta and Surabaya) started to relax restrictions with transitory sanitary measures in place.
column14: Indonesia bars foreign nationals from transiting through or entering the country since early-April.Domestic travel is largely restricted since end-April but since mid-May, domestic travel has started to ease
column16: Schools are reopening in shifts
column18: In areas with large-scale social restrictions, assembly of more than 5 people are prohibited. Worships places have reopened from 5 June as well as daily and wet markets from 8 June. From 15 June, limited outdoor activies including sports are authorised again.
column20: In zones without large-scale social restrictions, all business are reopening including restaurants; teleworking usage has been reduced. In areas with large-scale social restrictions, all public transportation options must operate with reduced hours and capacity. Non-essential businesses and stores are required to be closed. Restaurants and food stalls are open for takeaway and delivery only; markets and essential business can may open with social distancing. A number of activities are reopening from 15 June, including spas, salons and cultural sites.
column22:
- A first IDR 10.3 trillion (USD 725 million) stimulus package was unveiled the week of Monday 24 February to support consumer spending and tourism; however, it seems to consist mainly of reclassification and front-loading of previous spending commitments.


- a second fiscal stimulus package was announced on 13 March amounting 22.92 trillion IDR.


- a third fiscal stimulus package was announced on 31 March amounting IDR 405.1 trillion


- The government plans to reduce the number of restricted import goods by up to 50 percent on steel producers, and their derivatives, strategic food products (manufacturing industry inputs); horticultural commodities; animals & animal products; medicine, medicinal ingredients & food.


- Presidential Instruction Number 4/2020 issued on 23 March 2020 on Refocusing of Activities, Budget Reallocation, and Public Procurement in response to handle the Covid-19 in Indonesia. It results in reallocation representing IDR 62 trillion for state budget and IDR 72 trillion for village funds
column25:
- On 31 March, the authorities announced an additional budget of IDR 75 trillion for healthcare


- 17.2 trillion rupiah (USD 1.1 bln) of budget reallocated for healthcare (as of 18 March)


- The government purchased 500,000 tests which started to be used from 20 March


- The government developed temporary COVID-19 hospitals, inluding converting four apartment towers of Wisma Atlet Kemayoran in Central Jakarta on 23 March 2020 that will be able to accommodate up to 22,000 COVID-19 patients


- The second package includes incentives for medical staff dealing with covid-19 (IDR 15 million to medical specialists, IDR 10 million to physicians and dentists, IDR 7.5 million to nurses and IDR 5 million to other medical staff members; IDR 300 million in case of death of a medical worker) for a budget of IDR 6.1 trillion
column28:
- Key dispositions of the second fiscal package include exempting from income tax for six months manufacturing workers with annual income below IDR 200 million (budget of IDR 8.6 trillion)


- Incentives for medical staff dealing with covid-19 (IDR 15 million to medical specialists, IDR 10 million to physicians and dentists, IDR 7.5 million to nurses and IDR 5 million to other medical staff members; IDR 300 million in case of death of a medical worker) for a budget of IDR 6.1 trillion


- Provide housing interest subsidies for the bottom 40% (budget of IDR 1.5 trillion)


- Adding possible beneficieries and increase the number of basic food cards from 150,000 IDR to 200,000 IDR for six months (budget of IDR 4.6 trillion)


- the third fiscal package includes IDR 110 trillion for social protection (including food assistance and electricity discounts and waivers for 10 million households). In particular, more than 3 million people in Great Jakarta will receive from 20 April a staple food package every week worth IDR150,000. A staple food package worth IDR600,000 will be provided for laid-off workers in Jakarta. In addition, the government will give a monthly cash transfer of IDR600,000 for three months for each underprivileged families that do not participate to the Family Hope Programme and do not receive staple food packages.
column31:
- In the third fiscal package, it was announced that the corporate income tax will be reduced by 3 percentage points to 22% over 2020-21 and to 2% starting in 2022. IDR 70 trillion will be used for tax incentives and SMEs support.


- The second package exempts from income tax for six months manufacturing workers with annual income below IDR 200 million (budget of IDR 8.6 trillion) and includes reducing corporate tax payments for manufacturing companies (IDR 12.5 trillion).


- The first fiscal stimulus provide flight ticket incentive to 10 tourism destinations as well as taxincentive to hotels and restaurants
column34: Financing and credit restructuring for SMEs
column37: The second fiscal package includes easier repayment for overpaid taxes (IDR 2 trillion)
column40: The Finance Minister detailed on 18 May a IDR 150 trillion intervention, which includes direct support to some SOEs (via investment in working capital and accelerated compensation payments) and indirect support (IDR 35 trillion) to business channelled through certain banks which will receive public funds to provide loan restructuring and additional loans. Garuda Indonesia, Krakatau Steel, Bulog, PLN and Pertamina are the current beneficiaries of direct support. The package was increased to 290 trillion on 17 June.

- on 18 June, BI lowered its benchmark rate, the seven-day reverse repurchase rate, by 25 basis points to 4.25%, the lowest level since 2018


- On 19 March, BI decreased the policy rate by 25 basis points


- Early March BI stepped up interventions to stabilize the rupiah in the domestic non-deliverable forward (DNDF) and spot markets, as well as purchase of government bonds (SBN) on the secondary market.


- BI Increase the frequency of FX swap auctions for 1, 3, 6 and 12-month tenors from three times per week to daily auctions in order to ensure adequate liquidity, effective from 19 March.


- On 20 February, BI cuts its policy rate by 25 basis points to 4.75% for the seven-day reverse repo rate.
column47:
- On 14 April BI cut the reserve requirement ratio by 200 basis points for conventional banks and 50 basis points for islamic banks (effective from 1 May). BI also raised the macroprudential liquidity buffer ratio by 200 basis points for conventional banks and 50 basis points for islamic banks; to be fulfilled only via government bonds purchased in the primary market.


- BI announced on March 9 five measures to stabilize the rupiah, including cutting the USD reserve requirement ratio (RRR) to 4% from 8% and the rupiah RRR by 50 basis points, starting April 1 (only for banks with clients engaged in export and import activities).

column12:
As of Monday 29th June, Ireland is in Phase 3 of reopening. People can now travel anywhere in the country. Gatherings of 50 people indoors and 200 people outdoors are permitted if conducted in line with public health advice. All retail stores can reopen. Museums, galleries, theatres, concert halls, cinemas and places of worship have also opened, along wth adult education facilities, creches, childminding facilities, pre-schools and parks. Those aged over 70 are still being urged to stay at home as much as they can.
The government announced new restrictions effective from midnight on 8 August for three counties where localised clusters of cases had been identified. Residents of Kildare, Laois and Offaly must now restrict their movements to their own county except for work. Restaurants, pubs, galleries, theatres and cinemas that had reopened since the initial confinement in these areas are once again required to close. New limits have been placed on gatherings (indoor gatherings capped at six people) and contact sports must cease. The new confinement measures are expected to last for two weeks.
column14: There are no entry restrictions to Irish airports and ports. Anyone coming into Ireland, apart from Northern Ireland, will be required to either restrict their movements or self-isolate on arrival for 14 days. This includes Irish residents. There is now a requirement for entrants to complete a form that provides information about where the individual will be self-isolating. Essential supply chain services such as hauliers, pilots and maritime staff are exempt.
column16: Since 12 March, schools have been closed. As of Monday 29th June, adult education facilities, creches, childminding facilities and pre-schools have reopened.
column18: As of Monday 29th June, Ireland is in Phase 3 of reopening. Gatherings of 50 people indoors and 200 people outdoors are permitted if conducted in line with public health advice. Indoor swimming pools, gyms and team sports for children have also recommenced operations.
column20: As of Monday 29th June, Ireland is in Phase 3 of reopening. All retail stores can now reopen. Pubs and hotel bars operating as restaurants, as well as cafés and restaurants providing on premises food and beverages can reopen.
column22: The Government has announced various new policy measures in response to the Covid-19 pandemic. There was €2.4 billion additional spending announced for illness benefit payments announced on 9 March, as well as a further €3.7 billion announced on 24 March to cover the cost of a new Wage Subsidy Scheme. There has also been an increase in unemployment payments and supports for business.
column25:
The Irish health system was already experiencing significant challenges at the onset of the COVID-19 outbreak, but a number of measures are being put in place to support the delivery of health services at this critical time. These include agreement with GPs to ensure that cost is not a barrier to accessing services, the utilisation of private hospital capacity, and an expansion in both acute and community capacity.
The Government has allocated extra funding to the Health Service Executive for improving capacity in the health service, including using private hospital capacity, increasing staffing and overtime, developing home testing and remote management solutions for mildly ill patients and pushing community awareness and preventive actions. The package will also be used to promote greater use of technology and telephone support. Further health-related measures of a similar financial scale are under active consideration.
column28:
A package of sick pay and illness/supplementary benefits has been introduced to ensure that employees and the self-employed can abide by medical advice to self-isolate where appropriate, while having their income better protected than under current social welfare rules. For example, the government has waived the requirement for six waiting days for sick pay in respect of medically certified cases of self-isolation in accordance with public health guidelines and has removed the means test requirement for Supplementary Welfare Allowance in respect of medically certified cases of self-isolation.

There have also been measures announced to try and encourage businesses to keep workers in employment and to support those who have lost their jobs. On 24 March, the government announced the Temporary Wage Subsidy Scheme, providing 70% of take home pay up to a maximum weekly tax free amount of EUR 410 per week to help affected companies keep paying their employees. On 15 April, the changes were made to the design of the policy, including an increase in the subsidy from 70% to 85% of previous net weekly pay for those employees with previous average net pay up to €412 per week. On 23 June, the Minister of Finance confirmed that the scheme would be expanded to cover the salaries of apprentices that were engaged in a period of block release training in February.

As part of the July Stimulus Plan, published on 24 July 2020, the government announced that the Temporary Wage Subsidy Scheme would be replaced by the Employment Wage Subsidy Scheme from the 1st of September 2020 (subject to Oireachtas approval). The new measure will provide businesses a per-head subsidy on a flat rate basis and is scheduled to be in place until the end of March 2021 at a gross cost of €2.35 billion (0.7% of 2019 GDP). The Employment Wage Subsidy Scheme will be open to firms in all sectors, conditional on them operating at no more than 70% turnover in the period July to December 2020 compared to the same period last year.

Additional measures that have been announced for individuals and households include: i) workers who have lost their jobs due to the crisis will receive an enhanced emergency COVID-19 Pandemic Unemployment Payment of EUR 350 per week (an increase from EUR 203 per week); ii) the COVID-19 Illness Payment will be increased to EUR 350 per week; iii) the self-employed will be eligible for the COVID-19 Pandemic Unemployment Payment of EUR 350 directly from the Department of Employment Affairs and Social Protection. On 24 July, the government also announced (subject to Oireachtas approval) that self-employed individuals can off-set up to €25,000 worth of 2020 losses (and certain unused capital allowances) against 2019 profits. This is designed to benefit those self-employed that were profitable in 2019, but suffered revenue losses in 2020 due to the COVID-19 outbreak.
column31: On 24 July, the government announced that, subject to approval by the Oireachtas, the standard VAT rate will be decreased from 23% to 21% for the period 1 September 2020 to 28 February 2021. Across 2020 and 2021, this measure is estimated to cost EUR440 million (0.1% of 2019 GDP).
column34: Various supports to firms have been announced including: i) a €200 million Rescue and Restructuring Scheme available through Enterprise Ireland for vulnerable but viable firms; ii) Local Enterprise Offices in every county will be providing vouchers from €2,500 up to €10,000; iii) a Finance in Focus grant of €7,200 will be available to Enterprise Ireland and Údarás na Gaeltachta clients.
column37:
There have been a variety of taxation measures announced to alleviate short-term difficulties. For example; i) interest on late payments has been suspended for January/February VAT and both February and March PAYE (Employers) liabilities; ii) all debt enforcement activity is suspended until further notice; iii) current tax clearance status will remain in place for all businesses over the coming months; iv) the Relevant Contract Tax rate review scheduled to take place this month (March) is suspended; v) critical pharmaceutical products and medicines will be given a Customs 'green routing' to facilitate uninterrupted importation and supply.
On 2 May, the government announced additional measures, including: i) A commercial rates waiver for impacted businesses (on 27 May, the government proposed extending the waiver for 6 months in addition to the original 3 month waiver), ii) The 'warehousing' of tax liabilities for a period of twelve months after recommencement of trading during which time there will be no debt enforcement action taken by Revenue and no interest charge accruing in respect of the warehoused debt, iii) A commitment to local authorities to make up the rates shortfall, so that local authorities can continue provide full services to the public.
On 27 July, the government announced (subject to Oireachtas approval) accelerated repayments of corporation tax to businesses that would otherwise become due over the next 18 months. The maximum amount of the expected current year loss which will qualify for early carry-back will be 50%.
column40:
At the onset of restrictions, the government announced various such measures to support firms, including i) a €200 million Strategic Banking Corporation of Ireland Working Capital scheme; ii) the Microfinance Ireland COVID-19 Loan (the maximum amount of which has been doubled from €25,000 to €50,000) includes an option for a moratorium on interest and repayments for the first six months;
On 2 May, the government announced further measures that included: i) A €10,000 restart grant for micro and small businesses based on a rates/waiver rebate from 2019; ii) A €2 billion Pandemic Stabilisation and Recovery Fund within the Ireland Strategic Investment Fund (ISIF), which will make capital available to medium and large enterprises on commercial terms; iii) A €2 billion COVID-19 Credit Guarantee Scheme to support lending to SMEs for terms ranging from 3 months to 6 years, which will be below market interest rates;
column43: Information not available
column46: The ECB has committed to “do everything necessary within its mandate” to support the economy through this shock. To preserve bank lending and liquidity, the ECB will temporarily conduct additional longer-term refinancing operations (LTROs) and lower the interest rate applied in targeted longer-term refinancing operations (TLTRO III). On the supervisory front, the ECB has temporarily lowered bank capital requirements and introduced flexibility regarding the treatment of non-performing loans. Furthermore, the ECB has expanded its asset purchase programme by an overall EUR 870 billion (7.3% of euro area GDP) until the end of 2020, while opening the door to freeing its self-imposed limits. More details and additional measures are presented in the EU note.
column47: The Central Bank has cut the Counter Cyclical Capital Buffer from 1% to 0%. This decision will free up bank capital that can be used to provide credit, and to restructure and extend the loans of bank customers, both individuals and SMEs.
column48:
The government is also introducing legislation to prevent both the termination of residential tenancies and any rent increases for the duration of the COVID-19 crisis. Furthermore, the Commission for Regulation of Utilities has issued a moratorium on disconnections of domestic customers for non-payment to the gas and electricity suppliers.
On 24 July, the government announced (subject to Oireachtas approval) the Stay and Spend Scheme. The measure will incentivise taxpayers to support domestic hospitality providers by giving an income tax credit of €125 per taxpayer, or up to €250 for a jointly-assessed married couple once the couple submits receipts showing spending on qualifying expenditure of up to €625. The scheme is scheduled to run between 1st October 2020 and 30 April 2021.
column54: As part of the July Stimulus Plan announced on 24 July 2020, the government proposed extending the Help-to-buy scheme for the remainder of 2020 so that the level of support available to first time buyers will be increased to the lesser of €30,000 (up from €20,000 under the existing scheme) or 10 per cent (up from 5 per cent).

column12:
From 8 September a nightly curfew is imposed on cities with high infection rates (red areas).
'On 31 August the government approved a "traffic light" system, according to which different restrictions will be imposed on localities according to their infection rates. The new system will come into effect on 6 September.
column14:
On 31 August the list of countries from which returning Israelis no longer have to quarantine was extended to 30 (from 20 on 16 August). Foreigners are still largely barred from entering the country.
.
column16:
On 1 September all scholls opened for the new school year except in localities classified as red areas (highest infection rates).
' The educational system was largely reopened in May before the summer break.
column18: From 6 September restrictions differ according a traffic light system. In red areas (highest infection rates) indoor gatherings are capped at 10 people and outdoor gatherings at 20 people. In green areas (lowest infections rates) up to 250 people are allowed at outdoor gatherings (or 80% of maximum occupancy) and 100 people in indoor gatherings (or 60% of maximum occupancy).
column20: * Event halls allowed to open from 6 September with strict health and distancing restrictions in localities with low infection rates (green areas). Night clubs, bars remain closed.
column22:
* On 29 July parliament approved another aid package in particular to extend unemployment benefits and grants and loan guarantees to SMEs. Around NIS 50 billion are budgetary measures and NIS 30 billion are off-balance liquidity measures. Parliament also approved one-time payments to adults and families with children, excluding high-income earners (around NIS 6.7 billion)
'
* On 16 June the parliament approved grants to firms that rehire laid-off workers (around NIS 5.5 billion)
'
* On 2 June the parliament approved the expansion of the aid package from NIS 80 billion (approved 8 April) to NIS 100 billion. Around NIS 65 billion are spending and revenue measures, while NIS 35 billion loan guarantees and payment deferrals.
column25: NIS 10 billion allocated  (30 March) to increase health sector capacity, including for the procurement of protective gear, medicine and respirators, to increase the number of hospital beds for corona virus patients and the number of tests for the virus. An additional 1 billion is allocated for civil needs (police, food security, vaccine research)
column28:
* Eligibility to unemployment benefits was extended and broadened including for furlough workers (29 July): benefits will be paid in full until June 2021 or until unemployment falls below 10%. If unemployment falls between 7.5%-10%, benefits are reduced to 90% and if unemployment falls below 7.5% benefits will be paid for another month. Eligibility after 6 instead of 12 months of employment in the last 18 months.
'
* Extension of payments of up to NIS 4000 per month for people aged 67 and above until June 2021 (29 July)
'
* One-time payment for every resident (over the age of 18 and with income below NIS 651 000) of NIS 750, an additional grant of NIS 500 for each child up to the fourth child, and a grant of NIS 300 for each additional child (29 July).
'
* One time NIS 500 grant for each child up to fourth child per family, elderly people and people with disabilities (7 April)
column31:
* Extension of property tax reimbursement: property taxes will be reimbursed until June 2021 for SMEs (turnover up to NIS 100 million) that have experienced a decrease of turnover of at least 60% (29 July).
'
* Tax exemption on the capital withdrawal up to NIS 7500 from advanced study funds for 6 months, for individuals that suffered income losses (29 July).
'
* The purchase tax rates on buying a second or further home has been cut (29 July).
column34:
* Social assistance grant to self-employed and controlling shareholders with an annual taxable income of up to NIS 651,000, whose sales turnover fell by more than 40%. These self-employed people will receive a 70% grant of taxable income up to NIS 15,000 every two months, until the end of June 2021 (29 July).
'
* Business assistance grants for business and self-employed with turnover up to NIS 400 million that have experienced turnover decrease of at least 40%, payable every two months until June 2021 (29 July): For small firms (turnover < NIS 300 000) grants between NIS 3000-6000. Firms with turnover 300000-100 million and at least 40% turnover decline receive grant for reimbursement of fixed expenses up to NIS 500 000. Firms with turnover 100-200 million and at least 60% turnover decline receive grant for reimbursement of fixed expenses up to NIS 500 000. Firms with turnover 200-400 million and at least 80% turnover decline receive grant for reimbursement of fixed expenses up to NIS 500 000.
'
* Grant for small new businesses established between Jan-Feb 2020 up to NIS 4000, payable every two months until June 2021 (29 July)
'
* On 16 June parliament approved a grant of NIS 7500 for businesses for each employee with a minimum monthly salary of NIS 3300 that they rehire from 1 June, payed in four monthly installments.
'
* Grant for small businesses (up to NIS 20 million turnover) up to NIS 400 000 to cover fixed expenses (24 April).

* Grant to self-employed (24 April): A grant of 70% of the average monthly taxable income up to NIS 10 500 in April and May for the self-employed that experience a 25% decrease in activity
column37: * Tax and payment deferrals (NIS 9 billion). Payment of VAT, municipal taxes, social security contributions, utility payments, government fees have been deferred for SMEs until the end of April.
column40: Information not available
column43:
* Loan guarantees for SMEs. Expansion of the loan fund for SMEs from NIS 22 billion to NIS 50 billion (29 July)

* Loan guarantee fund for large firms: NIS 6 billion loan fund businesses for firms with annual revenue turnover over NIS 200 million.
column46:
* On 6 July the central bank announced to buy corporate bonds in the secondary market of up to NIS 15 billion

* On 6 July the central bank announced that it will renew its programme to provide the banking system with fixed-rate loans at 0.1% interest rate, for a term of 3 years, with the goal of increasing the supply of bank credit to small businesses. There are mo limitation on the total amount of the loans, and it will be in operation until further notice
'
* On 6 April the central bank lowered the policy rate from 0.25% to 0.1%

* On 23 March the central bank announced the start of purchases of government bonds of various types and maturities in the secondary market totalling NIS 50 billion (3.5% of GDP).

* Since 15 March, the Bank of Israel is offering banks repo transactions with government bonds (and corporate bonds as of 6 April) as collateral of an undisclosed amount.

* The Bank of Israel is also offering domestic banks one-week US dollar swap transactions of a total volume of up to NIS 15 billion (18 March).
column47:
* Regulatory capital requirements for banks were lowered by 1 percentage points (29 March).

* The Bank of Israel introduced (15 March) a number of regulatory leniencies for the banking sectors such as higher loan-to-value ratios of all-purpose household credits backed by a residence, allowing banks to increase credit facilities (overdrafts) to customers, and increasing limits in the banks' loan portfolios for credits to the construction and real estate industry.
column48: * Mortgage payment deferral: The Ministry of Finance instructed banks to allow for a 4-month postponement of mortgage payments (15 March)
column54: * Licenses (e.g. business, import, enviromnmental) are automatically extended until June 2021 (13 July)

column12: Effective May 4, restrictions relaxed, with greater freedom to move around residences and commercial areas, and to move between regions.
column14:
2 Jul: Italy maintains restrictions on non-European and non-Schengen arrivals.
2 Jun: Domestic movement restrictions lifted. Italian residents no longer face quarantine restrictions when returning to Italy. Non-residents from EU, UK, other Schengen area countries, Andorra, Monaco, San Marino and the Vatican City may enter Italy without quarantine.
17 Mar: Non European arrivals forbidden except for prescribed, essential reasons.
column16: 13 May: Schools to remain closed until September.
column18:
25 May: Additional re-openings, including swimming pools and gyms
'2 May: Smaller groups may assemble. For example, funerals permitted with a maximum of 15 attending. Bars and restaurants may offer take away, and many other retail trade activities may reopen (e.g. shopping centres; indoor and outdoor markets). Larger events and venues, sports events remain closed.
'11 Mar: All public events and venues closed.
column20: Industrial and construction activity allowed to restart. Wider range of shops and commercial services allowed to reopen, provided sanitary precautions are implemented.
column22: EUR 25 billion of measures, including EUR 20 billion of net debt measures. '1) EUR 3.2 bn for health care and civil protection; 2) EUR 10.3 bn for employment and incomes; 3) EUR 5.1 bn support to raise liquidity for businesses and households; 4) EUR 1.6 bn tax payment support.
column25:
EUR 3.2 billion for the national health service and to support civil protection. Within this package:

- EUR 1.4 bn to raise funding for the health care system for 2020, including EUR 845 m to recruit 20 000 more health workers.

- Ease burden of hospitals: dedicate entire facilities to patients infected with Covid-19, while redirected non-infected patients for other facilities.

- Increased cleaning of public transportation facilities, such as metro transit, buses, boats.

- Measures to increase purchases and production of medical materials (masks, ventilation machines)

- Repurposing of medical equipment and buildings (e.g. hotels) for the medical emergency.

- The production of face masks is incentivised

- Retired medical personnel are encouraged to come back to work

- Smart working has been extensively favoured, both in the private and in the public sector.
column28:
Over EUR 10 bn allocated:

- EUR 5.0 bn to strengthen the wage supplementation scheme for furloughed employees, and increase to a last-resort fund for workers not qualifying for these measures. This includes about EUR 1.3 bn for ordinary wage supplementation schemes, EUR 300 m for wage supplementation schemes to firms that already participate in the “cassa integrazione guadagni straordinaria” supplementation scheme, and EUR 3.3 bn for firms already that already participate in of the “cassa integrazione in deroga”. A Last Resort scheme is established for workers not qualifying (EUR 300 m).

- EUR 2.3 bn for one-off EUR 600 payment to various categories of self-employed and seasonal workers. A Last Resort scheme has been established for those not qualifying.

- EUR 400 m for one-year suspension in the repayment of real estate mortgages by workers having lost their job.

- Allowance of EUR 500 per month for up to 3 months for self-employed workers in the municipalities most affected.

- EUR 1.3 bn to strengthen childcare support for children up to 12 years old (15 extra days at a 50% wage replacement rate, compared with 0% or 30% of the ordinary leave) or, alternatively, a EUR 600 transfer to pay childcare services.

- EUR 30 m for EUR 1000 childcare payment to employees in the healthcare and law enforcement sectors.

- EUR 0.5 bn to raise by 12 days the paid leave for disabled workers and workers caring for a disabled relative.

- EUR 130 m to extend sick leave to cover days spent in quarantine.

- EUR 900 m for a EUR 100 one-off bonus to workers who continued to work at their workplace.

- Moratorium on debt payments, including mortgages.
column31: EUR 540 m for 60% tax credit on commercial rents.
column34:
- Increase to EUR 1.7 bn for the Fund to provide fee-free guarantee for SMEs loans. Eligibility has been enlarged, admission fees and costs reduced. Private individuals can contribute to the SMEs Fund's financing. Maximum guarantees raised from EUR 2.5 m to EUR 5 m.

- Further guarantees for firms most affected by the virus. Facilitate guarantees for self-employed workers, freelancers and individual entrepreneurs.

- Suspension of 6 months (until end of September) of loan repayment by SMEs.

- State guarantee for up to EUR 10 bn in new loans for medium-large firms.
column37:
- EUR 540 m for 60% tax credit on commercial rents.

- EUR 50 m for incentives to firms to sanitise workplaces.

- Suspension for 2 months of tax and social security payments in the municipalities most affected.

- For firms with an annual turnover below EUR 2 m, suspension of all the tax and social security payments coming due in March (valued at EUR 10 bn in deferred payments).

- Non-application of withholding tax for professionals without employees, with revenues below EUR 400 000 until 31 May 2020.

- Suspension of collection of tax collection files (valued at EUR 0.6 bn).

- EUR 50 m allocation for one-year suspension in repayment of loans to Invitalia to support SMEs in the most affected municipalities.

- Suspension of 2 months (until end of April) in the payment of the electricity, gas, water and waste bills in the most affected municipalities.

- Increase to EUR 1.7 bn for the Fund to provide fee-free guarantee for SMEs loans. Eligibility has been enlarged, admission fees and costs reduced. Private individuals can contribute to the SMEs Fund's financing. Maximum guarantees raised from EUR 2.5 m to EUR 5 m.

- Further guarantees for firms most affected by the virus. Facilitate guarantees for self-employed workers, freelancers and individual entrepreneurs.

- Suspension of 6 months (until end of September) of loan repayment by SMEs.

- State guarantee for up to EUR 10 bn in new loans for medium-large firms.

- EUR 500 m to support exporting firms.

- Incentive to sell impaired loans (NPLs) by converting deferred tax assets (DTA) into tax credits for financial and industrial companies.

- Establishment of a Fund to support the cultural sector. Increase in advances from the 2014-2020 Development and Cohesion Fund.
column40: Information not available
column43:
- Increase to EUR 1.7 bn for the Fund to provide fee-free guarantee for SMEs loans. Eligibility has been enlarged, admission fees and costs reduced. Private individuals can contribute to the SMEs Fund's financing. Maximum guarantees raised from EUR 2.5 m to EUR 5 m.

- Further guarantees for firms most affected by the virus. Facilitate guarantees for self-employed workers, freelancers and individual entrepreneurs.

- Suspension of 6 months (until end of September) of loan repayment by SMEs.

- State guarantee for up to EUR 10 bn in new loans for medium-large firms.
column46: Information not available
column47: Less significant banks and non-bank intermediaries are allowed to operate temporarily below the level of the Pillar 2 Guidance, the capital conservation buffer and the liquidity coverage ratio. Their deadline to submit their revised NPL reduction plans is postponed to 30 June. Other reporting and inspection deadlines are delayed.
column48:
- EUR 400 m for one-year suspension in the repayment of real estate mortgages by workers having lost their job.

- Moratorium on debt payments, including mortgages.
column54: Information not available

column12:
- On 7 April, the Prime Minister declared a state of emergency based on the Act on Special Measures for Pandemic Influenza and New Infectious Diseases Preparedness and Response, covering the most affected 7 prefectures (Tokyo, Kanagawa, Saitama, Chiba, Osaka, Hyogo and Fukuoka). The Prefectural Governors in the emergency zone issued stay-at-home requests to the local residents.


- On 16 April, all other 40 prefectures were covered by the state-of-emergency declaration. 13 prefectures including the originally covered 7 prefectures were designated as the special caution zones, where containment measures should be focused.


- On 4 May, state of emergency, which was intended to expire on 6 May, was extended to 31 May.


- State of emergency was lifted for 39 prefectures on 14 May, then for 3 prefectures including Osaka on 21 May, and for the rest of the 5 prefectures including Tokyo on 25 May. Requests for refraining from inter-prefectural travel were mostly lifted by 31 May, but will still be maintained until 18 June for several heavily affected areas including Tokyo.


- Requests for voluntary ban on inter-prefectural travel is completely lifted on 19 June.


- On 25 July, the government launched "Go To Travel Campaign" with JPY 1.7 trillion (0.3% of GDP) of the budget, which promotes domestic tourism by subsidising up to half of travel expenses. Taking into account the resurgence of the confirmed cases, arrivals and departures in and from Tokyo were excluded.


- On 26 July, the Minister for Economic and Fiscal Policy and Economic Revitalisation asked companies to perform 70% of the office work by teleworking, and encourage flexible working styles including staggered commuting.
column14:
- Starting with Hubei Province of China on 1 February, refusal of entry has been extended by mid-March to cover the most affected areas in risk countries. 14-day quarantines have been enforced for entrants from China and Korea outside the most affected areas on 9 March, followed by extensions to other areas including Europe, Egypt and the United States. Refusal of entry was expanded in early April to cover 87 countries and areas.

[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MoFA)'s Travel Advice and Warning on Infectious Diseases]
MOFA has issued a series of Travel Advice and Warnings on Infectious Diseases depending on the situation of the Novel Coronavirus. This warning system has the following 4 categories:

- Level 4, Evacuate and Avoid All Travel; Japanese nationals are urged to evacuate immediately from the country/area and avoid all travel regardless of the purpose.

- Level 3, Avoid All Travel; Japanese nationals are urged to avoid all travel to the country/area regardless of the purpose. Japanese residents in the country/area may be advised to consider or prepare for the evacuation: 87 countries and areas including China, the Republic of Korea, the United States, Canada, Australia, New Zealand, 44 European countries and areas and Iran.

- Level 2, Avoid Non-essential Travel; Japanese nationals are advised to avoid non-essential travel to the country/area, and to stay alert to the situation and take appropriate safety measures should they decide to travel: All over the world.

[MOFA's Travel Advice and Warning]
MOFA has also issued MOFA's Travel Advice and Warnings.

- Level 2, Avoid Non-essential travel l; Japanese nationals are advised to avoid non-essential travel, and to stay alert to the security situation and to take appropriate safety measures should they decide to travel: All over the world.
column16:
- On 28 February 2020, the Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology (MEXT) asked elementary schools, junior high schools, senior high schools, schools for special needs education and upper secondary specialized training schools to be temporary closed from March 2nd to the spring break season beginning in late March.


- Based on instructions or requests by the Governors, public schools in the 7 prefectures originally covered by the state-of-emergency declaration decided to close until 6 May.


- Following the lift of state of emergency on 25 May, public schools were reopened nationwide from June. Staggered school hours and/or hybrid of physical and online schooling are adopted in some heavily affected areas.
column18:
- On 26 February, the government asked large scale events and gatherings to be cancelled, postponed, or scale down for two weeks.


- The government asked for continuing to postpone or scale down large-scale events until late March.


- The state-of-emergency declaration under the law enabled prefectural Governors to ask cencelling large scale events and getherings in their jurisdictions.


- Following the lift of state of emergency, prefectural governments plan to gradually ease restrictions on large-scale events in coming months, mostly beginning from June.


- On 10 July, the government lifted the request for cancelling events with up to 5,000 participants. Professional baseball and soccer game stadiums started to invite audience subject to the upper limit.


- On 22 July, the government pushed back the schedule of lifting the capacity limit on large-scale events and gatherings to 1 September from originally scheduled 1 August.


- On 24 August, the government further pushed back the schedule of lifting the capacity limit on large-scale events and gatherings to 1 October.
column20:
- Governors in the 7 prefectures originally covered by the state-of-emergency declaration asked nonessential businesses to close until 6 May. Following the extention of state of emergency, requests for closures for nonessential businesses were also extended in many prefectures.


- Following the lift of state of emergency, local governments announced their plans to gradually ease restrictions on economic and social activity.
column22:
- On 7 April, the government launched the Emergency Economic Measures of JPY 117 trillion (21.7% of GDP), which adds another JPY 38 trillion of public spending.


- On 20 April, the Cabinet decided the FY 2020 supplementary budget of JPY 25.7 trillion to finance the Emergency Economic Measures. The National Diet approved the budget on 30 April.


- On 27 May, the Cabinet decided the FY 2020 second supplementary budget of JPY 31.9 trillion.
column25:
- On 28 January, the Cabinet issued a decree to list COVID-19 as a disease that the Infectious Disease Act and the Quarantine Act apply. With the decree enforced on 1 February, the authority can order the patients about forced hospitalisation and restrictions on work, mandate immigrations to take laboratory tests, and provide medical care with the costs shouldered by the government.


- On 14 February, the government decided the use of the contingent funds included in the FY 2019 budget to finance a package of immediate measures including increasing the testing capacity, subsidising production of masks and antiseptic solutions, and promoting development of therapeutic drug.


- On 17 February the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare (MHLW) asked people with cold symptoms, a fever 37.5 Celsius degree or over, a strong feeling of weariness or shortness of breath to isolate themselves at home and wait four days before contacting a doctor.


- The Basic Policy announced on 25 February prioritised the provision of medical service to vulnerable people such as the elderly and those with underlying diseases.


- The second measures launched on 10 March included measures for containment in childcare and long-term care facilities, support for the supply of masks, expansion of PCR testing and medical care capacity and development of therapeutic drug.


- 7 April measures and the first and second supplementary budgets for FY 2020 further increased health spending.


- On 28 August, the government launched a new package of health measures, which are to be financed by the contingency fund included in the FY 2020 supplementary budget. The measures cover: 1) an significant increase of the PCR tesiting capacity by the end of 2020; 2) universal supply of vaccines for all residents by mid-2021; 3) support for local governments' efforts in expanding medical and health centres capacity.
column28:
- On 14 February, the government eased the qualifications for the Employment Adjustment Subsidy, which provides SMEs and large corporations a financial support that covers 2/3 and 1/2 of the cost of special paid leaves, respectively.


- The second measures launched on 10 March included responses to the temporary school closures, such as support for parents' work leaves due to closure of their children's school, and employment support.


- On 28 March, the government announced to raise the subsidy rates of the Employment Adjustment Subsidy from 2/3 to 9/10 for SMEs and from 1/2 to 3/4, respectively, for those do not dismiss employees between April and June.


- 7 April measures and the FY supplementary budget include:
1) Cash transfer of JPY 12.8 trillion (2.4% of GDP) provided for every resident (JPY 100 thousand (USD 931) per person) and JPY 2 trillion (0.4% of GDP) for small and medium sized business owners who experience a significant fall of their earnings between February and June.
2) Enhancement of the Employment Adjustment Subsidy including raising the sibsidy rates announced on 28 March.


- The FY 2020 second supplementary budget include:
1) Cash tansfer of JPY 136.5 billion (0.02% of GDP) targeted at low-income single-parent households.
2) Further enhancement of the Employment Adjustment Subsidy of JPY 1.3 trillion (0.2% of GDP).
column31: Information not available
column34: 7 April measures include a wide range of subsidies to strengthen the economic structure.
column37:
- On 27 February, the National Tax Agency announced:
1) Deadline extension (from mid-March to mid-April) for tax return filing and payment of personal income tax, gift tax, and consumption tax (for the self-employed):
2) Deferments on tax payments for individuals and businesses negatively impacted by the COVID-19 outbreak on taxpayers' request.

7 April measures include:

- Tax payments and social security charges for businesses negatively impacted by the COVID-19 outbreak can be deferred up to one year.
column40:
- The first prompt measures announced on 13 February included JPY 500 billion (0.1% of GDP) of emergency loans and credit guarantees for SMEs such as the tourism industry.


- The second measures launched on 10 March included financial measures of JPY 1.6 trillion from the Japan Finance Corporation and other institutions, primarily focusing on micro, small and medium-sized business operators. The financial measures included a COVID-19 special loan program which enables unsecured interest-free loans to affected firms. 7 April measures expanded the program up to JPY 45 trillion ()
column43:
- The first prompt measures announced on 13 February included JPY 500 billion (0.1% of GDP) of emergency loans and credit guarantees for SMEs such as the tourism industry.


- The second measures launched on 10 March included financial measures of JPY 1.6 trillion from the Japan Finance Corporation and other institutions, primarily focusing on micro, small and medium-sized business operators. The financial measures included a COVID-19 special loan program which enables unsecured interest-free loans to affected firms. 7 April measures expanded the program up to JPY 45 trillion ()
column46:
- On 2 March, the Governor of the Bank of Japan (BoJ) announced that the Bank would strive to provide ample liquidity and ensure stability in financial markets through appropriate market operations and asset purchases.


- On 16 March, the BoJ decided to enhance monetary easing through three measures: 1) actively purchasing ETFs and J-REITs at annualised paces of up to about JPY 12 trillion (2.2% of GDP) and JPY 180 billion (0.03% of GDP), respectively; 2) facilitating corporate financing through (a) increasing the upper limit to purchase commercial paper and corporate bonds by JPY 2 trillion (0.4% of GDP) in total and (b) introducing a new operation to provide loans against corporate debt as collateral at 0% interest rate with maturity up to one year; and 3) providing further ample funds through various means including purchases of Japanese government bonds (JGBs) and U.S. dollar funds-supplying operations.


- On 27 April, the BoJ decided to enhance monetary easing by lifting annual JGB purchase benchmark of JPY 80 trillion (14.8% of GDP), while tripling the corporate bond and commercial paper purchase facility to JPY 20 trillion (3.7% of GDP). It also eased the collateral requirement for the special operation to provide 0% interest loans, so as to provide the loans up to JPY 23 trillion (4.5% of GDP).


- On 22 May, the BoJ enhanced the special operation to cover business loans provided based on the government's emergency loan programme, or those equivalents in terms of the lending conditions. The size of the new operation is set to be scaled up from JPY 25 trillion (4.5% of GDP) to JPY 55 trillion (10.1% of GDP).
column47: On 17 March, the Financial Service Agency (FSA) issued a public communication that reassures that regulatory capital and liquidity buffers can be used, as needed, to support the businesses affected by the Covid-19 outbreak.
column54: Information not available

column12:
* The government has initiated the second phase of the gradual easing of quarantine imeasures on August 31. Religious sites, sport complexes and halls, cultural places, and national parks and natural reserves were allowed to reopen under specific sanitary measures (space, number, occupancy). However, the regions of Shymkent and Atyrau have extended quarantine, and restricting public transports, and movement in the public space.

* The government has initiated a progressive easing of confinement measures since 17 August. Malls and covered markets could resume their activity with an occupancy rate limited to 30%. Beauty and hairdressing salons as well as outdoor entertainment parks have reopened under sanitary restrictions. Restrictive measures are retained, such as the ban on mass and family events. Bars, cinemas and food courts remain closed. The deconfinement measures only apply during the work week, confinement remaining during weekends. People over 65 can leave their home only for shopping basic necessities.

* According to the Kazakh Healthcare Minister, Kazakhstan has passed the peak of COVID-19 infection during the first week of August.

* On 6 August, the region of Almaty announced it would soften its quarantine requirements. However, the chief state sanitary officer of Nur-Sultan has signed a decree «On the extension of strict restrictive quarantine measures in the city of Nur-Sultan».

* On 29 July, the President asked the government to extend quarantine for additional two weeks until 16 August.

* Since 5 July, the Kazakh government has reintroduced nation-wide lockdown measures and extensions in two-week intervals. Toughening of lockdown restrictions had started the weekend of June 20-21, as the nation witnessed a hike in coronavirus cases after it eased the restrictions and lifted the state of emergency in May. Almaty and Atyrau have reinforced quarantine mesures in their regions.
*The Government requires masks to be worn at all public places, the fine for violation of the rule is KZT 13 890.

* According to the health minister, the recent growth in COVID-19 infections were initally caused by workplace outbreaks.
column14:
* Since August 31, intercity and interregional trains and buses were allowed to resume their activities.

* International flights to seven countries (the UAE, Belarus, Germany, the Netherlands, Egypt, Ukraine and Russia) gradually resumed since 17 August. A second category of countries has been established from which passengers need a COVID-19 test (negative)

* Kazakhstan has partly reopened its border with Kyrgyzstan, but travellers need specific documents stating an imperative motive to be allowed to cross the border.

* Public transport has been reopened with sanitary restrictions.

* Visa procedures have been simplifed for investors via the elicense.kz portal, partly as an attempt to revive FDI attraction in the downward pandemic context.

* Internal flights have resumed and all airports have reopened on 25 May. The new lockdown that started on 5 July did not affect national and international air travel.

* Kazakhstan extended visas for foreigners, stranded in the country amid the state of emergency and other travel bans, until July 10.

* The visa exemption for 56 countries (including EU
- and France) has been suspended until 1 November.
column16:
* On 4 August, the Kazakh Government announced it would distribute 500,000 computers to children from disadvantaged families to be able to start the new academic year online.

* Schools, except for kindergartens, and continuous learning institutions remain closed.

* The Minister of Education and Science announced that the first term of the new school year will be conducted online.

* In Nur-Sultan city all kindergartens, both state and public, suspended operations since 23 June, in accordance with a decision of city's Health Officer Zhanna Praliyeva. Such a decision comes due to the worsening epidemiological situation and reported surge in COVID-19 cases among kindergarten teachers.
column18:
* Quarantine rules were reinforced in all public places since 5 July, gatherings cannot exceed 3 people.

* Masks are required in all public spaces.

* Almaty and Atyrau have prohibited holding meetings, conferences, forums, seminars and other events of mass gatherings.
column20:
* Stores are progressively reopening as the lockdown measures have been partly lifted since 17 August.

* Since 5 July, non-essential stores and leisure activities are shut down in the country.

* Over the weekend of 27 and 28 June, all economic activities (including essential stores), public events, and public places have been shut-down in Nur-Sultan, Almaty, and Atyrau.

* In Almaty, the operation of public catering facilities, with the capacity of more than 30 seats, and in open summer areas with the capacity of more than 50 seats were suspended. In addition, over 500 enterprises are said to have been shut down due to non-compliance with sanitary restrictions.

* Activities in all spheres of work, service and trade, as well as public transport and vehicle traffic in Nur-Sultan were stopped from 10 p.m. on June 19 until midnight on June 22, 2020 (except for the movement to/from a place of residence to/from a workplace; buying food, medicines; visiting medical organizations in case of emergency).

* Local companies have been urged to use teleworking again by the city authorities especially in Nur-Sultan and Almaty.

* Oilfield operations have been closed or decreased on Tengiz site, due to regional outbreaks of the virus. Quarantine at the site hasbeen extended until 26 June.

* Hotels were allowed to reopen on 1 July.

* Small stores were allowed to resume activity, yet with reduced capacity.

* Some enterprises in Nur-Sultan and Almaty have resumed work with strong sanitary and epidemiological measures. By the end of April, industrial enterprises, construction companies and certain service providers were allowed to resume activities, while starting from 4 May non-essential stores and most business activities (eg. real estate and insurance companies, advertising agencies, lawyers and notaries) were allowed to reopen.

* Quotas on exports of key food products (wheat and flour) as well as all other restrictions on food product exports have been lifted on 1 June.
column22:
* The President of Kazakhstan, announced in its "adress to the Nation" on September 1 the re-creation of the Ministry of Emergency Situations, as well as the creation of a new development fund through the merger of Baiterek and Kazagro with a cut of their portfolios of companies by 50%.

* The government is developing a mid-term economic development plan until 2025 that is expected to be released early August with focuses on investment attraction, export, agriculture, and manufacturing.

* A new joint action plan of the government and the National Bank has been prepared to further support the economy. It includes an additional series of support measures on taxation, digitalisation, PPPs, regulations and investment. Additional transfers from the National Fund on social issues and infrastructure development and dividends from SOEs are also foreseen.
