* The government approved the "Comprehensive Economic Growth Recovery Plan" which consists of 10 areas and 172 systemic and sectoral measures to stimulate business activity, support employment and increase incomes. It provides for an expansion of the financing mechanism and concessional lending, including micro-business, and the active use of guarantee and reimbursement of export costs. A new version of the Strategic Development Plan until 2025 will also be presented in July.

* The city of Almaty has also announced on 26 May that it would also implement its own economic recovery plan as the city's economy has been severely hit by the pandemic.

* The government announced a total anti-crisis package excluding tax breaks and local support will amount to KZT 4.4 trillion tenge (roughly USD 10bn or 6-7% of GDP), now increased to 5.9 trillion tenges (circa 8.8% of GDP).

* The government set aside KZT 300 billion Tenge (607 million EUR) for infrastructure spending to create 120 000 jobs, exclusively for Kazakh nationals.

* International financial institutions have provided financial support to the government (Asian Development Bank, World Bank).
column25:
*According to official figures, more than 1.2 thousand health workers received payments from the State Social Insurance Fund in connection with infection with COVID-19 and pneumonia.

* The President of Kazakhstan, announced in its "adress to the Nation" on September 1 a long-term plan to fill national needs in medical jobs.

* Authorities reported that the R0 went down to 0.76 and that the hospital bed occupancy rate has decreased to 26% as of mid-August.
*Authorities have reported on the bed occupancy rate that decrease from 90% to 47% and on the R0 that went down from 1.2 to 0.99 between the beginning and the end of July 2020. Most recent hospital bed occupancy figures seem to be around 35% according to the Minister of Health.

* Kazakhstan has announced the establishment of a National Emergency Stabilization Fund for Essential Medicines that will act as a national pharmaceutical reserve to avoid future shortages.

* Kazakhstan estimated the costs of medical treatments for COVID-19 at KZT 8.5 bn since the pandemic started.

* A new Minister of Health, Alexey Tsoy, was appointed, replacing Yelzhan Birtanov who was diagnosed with COVID-19.

* A draft resolution of the Government of the Republic of Kazakhstan "On approval of the National Plan for the Protection of the Life and Health of Kazakhstanis in a Pandemic" has been prepared providing, among other measures, for an increase of financial means of support and medical centres, the creation of regional medical centres, as well as a broadening of the list of authorized organisations to provide medical support, and the development of online tracing and tracking systems.

* Kazakhstan declared that it spent at least 150 billion tenge (US$367.2 million) on medical equipment and support to health workers in the COVID-19 fight. It is estimated that doctors and medical staff have received more than USD77m in extra payments since the beginning of the outbreak.

* The Minister of Health reported doctor shortages in several regions including Mangistau and Atyrau.

* A new code on Health Public Care has been passed on 7 July and reinforces protection for medical workers against legal prosecution and promotes vaccination.
Estimated capacity is now 43,000 beds for coronavirus patients in hospitals.

* According to the government, the number of people tested daily for COVID-19 testing stands at 28,000 and aims to reach 40,000 shortly.

* Teleconsultation is expanding in Almaty, Nur-Sultan and other cities.

* The chief sanitary inspector of Kazakhstan ordered to integrate the information system of private laboratories into the laboratory information system of the national examination center. She also ordered to introduce the mobile application for remote tracking of people quarantined at home, and people with asymptomatic forms of COVID-19 among them.

* Free medical services from April 1 to July 1 are granted to all Kazakhstan citizens in the framework of the compulsory health insurance.

* Wage premium and bonuses are paid to medical staff (hospitals, ambulances, public agencies).

* Public budget financed the purchase of medical equipment to provent the spread of the pandemic, including protective equipment, laboratory equipment, disinfectants and medical devices.
column28:
* The President of Kazakhstan, announced in its "adress to the Nation" on September 1 the increase of digital payments of social benefits and aids, including renewed bonuses for health workers (KZT 150 bn).

* As of 24 August, the Enbek (Labor) state program, the Employment Roadmap and other similar state programs have provided employment to approximately 743,000 people.

* In connection with the extension of quarantine on the territory of Kazakhstan for 2 weeks, 799.6 thousand recipients of a one-time payment from the State Social Insurance Fund were assigned an additional 0.5 minimum wages (equivalent to KZT 21 500) during the first week of August.

* On 15 July, the government announced a new round of income support payments for an amount of 42 500 tenge. It is estimated that 1.780m people have received this income support since the beginning of the crisis. However, the implementation of the measure so far has been reported to be difficult. In addition, the head of government instructed, as during the state of emergency, to provide financial food assistance to certain categories of the population (more than 1 million people) and social assistance (about 128 thousand families), and automatically extend for three months the period of disability (about 30 thousand people).

* As of June 1, 224,700 people benefitted from the 2017-2021 mass employment and entrepreneurship program Yenbek.

* Kazakhstan has created 196,400 workplaces during the crisis according to the Kazakh Labour and Social Protection Minister, as part of the Employment Roadmap and other state programs, exclusive of Yenbek productive employment and mass entrepreneurship development state program. However, by the end of 2020, unemployment rate in Kazakhstan could increase up to 6.1% says the Minister of Labour and Social Security.

* The Ministry of Labour announced that employers must compensate employees at the minimum wage for the downtime induced by the quarantine.

* According to an official statement, as of 26 May, 4.6 million citizens received the first payment of income support (42 500 tenge).

* The government announced plans to create more than one million jobs this year as part of the new Employment Roadmap state program, as a major measures to secure employment in the post-emergency period. An additional KZT 1 trillion will be allocated to support employment under an “Employment Roadmap” program.

* The National Social Security Fund grants wage subsidies, channelled through firms to employees of MSMEs on unpaid leave (KZT 42 500 tenge a month, or 95 USD), until the end of the emergency situation. As of April 27, this has already benefited 4.25m workers. The payment has been extended to the second month of the quarantine.

* 10% increase in retirement pensions and state benefits.

* Employees who lost jobs due to the confinement will be compensated at 40% of their former salaries for a duration of up to 6 months.

* Children and adults from low-income families receiving Targeted Social Assistance (TSA), disabled people, and parents engaged in caring for a disabled child will receive food baskets. As of April 27, more than 570 000 people receievd food baskets. The food baskets will cover at least 1.1 million citizens.

* The authorities have sent SMS messages to thousands of eligible citizens inviting them to provide the information needed to facilitate their transfers. This is reckoned to be quicker and easier than sending cheques or leaving it to citizens to take the initiative to apply for assistance.

* In April and May, more than 1.6 million people have received assistance to pay utilities bills.
column31:
* The President of Kazakhstan, announced in its "adress to the Nation" on September 1 a revision of the Tax Code introducing a differentiation of tax rates.

* As part of the recovery package, an overhaul of tax policy has been announced: Kazakhstan would abandon a 10% flat tax rate and switch to a progressive personal income tax.

* The current drop in global demand for extractive goods and commodity prices has already forced the government to revise its state budget for 2020, with a planned cut of 1.25bn USD budget spending.

* March, 17: Major retail outlets, cinemas, theatres, sports facilities and other businesses being forced to curtail activities will be exempted from property taxes for one year and interest on loans for one quarter.
column34:
* The creation of a state commission for economic growth rehabilitation has been announced by the President on 27 May.
*A new action plan consisting of 43 additional steps towards supporting business has been elaborated following discussions with entrepreneurs of all regions, as well as the reviews of the State Commission to restore economic growth. The action plan encompasses simplifying the procurement process and increasing Kazakhstani content, broadening funding opportunities to acquire agricultural machinery in leasing and refund credits, and increasing exports.

* Deferral of repayment of loans for businesses and entrepreneurs experiencing liquidity problems can be extended upon request until 15 September.
*Loan portfolio to support business in Kazakhstan amounts to USD2.7 bn by June, according to the Kazakh Ministry of National Economy.

* Firms with a drop in turnover of more than 40% can get cash support to cover part of their fixed costs (up to 80%); full compensation of fixed costs will be provided to firms forced to close temporarily due to the lockdown.

* Public budget rules have been relaxed to encourage frontloading of public consumption and payments to private firms.
column37:
* SMEs remain exempted from contributions to the compulsory health insurance system until October 1.

* On 6 August, the Agency for the Regulation and Development of the Financial Market simplified the procedure for obtaining a deferral of loans for businesses by reducing application requirements and response delays.

* The Agency estimated that 33% of individual borrowers (1.89m people) and 42% of business borrowers (12,000 entities) have been granted a loan repayment deferral between March and June.

* Airports in the Republic of Kazakhstan will be exempt from land tax by the end of the year.

* Deferral of all tax and social payments for SMEs until 1 June.

* VAT rate has been reduced from 12% to 8% until 1 October 2020 for sectors of tourism, catering, hotel business, large retail facilities, shopping centers, cinemas, theaters, exhibitions and sports and fitness facilities, trade entities, with the exception of food and drugstores, transportation services, consulting services and information technology.

* April 27: Tax incentive measures covered more than 270 000 companies and individual entrepreneurs
column40:
* The President of Kazakhstan, announced in its "adress to the Nation" on September 1 the extension of the National Bank programme to replenish SMEs for an amount of KZT 200 bn.

* The Kazakhstan Sustainability Fund reported that businesses received concessional loans with an interest rate not exceeding 8% per year and for a duration up to 12 months as part of the SMEs support program. By now, the banks of Kazakhstan granted loans that amounted to 160 bn tenge (USD 386 mn) to 1,116 SMEs.

* The government announced it would establish an Industry Development Fund providing, among others, investment subsidies for agricultural machinery, reimbursement of transport expenses for up to 80 percent to the manufacturers of high value-added export products, soft loans under the 'Business Road Map 2025, and export loans.

* Banks have been asked to allow loan repayments deferrals until mid-June and refrain from charging penalties for borrowers affected by the emergency.

* April 27: More than 1.6 million citizens and 11 500 SMEs received deferral on loan payments in the amount of 360 billion tenge.
column43: *Subsidized lending is provided under the state program (“Economy of Simple Things”, KZT 1 trillion): the reserve of state-issued credit for the output of staple goods is to rise from KZT600bn ($1.5 billion) to KZT1trn. Interest on that credit is being cut from 13-15% to 6%.
column46:
* The National Bank is developing a 2030 Monetary Policy Strategy to improve the efficiency of the monetary policy and stabilize the foreign exchange market. In addition, the NBK and the government announced the introduction of additional measures “to return foreign exchange earnings to the country and to create favorable conditions for its implementation by exporters.” The NBK will also create a Monetary Policy Committee as part of this strategy.

* 20 July: The Central Bank reduced the base rate to 9.00% per annum with a narrowing of the interest rate corridor to +/
- 1.5 percentage points. Accordingly, the rate on permanent access operations to provide liquidity will be 10.5% and on permanent access operations to withdraw liquidity 7.5%.

* 17 July: The government and the National Bank announced that short-term government securities for an amount of USD 2.43 billion will be issued to support the economy.

* The Chair of the National Bank indicated that monetary policy will be aimed at keeping inflation around 8-8.5% in 2020.

* The National Bank of Kazakhstan has reduced the base rate to 9.5%, with +/
- 2 percentage points of corridor, since April and has confirmed the same level repeatedly since.

* The President of Kazakhstan has assigned the objective to stabilise the exchange rate to the NBK on 2 July. The NBK allowed the tenge to depreciate by over 15 percent since March 9, intervening in the market to mitigate excessive volatility. Amid pressures, the NBK introduced a limit on bid-ask spread and lowered the ceiling of FX purchase without supporting import documents (from $100,000 to $50,000) for the duration of the state of emergency.

* Foreign exchange controls for SOEs have been introduced to support the tenge.

* April 21: The NBK set temporary limits on the amount of cash that legal entities are permitted to withdraw from their bank accounts. The new measure will be effective starting from 1 June 2020 until 31 December 2020. Limits for small businesses are set at KZT 20m, for medium-sized enterprises
- KZT 120m and for large enterprises
- KZT 150m.
column47:
* Risk weights for SME exposure in tenge have been lowered from 75 to 50% and those for forex loans from 200 to 100%.

* April 20: Kazakhstan's financial regulator has recommended that local banks and insurers avoid using their accumulated profit for dividend payouts and share buybacks this year.
column48:
*Residents in Almaty can defer utility payments for March and April until the end of 2020 with no fines or penalty.

* The mayor of Almaty has announced a recovery plan for the city.

* Reimbursement of utilities expenses for April and May in amount of KZT15,000 will be provided for socially vulnerable groups of population
column51: * For the duration of the state of emergency and quarantine, state bodies (eg. Investment Fund of Kazakhstan) have suspended the calculation of rental payments for real estate for SMEs without additional charges.
column54:
*
* The President of Kazakhstan, announced in its "adress to the Nation" on September 1 the creation of a new Agency for Strategic Planning and Reforms, as well as the Agency for the Protection and Development of Competition under the President.

* The President of Kazakhstan, announced in its "adress to the Nation" on September 1 the digitalisation of certification, diplomas, licences, etc.

* In an effort to speed up digitalisation, amendments were made to digital technology laws, including the laws on personal data and informatization to revise the data collection process and introduce new concepts such as blockchain and cryptocurrency.

* The President highlighted the need for the AIFC to play a key role in supporting the responses to the pandemic, including by attracting investment, improving the regulations of the domestic securities market and improving the investment climate. The AIFC is developing in particular green financing, VCs and funding for medium-sized entreprises.

* Kazakhstan has set up an official platform to inform on COVID-19 and respond to questions: https://www.coronavirus2020.kz/

* As of April 27, to support the agrarian sector, 200bn tenge was directed to finance spring field work and forward purchase, including 70 bn allocated for the development of seed production and purchase of fertilizers and pesticides

column12:
*August 26: In a televised address, President Uhuru Kenyatta extended a nationwide curfew 30 days (until 26 September) following an increase in the number of COVID-19 cases in rural areas.
*July 27: Kenya's President Uhuru Kenyatta announced the extension of the nationwide curfew for another 30 days and banned alcohol sales in restaurants to curb the spread of COVID-19. The nightly curfew was due to be lifted on August 6 or 7.
*July 6: President Uhuru Kenyatta extended the current nationwide nightly curfew between 9 p.m. and 4 a.m. for a further 30 days.
*June 6: President Uhuru Kenyatta has announced an extension of the nationwide curfew by another 30 days. However, the President relaxed the curfew hours which will now be between 9 pm to 4 am from June 7, 2020. By the same token, he: 1) lifted the cessation of movement in Kwale and Kilifi counties and into and out of Eastleigh and Old Town from 4 am June 7, 2020 and 2) extended the cessation of movement into and out of the Nairobi Metropolitan Area, Mombasa and Mandera counties by another 30 days.
*May 20: A nationwide overnight curfew between 19:00 to 05:00 and the cessation of movement in and out of Eastleigh in Nairobi and Mombasa's Old Town area, Kilifi, Kwale, and Mandera counties, were extended until June 6.
*May 16: the government announced the closure of borders with Tanzania and Somalia and extends curfew until June 6 as COVID-19 cases rise above 800.
*April 24: Kenya's president extended a nationwide night-time curfew by 21 days and said people won't be able to enter or exit the capital and some coastal areas for a similar period.
*March 27: A daily curfew from 7 p.m. to 5 a.m. in the territory of the Republic of Kenya, for all persons not authorized to do so, or not being medical professionals, health workers, critical and essential services providers.
column14:
*July 31: The Kenyan government has released the list of countries whose travelers will be exempt from going into quarantine once they enter the country. The 18 quarantine-exempt countries include the UK, France, Italy, Ethiopia, Uganda and Rwanda. The US is also on the list, but travelers coming from California, Florida and Texas will not be exempt from quarantine.
*July 6: President Kenyatta announced that domestic commercial and passenger flights are scheduled to restart on July 15, while international travel will resume from August 1. He announced a phased reopening of the country, lifting restrictions on travel in and out of the Nairobi metropolitan area, Mombasa county and Mandera county.
*April 6: Kenyan authorities announced the end of all road, rail or air traffic to and from Nairobi, with immediate effect and for a period of 21 days. Same measures will apply from 8 April for the coastal towns and counties of Kwale, Kilifi and Mombasa. *March 25: Suspension of all international flights.
*March 15: Kenya suspended all inbound travel from countries with coronavirus. Only Kenyan citizens and foreigners with valid visas are allowed in Kenya for next 30 days. Persons who arrived in Kenya in past 14 days must self-quarantine. Those presenting with symptoms, such as fever present themselves to nearest health facility for testing.
column16:
*July 7: Kenya's Education Minister, George Magoha, announced that the 2020 school calendar year for both private and public schools will be considered lost due to Covid-19 restrictions (Kenya's academic year runs from January to November). As a result, final year exams, usually taken in October and November, have also been cancelled. He reiterated the closure of all primary and secondary schools in the country until January 2021. The re-opening of universities will take place on a “case-by-case” basis, and the institutions were encouraged to consider phased re-opening and continue holding virtual classes and graduation ceremonies.
*June 6: President Kenyatta instructed the Education ministry to prepare for reopening of schools beginning September. President Kenyatta further directed a new school calendar be made and released by mid-August.
*May 3: Education Cabinet Secretary Prof. George Magoha reiterated that schools will remain closed for one more month.
*March 15: Closure of schools and universities. *March 15: the Ministry of Education shared guidelines for enhancing teaching and learning for its 15 million students out of school as a result of school closures. Starting March 23, four main platforms are used for delivering educational programs and resources to learners: 1) radio programs are being broadcast on all weekdays on multiple radio channels including Radio Taifa and Iftini FM, in partnership with the Kenya Broadcasting Corporation; 2) Education television broadcasts have begun on the Edu Channel TV owned by Kenya Institute for Curriculum Development (KICD). Broadcasting schedules for television and radio are available on its website; 3) television programming is made available as live stream as well as on-demand content via KICD's EduTV Kenya YouTube channel; 4) learners can also access digital learning resources from the Kenya Education Cloud hosted and curated by KICD. In partnership with the Kenya Publishers Association, electronic copies of textbooks have been made available for free on the Kenya Education Cloud for all students. Also, to provide wider internet coverage to students and families, the Kenya Civil Aviation Authority, in partnership with Alphabet Inc. and Telkom Kenya, has been having Google's Loon Balloons floating over Kenyan airspace carrying 4G base stations.
column18:
*August 26: In his address, President Kenyatta noted that the maximum number of persons permitted to attend funerals and weddings is reviewed upwards to 100.
*August 1: The major sports KCB Karen Masters golf tournament, which is part of the South Africa based Sunshine Tour event -planned to take place from September 10 to 13-will be rescheduled to either December or early 2021.
*July 6: President Kenyatta announced that places of worship will be opened in three weeks to 100 people for services that are not more than one hour. These shall not include congregants under the age of 13 years or above the age of 58 years or persons with underlying conditions.
*June 6: President Kenyatta extended the ban on re-opening bars for another 30 days.
*May 3: The National Emergency Response Committee (NERC) has directed the Inspector General to designate a place for curfew offenders where social distancing requirement can be observed and cautioned mosques that have revised prayer time and are now opening for prayers at night during this month of Ramadhan. All religious leaders are advised to stop this practice forthwith, failure of which legal action will be taken against them in accordance with Public Health Act.
*April 1: the Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission announced the postponement of by-elections for Members of both county and national assemblies in a number of Kenyan counties (date TBD).
*March 22: All religious gatherings are suspended.
*March 15: Citizens to avoid crowds, including at weddings, funerals, churches and shopping malls. Limited visits to hospitals.
column20:
*August 26: President Kenyatta ordered bars and nightclubs to remain shut down during the extended nationwide curfew from 26 August to 26 September.
*August 5: Tourism Cabinet Secretary Najib Balala, confirmed that lodges, hotels and resorts are allowed to sell alcohol to their checked-in clients on room-service basis, only.
*July 6: President Kenyatta stated that public gatherings (both political and personal events such as weddings) also remain banned for a further 30 days. All bars are closed until further notice and whilst restaurants have reopened, they must comply with social distancing regulations.
*June 16: Kenya's Health Cabinet Secretary, Mutahi Kagwe, announced the extension of closing hours of restaurants and hotels from 5.00p.m to 7.30 p.m daily with stern warning that those who break the law will have their operating licences revoked. The operators of these restaurants must however ensure they have thermo-guns at the entrance of the premises to screen clients for temperature, provide handwashing stations and soap at the entrance and also provide sanitizers in strategic places at the facilities.
*April 28: The National Emergency Response Committee (NERC) on Coronavirus has approved guidelines for partial reopening of eateries and restaurants.
*March 15: Government offices, businesses and companies are encouraged to allow staff to work from home, except those in critical or essential services.
column22:
*May 23: President Kenyatta announced his 8-Point Economic Stimulus Programme, amounting to a total of Ksh 53.7 Billion to focus on: 1) infrastructure (Ksh. 5 billion to hire local labour to rehabilitate access roads, footbridges and other public infrastructure) ; 2) education (an envelope of KSh. 6.5 Billion will mainly help hiring 10,000 teachers and 1,000 ICT interns to support digital learning); 3) SMEs (to fast-track payment of outstanding VAT refunds and other pending payments and the injection Ksh 3 Billion as seed capital for the SME Credit Guarantee Scheme); 4) health (Ksh.1.7 Billion for the expansion of bed capacity in public hospitals; to hire an additional 5,000 healthcare workers with diploma/certificate
- level qualification for a period of one year. This will not only enhance Kenya's COVID-19 response capability but also the implementation of the Universal Health Coverage programme); 5) agriculture (a Ksh. 3 billion are earmarked for the supply of farm inputs through e-vouchers, targeting 200,000 small scale farmers); 6) tourism (soft loans to hotels and related establishments through the Tourism Finance Corporation and the Utalii hospitality college); 7) the environment (rehabilitate wells, water pans and underground tanks in the Arid and Semi-Arid areas. For this purpose, we have set aside Ksh. 850 million) 8) manufacturing (an initial investment of Ksh. 600 million to purchase locally manufactured vehicles has been earmarked thereby enforcing the “Buy Kenya Build Kenya” policy).
*April 25: President Kenyatta announced the creation of the National Hygiene Program, aimed at guaranteeing the youth employment and also taking care of the environment in the same beat. This initiative will entry into force on 29 April. The first phase of the program will be launched and will cater to over 26,000 youth, in 23 informal settlements in seven of the counties most affected by the pandemic.
*March 25: The president of the Republic of Kenya outlined the tax interventions the Government intends to make to “cushion” the country against the economic effects of the COVID-19. These measures are proposals only at this point and will enter into force after the approval from the National Assembly. He noted that his Administration has offered a voluntary reduction in the salaries of the senior ranks of the National Executive, as follows: The President & Deputy President
- 80%; Cabinet Secretaries
- 30%; Chief Administrative Secretaries
- 30%; Principal Secretaries
- 20%.
*March 12: the Ministry of Tourism and Wildlife announced that it has set aside USD5 million to support Tourism Sector for its post Covid-19 recovery plan.
column25:
*August 21: The Department of Health of Garissa County, which borders Somalia, is set to begin a 10-day mass testing for the novel coronavirus from August 24.
*July 27: Health Cabinet Secretary, Mutahi Kagwe, said that the government had engaged cultural and traditional elders from several communities
- such as the Kisii and the Abaluhya
- to postpone the annual circumcision initiation ceremony to later next year. The cultural festivities, which usually which attract hundreds of community member between April and December in Western Kenya, will be restricted amid fears of potential heighten the spread of coronavirus.
*June 10: The Government launched protocols for home-based isolation and care, anticipating to discharge asymptomatic Covid-19 positive cases. Health Chief Administrative Secretary, Rashid Aman, announced that the protocol implementation would start immediately. Those who cannot afford to be isolated in their houses because of space, will be placed in a facility within the community that meets the recommendations for providing such care, he said. This measure is based on available data in Kenya showing that 78% of infected persons admitted in hospitals, are either asymptomatic or mildly symptomatic.
*May 4: Kenya has launched its mass COVID-19 testing campaign in the capital Nairobi. The tests is being rolled out in other highly infected areas such as Kibera, Eastleigh and the city of Mombasa.

* Kenya has earmarked Ksh40 billion (0.4 percent of GDP) for additional health expenditure, including enhanced surveillance, laboratory services, isolation units, equipment, supplies, and communication; social protection and cash transfers; food relief; and funds for expediting payments of existing obligations to maintain cash flow for businesses during the crisis.
*March 25: The government announced the disbursement of KES 1 billion for the recruitment of additional medical personnel.
*March 15: Charges on mobile money transactions dropped to limit use of cash. The central bank encouraged the waiving or reducing of charges on mobile money transactions to disincentivize the use of cash. *March 13: The country's first Covid-19 case is announced.
column28: *March 25: Appropriation of an additional KES 10 Billion to the elderly, orphans and other vulnerable members of our society through cash-transfers by the Ministry of Labour and Social Protection, to cushion them from the adverse economic effects of the COVID-19 pandemic. The announced plan includes a proposed 100-percent tax relief for persons earning gross monthly income of up to KES 24,000 who fall under the "low income earners" category. The proposal will channel additional disposable income to this group estimated at approximately KES 1,700 per month. The government has also proposed to reduce the top Pay-As-You-Earn (PAYE) rate from 30 percent to 25 percent. This incentive is expected to align with the 100-percent tax relief for low income earners, allowing the government to channel additional resources to cushion the affected individuals from the impact of the virus.
column31:
*The government has also earmarked funds for expediting payments of existing obligations to maintain cash flow for businesses during the crisis. Given lower revenues due to decreased economic activity and the need to accommodate emergency spending, the government is currently reassessing the budget deficit target for year 2019/20.
*March 25: The President announced a reduction of the resident corporate income tax from 30 % to 25 % and the reduction of the turnover tax rate from the current 3% to 1% for all Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises (MSMEs). In his address, he ordered temporary suspension of the listing with Credit Reference Bureaus (CRB) of any person, Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises (MSMES) and corporate entities whose loan account fall overdue or is in arrears, effective 1st April, 2020.
column34: Information not available
column37: Information not available
column40:
*August 8: Education Cabinet Secretary George Magoha indicated plans by the ministry to provide Sh7 billion concessionary loans to bail out struggling private schools

* May 1: Kenya's National Treasury will create a fund of close to Sh100 billion to cushion distressed Micro,Small and Medium Enterprises against the coronavirus effects.This will ensure that loan rates remain affordable to MSMEs.
column43: *August 18: The Tourism Finance Corporation (TFC), a specialised Development Financial Institution established by the government of Kenya, will disburse Sh3billion (approx. 27,707,328,494.50 USD) stimulus package to the hardest Covid-19 hit hotels to boost the tourism and hospitality industry. According to TFC Director, Jonah Orumoi recipients will be charged a flat rate of 5 per cent interest repayable in a 5 to 10-year period.
column46:
*June 25: Kenya's Central Bank (CBK) left interest rates unchanged for the second time in two months at 7.0%, after cutting them in March and April after the first case of COVID-19 was confirmed. On this occasion the CKB announced that commercial banks have restructured loans worth 679.6 billion shillings ($6.39 billion), nearly a quarter of the industry total.
*June 24: The CBK announced the extension of various relief measures on mobile phone payments that were introduced on March 16, 2020 to help promote cashless transactions by a further six months. These include 1) extending free mobile money transactions below 1,000 shillings (about USD 9.5), which account for over 80% of mobile money transactions and 2) the removal of both the monthly limit for transactions and the threshold of how much money financial services users can hold in their wallets. These last two measures were originally introduced to stem cases of money laundering and the CBK has said it has increased its surveillance after their removal to ensure compliance.
*May 27: At its monthly meeting, the Monetary Policy Committee concluded that the current accommodative monetary policy stance remains appropriate, and therefore decided to retain the Central Bank Rate (CBR) at 7%. This follows a cumulative 125-bps cut in the last two meetings
- the CBR was cut by 25 bps in April and 100 bps in March.
*March 24: The Central Bank rolled out the following measures: (i) lowered its policy rate by 100 bps to 7.25%; (ii) lowered banks' cash reserve ratio by 100 bps to 4.25% to provide additional liquidity of KES 35 Billion to commercial banks to directly support borrowers that are distressed as a result of the economic effects of the COVID-19 pandemic; (iii) increase the maximum tenor of repurchase agreements from 28 to 91 days; and (iv) announced flexibility to banks regarding loan classification and provisioning for loans that were performing on March 2, 2020, but were restructured due to the pandemic.
column47: Information not available
column54:
*August 13: At least 6,500 households in Kirinyaga County will benefit from a relief food programme which has been launched by Governor Anne Waiguru. This is the second phase of the programme that kicked off in May and which seeks to shield needy and vulnerable families from the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic.
*August 7: East African Community (EAC) partner states have agreed to start launching a regional electronic cargo and driver tracking system as one of the measures aimed at preventing further spread of the Coronavirus disease, and minimize loss of lives. The Regional Electronic Cargo and Driver Tracking System (RECDTS) will be launched at five border points. After Rusumo on August 12 next will be the Mutukula border between Tanzania and Uganda on August 14; the Malaba border between Kenya and Uganda on August 21; Namanga border between Tanzania and Kenya on August 28 and finally, Kobero border between Burundi and Tanzania on August 31.The launch will run from August 12 to 31 at the various border points. It will start at the Rusumo border between Rwanda with Tanzania.
*July 30: The Cabinet Secretary of Education Prof. George Magoha announced that owing to the results of a survey of all Teacher Training Colleges, Universities and TVET institutions showing that few of them have put in place necessary measures to comply with the Ministry of Health's COVID-19 protocols to guarantee the safety of staff and learners, their reopening is delayed to 2021. Initially, tertiary institutions were expected to reopen in September. Universities however, will continue offering online classes
- including examinations and even graduations.
*July 21: The United Nations has entered a strategic partnership with the Nairobi Hospital to manage diplomatic personnel and their dependents with suspected or confirmed cases of Covid-19. The partnership will see the construction of a Sh1.1 billion facility within eight weeks. It will have a 150 beds with 25 in the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) and 50 in the High Dependency Unit (HDU). The semi-autonomous hospital will serve over 20,000 UN staff based in Kenya and Africa and their families and will also be open to locals.
*April 26: In a circular, the Head of Public Service Joseph Kinyua, informed that the government is rolling out a voluntary pay cut programme starting this end month covering lower cadre civil servants to support the fight against COVID-19. The law requires that whoever contributes to the fund must still retain at least a third of their gross salaries after all the deductions.

column12:
* 4 May: Phase 1 of easing restrictions: Individuals may leave their residences for three hours each day (as opposed to alternating days) and certain businesses such as car dealerships, real estate offices, consulting firms and certain types of retail firms may resume operations.
*18 May: Phase 2 of easing restrictions: Individuals are permitted to leave their residences for four hours each day. Additional businesses will be allowed to resume operations including dentists and physiotherapists, hairdressers, green markets, certain restaurants and cafés for takeout only, call centres, and museums and galleries. Rail transport will also resume, as will urban and interurban transportation networks. Passengers are required to prove that they are travelling during their allocated time slot or that they are essential workers.

* 1 June: Phase 3 of easing restrictions: Nurseries, kindergarten, taxis, dine-in restaurants, cinemas, theatres, shopping malls and select sports events have resumed operations. Mosques, churches and other religious centres have reopened
column14:
* 8 June: All land borders have been reopened; travellers entering Kosovo must pass a medical examination and COVID-19 test, but are no longer required to self-isolate for seven days
*June 28: International flights are permitted again
column16:
* 1 June: Reopening of Nurseries, kindergarten
*15 June
- 30 June: Reopening of elementary and secondary schools
column18:
*18 May: museums and galleries allowed to open
*1 June: Mosques and Churches have reopened
*8 June: No more restrictions on movement and gathering, but distancing of 1.5 metres required. Major film festivals have been postponed to the end of August
column20:
*4 May: Certain businesses such as car dealerships, real estate offices, consulting firms and certain types of retail firms may resume operations.
*18 May: Dentists and physiotherapists, hairdressers, green markets, certain restaurants and cafés for takeout only, call centres

* 1 June: Taxis, dine-in restaurants, cinemas, theatres, shopping malls have resumed operations.
*June 8: No more restrictions beyond keeping physical distance and limiting the numbers of people in closed spaces, open borders with neighbours
column22:
*30 March, the government passed a major emergency support package of about 180 million EUR (~2.5% of GDP) to support individuals, firms, and municipalities affected by the COVID-19 crisis.
*18 May, 10.9 million EUR additional to the emergency support package, of which EUR 9.4 million was allocated to the Ministry of Economy, Employment, Trade, Industry, Entrepreneurship and Strategic Investments and EUR 1.5 million to the Ministry of Finance and Transfers.
*19 June, 53 million EUR for a new agricultural support programme, delivering direct payments to farmers.
column25:
Support to vital workers: Vital health and safety personnel such as doctors, police officers and
firefighters will receive EUR 300 per month in additional wages from the government during the
crisis. Likewise, workers at pharmacies, grocery stores and other essential businesses will receive
EUR 100 per month in additional wages from the government during the crisis
column28:
*19 June, 53 million EUR for a new agricultural support programme, delivering direct payments to farmers.
*All payments to social welfare recipients have been doubled during April and May.
*Support for crisis-related unemployment: The government has guaranteed that all individuals who lose their jobs due to the COVID-19 crisis have received monthly payments of EUR 130 from April to June.
column31: *removal of VAT on imports of wheat and flour
column34: *7 April: Up to 230 EUR will be awarded for any new hired employee during the COVID-19 situation with a defined term contract of at least one year. The total coverage amounts to EUR 6 million.
column37:
*The Tax Administration of Kosovo has extended the deadline to file and pay tax liabilities and pension contributions until 30 June.
*taxpayers affected by the crisis will be able to apply for an extension of tax payment deadlines for up to three years.
*18 May: all interest on unpaid property taxes would be suspended until 2021.
column40: Information not available
column43: *7 April: Micro-enterprises and self-employed workers can apply to receive credit guarantees valued up to EUR 10 000
column46: Information not available
column47: Information not available
column54: Information not available

column12: Information not available
column14:
As of 3 June, self-isolation is not required for Latvian nationals, permanent residents, and foreigners who have not visited any "unsafe" countries in the last 14 days
- i.e., countries where the 14-day cumulative number of Covid-19 cases exceeds 15 people per 100,000 inhabitants
- or countries outside of the EU, EEA, or Switzerland.
column16: Information not available
column18: From 17 August, up to 1000 persons are allowed to gather indoors and up to 3000 outdoor. The limit no longer depends on the size of the premises.
column20:
From 17 August, cultural, sports, and religious activities, as well as public catering locations, are allowed to work for longer hours: until 2.00 a.m. The beginning of working hours remains 6.30 a.m. The number of people permitted to gather at a specific location is not allowed to exceed 50% of a specific location's capacity.

'The necessary space per person at catering places, shopping centres and cultural events reduced from 4 to 3 square meter.

'Restaurants must provide a distance of one metre between tables, as well as an area of at least 3 metres squared of public indoor space per visitor. No more than eight persons are allowed to be at one restaurant table.

'Activities organized by entertainment venues, such as discos and night clubs, allowed to work until 24:00.
column22:
On 20 March the Parliament approved a special fixed-term draft law on measures for preventing and overcoming the crisis, which takes effect from the date the state of emergency was declared (March 12). According to Finance Minister Janis Reirs, planned support (including off-budget items) is two billion euros, about 6.5% of GDP.
'Actions are taken to restructure European Union funds to finance measures for reducing negative impacts created by Covid-19 crisis and support the economy afterwards.
column25: About EUR 8 million has been earmarked to cover salary increases for three months for about 4,500 “front line” medical workers. In addition, about EUR 2 million will be allocated to mass media outlets and about EUR 14 million will be used to increase the capital of the three largest hospitals.
column28:
Compensation for up to 75% of workers' salaries, of not exceeding EUR 700 per month, is given to employees in companies directly impacted by the COVID-19 crisis (expected cost
- 102 million euros). These benefits are not subject to personal income tax and the mandatory state social security contributions. The companies applying will need to show that, due to the crisis, either business dropped by more than 30% year-over-year in March/April 2020, or it dropped by 20% year over year with at least one of the following criteria:
1) the company's exports in 2019 make up 10% of turnover or are no less than 500,000 EUR;
2) the average monthly salary paid to employees before taxes in 2019 was no less than 800 EUR;
3) the company's long-term capital investment as of 31 December 2019 was at least 500,000 EUR.

'The government will cover the payment of sick leave related to Covid-19 or quarantine from 22th March 2020 till 30th June 2020 from the second day of incapacity for work. Sickness benefit is provided at 80 percent of the beneficiary's average insurance wage (expected cost
- EUR 34.5 million).

'Local governments, during the emergency period and a month after it, are entitled to support citizens by allocating grant to provide basic needs for family (person). The central government compensates to local government 50 percent of allocated grants to citizens, but not more than 40 euros per person for three month period.
column31:
On March 20 a law was adopted allowing deferral of tax payments in crisis-affected sectors for a period of up to three years. Expected cost
- EUR 196 million.
column34:
State and local government authorities will release firms from rent obligations. They will also be allowed not to impose late interest and contractual penalties in case of overdue payments, except for on those paid for consumed services and utilities
- electricity, thermal energy, water supply, and other property maintenance services.

'There are several programs to support businesses. About €32 million will be allocated to support the culture industries; about €45 million will be allocated to support the farming sector; about €75 million will be allocated to support the road construction sector and about €100 million will be allocated to support large manufacturers.
column37:
Liquidity measures for firms in all sectors: refund of approved amount of VAT to all taxpayers within 30 days after VAT return has been submitted, as well as a VAT refund that has been carried forward in previous periods (expected cost
- EUR 60 million); Personal Income Tax (PIT) taxpayers will be exempt from advance payments for the taxation year 2020 (expected cost
- EUR 35 million)
column40:
Loans for up to 3 years for companies to finance new working capital (up to 200 million euros). Loans will have significantly reduced collateral requirements and reduced/subsidized interest rate, with a grace period of the principal amount up to 12 months.

'About €250 million will be invested in the share capital of airBaltic.
column43: Loan guarantees (up to 715 million euros), so that an enterprise facing short-term cash flow problems can postpone the payment of the principal until the situation is resolved.
column46: The ECB has committed to “do everything necessary within its mandate” to support the economy through this shock. To preserve bank lending and liquidity, the ECB will temporarily conduct additional longer-term refinancing operations (LTROs) and lower the interest rate applied in targeted longer-term refinancing operations (TLTRO III). On the supervisory front, the ECB has temporarily lowered bank capital requirements and introduced flexibility regarding the treatment of non-performing loans. Furthermore, the ECB has expanded its asset purchase programme by an overall EUR 870 billion (7.3% of euro area GDP) until the end of 2020. This mainly consists of the EUR 750 billion Pandemic Emergency Purchase Programme, to which some of the ECB self-imposed limits for asset purchases will not apply.
column47: The Financial and Capital Market Commission will allow use of accumulated liquidity and capital reserves for banks according to an individual and flexible approach.
column54: Information not available

column12:
*June 22: Curfew starts at 6pm instead of 6pm.
*June 9: End of the state of emergency.
*June 5: Curfew starts at 9pm and it is lifted in the counties that have not reported any cases of the disease so far.
*June 4: Mandatory coronavirus test on anyone caught violating the nationwide dusk-to-dawn curfew.
*May 22: Extension of the “stay-at-home” order for an additional 2 weeks, with curfew starting at 6pm.
*May 8: President is extending the order for people to stay at home and observe the protocols that were originally instituted on April 10, 2020 by an additional two weeks.
*April 24: Extension of the “stay-at-home” order to all 15 counties of Liberia.
*April 27: Compulsory wearing of face masks by everyone in public places.
*April 8: Declaration of the state of emergency for 3 weeks renewable, subsequently approved for 60 days by the Liberian legislature, until June 11;
*April 8: Quarantine of all 15 Liberian counties, starting April 10, until further notice.
*April 8: Lock-down of the 4 counties of Montserrado, Margibi, Nimba and Grand Kru with a “stay-at-home” order (except for designated essential staff required to be indoors by 3pm) for the following 14 days, starting April 10.
*March 21: Declaration of national health emergency.
column14:
*June 22: The re-opening of Roberts International Airport is pushed back by one week to June 28.
*June 5: Opening of the Roberts International Airport to commercial flights on June 21.
*June 5: Restriction on movement between counties that have not yet been affected by Covid-19, with the exception of basic supplies.
*April 8: Prohibition of movements between Liberian counties, starting April 10, until further notice; Montserrado and Margibi counties remaining quarantined as a single unit.
*April 1: Border closure with Sierra Leone.
*March 31: Border closure with Guinea and Ivory Coast.
*March 21: Suspension of all commercial flights (except cargo, chartered and special flights), starting March 23.
*March 21: Restriction of the movement of people in and out the affected areas: all travel in and outside the Montserrado and Margibi areas are discouraged.
*March 21: Limitation on public transport for taxis, kehkehs and motorbikes/pempem.
*March 16: Ban on travel to and from all countries with more of 200 cases and on non-essential travel by all government officials; Minimisation of travels within Liberia, specifically to cross-border traders and travellers and to all government officials.
column16: *March 21: Closure of schools and universities.
column18:
*May 17: Partial re-opening of the places of worship (churches, mosques), with 25% of the regular worship-hour occupancy for each service.
*March 21: Closure of places of worship, including churches, mosques and religious centers.
*March 21: Ban on public gatherings of more than 10 people, including weddings and funerals.
*March 21: Mandatory hand washing with soap and clean water at homes and all public and private establishments.
*March 16: Ban on large public gatherings and large crowds; Recommendations to follow good hygiene practices and social distancing protocols.
column20:
*June 5: Re-opening of hotels, guesthouses and gaming centers, with the observance of the required health measures, starting June 21.
*May 22: Re-opening of stores selling food commodities, dry goods, building materials and electronic appliances, taking the 25% of their full occupancy at a time while observing social distancing.
*April 8: Closure of all no-essential businesses and government offices (except for essential businesses, health facilities and few key government offices) in the 4 locked-down counties.
*March 21: Closure of bars, nightclubs, casinos, cinemas and others entertainment centres, beaches, barbershops and beauty salons.
*March 21: Ban on street selling (for adults and children).
*March 21: Restrictions for restaurants, pharmacies and banks (admittance limited to 5 customers, keeping a distance of 6 feet apart), supermarkets (admittance limited to 10 customers, keeping a distance of 6 feet apart); Social distancing required in all markets and health facilities and institutions, including pharmacies (which are to remain open).
*March 16: Paid leave granted to all non-essential governmental employees.
column22:
*April 17: Establishment of an Emergency COVID-19 Relief Fund to complement Liberian government's purchase of necessaries for vulnerable people and testing kits, PPE and other protective gears for health workers; The Fund is to be founded by voluntarily contributions (the proposal of 25% of salaries of all gainfully employed persons for the period of May and June 2020 was rejected) and by private donations.

*April 15: Proposal of full payment by the government of the loans owed by market women, and petty and small traders in affected counties, subsequently approved by the Liberian Legislature.
column25:
*The authorities are hoping to finalize a COVID-19 preparedness plan in conjunction with the donor community, and the draft is still evolving. The World Bank has to date disbursed about USD 4 million for actions under the plan from its overall funding envelope. The plan includes the support to health care workers, purchase and repair of health equipment, procurement of drugs and other medical supplies, deployment of surge staff to contact tracing activities, border areas, rapid response teams, training, planning, communications and information sharing, staffing and equipping laboratories, and logistical and supply support.

*The Central Bank of Liberia (CBL) has suspended fees and charges for most electronic transfers and point-of-sale outlets used by merchants and mobile money operators, in order to better facilitate the use of electronic payments; and increased allowable daily limits. The bank has also increased the allowable daily and aggregate limits for mobile money transactions for a period of three months.

*April 8: Call upon all retired health workers in Liberia to join with their counterparts to reinforce capabilities and strengths to fight COVID-19.

*March 21: Setting up of a dedicated hotline to report people who show signs and symptoms to the relevant health and security authorities.

*March 13: Establishment of a Special Presidential Advisory Committee on Coronavirus (SPACOC) and an Executive Committee on Coronavirus (ECOC) under the umbrella of the President
column28: *April 15: Proposal of re-appropriation of US$25 million to support food distribution to households in designated affected counties for the lock-down period to be implemented by the World Food Program in collaboration with a COVID-19 Food Support National Steering Committee, subsequently approved for the entire country by the Liberian Legislature, with priority given to vulnerable population and the first responder population as well as the disadvantaged youth, the homeless, orphanages, senior citizens, and people with disabilities, and accommodating locally produced food first; Proposal of governmental taking up of electricity and water bills of households in the affected counties for the duration of the stay-at-home order, subsequently approved by the Liberian Legislature.
column31: Information not available
column34: Information not available
column37: Information not available
column40: Information not available
column43: Information not available
column46:
*The Central Bank of Liberia reduced the policy rate by 500 bp to 25% partly to support increased financial intermediation.

*In mitigation of the situation, the Central Bank of Liberia (CBL) is expediting the procurement of additional banknotes to help meet the Liberian dollar demand in the economy. In response to the difficulties being felt by the private sector, the CBL is also allowing banks to practice limited forbearance on asset classification, provisioning, and leading policies in hard-hit sectors of the economy, while remaining vigilant for signs of banking sector stress.
column47: Information not available
column54: *April 9: The World Bank has approved a US$7.5 million International Development Association (IDA) financing to help Liberia. The financing, which consists of a US$3.75 million grant and US$3.75 million concessional IDA credit, will strengthen the Government of Liberia's immediate capacity to respond to the COVID-19 outbreak and in the longer-term, strengthen its response to disease outbreaks and emergencies. This complements ongoing support provided though the Second Regional Disease Surveillance Systems Enhancement (REDISSE II) project which has made available up to US$9.5 million for the response.
