column12: On 16 June, the three-month long quarantine ended. As of 17 June, emergency situation regime (with some restrictions applied) entered into force.
column14:
Restriction of the arrival of regular flights and ferries from the affected countries to Lithuania (the affected countries are those with a total 14-day morbidity rate higher than 25 cases per 100 000 population).

- Temporary internal border control and checks for persons entering and leaving Lithuania at the internal border of EU have been extended from 17 June 2020 to 14 September 2020. Checks are carried out at the international airports and in Klaipeda State Seaport. Passenger control at internal land borders with Latvia and Poland is not carried out.

- Checks are carried out at airports, Klaipeda Seaport, and at the external EU border crossing points with Belarus and Russia.

- Control of the arrivals at border crossing points. For those from the national list of affected countries: temperature measurement; mandatory completion of a passenger card within 24 hours, by registering electronically or by filling in a paper form; a 14-day isolation requirement applies.

- For those arriving from other countries, i. e. the unaffected countries, no restrictions apply. Travellers are informed and consulted on further steps in case symptoms occur.

- Citizens of the countries of the EU/EEA, the Swiss Confederation and the United Kingdom, and persons lawfully residing in these countries, who arrive from these countries are allowed entry to Lithuania as of 1 June, provided that the incidence of COVID-19 in their country has not exceeded 25 cases per 100 000 of population in the last 14 calendar days. Lithuanian citizens are allowed to come back from any country.The list of such countries is approved and made public every Monday.
Entry is also allowed for:

- foreigners residing in third countries where the incidence of COVID-19 has not exceeded 25 cases per 100 000 of population in the last 14 calendar days, applying the principle of reciprocity;

- foreigners holding a national visa of the Republic of Lithuania or for whom the Migration Department has adopted a decision to issue a national visa (usually granted for foreigners who arrive to work, study, conduct scientific research or to engage in legal activities in Lithuania)
Other exceptions apply (e.g. diplomats, NATO personnel, health care professionals).
column16: The new school academic year started  on 1 September, 2020.
column18:
Indoor/outdoor events:
A distance of at least 2 meters between participants needs to be ensured in the case of indoor events and of 1 meter in the case of outdoor events if participants do not wear protective equipment (face masks, respirators etc.). These requirements do not apply to athletes, their coaches, performers, organisers and staff.

Mass events: For the period between 1 and 30 Septermber 2020, the number of participants in mass events held at closed and open spaces is no longer limited, provided that the organiser ensures the availability of electronic ticket and/ or the electronic registration of participants. Otherwise, limitations on the number of participants will be applied (maximum of 300 persons).
column20: As of 17 June, emergency situation regime with safe distance and hygiene restrictions is applied on economic activities including services and trade in public places, leisure and entertainment places, catering establishments, activities of casinos, and events.
column22:
The government introduced on 16 March 2020 a fiscal package of EUR 2.5 billion (including EUR 0.5 billion for health) under the action plan to mitigate the impact of COVID-19. This was followed by the introduction of additional measures. The measures aim to:
- Ensure the effective functioning of the health care system: the funds are dedicated, in particular, to the acquisition of equipment, finance additional health care costs, including bonuses to health care workers, and ensure subsidiary social guarantees for employees infected by a contagious disease.
- Help safeguard jobs and incomes, including subsidies wages, benefits for self-employed and funds to ensure the payment of sickness benefits of carers.
- Help business to save liquidity, including postponement of the payments date of tax arrears for the affected taxpayers.
- Stimulate the economy, including through the acceleration of investment programmes and reallocation of EU funds. To this end, EUR 265.5 million of EU investment funds have been reallocated to health, employment, business and tourism sectors for mitigating the COVID-19 impact and changes were introduced in national regulations to speed up the use of EU funds (target value
- EUR 1.7 billion). The government also enabled full use of the Climate Change Programme (EUR 18 million), Road Maintenance and Development Program (EUR 142 million) and accelerating the program for renovation of the multi-apartment buildings (EUR 90 million). Under the program for renovation of multi-apartment buildings, final recipients received by end-July 2020 over EUR 72 million out of EUR 90 million planned.
A Fund for Mitigation of Consequences of COVID-19 Transmission was established offering possibilities for legal and natural persons to make donations. To ensure the liquidity of State Treasury, the right was granted to the government to borrow additional EUR 5 billion (entered into force on 18 of March). Additional ceiling for the State guarantees amounting up to EUR 500 million was set in order to develop or supplement existing financial instruments when the State assumes the primary risk (entered into force on 18 of March). The government will provide short-term loans to municipalities and reimburse emergency management costs which were a result of central government decisions. Municipalities will also be able to have higher budget expenditures than earlier approved
- EUR 30 million for small municipalities and EUR 10 million for big municipalities.
A medium-term investment promotion plan was approved on 10th June 2020, entailing measures that focus on human capital, innovation, digital economy and business competitiveness, energy, and economic infrastructure.
column25:
Testing requirements:
- Foreigners arriving to Lithuania from affected countries (where COVID-19 incidence for 14 days reaches 25 cases per 100 000 population) must have confirmation of a negative coronavirus test performed within a 72-hour period before arrival, while foreigners, crew and crew members who work in Lithuanian companies engaging in international commercial transport and stay in the country for more than 72 hours are required to apply to the COVID-19 testing institution and perform the test in less than 24 hours after the expiry of the 72-hour period.

- Lithuanias arriving from the affected countries must have a confirmation of a negative coronavirus test carried out within 72 hours before arrival or within 24 hours after arrival. Registration requirements:
- Registration is compulsory for all people arriving from abroad; those arrived from affected country and from third countries are required to register and self-isolate for 14-days.
The list of countries affected by COVID-19 is updated weekly upon consideration of epidemiological indicators.
column28:
Fiscal measures to mitigate the economic impact of COVID-19, include:

- State wage subsidies: If quarantine prevents the employer from providing the contracted work to the employees, the employer has the right to declare downtime or partial downtime
- employees may not be required to perform work functions and are paid at least the minimum wage. State subsidies apply: 90 % of the employee's calculated salary/100% of the calculated salary if the employee is 60 years and older, but not more than EUR 607 gross, or 70 % of the employee's calculated salary, but not more than EUR 910.5 gross.
- Payments of EUR 257 per month for affected self-employed persons who due to emergency cannot further carry out their activities (support was granted from the start of quarantine auntil two months after its end). A subsidy for job creation is also provided for those self
- employed, who were eligible for the flat-rate benefit (EUR 257 EUR) and are willing to change their economic activity.
- If health care professionals, officials or other employees are infected with the illness for which the emergency is declared, they are offered a maximum sickness benefit of 100% net average wage.

- Ensuring the payment of sickness benefits of carers.

- Prolongation (from 3 to 6 months) the grace period for repayments on mortgage loans to redundant persons.
- Possibility of deferring or arranging in instalments the electricity and gas payments to public provider.
- NGOs enhancement measure which will ensure funding for additional costs for NGOs that are active in the social field and provide essential social services.
- The Labour Code was amended regarding possible suspension from work. After the government declares an emergency situation and (or) quarantine, in order to ensure the protection of the health of employees and third parties, the employer must offer an employee whose health condition threatens the health safety of other employees to work remotely. If the employee is not in agreement or does not provide a response to the employer offer to work remotely remotely in writing, the employer can suspends the employee.
- Special measures after quarantine have been approved for employees, the self-employed, people who lost their jobs and employers, with a total value of approx. EUR 1 billion.

- Additional social measures were introduced, expected to benefit around 1.4 million people. These include the extension of wage subsidies for another six months for employers who meet certain conditions, a temporary job search benefit for for unemployed persons who are not entitled to unemployment social insurance benefit or its payment has expired (valid for 6 months), an additional child benefit for a period of 6 months to low-income families, and a lump-sum benefit (EUR 200) for the eledely and disabled.

- Income taxation for low and middle wage earners was reduced by increasing the maximum annual non-taxable amount of income for 2020 (from EUR 4200 to EUR 4800).
column31: - Recommendation for municipalities to exempt the taxpayers from taxes levied on business property and land.
column34: Information not available
column37:
1. The fiscal package under the action plan to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 includes the following measures:

- Postponement of the payments date of tax arrears for the affected tax payers.

- Exemption from fines and default interest for failure to comply with tax obligations on time.
- Postponement of submission (and payment of) personal income tax returns and advanced corporate income tax returns.

- Relief from import duties and VAT exemption on importation granted for goods needed to combat the effects of the COVID-19 outbreak pursuant to Commission's decision.
- Possibility for business customers to defer or arrange the payments in instalments to the public provider of electricity and gas.

- Reduction of the tax on rent of the State-owned immovable property. EUR 1.5 million for the implementation of this measure. 2. A new law adopted by Parliament on 21 April 2020 regarding the COVID-19 impact on insolvency of legal persons was submitted to Parliament on 8 April. The law includes: suspension of the debtor's duty to file for bankruptcy or restructuring proceedings for the period of three months after the end of quarantine period; creditor's right to file for bankruptcy or restructuring proceedings is limited for the quarantine period; suspended calculation of term when the debtor is not able to carry out the approved restructuring plan and as a result the restructuring could be terminated
- for the period of three months after the end of quarantine period. 3. New financial instruments were introduced to support SMEs during the COVID-19 crisis. These incude interest compensation, lease fee compensation, loans for payable invoices ASAP (implemented); loans for travel and accommodation services providers and loans to businessses most affected by COVID-19 (implemented).
4. An ongoing aid for the tourism sector program incudes the measures "Tourism Innovations", "Loans to tourism service providers" and "Insurance guarantees for tour operators" covering tourism sector innovations, liquidity promotion (loans, compensations and liquidity guarantees), and demand promotion (marketing measures, holiday vouchers for medics, etc.). EUR 45 million from the state budget are planned for the implementation of these measures.
5. The State Investment Management Agency (VIVA) was established for addressing financing challenges for large and medium enterprises that suffered from Covid-19 crisis.
column40:
- Allocation of EUR 1.7 billion to the firms facing liquidity and financial problems: EUR 437 million for loans (including EUR 200 million loans to the most affected sectors), EUR 145 million for risk capital investment, and EUR 50 million for compensations of loans and leasing contracts interests (during the payment holiday up to 6 months), EUR 100 million for a Business Support Fund, and EUR 50 million for payable invoices loans, EUR 100 million for a partial rent compensation, EUR 100 million for subsidies to micro-enterprises .
- A new borrowing instrument enables SMEs to apply for soft loans on the condition that they have run out of working capital due to disruptions in settlements with purchasers whose activities have been terminated or restricted due to quarantine. The maximum loan amount will be up to EUR 100 thousand.
- Starting from 24 April young firms (SMEs established less than 3 years ago) may get soft loans under the measure "Loans to the businesses most affected by COVID-19". Loans under this measure are easier to apply for, and are available to companies that have lost 30% or more of their turnover due to the COVID-19 outbreak. The maximum loan amount per firm has increased tenfold and now may reach up to EUR 1 million.
column43:
- Allocation of EUR 1.7 billion to the firms facing liquidity and financial problems: EUR 851 million for state guaranties

- The guarantee limit for the Agricultural Credit Guarantee Fund and ceiling for INVEGA (promoting the development of small
- and medium-sized enterprises) guarantee are set to increase by EUR 500 million.
column46: - The Bank of Lithuania has implemented a number of monetary policy measures adopted by the Eurosystem in response to the COVID-19 crisis. In this context, the central bank has significantly increased government bonds purchases and implemented collateral easing measures.
column47:
- In order to boost corporate and household lending, the Bank of Lithuania released the countercyclical capital buffer, reducing the rate from 1% to 0% on 18 March 2020.
- The Bank of Lithuania is taking a more flexible approach in terms of some capital and liquidity requirements imposed on banks. This would allow banks to provide additional EUR 2 billion in loans to businesses and residents. Systemic risk buffer has not been applied so far in Lithuania. Additional measures to increase liquidity will be implemented via joint ECB/Eurosystem efforts.

- New legal provisions, in effect from 30 March 2020, create the legal preconditions for the Bank of Lithuania to respond more effectively to liquidity problems in the market and assist a broader range of financial institutions. The new law enables the central bank to grant loans not only to credit institutions but also to other financial institutions experiencing liquidity problems.
column54: Information not available

column12:
On 15 April, the government presented its staggered exit strategy. Employers are encouraged to continue to revert to working-from-home-solutions where possible. In line with the Government's exit strategy, civil servants and government employees have been invited to gradually return to their offices from 20 July onwards while respecting the guidance of social distancing. *As of 24 June, the state of emergency has ended and with it the government has passed two laws that form the legal basis for the distance and hygiene regulations.
'COVID-19 patients need to self-quarantine, except if hospitalised.
*As of 23 July , the following restrictions apply, subject to fines in case of violation: (ii) Penalty for non-compliance with isolation or quarantine measures is a fine of EUR 25 to 500.
(iii) In the event of a repeated offence, failure to comply with preventive measures by shopkeepers, craftsmen, managers or other persons responsible for catering activities is punishable by withdrawal of the establishment permit for a period of three months.
(iv) As regards restaurants, a) no more than 10 people may be seated at any table; b) tables must be separated 1.5m from each other; c) wearing of facial protective gear is mandatory for staff at all times and for clients when not seated; and d) restaurants must close at midnight.
(v) Indoor fairs are prohibited.
(vi) The wearing of facial protective gear is mandatory in public transport and at any moment in which a social distance of 2m cannot be maintained
- except for children below the age of 13.



The following containment measures were put into place as an initial response to the COVID-19 outbreak:
*The state of emergency (“état de crise”) was declared on 18 March and approved by Parliament on 21 March for a period of 3 months.

* Movement on public roads by individuals was prohibited, except for a specified set of activities. Outdoor leisure activities (walking, jogging) were only allowed alone or together with persons from the same household.

* All large gatherings are prohibited and all public events are cancelled until at least 31 July, with the exception of marriages and funerals with a maximum of 20 participants.

* All shops (except supermarkets, craft and gardening companies, pharmacies, laundries, banks, newsagents and petrol stations), as well as all bars, cafes, restaurants, nightclubs, swimming pools and libraries had to remain closed, with possible fines in case of non-respect. Delivery, drive-in and take-out are authorised.

* Public service was reduced to tasks that are essential to the State's proper functioning and the management of the COVID-19 crisis.

Exit strategy:
*In the first phase, started on 20 April, construction sites, craft & gardening enterprises and stores, and recycling centers re-opened. Since 4 May, schools resumed progressively in line with the staggered exit strategy.
*The situation is continuously monitored, including through systematic testing, to inform decisions and adapt the strategy if necessary.
*As of 4 May, all medical activities have resumed and retirement and nursing homes permit visitors.
*On 11 May, the hospitality and retail sectors reopened under strict sanitary requirements.
column14: Information not available
column16: All schools, universities and kindergartens were closed on 16 March. On 4 May, final-year secondary classes and professional school have resumed. In a second phase, starting 11 May, the remaining secondary school students returned to classes. In a third phase, starting 25 May, elementary school, kindergartens and nurseries will re-open. A weekly rotation system between classes is in place to minimize contact. Additional protective measures have been implemented.
column18:
*As of 23 July , the following restrictions apply, subject to fines in case of violation:
(i) In-door private gatherings of no more than 10 people. Out-door gatherings in a public place are limited to 20 people. However, gatherings of more than 10 people at public events in a closed or open space are authorised under the double condition of assigned seating and the wear of a mask is mandatory if two meters distance cannot be complied with.
column20: A gradual reopening of all economic and commercial activities took place in May
column22: Luxembourg has presented two economic packages to address the consequences of the COVID-19 crisis. On 25 March, the Government presented a stabilisation package, worth EUR 10.4bn in total (as of 29 April). On 20 May, the Government presented the “Restart Luxembourg” package, worth EUR 700-800m, aimed at supporting the most affected companies, maintaining employment and fostering an ecological recovery during the exit strategy.
column25:
* Additional expenditures in the context of health and crisis management, notably for the procurement of medical equipment and infrastructure (up to €194m).

* Medical teleconsultations to be reimbursed.

* In order to ease the burden on general practitioners, upstaffing of “maisons médicales” and establishment of four regional centers designated specifically for COVID-19 patients. *Luxembourg has adopted one of the most ambitious testing strategies at European level, testing for those showing symptoms as well as large-scale testing aimed at identifying asymptomatic persons (around 20 000 tests per day). Luxembourg also systematically extends the testing to over 200.000 cross-border workers, accounting for up to 20% of the official total number of COVID cases in Luxembourg. Luxembourg's testing strategy is in line with international recommendations. Travellers arriving at the Luxembourg Airport will receive a voucher valid for several days to be tested in a medical laboratory of their choice. Business employees travelling for work will be able to take a COVID-19 test within 2 days prior of their departure.
*Employers that are allowed to perform their activities must take all the necessary measures to protect the health of their employees, notably by ensuring social distancing and making protective gear available.
*The COVID-19 Task Force has developed a “Large Scale Testing Strategy” based on a voluntary diagnostic test, accessible to the population, as well as cross-border commuters.
*The wearing of facial protective gear is mandatory in public transport and at any moment in which a social distance of 2m cannot be maintained
- except for children below the age of 13. On 20 April, every resident has received a kit of 5 masks. On 5 May, a second distribution of 50 masks for each person aged 16 and every cross-border worker was decided.
column28:
Tax measures

- Possibility for companies to request cancellation of Q1 and Q2 2020 corporate tax advance payments and for the deferral of payments due after 29 February, without late payment penalties.

- Deadline for filing corporate and personal income tax returns was extended to 30 June 2020.

- Outstanding VAT credits below €10,000 have automatically been reimbursed during the week of 16 March. Penalties for the late submission of VAT and other declarations were waived (estimated impact: €300m).

- Additional flexibility from 1 April by the "Centre commun de la sécurité sociale" for companies' payments of social contributions, notably through a temporary waiver on late payment fees and of forced recoveries of late payments.
-Tax relief for landlords who waive a share of the rent owed by tenants during 2020 to encourage rent reductions (capped at EUR 15 000).

- Suspension of the default interest on overdue social security contributions until 31 December 2020.

Expenditure measures

- Under the stabilisation package, the short-time working scheme (“chômage partiel”) was extended to all companies affected by effects of the current crisis, with 80% of employee's salary being reimbursed through the Fonds pour l'emploi, floored at minimum wage and up to a level of 250% of minimum wage (estimated impact: €989m). Simplified, online procedures were put in place for companies requesting “chômage partiel”. Accelerated process through the introduction of advance payments. The short-time working scheme for structural reasons was further extended until 31 December (all companies affected by the sanitary crisis remain eligible).

- Wide range of available direct aid schemes to companies remain fully available.

- New aid scheme introduced to support SMEs in temporary financial difficulties due to exceptional and unpredictable events (such as the current COVID-19 outbreak), providing repayable advances of up to €500 000 (estimated impact: €400m). This scheme was extended until 15 September as part of the recovery package.

- Companies with less than 10 employees, forced to cease their activities under the state of emergency, may receive tax-free lump-sum grants of up to €5000 (estimated impact: €50m). At the end of April, additional financial support was decided for businesses forced to cease their activities under the state of emergency or experiencing a significant loss in turnover (€5000 for companies with less than 10 employees & €12 500 for companies with 10-20 employees).
-Tax-free lump-sum grant of €2500 to self-employed professionals (estimated impact €27.5 m). A complementary tax-free grant between €3000 and €4000 was implemented with broader eligibility criteria (adopted after 29 April).

- Financial aid for professional journalists of €5000 (adopted after 29 April).

- Financial support for COVID-19 related R&D and investment aid for production of articles relevant to the fight against COVID-19 (e.g. protective masks). Targeted support for start-ups through an increase of the co-funding rate and a call for projects to address the consequences of COVID-19 (estimated impact €34 m).
-Financial contribution to the “COVID-19 Therapeutics Accelerator” initiative to develop treatments against COVID-19.

- One-off special advance payment to companies to reimburse for costs related to special leave for family reasons due to school closures (estimated impact: €222m).

- As of 1 April (and until the end of the state of emergency), health insurance covers 100% of sickness leave payments from the first day of leave to provide liquidity support for employers and avoid income loss for employees.
Additional measures under the recovery package:
-A Recovery and Solidarity Fund worth EUR 200m will be set up for a period of 6 months (1 July to 31 December) to support companies and independent professionals in the hospitality, events and tourism sectors, fitness centres and similar activities. The Fund will provide lump-sum, tax-free grants to eligible companies worth EUR 1 250/month per working employee and EUR 250/month per employee in a short-time work scheme. To be eligible, companies must (i) have restarted their activity and (ii) have had a turnover loss of at least 25%. Companies may not dismiss more than 25% of their FTEs. Support is capped at EUR 10 000/month for companies with less than 10 employees; at EUR 50 000/month for companies with 10-49 employees; at EUR 100 000/month for companies with 50+ employees.
-Regressive grants for the in-store retail sector (except food stores) with less than 250 employees to help restart activities (EUR 1 000/employee in June, EUR 750/employee in July, EUR 500/employee in August
- capped at a total of EUR 50 000/month).
-To create incentives for investment into projects of economic development, digitalisation or environmental protection, an investment support of up to 50% of eligible costs (capped at EUR 800 000) has been created.

- Several measures to promote a green recovery:
(i) 50% increase of subsidies granted for promoting sustainable energy renovation of buildings
(ii) 25% increase of subsidies granted for promoting heating systems based on renewable energy sources
(iii) 60% increase of subsidies granted for promoting the purchase of electric cars and vans (from EUR 5 000 to EUR 8 000)
(iv) doubling of subsidies granted for promoting the purchase of electric vehicles other than cars
(v) new subsidy programme for individuals to install electric charging stations
(vi) temporary compensation for the administrative burden related to programmes supporting energy efficiency in the private sector
(vii) enlargement of the scope of beneficiaries of aid for solar energy installations above 30kW

Loan facilities & loan conditions

- Commitment by Luxembourg banks to offer a 6-month moratorium on loan repayments for SMEs, self-employed and liberal professionals.

- New loan facility by SNCI in collaboration with commercial banks, with an envelope of up to €700m.

- Relaxation of repayment terms for SNCI loans and credits.

Guarantees

- New loan guarantee facility of €2.5bn, with the State providing a guarantee of 85% on credit lines granted by select banks between 18 March and 31 December 2020.

- New "SME Guarantee" of €200 m by SNCI to provide guarantees for obtaining new working capital lines from banks active in corporate financing
- Companies with cash flow difficulties can request guarantees from “mutualités de cautionnement”.

- Use of “export guarantees” provided by the Office du Ducroire to support companies to develop their activities on international markets has been extended. Draft law tabled to Parliament to increase the amount of guarantees provided by the Office du Ducroire to €500m.

Sectorial
-Temporary suspension of refunds for cancelled package holidays in support of travel agents.
-Suspension of registration fees for the digital sales platform “Letzshop.lu” in 2020.
-The “Restart Tourism” strategy was presented on 4 June 2020, consisting of:
(i) A voucher worth EUR 50 for one night of accommodation in Luxembourg for every citizen above 16 years and every cross-border worker.
(ii) A tourism fund of EUR 3m will be set up to support non-profit organisations and support the sector as a whole.
(iii) Acceleration of the sector's digitalisation through the centralisation of data for marketing purposes.
(iv) Strengthening of investment in the sector to ensure sustainable development and present Luxembourg as a business events destination.
(v) A label certifying compliance with sanitary measures will be developed.

- Various financial support measures for the cultural sector, among which:
(i) A compensation for losses incurred due to cancelled events until 31 August 2020
(ii) An investment support for regional museums and cultural sites
(iii) Additional calls for projects through the Ministry

- Various financial support measures for the sports sector, among which:
(i) A direct aid for registered sport clubs (EUR 20 per licenced athlete)
(ii) A compensation for losses incurred due to cancelled events (capped at EUR 3 000)
(iii) A lump-sum grant for the acquisition of sports material (capped at EUR 5 000)

- “Fit 4 Resilience” will support the elaboration of business plans with the help of consultants.

- Financial support measures for cultural professionals (estimated impact: €2m).

- To support the legal profession, increase by 10% of the hourly rates for legal assistance provided by the State.

- Several measures to support the agriculture sector were adopted on 12 June:
(i) A lump-sum grant between EUR 2 500 and 5 000 for businesses affected by the COVID-19 crisis
(ii) Start-up aid for small farm-businesses that market local, seasonal and organic agricultural products
(iii) Support measures will be tailored to better address environmental challenges

- Several measures to support the audiovisual sector were adopted on 12 June:
(i) A repayable advance up to EUR 250 000 based on the aid scheme for SMEs in temporary financial difficulties due to exceptional and unpredictable events (as introduced by the stabilisation package), with criteria adapted to the particular needs of the audiovisual sector.
(ii) A lump-sum grant of up to EUR 10 000 to provide further liquidity support and compensate for incurred losses.
(iii) Temporary waiver of the obligation to refund financial support granted prior to the COVID-19 crisis in case the project is not finalised.

Expenditure measures

- Wide range of available direct aid schemes to companies remains fully available.

- Companies with less than 10 employees, forced to cease their activities under the “state of crisis”, to receive tax-free lump-sum grants of up to €5000 (estimated impact: €50m).

- New aid scheme introduced to support SMEs in temporary financial difficulties due to exceptional and unpredictable events (such as the current COVID-19 outbreak), providing repayable advances of up to €500 000 (estimated impact: €300m).

- One-off special advance payment to companies to reimburse for costs related to special leave for family reasons due to school closures.

Tax measures

- Deadline for filing corporate and personal income tax returns is extended to 30 June 2020.

- Outstanding VAT credits below €10,000 have automatically been reimbursed during the week of 16 March. Penalties for the late submission of VAT and other declarations are waived (estimated impact: €50m).

column46: Luxembourg is part of the euro area. The ECB is the competent institution for monetary policy.
column47:
Macroprudential:

* In line with the increased flexibility provided by the European Central Bank for “significant institutions”, the Financial Sector Supervisory Commission (CSSF) applies the same flexibility for “less significant institutions”.
column51: Temporary suspension of refunds for cancelled package holidays in support of travel agents.
column54:
Regulatory measures:

- Possibility to hold shareholder meetings by remote vote, proxy or videoconference has been introduced. Board meetings may also be held without physical meetings.

- Temporary derogations to the accounting law for companies, notably to extend the deadlines for filing and publishing accounts.

- Suspension of the obligation to make an admission of cessation of payments leading to bankruptcy.

- Non-commercial rents may not be raised until 31 December 2020.

Labour measures:

- Strengthening of protection against dismissals for workers on short timesickness leave and all workers in companies claiming “chômage partiel”.

- Automatic extension of trial contracts in companies claiming “chômage partiel”.

- Temporary, conditional derogations to labour law for essential sectors, notably to increase maximum limits of daily and weekly worktimes and to allow for the possibility to cancel or refuse annual leave.

- New online platform (“JobSwitch”) to connect unemployed persons, workers on short time and self-employed professionals to companies in need of labour.

Sectorial:
-The CSSF has issued recommendations to supervised entities to facilitate work-from-home solutions wherever possible, subject to appropriate IT security conditions. The CSSF reiterated this recommendation in the context of the exit strategy, noting that the return to the workplace should be limited to a minimum.
-The CSSF has launched a weekly questionnaire to investment fund managers to receive regular updates on financial data (total net assets, subscriptions and redemptions) and governance arrangements.
-The insurance regulator (CAA) has temporarily suspended the deadlines on non-judicial dispute resolutions with insurance companies.

- The CSSF and CAA have provided flexibility as regards reporting deadlines in several areas.
-Automatic extension of elapsing construction permits by a year following the end of the state of emergency.
-Authorisation of heavy-duty transport on Sundays and temporary suspension of training obligation for professional truck and train drivers in order to ensure the transport of goods.

Public financial management:
Parliament passed a law to extend the legal deadline for submitting the general account of the State.

column12:
- On 18 March, the government imposed a nation-wide lockdown (the Movement Control Order) until 31 March (announced on 16 March). The MCO consists of the stay-at-home measure and closure of all non-essential businesses.

- On 25 March, the Movement Control Order was extended until 14 April.

- On 10 April, the Movement Control Order (MCO) was extended until 28 April.

- On 23 April, the Movement Control Order (MCO) was extended until 12 May with some relaxation. Under Phase 4 of the MCO effective 29 April, people can go out beyond a 10km radius for essential service purchases, such as daily food and medical services. Two people from one household can go out.

- On 4 May, the Conditional Movement Control Order was introduced to replace the MCO. Four people can go out together in a car.

- On 13 May, the Conditional Movement Control Order was extended until 9 June.

- On 10 June, the Recovery Movement Control Order (RMCO) started. The RMCO will continue until 31 August. All restrictions on business activities, domestic travels and school closure are eased with a few exceptions, such as entertainment places and contact sports.

- On 1 August, wearing a mask is mandatory in public space and transportation.

- On 1 September, the RMCO was extended to 31 December 2020.
column14:
- On 27 January, a temporary entry ban was imposed for travellers from Hubei province, China.

- On 9 February, Zhejiang and Changdu provinces, China were added to the list.

- On 28 February, Daegu city and Cheongdo district in Korea were added to the list.

- On 5 March, Lombardy, Veneto and Emilia-Romagna in Italy; Hokkaido in Japan, and Tehran, Qom and Gilan in Iran were added to the list.

- On 13 March, the entry ban was extended to all travellers from Korea, Italy and Iran.

- On 14 March, Denmark was added to the list.

- From 18 March, all international travellers were banned to enter the country until 31 March. Some state governments imposed stricter bans than the national level.

- On 25 March, the Movement Control Order was extended until 14 April.

- On 10 April, the Movement Control Order (MCO) was extended until 28 April.

- On 23 April, the Movement Control Order (MCO) was extended until 12 May.

- On 4 May, the Conditional Movement of Control Order was introduced to replace the MCO. The borders remain closed. Inter-state travel is allowed for work purposes.

- On 13 May, the Conditional Movement Control Order was extended until 9 June.

- On 10 June, the Recovery Movement Control Order (RMCO) started. The RMCO will continue until 31 August. All restrictions on business activities, domestic travels and school closure are eased with a few exceptions, such as entertainment places and contact sports.

- On 24 June, the border restrictions were relaxed concerning the entry of expatriates in high management positions. Different quarantine rules are applied depending on which country they come from.

- On 1 July, the border restrictions were relaxed for healthcare travellers.

- On 17 August, business travel to/from Singapore was allowed under certain conditions of testing and quarantine (the application started from 10 August).

- On 1 September, the RMCO was extended to 31 December 2020.
column16:
- Under the MCO, schools are also closed from 18 March to 31 March.

- On 25 March, the Movement Control Order was extended until 14 April.

- On 10 April, the Movement Control Order (MCO) was extended until 28 April.

- On 23 April, the Movement Control Order (MCO) was extended until 12 May.

- On 4 May, the Conditional Movement of Control Order was introduced to replace the MCO. Schools are closed.

- On 13 May, the Conditional Movement Control Order was extended until 9 June.

- On 10 June, the Recovery Movement Control Order (RMCO) started. The RMCO will continue until 31 August. All restrictions on business activities, domestic travels and school closure are eased with a few exceptions, such as entertainment places and contact sports.

- From 24 June, schools started to reopen in phases.
column18:
- Mass gatherings and international conferences have been prohibited until 30 April (announced on 13 March).

- On 18 March, the government imposed a nation-wide lockdown (the Movement Control Order) until 31 March (announced on 16 March).

- On 25 March, the Movement Control Order was extended until 14 April.

- On 10 April, the Movement Control Order (MCO) was extended until 28 April.

- On 23 April, the Movement Control Order (MCO) was extended until 12 May.

- On 4 May, the Conditional Movement of Control Order was introduced to replace the MCO. Social gatherings are still banned.

- On 13 May, the Conditional Movement Control Order was extended until 9 June.

- On 10 June, the Recovery Movement Control Order (RMCO) started. The RMCO will continue until 31 August. All restrictions on business activities, domestic travels and school closure are eased with a few exceptions, such as entertainment places and contact sports.

- On 1 September, the RMCO was extended to 31 December 2020.
column20:
- On 16 March, the government announced that the Movement Control Order would be imposed from 18 March to 31 March.

- On 25 March, the Movement Control Order was extended until 14 April.

- On 10 April, the Movement Control Order (MCO) was extended until 28 April.

- On 23 April, the Movement Control Order (MCO) was extended until 12 May.

- On 4 May, the Conditional Movement of Control Order was introduced to replace the MCO. Most businesses can restart their operations.

- On 13 May, the Conditional Movement Control Order was extended until 9 June.

- On 10 June, the Recovery Movement Control Order (RMCO) started. The RMCO will continue until 31 August. All restrictions on business activities, domestic travels and school closure are eased with a few exceptions, such as entertainment places and contact sports.

- On 1 September, the RMCO was extended to 31 December 2020.
column22:
- On 27 February, the government announced a stimulus package amounting to 1.3% of GDP. The package include the deferment of income tax payment, the reduction of social contribution, among others.

- On 16 March, the government announced supplementary fiscal measures amounting to 0.04% of GDP, which includes a monthly allowance to workers forced to take unpaid leave (from March to August) and a 15% electricity discount to the tourism industry and 2% discount to the commercial, industrial and agriculture sectors and domestic users (from April to September).

- On 27 March, the government announced the second stimulus package amounting to 17% of GDP. This includes cash assistant to low-income households until May.

- On 6 April, the government announced new measures (RM 10 billion, 0.7% of GDP) to support SMEs, which also includes an enhanced wage support scheme.

- On 5 June, the government announced an additional stimulus package (Short-Term Economic Recovery Plan, RM 35 billion), which incudes the extension of the wage subsidy programme.
column25: Information not available
column28: The second package was announced on 16 March. It includes a monthly allowance to workers forced to take unpaid leave (from March to August)
column31: Information not available
column34: Information not available

column40: Information not available
column43: Information not available
column46:
- On 3 March, Bank Negara Malaysia cut its policy rate by 25bps to 2.5%.

- On 19 March, the central bank reduced its statutory reserve rate from 3.00% to 2.00% to provide sufficient liquidity to financial institutions.

- On 27 March, the central bank announced that it would enhance the existing financing facilities for SMEs by increasing the funding allocation.

- On 5 May, the central bank cut its policy rate by 50bps to 2.00%.

- On 7 July, the central bank cut its policy rate by 25bps to 1.75%.
column47: On 25 March, the central bank allowed banking institutions to reduce the capital conservation buffer.
column48:
- On 25 March, the central bank requested a 6-month deferment of bank loans to individuals and SMEs affected by the outbreak.

- On 29 July, the central bank announced that banks would provide a targeted extension of the moratorium and repayment flexibility to individuals and SMEs affected by the outbreak.

- On 25 March, the central bank requested a 6-month deferment of bank loans to individuals and SMEs affected by the outbreak.

- On 29 July, the central bank announced that banks would provide a targeted extension of the moratorium and repayment flexibility to individuals and SMEs affected by the outbreak.
column54: Information not available

column12:
*May 8: Lifting of curfew nationwide.
*March 25: Declaration of the national health emergency on top of the prevailing state of emergency due to insecurity, while maintaining the electoral process scheduled for March 29 and April 19.
*March 25: Curfew from 9pm to 5am, starting March 26, until further notice.
column14:
*April 1: Strengthening of sanitary surveillance in airports and land corridors.
*March 27: Limitation of the number of passengers in public and private vehicles, including taxis and motorbikes.
*March 25: Closure of land borders (except fret, essential goods transportation).
*March 17: Suspension of commercial flights from affected countries (except cargos), starting March 19, until further notice.
*March 13: Mandatory quarantine for people coming from affected countries.
column16: *Re-opening of schools for the final year students, starting June 2. The school reopening for other students is scheduled for September 1st.
column18:
*May 8: Obligation to wear masks in public places.
*March 25: Restrictions on markets required to respect barrier measures while remaining open.
*March 17: Ban on public gatherings, including workshops and conferences; ban on social ceremonies, including weddings, baptism and funerals, sport, cultural and political gatherings of more than 50 people, starting March 19; Recommendations to follow good hygiene practices and social distancing protocols.
column20:
*April 16: Retail markets will remain open from 6am to 4pm, starting April 2.
*April 3: Re-organisation of the working hours in public administration (except defence, security and health services), from 7.30am to 2pm, starting April 1.
*March 17: Closure of nightclubs and bars, starting March 19.
column22:
*April 27: The Heads of States of the West-Africa Economic and Monetary Union (UEMOA) declared a temporary suspension of the UEMOA growth and stability Pact setting six convergence criteria, including the 3% of GDP fiscal deficit rule, to help member-countries cope with the fallout of the Covid-19 pandemic.

*April 10: A package of economic measures was announced to ease liquidity constraints on ailing firms, including an SMEs-support guarantee fund, clearing the budget spending float, granting tax deferral and relief to ease liquidity constraints on the hardest-hit companies, especially in the hospitality sector (hotels, restaurants, transportation).

*April 10: Payment of a special bonus to mobilised health personnel and to the elements of the security and defence forces assigned to the surveillance of the curfew and assembly places.

*March 17: Setting up of initial budget of XOF6.3 billion to fight against the Coronavirus pandemic.
column25:
*The government has updated its medical response plan, now costed at about 0.5% of GDP, to prevent the spread of COVID-19 and strengthen its medical care capacity, in collaboration with the World Health Organization (WHO).

*Collaboration with the World Bank in order to enhance medical care capacity (respirators, quarantine facilities, etc.)

*April 10: Giving up of 3-month salary of the President, 2 months for the Prime Minister, and 1 month for other members of the government; Launch of “One Malian, one mask” programme, ordering 20 million washable masks to be locally produced.

*April 8: Government to disinfect public places, notably markets.

*April 1: Government to raise public awareness of preventive measures; Take care of the sick and their families; Support and protect health and security personnel.

*March 21: The Central Bank of West African States (BCEAO) has introduced measures to promote the use of electronic payments.
column28:
*April 10: The government has unveiled a package of social measures to support the most vulnerable households. These measures include:

- Setup of a XOF100 billion special fund to provide targeted income support to the poorest households;

- Supply of electricity and water free of charge to the poorest consumers for the months of April and May 2020;

- 3 month exemption from VAT on electricity and water tariffs;

- 3 month exemption from customs duties on the import of basic food (rice and milk);

- Distribution of 56 000 tons of cereal and 16 000 tons of livestock feed, free of charge.

*April 2: Setting up of fixed prices for basic commodities (sugar, rice, edible oil, cotton cake, bread, butane gas).

column46:
*June 22: The Monetary Policy Committee cut by 50 basis points the ceiling and the floor of the monetary policy corridor, to 4 and 2% respectively.

*The Central Bank of West African States (BCEAO) launched a special 3-month refinancing window at a fixed rate of 2.5% for limited amounts of 3-month “Covid-19 T-bills” to be issued by each UEMOA sovereign to help meet immediate funding needs related to the current pandemic. The amount of such special T-bills issued by Mali amounted to 0.8% of GDP.

*March 25: The West African Development Bank (BOAD) decided to grant to the WAEMU (UEMOA) members countries XOF120 billion in concessional loans (XOF15 billion per country) to be disbursed immediately; such loans are softened though the interest subsidy mechanism replenished by BCEAO and the WAEMU Commission for XOF25 billion and XOF15 billion, respectively.

*March 23: The BCEAO raised the liquidity made available to banks at its weekly and monthly auctions of March 23, allowing average refinancing rates to remain relatively close to the floor of the monetary policy corridor of 2.5%. This was followed, starting with the weekly refinancing auction on March 30, by the adoption of a full allotment strategy at a fixed rate of 2.5% thereby allowing banks to satisfy their liquidity needs fully at a lower rate.
column47: *March 21: The Central Bank of West African States (BCEAO) has: i) extended the collateral framework to access central bank refinancing to include bank loans to prequalified 1700 private companies; ii) set-up a framework inviting banks to accommodate demands from firms with COVID-19 related repayment difficulties to postpone for a 3 month renewable period debt service falling due, without the need to classify such postponed claims as NPL.
column54:
*May 19: Release of 400 prisoners as a preventive step against the spread of Covid-19. Hundreds of detainees had previously been affected by these clemency measures.

*April 30: The International Monetary Fund approved a disbursement of USD 200 million under the Rapid Credit Facility to help Mali meet urgent balance-of-payments and fiscal needs stemming.

*April 10: The World Bank has approved a USD 25.8 million International Development Association (IDA) 50% grant and 50% credit to support Mali's response to Covid-19. The Covid-19 Emergency Response project will help improve access to health care services and promote an integrated response to Covid-19 through greater screening, detection and treatment of patients; as well as improved laboratory capacity and surveillance.

*The United Nations system will provide support in various sectors with more than USD 3 million (nearly XOF 2 billion).

*April 6: The UN Mission in Mali (MINUSMA) signed three assistance protocols worth about USD 3 million (XOF 1.6 billion). These funds will make possible to finance projects aimed at acquiring specialized medical equipment and to provide health care personnel with adequate training.

column12:
*July 10: Lifting of the curfew.
*May 14: Obligatory use of masks in all public places.
*May 6: Curfew is modified from 11pm to 6am.
*March 20: Curfew from 6pm to 6am, beginning March 21.
column14:
*July 10: Resuming of interregional movements of people and domestic flights.
*March 29: All road traffic and movement of people between the wilayas (regions) is prohibited except for health workers, service delivery missions and the transportation of goods.
*March 22: Border closure.
*March 15: Mandatory quarantine for all travellers coming from an affected country.
*March 15: Suspension of all commercial flights beginning March 17.
*March 15: Land border control is reinforced.
column16:
*Re-opening of schools for examination classes on July 1.
*March 15: Closure of schools.
column18:
*May 10: Re-opening of mosques after a week of no new coronavirus cases. Authorities allowed mosques to open for prayer, but called on worshippers to respect social distancing and wear masks.
*May 6: Friday prayer resume starting May 8.
*March 27: Suspension of Friday prayer.
*March 20: Ban on public gatherings.
*March 15: Suspension of large public gatherings.
column20:
*July 10: Re-opening of restaurants and cafes.
*May 6: Re-opening of public markets; restaurants are allowed to do take-away, starting May 7.
*March 29: Closure of all public markets except those selling food.
*March 20: Closure of restaurants and cafes.
column22:
*May 6: The government has approved additional health, medical supplies, social protection, SME support, foodstuff stocks, and security-related expenditures to address the pandemic (about USD 210 million, 3.2% of GDP).

*March 25: The government announced the creation of an emergency fund of about USD 80 million (1.1% of GDP) for urgent the procurement of medical supplies and equipment, subsidies to 30 000 poor households and financial support to small individual businesses. It also waived customs duties and taxes on imports of essential goods and signalled that it will take additional measures as more resources are mobilised.
column25:
*March 31: Assignment of an operational multidisciplinary medical team to monitor people placed in sanitary confinement, intervene and rescue as necessary.
*March 31: Opening of a new hospital equipped with 100 beds for the confinement of suspected cases

column46:
*March 26: Creation of the "Fund for Social Solidarity and the Fight against the Coronavirus". The fund is part of the measures taken by the government to deal with the pandemic and its health, economic and social consequences. It is to receive contributions from the State, public and private entities and individuals.
*Measures taken by the central bank to support the economy include: a reduction of the policy rate from 6.5% to 5%; a reduction of the marginal lending rate from 9% to 6.5%; and a decrease of the reserve requirement ration from 7% to 5%.

column12:
*May 29: Mauritius lifted lockdown restrictions as of midnight, May 30.
*May 1: The Council of Ministers extended the lockdown from 4 May to 1 June. A first phase of controlled reopening is planned from 15 May 2020 to allow for the progressive resumption of activities.
*April 13: nationwide lockdown has been extended to May 4.
*March 30: The period of confinement was extended to April 15. *March 23: A curfew is in place from 20:00 to 08:00 local time until further notice. People are not permitted to be in the streets during those hours except for emergency purposes. *March 20: A period of confinement for two weeks has been announced.
column14:
*September 1: the government of Mauritius announced that reopening of its borders will take place in three phases. The first phase comprises the repatriation of Mauritians stranded abroad which will continue until 30 September 2020. Arriving passengers will continue to be quarantined in the centres made available by the State. The second phase will start on 01 October 2020 during which travel to and from certain destinations will be allowed but priority will be given to Mauritian nationals, licensed residents, those employed in Mauritius and other visitors wishing to travel to Mauritius. The third phase of reopening the borders will be determined as the pandemic evolves. Citizens who are directly affected by the restrictions, currently put in place, including hotel taxis and tourist operators, will continue to receive financial assistance from the Government.
*July 20: Following the successful resumption of commercial flights to and from Rodrigues Island since 1 July, the Air Mauritius has announced that its route between Port Louis-Sir Seewoosagur Ramgoolam and Rodrigues-Plaine Corail Airports will start with two flights a day by 1 August 2020. Air Mauritius international commercial flights remain suspended until 1 September.
*June 15: Mauritius Prime Minister has prohibited the entry of aircraft and ships to the island until 31 August 2020, except for those approved by him.
*March 18: The Prime Minister announced that all passengers, including Mauritians and foreigners, will be prohibited from entering Mauritian territory for the next 15 days, which started at 6:00 GMT (10:10 a.m. Mauritian time). Passengers leaving Mauritius will be allowed to leave. Cargo airplanes and ships will also be allowed to enter the country.
column16:
*June 6: The Vice-Prime Minister, Minister of Education, Tertiary Education, Science and Technology, Mrs Leela Devi Dookun-Luchoomun, announced that resumption of classes will be made in two stages
- on August 1st and September 12, and under strict sanitary and social distancing conditions (i.e. mandatory face coverings, daily contactless temperature checks at school entrance, and Social distancing within classrooms and school compound and outside school premises).
*May 29: Prime Minister Jugnauth announced schools will however remain closed, as full resumption remains slated for August 3.
*May 1: Schools will remain closed until August 1st, 2020.
*April 1: The Ministry of Education announced the guidelines and broadcast timetables for online learning from grades 1 to 13. All higher education courses are already available online. In addition, the Mauritius Institute of Education (MIE) has made distance courses available to educators, parents and students on its website the Early Digital Learning Program and developed a support program for Special Education Need Schools. For pre-primary, the MIE posted on its website a series of programs, accessible to parents.
*March 18: The Government announced that all schools and universities would be shut until further notice.
column18:
*May 29: Prime Minister Jugnauth announced that despite the lockdown lifted on May 30 at midgnight, beaches, cinema, discotheques will not open straight away.Collective sports, religious events and cultural events will also not be possible.
*May 1: It was announced that religious, political and union gatherings remained banned; bakeries, barbers, butchers and fishmongers will be able to re-open on May 15. Markets, bars and shopping centers will remain closed until June 1, while schools will resume on August 1. Beaches are also prohibited on the Indian Ocean island, a tourist hot spot, while a maximum of 10 people can attend weddings and funerals.
*April 8: The election of Counsellors of French living abroad and of Consular Delegates scheduled for 16-17 May has been postponed (date TBD). Four out of the 443 Counsellors are elected in the capital city of Port-Louis for a 6-year term.
column20:
*May 30: Following the Government's decision to lift the curfew on 30 May 2020, all officers of the Public Service are to resume work starting 01 June 2020 and the Tourism Authority will allow those in the sector to resume operations, except for marine activities, starting 31 May 2020, under strict sanitary measures.
*May 29: Prime Minister Jugnauth announced restaurants, café, food-court, shops, shopping malls and prayer houses can start their activities under some sanitary precautions as of May 30.
*March 20: The Ministry of Finance, Economic Planning and Development announced that during the confinement period, the general public will be restricted for movement. Employers shall encourage “Work -from-Home” to ensure business continuity. For activities that are necessary for functioning of the country, some employees will be allowed to attend duty on-site provided they are in possession of an authorised COVID 19 Work Access Permit, which will be authorised by the Monitoring Committee COVID 19, set up by the Government.
*March 24: The authorities closed all supermarkets, bakeries and shops (until 2 April). Only essential services including police, medical, and fire rescue are permitted to operate. Pharmacies and banks are operating with reduced hours and additional regulations. The Ministry of Commerce and the Mauritius Chamber of Commerce and Industry have established a website for the distribution of essential goods.
column22:
*June 23: Minister of Finance, Economic Planning and Development, Renganaden Padayachy, introduced the Supplementary Appropriation Bill (2019-2020) at the National Assembly which makes provision for an additional financial allocation of Rs 33,700,000,000, with regards to Government expenditure for financial year 2019-2020. According to the Minister this amount will help meet the expenses, calculated at Rs 25.2 billion, in connection with the COVID-19 pandemic. These include, inter alia, 1) the Rs 1.2 billion Ministry of Health and Wellness for the purchase of Medical Supplies in connection with the COVID-19 pandemic; 2) Rs 11.0 billion in respect of the Wage Assistance Scheme put in place to provide financial support to employees of the private sector who became technically unemployed during the COVID-19 lockdown/curfew period. The provision caters for the expected disbursement under the scheme up to June 2020; 3) Rs 45 million for basic food items distributed to families on the Social Register of Mauritius, those receiving Carers' Allowance as well as residents of homes in connection with the COVID-19 pandemic; 4) Rs 10.0 billion as transfer to the National Resilience Fund for implementing schemes and programmes to ensure resilience in the wake of COVID-19. Out of this amount, Rs 9.0 billion has been earmarked as support to the National Air Carrier “Air Mauritius”; and 5) Rs 0.65 billion to account for the purchase of SDRs (Special Drawing Rights) by Government upon request made by the IMF in accordance with the Articles of Agreement.
*June 16: The Minister of Housing and Land Use Planning, Louis Steven Obeegadoo, announced that the 2020-2021 Budget will provide for the construction of 12,000 houses in a period of 3 years, which he stressed, is an unprecedented financial commitment from the Government to act quickly and efficiently to build a large number of social housing within a short deadline. This measure is partly due to the sudden and exponential increase in squatters who violated curfew law during the COVID-19 pandemic, whereby some 170 squatters erected illegal structures on state land in two weeks. Once vacated, some of the state land currently occupied by squatters will be also used for the construction of health centres.
*May 15: The COVID-19 (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill was adopted by the National Assembly after three days of deliberations. It aims at empowering the economy, save enterprises and jobs, and build for a recovery overtime.
*May 13: Primer Minister, Mr Pravind Kumar Jugnauth, introduced the COVID-19 (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill and the Quarantine Bill in the National Assembly. While the former aims at amending 57 laws, inter alia, the Bank of Mauritius Act, the Central Electricity Board Act amended, the Central Water Authority Act amended, Civil Status Act, the latter seeks to repeal the Quarantine Act, which dates back to the year 1954, and re-enact a reformed and modern appropriate legislative framework so as to provide more measures for the prevention and spread of communicable diseases. Both Bills will include strict sanitary measures that will be enforced in public transport, schools, metro, offices, elevators, taxis and other public places. These sanitary measures will also be applicable at the airport with the arrival of repatriated Mauritians from other countries.
column25:
*August 18: Prime Minister, Mr Pravind Kumar Jugnauth, announced at the National Assembly that the COVID-19 laboratory, being set up at the Sir Seewoosagur Ramgoolam International Airport to effect PCR tests on all arriving passengers, will be operational in a few weeks.
*June 4: Minister of Finance, Economic Planning and Development, Dr Renganaden Padayachy, presented the National Budget 04 June 2020. In a joint statement, PM Jugnauth affirmed that the priority of Budget 2020/2021 is to revive the Mauritian economy amid the Covid-19 pandemic and give a new impetus to most affected sectors such as agriculture and tourism.
*May 15: The COVID-19 Quarantine Bill was adopted by the National Assembly after three days of deliberations. It seeks to prevent the resurgence of COVID-19 infection, and step up the preparedness and response of the country to any future pandemic.
*April 27: Mauritius rolled out its mass testing, with the aim to screen over 100 000 people over the next two weeks. Mass testing with immediate quarantine of infectious people and their contacts would allow the lockdown to be gradually released while protecting lives and controlling the epidemic.
*April 5: Minister of Foreign Affairs, Regional Integration and International Trade, Mr. Nandcoomar Bodha, announced that between April 9-19, Air Mauritius will fly daily to China, to recover 231 tonnes of medical equipment including, masks, protective suits, medicines, thermometers and other health devices.
*March 2: Operational Plan on COVID -19 prepared by the Ministry of Health and Wellness was circulated to all stakeholders inclusive of the media, private sector, ministries and departments, the port and the airport.
column28:
*March 31: Self-employed individuals who are either in business (examples: shops, hawkers, hair dressers, etc.) or are casual workers (examples: masons, plumbers, artists etc.) are eligible under the Assistance Scheme to the Informal Sector to receive a financial support of Rs 5,100 (i.e. 50% of Guaranteed Income) for the period March 16 to April 15, 2020.
*March 20: the Mauritius Revenue Authority issued a communique stating that taxpayers who are unable to submit returns or effect payment of tax due to the lockdown will not be charged any penalty or interest for late submission or payment. No cut-off date has as of yet been communicated on this grace period.
column31: Information not available
column34:
*July 27: The Minister of Finance, Economic Planning and Development, Dr Renganaden Padayachy, announced in a press statement that the Mauritius Investment Corporation (MIC) has so far received applications from 40 companies and will shortly make its first disbursement to big corporates that are in financial distress following the COVID-19 crisis.
*June 24: The Mauritius Revenue Authority (MRA) informs the public that the Government Wage Assistance Scheme (GWAS) and the Self-Employed Assistance Scheme (SEAS) have been extended for the month of June 2020 to operators having the necessary licence/permit from the relevant authorities to operate the following activities: 1) Tourism sector; 2) Premises that remained closed or activities that were not allowed to be carried out under Covid-19 Regulations 2020 and 3) Self-employed. The GWAS, initially established in March 2020, is an economic measure by the Government of Mauritius to provide a Government wage subsidy to Employers, as a response to the COVID-19 pandemic, to ensure that all employees are duly paid their salary.
*March 31: The Minister of Finance Economic Planning and Development announced the Wage Assistance Scheme whereby enterprises will be entitled to receive an amount equivalent to the 15 days' basic wage bill for all of its employees drawing a monthly basic wage of up to Rs 50,000 subject to a cap of Rs 12,500 per employee. This money will be credited to their account and if they do not have a bank account, they will receive same by post. All eligible persons are requested to register with the MRA online or contact the MRA on the dedicated hotline.
*The Government decided to implement a Self-Employed Assistance Scheme (SEAS) through the Mauritius Revenue Authority (MRA) to assist Eligible Self-Employed individuals will receive a financial support of Rs 5,100 (i.e. 50% of Guaranteed Income) for the period March 16 to April 15 2020.
column37:
*June 26: The Mauritius Revenue Authority (MRA) announced the extension of Corporate Tax filing deadline & Payment of Taxes. Companies, with an accounting period ended in the month of September to December 2019 and where no tax is payable or a loss is declared will not be subject to penalties for late submission of their annual Corporate Tax return provided that the return is submitted on or before 31 July 2020. It also informed that all companies engaged in tourism activities, with accounting period ended on any date between 01 September 2019 and 30 June 2020, and which are eligible to the Government Wage Assistance Scheme (GWAS) for the month of June 2020, that they may avail themselves of an extended delay to pay any tax due in accordance with their annual income tax return, as follows:
a) half of the tax shall be payable on or before 28 December 2020; and
b) the remainder shall be payable on or before 28 June 2021.
column40:
*March 31: In addition to the moratorium of 6 months on capital repayments, eligible Enterprises will also benefit from a moratorium of 6 months on interest payments in respect of their existing loans with Commercial Banks. Under the Special Relief Amount of Rs 5 billion earmarked by the Bank of Mauritius through its Support Programme, MSMEs are eligible for a moratorium of 6 months on both capital and interest payments in respect of new loans with Commercial Banks.
*March 23: The government announced a Special Foreign Currency (USD) Line of Credit ($300 million)
- targeting operators having foreign currency earnings, including SMEs and a swap arrangement to support import-oriented businesses (initial amount $100 million).
column43: *March 31: The Development Bank of Mauritius (DBM) DBM disburse an amount not exceeding Rs 1 Million to eligible Micro and Small Enterprises (MSE) applying for loan facilities
column46:
*April 17: the Bank of Mauritius has reduced the interest rate applicable on its Special Relief Amount under its COVID-19 Support Programme equally by 100 basis points.
*April 16: the Monetary Policy Committee decided to reduce the Key Repo Rate by 100 basis points to 1.85 per cent per annum.
*April 6: The Stock Exchange of Mauritius Ltd (SEM) and the Central Depository & Settlement Co. Ltd (CDS) resume trading and settlement activities.
*April 2: the Stock Exchange of Mauritius (SEM) announced that it remained closed until further notice. The SEM initially suspended trading activities on 20 March.
*March 23: The Bank of Mauritius is introduced a 2.5% Two-Year Bank of Mauritius 2020 Savings Bond for an amount of Rs 5 billion.
*March 23: The Bank of Mauritius (BOM) announced additional support measures: i) support to households
- six-month moratorium on household loans at commercial banks, while BOM will bear interest payments for households with the lowest income.
*March 23: During the national confinement period, fees applicable on shared ATM services have been waived. *March 13: The Bank of Mauritius issued five responses to keep credit flowing to the economy: (i) Cut its cash reserve ratio by a percentage point to 8%; (ii) Release of $130 million to fund businesses struggling with the impact of the virus; (iii) Instruct banks to suspend capital repayments on loans for affected businesses; (iv) Ease supervisory guidelines on handling credit impairments.
column47: Information not available
column48: *April 25: The Minister of Commerce and Consumer Protection, Mr Yogida Sawmynaden, announced that as of April 26, the prices of additional basic commodities and sanitary products will be controlled in a bid to prevent profiteering and hoarding.
column51: *May 5: the Stock Exchange of Mauritius (SEM) has extended deadlines for the publication of Financial Statements by listed companies, for the periods ending (Yearly: 31-Dec-19 and Quarterly: 31-Mar-20).
column54: *May 15: the Cabinet approved by the post Covid-19 Action Plan, spelling out 13 emergency measures to help preserving cultural life and supporting artists to sustain creativity to mitigate the effects of the Covid-19 pandemic on the cultural industry, which was prepared by the Ministry of Arts and Cultural Heritage.

column12:
On 23 March, the Ministry of Public Administration ordered that vulnerable federal employees go teleworking during the sanitary emergency. It also allowed for alternate work days for public servants with children under the age of 12 and staggered entry times between federal officials.

On 24 March Mexico entered phase 2 of the pandemic. The Federal government established its wide-reach campaign “Jornada Nacional de Sana Distancia” to promote basic hygienic measures and social distance, urging citizens to stay at home, recommending the suspension of non-essential activities of the public, private and social sectors.

On 28 March, the President of Mexico, in a national message, made an urgent call to stay home and leave only for essential activities, such as buying first necessity products and caring of vulnerable persons. He also re-affirmed the suspension of the Federal government non-essential work and encouraged the private sector to join these efforts.

On 30 march, a Sanitary Emergency was declared by the Council for Public Health. It was ordered the immediate suspension of non-essential activities of the public, private and social sectors, until 30 April. Exempting medical and sanitary services, public security and fundamental activities to keep the economy running. The operation of social programs and critical infrastructure for the distribution of first necessity goods and services were also exempted. Vulnerable people and those over 60 years old were instructed to strictly keep home confinement.

On 31 March, was sign the Governability and National Unit Agreement to fight COVID-19, by which the Federal government and the State governments will coordinate to observe the measures established given the sanitary emergency.

On 20 April Mexico enter phase 3 of the epidemic extending the suspension of non-essential activities until 30 May.
column14:
As of this date, the Mexican Government has not imposed any restrictions to entry, transit or exit of foreign citizens due to COVID-19 outbreak, nevertheless in addition to regular migratory procedures they will be ask to fill a questionnaire according to the specifications of the Ministry of Health.

Some airlines imposed 14-day quarantine to passengers arriving from Europe and China, before being able to fly to the United States. Other airlines recommend passengers arriving from high-contagious-rate countries to voluntary quarantine for a two-week period.

Mexico and the United States agreed to restrict non-essential crosses through their common border. In order to keep bilateral trade flow during the sanitary crisis, besides commercial exchanges, workers authorized to work on both sides of the border, as well as medical and emergency services are excluded from those measures.

On 17 March, Guatemala closed its border with Mexico for an initial period of 15 days and Belize limited all border crossing with Mexico on 21 March, except for the freight-transport sector.

On April 26, National Migrations Institute, instructed the immediate departure of foreign citizens housed in migratory farms and stations in compliance with sanitary measures.
column16:
On 16 March, the Ministry of Public Education ordered the suspension of classes in preschool, primary and secondary schools.

On 17 March, the Autonomous National University of Mexico (UNAM) suspended classes. State and private universities, as well as independent high-education institutions have taken similar measures since then.

The educational contents from pre-school to high school levels will be transmitted through the public communication systems.

A phone number, “Your Teacher online” has been activated to offer mentoring to students of basic education level; in the same way, massive courses online, certifications, teleseminars, and teleconferences aimed to improve teachers' digital abilities have been launched.

As of 30 March, a program for capacity building online is available to provide support to teachers during the containment period.
column18:
At national level, public events have been cancelled until 30 May.

The Mexico City Government announced the closure of parks, shopping centres and department stores in the city. Restaurants are limited to providing take-out to customers.
column20: Information not available
column22:
On 24 March, the extraordinary budget was allocated to the Ministry of National Defence (up to MXN 4 billion/USD 160 million) and to the Ministry of Navy (up to MXN 500 million/USD 20.5 million), to reinforce the Plan DN-III and Plan Marina in response to the COVID emergency.

The Health Institute for Wellbeing (Instituto de Salud para el Bienestar/INSABI) authorized MXN 4.5 billion (USD 180 million) to buy medical devices, medicine and health equipment.

Through INSABI, States will receive transfers up to MXN 15.3 billion (USD 629 million). In addition, they will have advance funding for MXN 10 billion (USD 411 million).

Various States have been taken fiscal measures such as deferral of tax payments, discounts in payroll taxes and property taxes, or reduction in special taxes like vehicular ownership, etc. as well as postponements of tax inspection.

Fiscal credits to hydrocarbons assignees that will have reductions in their productions value, up to USD 2.6 billion. The measure applies also for those that realize monthly interim payments. These provisions will not be applicable if there is a favorable balance in the shared profit in the tax declaration of provisional payment. The provisions apply to the 2020 fiscal year.
column25:
On 24 March, the Federal Government announced a hospital conversion to better coordinate and integrate available space in hospitals and other infrastructures to take care of COVID-19 patients. These measures include the use of the military health system, as well as the infrastructure for natural disasters or other catastrophic events (Plan DN-III and Plan Marina).

Government launched a call to recruit 43,000 additional health personnel, including nurses, doctors and specialists, to support the response to the health crisis, including in marginalized areas.


- On 30 March, the National Health Emergency Agreement was published. It includes the role of different Ministries to assure the availability of tests, equipment and medicines to deal with the crisis.

On 1 April, the Ministry of Health launched the app “COVID-19MX”, which seeks to reinforce knowledge, to promote measures of prevention on COVID-19 and to facilitate exchange of information between health officials and citizens. The app also gathers health data from users to determine their risk levels and enables them to self-diagnose.

On 7 April, Mexico established an air bridge with China that will consist of 30 flights to buy medical equipment. So far, seven flights have taken place.

On 13 April, the Government of Mexico signed an agreement with 146 private hospitals from 27 States, where 50% of its beds will be used by the Federal Government to take care of patients not affected by COVID-19 in order to reduce pressure in the public hospitals, which could concentrate up to 12,500 patients of coronavirus.
column28:
The elderly and the disabled will receive, in advance, two bimonthly payments of their universal pension.

Some subnational governments have put in place financial support to self-employed, rural workers (corn producers), family businesses and vulnerable groups (women, indigenous people).
column31: Information not available
