On 27 March, the government revamped the response package by expanding the coverage of the wage subsidy scheme that would amount up to NZD 12 billion if fully taken up by firms. On 15 April, additional support measures targeted to small and medium businesses were announced, including tax loss carry-back scheme that can amount to NZD 3.1 billion over the next two years. At this point, the overall size of fiscal measures amounted up to NZD 22.1 billion (7.1% of GDP). This package came on top of the NZD 12 billion increase in infrastructure spending announced in January, before the COVID-19 crisis.
On 14 May, the government announced the Budget 2020, which includes the COVID-19 Response and Recovery Fund amounting to NZD 50 billion (16.3% of GDP). Some NZD 15.9 billion (5.2% of GDP) of the massive fund has been allocated so far, namely on extending the wage subsidy scheme, infrastructure investment in public homes, and trades and apprenticeship training.
column25:
In the context of the Covid-19 support measures announced on 17 March, NZD 500 million was allocated to the health sector.
On 28 March, the government announced that it will temporarily remove tariffs on all medical and hygiene imports needed for the COVID-19 response. These include all diagnostic reagents and testing kits used for COVID-19 testing and soap imports.
column28:
The major support measure included in the government's response package announced on 17 March was the wage subsidy scheme, which are paid to businesses that lost at least 30% of revenue due to the COVID-19 crisis so that they can continue to employ and pay their staffs. The coverage of the wage subsidy scheme was expanded to all businesses on 27 March, expected to cost NZD 8-12 billion depending on the uptake. The 2020 Budget announced on May 14 allocated NZD 3.2 billion to extend the scheme originally ending in mid-June until September, while narrowing the target to businesses experience more than 50% drop in revenue. However, the target was expanded again in 5 June to businesses experiencing more than 40% drop in revenue, covering extra 40 000 businesses.
The economic response package announced on 17 March also included the NZD 2.8 billion increase in benefit payments coming in the form of a NZD 25 per week increase in core benefit payments and a doubling in the winter energy payment to NZD 1400 for couples and NZD 900 for single people. Also, the threshold for In Work Tax Credit has been removed. Furthermore, a NZD 27 million package is being provided to social sector services and community groups to bolster existing essential social sector services, provide support for disabled people in lock-down, and fund innovative community-led solutions to support local resilience.
On 14 April, the government announced a tertiary student support package that includes increasing the student loan amount available for course-related costs for full-time students from NZD1,000 to NZD 2,000, on a temporary basis.
The COVID-19 Response and Recovery Fund (CRRF) announced on 14 May included NZD1.6 billion fund for boosting trades and apprenticeship training, which aims to retrain about 10,000 hospitality and aviation sector workers for construction, agriculture, and manufacturing sector jobs, as well as also for health, counselling and care works. Also included in the CRRF was NZD 3 billion infrastructure investment with 8000 new public homes being built.
column31: On 16 April the government introduced tax loss carry-back scheme estimated to cost NZD 3.1 billion over the next two years. The policy responsive package announced on 17 March includes business tax changes amounting to NZD 2.8 billion, including an increase in the provisional tax threshold and the reintroduction of depreciation charges for commercial buildings.
column34: NZD 600 million will be spent on support for the aviation industry.
column37: Information not available
column40: A loan scheme for businesses with 50 or less full-time equivalent employees was announced on 12 May, allowing a business to borrow NZD 10,000 plus NZD 1,800 for each equivalent full-time employee up to a maximum of NZD 100,000. There will be no interest if paid back within a year, otherwise 3% for up to 5 years, with no repayments required for the first 2 years. It was announced on 5 June that  the application deadline for the scheme will be pushed back from 12 June to 24 July.
column43: On 24 March, the government and RBNZ announced a support package for homeowners and businesses impacted by the economic effects of Covid-19. The Business Finance Guarantee Scheme (NZD 6.25 billion) for solvent SMEs, with the government bearing 80% of the risk of these loans and banks the remaining 20%. On 2 May, the scheme was made available to more firms, by for instance removing the minimum revenue threshold for borrowers eligibility to the scheme. To support this scheme, the RBNZ introduced the Term Lending Facility (TLF) that provides funding for banks for terms of up to three years at low interest rates.
column46:
On 15 March, the Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) cut its policy rate (the overnight cash rate) by 75 basis points to 0.25%, and committed to maintain this rate for at least 12 months.
On 20 March, the RBNZ announced measures to supply banks with more liquidity via both foreign exchange swaps and the reinstated Term Auction Facility, which offers banks term funding of up to one year against a range of collateral. It also put in place with the US Federal Reserve a USD 30 billion USD swap arrangement for at least six months.
On 22 March, the RBNZ announced a Large Scale Asset Purchase programme (LSAP) of New Zealand government bonds (quantitative easing) amounting to NZD 30 billion (about 10% of GDP) over 12 months. On 7 April, LSAP was revamped to include NZD 3 billion of Local Government Funding Agency (LGFA) debt. The government will cover any loss the RBNZ incurs on the LSAP up until September 2021. On 13 May, the amount of the LSAP was revamped to NZD 60 billion, while the scope of asset purchase was expanded to include the government inflation-indexed bonds.
On 12 August, the RBNZ decided to expand its LSAP to NZD 100 billion and extended the period of operation up to June 2022 from June 2021 previously. Furthermore, it changed the rules to allow itself to purchase up to 60% of the Government bonds outstanding, from 50% originally.
column47:
On 15 March, as regulatory relief, the RBNZ postponed the start date of the increased capital requirements for banks initially planned for 1 April by 12 months, to 1 July, 2021. In addition, the RBNZ has reduced banks' core funding ratios (i.e., funding from deposits and long-term domestic borrowing) from 75% of assets to 50% to support increased lending.
On 30 April the RBNZ decided to remove mortgage loan-to-value ratio (LVR) restrictions for 12 months starting from 1 May, to ensure LVR restrictions does not impede the mortgage deferral scheme implemented in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.
column48: The financial support package announced by the government and RBNZ on 24 March includes a six-month interest and principal payment holiday for mortgage holders and SMEs who have lost income because of the economic disruption caused by the Covid-19 crisis. On 30 April, the RBNZ decided to remove mortgage loan-to-value ratio (LVR) restrictions for 12 months starting from 1 May, to ensure LVR restrictions does not impede this mortgage deferral scheme.
column51: The financial support package announced by the government and RBNZ on 24 March includes a six-month interest and principal payment holiday for mortgage holders and SMEs who have lost income because of the economic disruption caused by the Covid-19 crisis. The RBNZ will help banks to put this scheme in place with appropriate bank capital rules. A legislation providing insolvency relief to businesses affected by COVID-19, for instance by placing existing debts into hibernation until they are able to start trading normally again, was enacted on 15 May.
column54: Information not available

column12:
*June 22: Extension of the state of emergency in Tillabéri and Gotheye departments.
*June 15: Extension of the state of emergency in for an additional 3 months in Diffa and in several departments of the Tillaberi and Tahoua regions.
*May 13: Lifting of quarantine and curfew in Niamey.
*April 12: Obligatory use of masks in Niamey.
*March 27: Declaration of public health emergency.
*March 27: Quarantine declared for Niamey, the capital, for two weeks, starting March 29.
*March 27: Curfew in Niamey from 7 pm to 6 am, starting March 28.
column14:
*May 15: Release of inter-urban passenger transportation.
*March 20: Health checks at border crossings and various entries points in cities.
*March 20: Closure of bus stations and suspension of public transportation for at least one week, starting March 21.
*March 17: Closure of Niamey and Zinder international airports (except for domestic, cargo, health and military flights), starting March 19.
*March 17: Closure of land borders for at least two weeks (except for goods), starting March 19.
column16:
*Re-opening of schools, starting June 1.
*March 17: Closure of schools and universities, starting March 20. Reopening is scheduled for June 1.
column18:
*May 22: Suspension of the ban on workshops and seminars, starting May 25.
*May 13: Reopening of places of worship.
*March 19: Prohibition of collective prayers, closure of places of worship and ban on religious gatherings, upon the decision of religious chiefs.
*March 20: Prohibition of non-essential visits to prisons.
*March 17: Ban on public gatherings of more than 50 people.
*March 13: Cancellation of international meetings due to take place in Niamey (Francophonie and OIC).
column20:
*May 22: Reinstatement of normal working hours, i.e. from 8 am to 5.30 pm, from Monday to Thursday and from 8 am to 1 pm on Fridays; lifting of the reduction of staff, starting May 25.
*March 17: Closure of bars, nightclubs and others entertainment centres, starting March 18; Recommendations to follow good hygiene practices and social distancing protocols (in markets, shops, restaurants, private companies, airports and public places).
column22:
*May 8: The cabinet has approved a supplementary budget with 1.3% of GDP in resources re-allocated to additional spending toward health, security and social assistance.
*April 27: Heads of states of the West-Africa Economic and Monetary Union (UEMOA) declared a temporary suspension of the UEMOA Growth and Stability Pact setting six convergence criteria, including the 3% of GDP fiscal deficit rule, to help member-countries cope with the fallout of Covid-19. This temporary suspension will allow member-countries to raise their overall fiscal deficit temporarily and use the additional external support provided by donors in response to Covid-19. The Heads of States' Declaration sets a clear expectation that fiscal consolidation will resume once the crisis is over.
*March 27: Exemption from duties and taxes on all imported products used in the fight against Covid-19 (protective masks, hydro-alcoholic gel, etc.).
*March 27: Suspension of on-site tax inspections during the months of April and May 2020.
*March 25: Presentation of the response plan, consisting of an immediate health response and broader economic and social mitigation measures, to donors. Key elements, such as temporary tax relief for hard-hit sectors, two months of free utilities for vulnerable households and distribution of food from the strategic reserve, being already implemented.
column25:
*April 28: Revaluation of the response plan for containment and prevention from an initial cost of XOF597 billion to XOF1436 billion or EUR2.19 million (18% of GDP).
*March 27: The government announced XOF597 billion (7.4% of GDP) Covid-19 response plan.
*March 27: Free care for confirmed coronavirus (Covid-19) patients following the chloroquine and/or azithromycin protocols; implementation of a strategy to actively search for suspected cases and reinforce screenings and confinement; reinforcement of protective equipment for health personnel; recruitment of 1500 health workers to the state civil service.
*March 21: The Central Bank of West African States (BCEAO) has introduced measures to promote the use of electronic payments.
*March 17: Free diagnosis and care of any confirmed case.
*March 17: Revision of a contingency plan to accommodate new requirements and allocation of XOF1 billion from the national budget for its financing.
column28:
*March 27: Extension of the deadline for payment of the vignette to the end of June 2020 instead of March 31, 2020.
*March 27: State coverage of electricity and water bills for the months of April and May for some segments of the population; strengthening of annual support towards vulnerable households (free provision, price moderation); remission of sentences in favour of 1540 detainees.
column31:
*March 27: Establishment of removal credit facilities for importers for a period of 15 to 90 days, subject to a bank guarantee.
*March 27: Value added tax (VAT) exemption for the entire duration of the suspension of business and for inter-urban land passenger transport; postponement of the payment of the second instalment of the synthetic tax on the transport sector until May 1 instead of March 1; application of a reduced VAT rate of 10% in the hospitality sector; application of a depreciation rate for buildings of 5% in order to take into account the capital invested in the hotel sector; exemption of the MFI for the 2019 financial year in the hospitality sector; suspension of proceedings for the collection of taxes and duties for 3 months, i.e. until June 30 for travel agencies; suspension of the tax collection proceedings for 2 months starting April 1 for bars and licensed premises; suspension of tax collection proceedings for 2 months as of April 1 in the sports and leisure sectors.

column37: Information not available
column40: Information not available
column43: Information not available
column46:
*The Central Bank for West African States (BCEAO) launched a special 3-month refinancing window at a fixed rate of 2.5% percent for limited amounts of 3-months “Covid-19 T-bills” to be issued by each UEMOA sovereign to help meet immediate funding needs related to the current pandemic. The amount of such special T-Bills issued by Niger amounted to 1.4% of GDP.
*March 25: The West African Development Bank (BOAD) decided to grant UEMOA members countries XOF120 billion in concessional loans (XOF15 billion per country) to be disbursed immediately; such loans are softened though the interest subsidy mechanism replenished by the Central Bank of West African States (BCEAO) and the UEMOA Commission for XOF25 billion and XOF15 billion, respectively.

*March 23: The BCEAO for UEMOA has taken preemptive steps to better satisfy banks' demand for liquidity and mitigate the negative impact of the pandemic on economic activity. The BCEAO adopted a full allotment strategy at a fixed rate of 2.5% (the minimum policy rate) thereby allowing banks to satisfy their liquidity needs fully at a rate about 25 basis points lower than before the crisis.
column47:
*The WAEMU (UEMOA) authorities have extended by one year the five-year period initiated in 2018 for the transition to Basle II/III bank prudential requirements. In particular, the regulatory capital adequacy ratio will remain unchanged at end-2020 from its 2019 level of 9.5%, before gradually increasing to 11.5% by 2023 instead of 2022 initially planned.
*March 21: The BCEAO has: i) extended the collateral framework to access central bank refinancing to include bank loans to prequalified 1.7000 private companies; ii) set-up a framework inviting banks and microfinance institutions to accommodate demands from customers with Covid-19-related repayment difficulties to postpone for a 3 month renewable period debt service falling due, without the need to classify such postponed claims as non performing.
column54:
*April 28: World Bank has approved USD273 million in International Development Association (IDA) financing for Togo, Benin, Burkina Faso and Niger to facilitate access to services for vulnerable people (especially women and the poorest segments of society), through the West Africa Unique Identification for Regional Integration and Inclusion (WURI) Program.
*April 15: The World Bank has approved USD13.95 million to prevent, detect and respond to the threat posed by Covid-19 and strengthen national systems for public health preparedness in Niger.
*April 15: Disbursement of USD114.49 million from the International Monetary Fund (IMF).

April 15 : IMF website https://www.imf.org/en/News/Articles/2020/04/14/pr20157-niger-imf-exec-board-approves-disbursement-to-adress-covid-19 + Jeune Afrique https://www.jeuneafrique.com/913133/economie/coronavirus-les-dernieres-infos-economiques-africaines/?utm_source=newsletter-ja-eco&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=newsletter-ja-eco-03-04-20

column12:
*June 29: Extension of the Second Phase for another 4 weeks, from June 30 to July 27.
*June 2: The state of Kano enters in “Phase 1” (government offices, markets and banks will operate for limited hours).
*June 2: Curfew from 10pm to 4am.
*June 2: Caution advance into the Second Phase of the national response, from June 2 to June 29.
*May 21: Lifting of partial lockdown in some states.
*May 18: Extension of lockdown in Kano state.
*May 11: Bauchi state has put three areas that border Kano state under a 10-day total lockdown.
*May 5: Residents of Ogun states will now be arrest if found not to be wearing face masks in public.
*May 5: Nationwide curfew from 8pm to 6am. This means all movements will be prohibited during this period except essential services.
*May 2: Easing of lockdown measures in FCT, Lagos and Ogun States.
*April 28: Extension of the lockdown in Kano.
*April 27: Obligation to wear masks, first in Lagos state and then extended to all of Nigeria.
*DATE: Extension of lockdown with extended curfew from 8am to 6pm in Abuja, Lagos and Ogun state.
*March 30: Lockdown of the Federal Capital Territory (FCT) and Lagos.
*March 29: Cessation of movement in the Federal Capital Territory, in Lagos and Ogun States.
column14:
*July 7: The Federal Airports Authority of Nigeria has released new procedural guidelines (new Standard Operating Procedure, SOP) for air travellers and other airport users.
*DATE: Resuming of domestic flights, starting July 8.
*June 29: Permission of inter-state travels outside curfew hours, starting July 1.
*May 5: Ban on non-essential inter-state passenger travel, partial and controlled interstate movement of goods and services.
*March 27: Restriction on sea transport. Only cargo vessels that have been at sea for more than 14 days are allowed to dock in ports after the crew have been tested and confirmed disease-free by the Port Health Authorities.
*March 25: Closure of Asaba airport beginning March 27.
*March 25: Closure of land borders beginning March 29.
*March 23: The Nigerian Immigration Service has announced the temporary suspension of passports and migrant registration.
*March 21 : Closure of Abuja and Lagos international airports.
*March 21: Suspension of all passenger train services.
*March 20: Closure of international airports in Enugu, Port Harcourt and Kano.
*March 20: Entry ban extended to two more countries [Sweden and Austria].
*March 18: Entry ban from countries with more than 1 000 cases [China, France, Germany, Japan, Italy, Iran, Netherlands, Norway, South Korea, Spain, Switzerland, United Kingdom, United States]; mandatory quarantine and suspension of visa issuance for people coming from these countries.
*January 28: Strengthen surveillance at five international airports: Enugu, Lagos, Rivers, Kano and FCT.
column16: *March 20: Closure of schools and universities.
column18:
*June 2: Restricted re-opening of places of worship; only regular religious gatherings would be allowed and worshippers should follow social-distancing rules. Funerals are limited to 20 people.
*May 21: Lifting of the ban on religious gatherings in some states.
*March 24: Ban on gatherings in places of worship.
column20:
*June 2: Full resumption of banks and manufacturing industries.
*June 2: Managed access to markets and locations of economic activity to limit the risk of transmission.
*May 4: Re-opening of government offices and banks.
*Work at home is encouraged in several states and government institutions while isolation centres are being expanded in Lagos states.
*March 27: A circular was issued by the Head of Civil Service of the Federation directing some public servants in non-essential roles to work from home.
*March 24: Closure of shops and markets (except for those selling essential commodities).
*March 23: Suspension of official activities (closure of all courts starting March 24, suspension of the Federal Executive Council and National Council of State meetings, and of the Independent National Electoral Commission activities).
column22:
*The Federal Government adopted a revised budget for 2020 in response to the COVID-19 shock. A N500 billion (0.3% of GDP) COVID-19 intervention fund is included in the revised budget to channel resources to additional health-related current and capital spending (tests, supplies and facilities) an public works programs to support the incomes of the vulnerable. The coverage of the conditional cash transfer program has been broadened and an allocation of N150 billion to support state and local government's spending needs has been made available through the budget. They have also unveiled a 2.3 trillion naira stimulus package, which focuses on job-intensive projects including in agricultural, road and housing sector
- a bulk of which is to be financed from CBN
- supported credit facilities and from sovereign wealth and other saving funds.
*April 16: Nigeria received N42.6 billion, including USD50 million grant from the European Union. The Nigeria Solidarity and Support Fund was established, looking to raise USD50 million to support physical infrastructure of healthcare centres in Local Government and existing Social Investment Program.
*Contingency funds of Naira 984 million (USD 2.7 million) have been released to the NCDC, and an additional Naira 6.5 billion (USD 18 million) was distributed for purchasing testing kits, opening isolation centres and training medical personnel. A grant of Naira 10 billion (USD 28 million) was released to Lagos State to increase its capacity to contain the outbreak. The government is reviewing its 2020 budget and, given the expected large fall in oil revenues, announced plans to cut/delay non-essential capital spending by Naira 1 trillion (close to 1% of GDP). A fiscal stimulus package to provide relief for taxpayers and to incentivise employers to retain and recruit staff during the downturn is being designed. Import duty waivers for pharmaceutical firms will be introduced. Regulated fuel prices have been reduced.
*The President ordered an increase of the social register by 1 million households to 3.6 million to help cushion the effect of the lockdown.
column25:
*July 5: The government has launched an online course on Infection, Prevention & Control (IPC) for health workers.
*April 27: The government has agreed to pay an additional 50% of salary to all Health Workers in Federal Government Teaching Hospitals and Federal Medical Centers in the Special Covid-19 Hazard and Inducement Allowance.
*April 9: The telecom operator Airtel says about USD 500 000 will go towards equipment for a medical facility and USD 300 000 will go towards the purchase of more than 100 000 N95 respirators for health workers in the country. Airtel will also offer free SMS messaging to customers on all networks, as well as free data for customers to access educational and health sites. The tax-free areas are those indicated by the Federal Ministry of Health and the Nigeria Center for Disease Control (NCDC).
*April 4: Activation of two new laboratories for testing [Defence Reference Laboratory in Abuja and Biosafety Laboratory in Lagos].
*NCDC launched a WhatsApp APL, a free-to-use service to provide a central source of accurate, verified and current information on Covid-19 in Nigeria.
*March 27: The Federal Government released Naira 10 billion to Lagos State, and Naira 5 billion in special intervention funds to NCDC to equip, expand and provide personnel to its facilities and laboratories across the country. Furthermore, all NCDC staff and experts who are away on training or international assignments are to return immediately. The Nigerian Air Force (NAF) conducting an evacuation mission to bring back Nigerian specialists located in Central Africa.
*March 26: The Central Bank of Nigeria (CBN) announced Covid-19 fund contributions by seven Nigerian billionaires and banks. Access Bank Plc, Nigeria's biggest lender in assets, is teaming up with Aliko Dangote, to provide treatment and isolation centres across Africa's most populous nation as it braces for the impact of the virus.
*March 9: Establishment of a Presidential Task Force for the control of the virus.
*January 28: The NCDC announced that it had set up Covid-19 group and was ready to activate its incident system if any case emerged in Nigeria.
*January 31: The Federal Government set up a Coronavirus Preparedness Group to mitigate the impact of the virus if it spreads to the country.
column28:
*May 15: Food and non-food items delivered to displaced persons in Kogi State.
*May 18: The Federal Government has delivered 5.318 metric tons of assorted foodstuff to the government of Kano state for distribution to the less privileged, the vulnerable and people living with disabilities against the effect of the Covid-19 pandemic.
column31: Information not available
column34: *June 25: The Nigerian government has announced a Naira 6 billion stimulus package to support businesses hardest hit by the coronavirus pandemic.
column37: Information not available
column40: Information not available
column43: Information not available
column46:
*The Central Bank of Nigeria (CBN) cut monetary policy rate by 100 basis points in May while expanding liquidity available for nonbank financial institutions, leading to significant lowering of market yield of government securities.
*The Central Bank of Nigeria (CBN) maintained its current monetary policy rate (March) and introduced the following measures: i) reduce interest rates on all applicable CBN interventions from 9% to 5% and introduce a one year moratorium on CBN intervention facilities; ii) create Naira 50 billion (USD 139 million) in targeted credit facilities; iii) liquidity injection of Naira 3.6 trillion (2.4% of GDP) into the banking system, including Naira 100 billion to support the health sector, Naira 2 trillion to the manufacturing sector and Naira 1.5 trillion to impacted industries. Regulatory forbearance was also introduced to restructure loans in impacted sectors. The CBN is also co-ordinating a private sector special intervention initiative targeting Naira 120 billion (USD 333 million) to fight Covid-19.
*March 27: Beginning of the process of reviewing the federal budget. President Buhari directs the Minister of Industry, Trade and Investment, to work with the Manufacturers Association of Nigeria (MAN), to ensure that production of essential items such as food, medical and pharmaceutical products continues.
column47: Information not available
column54:
*The president ordered the release of inmates in correctional facilities in order to decongest prisons.
*April 28: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) Executive Board has approved USD 3.4 billion in Emergency financial assistance under the Rapid Financing Instrument to support the authorities' efforts in addressing the economic impact of Covid-10 shock and the sharp fall in oil prices.
*April 16: Naira 42.6 billion was received, including USD 50 million grant from the European Union.
*April 6: Abuja has announced that it has requested USD 6.9 billion from major multilateral donors, of which USD 3.4 billion is being requested from the IMF, USD 2.5 billion from the World Bank and USD 1 billion from the African Development Bank (AfDB).
*March 26: The Federal Government received 107 boxes of medical supplies from China, comprising surgical masks, protective clothing, face shields and detection kits.

column12:
* June 15: Introduction of a new State of Emergency, lasting until June 22, 2020.

* June 5: June 5 declared as a non-working day. Visits to all cemeteries (except for funerals) are forbidden until June 8.

* June 4: Full ban on movement for all Skopje municipalities and other 10 municipalities, beginning at 9:00 pm and ending at 5:00 am on June 8.

* June 4: Curfew in all municipalities from 9:00 pm until 5:00 am on June 5. Curfew from 4:00 pm until 5:00 am the following day from June 5 to June 7.

* May 30: Declaration of a new nationwide state of emergency lasting until June 13, 2020.

* May 27: all restrictions on movement have been lifted.

* May 20: A curfew is introduced. It will last from 19h00 to 5h00, starting on Saturday and ending on Tuesday 26 May.

* May 20: Movements through public transport vehicles is banned ifrom 19h00 until 5h00.

* May 15: People over 67 or younger than 18 are now allowed to go outside from 5h00 to 19h00 as the others.

* May 15: The State of emergency has been extended for 14 more days.

* May 8: Curfew on weekends are relaxed too. Going outside is allowed from 5h00 to 19h00, like in the weekdays. Restrictions for age groups still hold.

* April 22: Curfew on weekdays are relaxed. Every citizen is required to wear masks or scarfs in public places and gathering places. Going outside is allowed from 5h00 to 19h00. Restrictions for age groups still hold.

* April 16: A new 30-day "State of emergency" has been announced.

* April 14: An extended curfew is introduced over the Orthodox Easter holiday and lasts from 16h00 on April 17 through 05h00 on April 21.

* April 13: the government launches the app "StopKorona!". The app uses short-range Bluetooth communications to establish a voluntary contact-tracing network, and thus keep data on phones that have been in close proximity with each other. Users can: report to the Ministry of Health if they have been diagnosed with COVID-19; be alerted to whether they were in close contact with an infected person.

* April 3: the government has launched a new specialised web page (koronavirus.gov.mk), that offers comprehensive guidelines, an overview of the number of infections, and the measures the country is taking to stop the spread of the pandemic.

* March 21: a curfew was introduced from 21h00 to 6h00, starting on March 22.

* March 18: A "State of emergency" of 30 days is declared.

* Mid-March: a curfew is introduced between 16h00 and 05h00 on weekdays; citizens older than 65 may only leave the house between 10h00-12h00 on weekdays; person younger than 18 may only leave the house between 13h00-15h00. Curfew violators could face up to one year in prison.

* March 13: The municipalities of Debar and Centar Zupa, early hotspots for the pandemic, are under lockdown for 30 days. These restrictions were lifted on April 13.
column14:
* June 26: The Government of North Macedonia announced the opening of North Macedonia's border crossings effective June 26, 2020. There are no requirements for a PCR test or isolation for entering North Macedonia. All airports in North Macedonia are currently closed for commercial flights. The Government of North Macedonia has announced the airports will be re-opened beginning July 1.

* All border crossings in North Macedonia are closed to foreign citizens, with a few exceptions (mainly freight vehicles, diplomatic corps). Skopje International Airport is closed to air traffic (except for state, military, medical and emergency flights), as well as St. Paul the Apostle Airport in Ohrid.
column16:
* April 8: The government in partnership with a local telecoms provider, Makedonski Telekom, will donate mobile internet for distance learning purposes to 30 000 primary and secondary school students from families at social risk.

* The government has developed an online learning portal where students can access recorded classes, live lessons and play-based learning activities. In partnership with UNICEF, the government has established an online database of free picture books, worksheets and teaching materials in multiple languages available to all parents and teachers. Finally, the government has an online library with materials specifically designed for pre-school and early primary school aged children available in Macedonian, Albanian, Turkish and Bosnian.
column18:
* May 22: Association in groups of more than five persons in parks and other public places and areas is still banned.

* February 28: All sports events should take place without any audience until 6 March. This measure was later extended until 13 March.

* February 28: All mass gatherings are cancelled.

* The General elections planned for April 12, are postponed. No new date has yet been set.
column20:
* May 13: the Government decided to allow the opening of closed shopping malls under strict sanitary conditions

* May 8: some shops were authorised to open business provided they had the infrastructure to maintain sufficient physical distance between custommers.
column22:
* May 17: the government implemented a third package of measures which is based on 3 main pillars: (i) distribution of means of payment to the population in order to encourage the consumption of local goods and services; (ii) a direct support for the economy; (iii) and an aid for the agrarian sector in North Macedonia. The value of the third package is estimated to cost around EUR 355 million and will affect 733.000 users.

* North Macedonia opened a “solid COVID-19 fund” to collect donations from the civil society.

* The government implemented a fiscal package (0.2% of GDP) to help address firms' liquidity problems and protect jobs, targeted to affected sectors such as transport, hotel and restaurants for three months starting in April.
column25:
*April, 3: A field hospital is being built by the army adjacent to the Skopje Infectious Diseases Clinic and equipped to receive some 130 patients early next week.

* The government has implemented price controls on medicines, disinfection products, and abolished import duty on medical supplies.

* Ban of export of medical devices and material needed for tackling COVID-19 crisis, unless authorised by Ministry of Health.

* The government has requisitioned all the masks available from private companies to redistribute them to medical personnel.
column28:
* May 17: As part of a third package of measures, up to denars 6,000 for tuition fees and a payment card of 3,000 denars and co-financing vouchers up to denar 30,000 for IT and digital skills training will be distributed to North Macedonian students.
The measure is estimated to affect 100,000 students and mobilise around EUR 12 million.

* Public officials will receive salaries reduced to the legal minimum of 14 500 denars (EUR 230) for April and May 2020. Presidents and members of the governing and supervisory boards of public institutions will not receive compensation for the duration of the crisis unless it is their only source of revenue. [Measures 5 and 6]

* Doctors and medical staff of infectious disease clinics and departments, like all members of the emergency medical teams will receive a 20% higher salary for May and June 2020, via a home payment card.

* The payment of rent for social housing and the payment of rent will be postponed for all users.

* April 6: Unemployed or part of the informal economy will have fast access to the social protection system from April to May, and will receive an average of 7,000 (EUR113) dinars per household (20,000 households are targeted).

* April 6: Monthly allowance of 50% of the average monthly net salary for the last 24 months distributed to employees who lost their job due to COVID-19. [Measure 4]
column31: Information not available
column34:
* As part of the the third package of measures supporting agriculture in North Macedonia will mobilise up to EUR 76.1 milion.
'
* May 17: As part of the third package of measures, the government will indirectly support the domestic tourism sector by distributing vouchers to the local population. Payment cards credited will be distributed with denar 3,000 and denar 6,000 vouchers in order to stimulate domestic tourism by the poorest households.
The measure will affect about 100,000 citizens from the poorest households, i.e. earning less than denar 15,000 per month (the minimum wage is MKD 14,500 per month). The voucher will be used in domestic hotels and other accommodation facilities, while with the payment card will encourage the purchase of domestic tourism products and services.

* The government has announced a wage subsidy for the months of April, May and June 2020 for companies in the tourism, transport and hospitality sectors. The subsidy per employee will amount up to 50% of the average salary paid in 2019, provided that: the company has not reduced the number of employees since February 2020; the company does not pay out dividends during 2020; the company has not paid bonuses to the employees after this measure comes into force. North Macedonia will subsidise salaries for the months of April and May 2020 up to a maximum of 14 500 denars (EUR 235) per month and per employee [Measure 1]
column37:
* May 14: the Government introduced a tax deferral system for excise duties for selected excise goods (mainly auxiliary medicines and desinfectants).

* April 24: the Government introduced a tax deferral system for VAT returns.

* March 26: The government has announced that companies can be released from the advance payment of corporate income tax for April, May, and June provided that:

- the company has not reduced the number of employees since February 2020;

- the company does not pay out dividends during 2020;

- the company has not paid bonuses to the employees after this measure comes into force.

- the company is active in the catering, tourism or transport industry. [Measure 25]
column40:
* May 17: as part of the third package of measures, the Development Bank of Northern Macedonia will deblock interest free loans worth EUR 31 milion. This credit line ill be available to all micro and small companies and it will also offer a 30% grant (non-refundable) for those companies that are run or founded by women or employ young people, are export-oriented or introduce innovation and digitalization in their operations. [Measure 19]

* The Development Bank of Northern Macedonia issued a first set of 13.7 million (5.7 million + 8 million) interest-free loans for micro, small and medium enterprises the amount of which depended on the number of employees. The loans were up to 90 000 euros. [Measure 12]
column43: * State guarantee for commercial loans for start-ups and small and micro companies: a support for start-ups and small and micro companies through commercial banks with EUR 10 million initial capital for easier access to funds will be granted, mainly by taking part of the credit risk.
column46:
* March, 16: The National Bank Operational Monetary Policy Committee (OMPC) decided to cut the policy rate by 0.25 percentage points to 1.75%.

* March, 20: Additional measures were taken by OMPC, mainly promoting more favourable credit standards for the companies affected of the COVID-19 crisis and easing the standards for household and corporate loans restructuring. Loans are interest-free. [Measure 10]

* April 15: the Nationa Bank reduced by a third the amount of CB bills offered to banks at the auction.
column47: * The National Bank has revised its credit risk regulation, to encourage banks to restructure loans temporarily, and has relaxed the loan classification standards for NPLs. It has also reduced the base for the reserve requirement by the amount of new loans to firms in affected sectors and has extended the deadline for banks to submit their first Internal Liquidity Assessment Report in order to allow them to focus on providing credit while maintaining the quality of the loan portfolio. [Measure 9]
column48: * Support private associative initiatives that respond to the need for solidarity arising from the COVID-19 crisis. MKD 30 million (EUR 485 000) will be allocated in tranches of MKD 600 000 to 900 000 to associations and foundations working in the field of information, education, assistance, including legal assistance, for the populations affected by the pandemic, as well as the fight against corruption and the promotion of sustainable means of agricultural production.
column54: * May 15: the Government adopted a Decision on new loans from international institutions that will be repaid with a Eurobond sale that will likely take place late in 2020 or early next year.

column12:
Confinement measures were mainly established in a package of emergency measures announced 12 March. National self-isolation and quarantine rules apply and may be subject to fines. There is overall strong public health advice on social distancing, promotion of teleworking and similar.

Relaxation of restrictions announced 7 May included increasing the maximum size of groups that can meet from 5 to 20 persons.
column14:
Measures (largely announced in the package of emergency measures on 12 March) have included, restrictions on stays outside resident municipality, and border control measures on incoming foreigners. The restrictions for incoming EEA citizens were lightened on 9 April.

Relaxation of restrictions announced 7 May included ending the prohibition on foreign travel, though with advice against it and retention of compulsory quarantine for those returning from outside Norway.

Further lifting of restrictions includes leisure travel from other Nordic countries (June 15), and travel from most EEA countries (July 15).
column16:
Schools and universities were closed 13 March. An initial package of derestrictions (announced 8 April), included the reopening of day-care centres between the 20th and 27th April and reopening of primary schools and out-of-school programmes 27th April.

All schools and universities had reopened by the 11 May.
column18: Relaxation of restrictions that came into force 7 May included allowing events of up to 50 people.
column20: As part of an initial package of derestictions (announced 8 April), as of 20th April health services where there is one-to-one contact, such as psychologists and physiotherapists, were permitted to resume operations. Similarly, non-health services where there is one-to-one contact, such as hairdressers and skin care professionals, have been allowed to re-open since 27th April.
column22:
12 May, government publishes Revised National Budget. This included some important extensions of measures. The Budget revised the estimated fiscal impulse of the measures to 5.1% of mainland GDP.

3 April, government announces a further package of measures. This includes extension of the guarantee scheme for bank loans to companies with more than 250 employees, temporary discretion on whether laid off employees can continue as members of pension schemes and additional support (comparatively small-scale fiscally) for a wide range of groups and sectors, including: students, apprentices, kindergartens, immigrants, brewery industry, fuel industry, horse racing, and reindeer herding.

31 March, parliament agrees third package of measures. Valued at NOK 9 billion, it includes further support to students, municipalities, the environment and low-income households.

27 March, package of measures, notably including financial support to cover the fixed costs of businesses with falls in turnover (outlays estimated at NOK 10-20 billion per month).

19 March, loan guarantee and credit support schemes announced (NOK 100 billion).

13 March, package of measures: total increase in budget outlays from the economic measures was estimated to exceed NOK 65 billion (includes a loss provision of NOK 10 billion for the new loan scheme in private banks with a state guarantee and of NOK 6 billion for the aviation guarantee scheme).
column24: Th e structural non-oil deficit is estimated to increase by NOK 175 billion in 2020.
column25: Measures includes steps for the health care system to handle the acute crisis. This include securing necessary equipment and personnel. Revised National Budget (12 May) announced increased funding for hospitals.
column28:
The greatest support to households in terms of government spending is through measures extending existing unemployment benefit and other income-assurance schemes. Measures have included:

- Removal of the three waiting days between the period when employers have to provide salary to workers in temporary layoffs and the period when the workers are entitled to daily unemployment benefits.

- Provisions for employees who are on temporary lay-off to receive full wage compensation from day 3 to day 20, up to NOK 50 000 per month.

- A scheme for temporary income compensation to self-employed, including sickness benefit.

- Extension of unemployment benefit for those dismissed or laid off from work, and provisions for the advanced payment of unemployment benefit.
Other measures include:

- Compensation for parents that have to stay home due to closure of schools and kindergartens.

- Measures to ensure pension rights are not affected negatively for retired health personnel who return to service in connection with the COVID-19 outbreak.

- Facilities for laid-off employees to remain on company pension schemes.

- A range of additional support (comparatively small in fiscal terms) for a wide range of groups: including: students, apprentices, kindergartens and immigrants
column31:
Measures (many first announced in the 13 March package of measures) include:
'
- A cut in the employer's social insurance contribution by 4 percentage points for the equivalent of 2 months

- Reduction in the number of days that employers are obliged to pay salary to workers on temporary lay-offs, from 15 to 2 days

- Change in corporate tax regulations so that companies that are lossmaking can re-allocate their loss towards previous years' taxed surplus

- Change in tax regulations so that owners of lossmaking companies can postpone payments of wealth tax.

- Reduction in the low VAT rate, which includes passenger transport, accommodation and parts of the cultural sector, from 12 to 8 per cent until 31 October.

A tax support package for the oil and gas sector was announced (30 April). https://www.regjeringen.no/en/aktuelt/package-of-measures-to-support-the-oil-and-gas-industry-and-the-supply-industry/id2700656/?utm_source=www.regjeringen.no&utm_medium=epost&utm_campaign=nyhetsvarsel%2001.05.2020&utm_content=Energy
column34:
A financial support scheme has been announced (27 March) that will cover a portion of the fixed cost for companies facing a large turnover decrease related to Covid-19, the scheme is expected pay out between NOK 10 and 20 billion per month. The scheme was initially to subsidise costs in April and May only but was later extended (on 1 July) to August. The scheme opened for applications on April 18.

- On 1 July the government annonced a labour-cost subsidy scheme (lonnstilskudd) for employers who take back laid-off workers during July and August. Payouts will be made in autumn and can amount to up to NOK 15 000 per month per employeed. Around NOK 4 billion of payouts are estimated.

- The various support for the air travel sector includes purchase of domestic air routes where there is no basis for commercial operations.

- A range of support has been announced for innovative and research-oriented businesses (mainly announced in the 27 March package) This includes: grants for young growth companies, innovation loans, interest-payment support, grants for private innovation groups, business-oriented research support, capital for funding and matching investments.

- A special support programme for culture, sport and voluntary sectors has been announced (quoted value, NOK 900 million).

- Other sectors targeted with special measures (many of them announced in the 27 March package) include the brewery industry, fuel industry, horseracing and reindeer herding.
column37:
". Deferral of income tax and VAT payments (further extensions were announced 16 April)

- The various support for the air travel sector includes suspension of the tax on air passengers for flights until 31 October 2020 and suspension of payments of aviation charges until 31 June 2020.
column40: Government  loan and guarantee schemes announced 15 March include reinstatement of Government Bond Fund that purchases company bonds (in total up to NOK 50 billion) (announced at same time as state guarantees for firms).
column43:
Government loan and guarantee schemes announced 15 March includes state guarantees for enterprises, initially for firms with less than 250 employees, later extended to all enterprises (in total up to NOK 50 billion).

The various support for air travel sector includes an aviation-sector guarantee scheme totalling NOK 6 billion, with a 90 percent government guarantee on each loan,

Increased loan-loss provisions (valued at NOK 10 billion) for the Norwegian Export Credit Agency (GIEK) were announced in the Revised National Budget (12 May).
column46:
May 8. Norges Bank cuts the policy rate to 0%.
March 31. Norges Bank announces that it will purchase foreign currency during April, the equivalent of NOK 2 billion per day.
March 20. 75-basis-point cut to 0.25%.
March 19. Central bank signals possible intervention in the foreign-exchange market, swap facility between Norges Bank and the US Federal Reserve announced.
March 18. Lighter security pledges for access to loans from Norges Bank.
March 13. 50-basis-point rate cut to 1%. Extended credit facilities to banks."
column47:
"March 23. Additional leeway for bank lending though increase in share of new mortgages that banks can issue for which some macroprudential rules do not apply.
March 13. Reduction in countercyclical buffer for banks.
column54: Lighter share-price rules in the event of a change of control in listed companies, with a view to facilitating acquisitions and restructurings (announced in 27 March package).

column12:
* March 13: Declaration of the national state of emergency. Declaration of curfew that has been extended progressively and now applies to the entire day, with some exceptions.

* March 19: Tightening of measures, with closure of all non-essential firms and businesses starting from March 21.

* April 1: Tightening of measures, with women and men allowed to go out on alternative week days.

* June 1: Lifting of restrictions for going out for men and women and easing of curfew from 7pm to 5am. Elimination of strict confinement on Sundays starting from June 7.

* June 6: Reinstatement of restrictions for going out by gender and ID number, with total quarantine on week-ends, in Panama West and Panama starting from June 8. Other provinces will maintain the curfew from 7 pm to 5 am. *August 18: In Panamá and Panamá Oeste lifting of mobility restrictions by ID number since August 24, while gender restrictions will remain.
column14:
* March 13-15: Suspension of all inbound and outbound flights from/to Europe and Asia; closure of all maritime, terrestrial and air routes starting from March 16 at midnight, with exceptions for residents and nationals.

* March 20: Suspension of all commercial international flights starting March 22.

* March 25: Suspension of all domestic flights.

* June 22: Extension of suspension of international flights for another 30 days.
column16:
*March 10: Suspension of classes in North and Central Panama, as well as San Miguelito until April 7.

* March 11: Suspension of classes at national level.
column18:
* March 13: Suspension of events and activities involving the agglomeration of people.

* March 16: Closures of all recreational, sports and public spaces involving the agglomeration of people. Obligation for supermarkets to comply with sanitary measures, with hygienic gel for public use on the premises. Obligation for clients to keep a distance of one metre from each other in restaurants, banks and pharmacies.
column20:
* March 19: Closure of all non-essential firms and businesses starting from March 21, excluding food, pharmaceutical, transport and logistics, security, fuel, construction and financial sectors among others.

* March 24: Closure of the construction industry.

* April 21: Laundries, savings and credit cooperatives, agricultural production cooperatives, and cargo transport cooperatives are included in the sectors exempted from shut-down measures.

* May 5: Reopening of the hardware stores with limited opening times, only allowed to operate via telephone or digital platform.

* May 13: Reopening of the e-commerce and online shopping stores, repair shops, artisanal fishing, and technical service providers (e.g. plumbers, electricians) in respect of sanitary measures.

* May 25: Extension of the temporal suspension of the construction sector for another 15 days.

* June 1: Re-opening of the the second block of activities, including industry, non-metal mining, construction of priority public infrastructure projects, as well as worship places, parks, social and sports areas at 25% of their capacity and with distancing rules.
column22:
* March 13: Authorisation for the Ministry of Finance to request a temporal suspension of the financial limits over social fiscal responsibility established by law 34 of 2008, modified by law 102 of 2019, before the National Assembly, if necessary.

* March 18: Announcement of the Plan Panama Solidario. It will count with measures to mitigate the negative economic effects of the coronavirus and an initial budget of 50 million balboas.

* April 3: Approval of the law which allows government to use the resources of the Panama Savings Fund (Fondo de Ahorro Panamá) for the coronavirus emergency.

* April 30: The National Emergency Fund counts with 191 million balboas, of which 140 million balboas have been destined to the Plan Panama Solidario. So far 56 million balboas have been used for vouchers.

* July 6: New financial resources of 223 millions balboas assigned to the Plan Panama Solidario.

* July 6: New measures announced as part of recovery plan include a salary cut of high-level public servants between up to 50% for the President and Vicepresident of the Republic for six months; measures for the protection of jobs; zero tariff on imports of mais for animal feeding.

* August 12: The Ministry of Economy and Finance (MEF) has so far transferred 214,699,966 balboas to the Presidency for responding to the emergency, of which 131,771,823.70 balboas for the physical voucher (April, May, June) and 43,932,400.30 for the digital voucher.
* August 18: Launch of the Programme Recuperando Mi Barrio, as part of the 12 actions of the Economic Recovery Plan announced in July. It will allow to create temporary jobs through renovation of buildings and public infrastructure.
column25:
* January 23: Activation of the Centre of Emergency Operations in Health (CODES) and declaration of the green health alert starting January 22 by the Ministry of Health.

* January 28: Adoption of the Plan Nacional ante la amenaza por el Brote del Nuevo Coronavirus, including the recognition of the Ministry of Health as the only entity authorised to trasmit information over the coronavirus epidemics and the call for mass medias to coordinate with the Ministry. Authorisation for the Ministry of Finance to assign an initial budget of one million balboas to the Ministry of Health for all initial expenses aimed at stopping the propagation of the coronavirus by Cabinet resolution.

* March 3: Authorisation to assign three million balboas to the Ministry of Health for initial expenses and five million balboas if the cases exceed the current predictions.

* March 18: Construction of the modular hospital Panama Solidario, in Albrook. The hospital will count with 100 beds, 26 for intensive care, for a cost of 6.5 million balboas.

* March 19: Declaration of the provinces of Panama, West Panama and Colon as "epidemic areas" subject to sanitary control.
column28:
* January 28: Coordination between the Ministry of Health and the Social Security Fund (Caja de Seguro Social) for the recognition of the quarantine period as a period of incapacity to work.

* March 16: Payments of pensions by the Social Security Fund to retirees to be done on cards instead of checks to avoid queues and reduce exposition to coronavirus. First 14,000 cards distributed on April 6.

* March 18: Launch of the Plan Panama Solidario with an initial budget line of 50 million balboas destined to vouchers and food baskets for informal workers, workers whose job was suspended because of coronavirus and unemployed people. This voucher can be used for the purchase of food and medicines.

* March 31: Public servants with a salary above USD 1,000 will be able to voluntary contribute to the Fondo Panama Solidario created for the coronavirus emergency, with some exceptions such as health personnel and security forces. The solidarity vouchers will amount to USD 80 per month in 4 instalments of USD 20.

* April: Increase in the electricity subsidies benefitting all consumers of up to 1000 kwh per month for 3 months covering up to 30-50% of the electricity bill. Electricity subsidies will reach 1100 thousand families for a total of 39 million balboas for the first month.

* June 11: Increase of the Panama Solidario voucher from USD80 to USD100 per month starting from July 1st.
column31: Information not available
column34: * May 14: Launch of the Plan Panama AgroSolidario to support agricultural producers with loans at zero interest rate. The National Bank of Panama will receive 150 millions for the provision of the loans between 2020-2022.
column37: * March 24: Extension of the term for the payment of national taxes, rates, special contributions and any other debts of competence of the General Directorate of Revenue to 120 days counted from March 20. This applies to citizens and firms.
column40: * August 3: Launch of the Programme Banca de Oportunidades for the economic recovery of microenterprises, with loans from 2,000 to 5,000 balboas with repayment terms up to 84 months. The government initially assigned 20 million balboas to this project, which is the first of 12 actions of the Plan de Recuperación Económica y Social.
column43: Information not available
column46: Information not available
column47: * March 18: Measures to allow banks more flexibility vis-a-vis their clients. "Modified loans" whereby banks can grant the extension of the re-payments of loans, reduce their interest rates and modify their terms without being penalised by having to increase their bank reserves.
column48:
* March: Electricity companies have agreed to maintain their services even to those clients who failed to pay their electricity bills during the time of the emergency.
*May 1: Any process of eviction will be considered illegal during the state of emergency. Rents and surcharges for late payments are frozen until two months after the lifting of the state of emergency.

* May 4: Extension of the moratoria on payment of loans to 31 December 2020. There will be no waiver of interests, but banks will not apply a surcharge for late payments.

* May 4: Approval of legislation n. 295 for the temporal suspension of the payments of energy, internet, and fixed and mobile telephone bills for four months without interests by National Assembly. The measures apply to the retired, to workers with a monthly salary inferior to 2,000 balboas, and to those not working because of the crisis, as well as own-account workers, owners of bars, restaurants and other small businesses affected by the coronavirus crisis.
column51:
* March 18: Measures to allow banks more flexibility vis-a-vis their clients. "Modified loans" whereby banks can grant the extension of the re-payments of loans, reduce their interest rates and modify their terms without being penalised by having to increase their bank reserves.

* April 8: Suspension of the payment of rents in the Colon Free Zone for the months of April, May and June 2020. The measure will not apply to those firms showing exporting activities.
*May 1: Any process of eviction will be considered illegal during the state of emergency. Rents and surcharges for late payments are frozen until two months after the lifting of the state of emergency.

* May 4: Extension of the moratoria on payment of loans to 31 December 2020. There will be no waiver of interests, but banks will not apply a surcharge for late payments.

* May 4: Approval of legislation n. 295 for the temporal suspension of the payments of energy, internet, and fixed and mobile telephone bills for four months without interests by National Assembly. The measures apply to the retired, to workers with a monthly salary inferior to 2,000 balboas, and to those not working because of the crisis, as well as own-account workers, owners of bars, restaurants and other small businesses affected by the coronavirus crisis.
column54:
* March 13: Lifting of tariffs over imports of medical and care products. Maximum gross profit margin fixed at 23% in all retail businesses at the national level for all care products in high demand.

* March 17: Announcement of the reduction of fuel prices by 25% and of electricity prices by 5%.

* March 20: Firms affected by the lockdown can suspend the contracts of their workers until the end of the emergency. The latter will be eligible for income support by the Plan Panama Solidario.

* March 25: Disbursement by the World Bank of USD 41 million through the Development Policy Loan with a Catastrophe Deferred Drawdown Option (CAT DDO) to face the coronavirus emergency.

* March 26: Sale of USD 2.5 billion worth of government bonds with maturation in 2056 at an interest rate of 4.5% to fight the coronavirus.

* April 14: Approval of three additional lines of credit. USD 300 million from the IaDB will support SMEs (USD 150 million) and the agriculture sector (USD 150 million); USD 500 million from the IMF; and USD 500 million from MIGA (World Bank Group) to cover health, food, security and employment needs.

* April 21: Extension of the temporary suspension of contracts for an additional month.

* May 4: The USD 515 million provided by the IMF will be managed by the National Bank of Panama and used to support banking sector liquidity.

* May 14: Approval of the law for budget support of the local governments for the mobilisation of the resources at their disposal.

column12:
* From 15 June and until 19 July (extended on 5 July): Third stage of re-opening ("smart quarantine"). Departments of Pargauarí and Concepción remain in phase 2, while the district of San Roque González de Santacruz (Paraguarí) is put into total lockdown (phase 0). During phase 3, non-essential trade can open, movement is subject to a curfew (23:00
- 05:00 on weekdays, 00:00
- 05:00 on week-ends). The range of economic activities that open is increased, outdoor sports activities (without physical contact) are allowed, as are indoor sporting activities subject to sanitary protocols and registration of attendance. Religious ceremonies can take place with guaranteed social distancing and limits on the number of attendants (20) as well as registration of attendance.

* May 25: Second stage of re-opening ("smart quarantine"). During this phase, non-essential trade can open with reduced opening hours (10am to 7pm) as long as public areas remain closed and registers are kept for stays over 30 minutes. Food and drink establishments can operate for take away and delivery only. Personal services can function in the client's residence of permises. Construction can resume. Offices can open at 50% of capacity, including schools for personnel only (teaching remains done at distance). Cultural activities can resume without members of the public. Individual sporting activities are allowed, including individual training by professional athletes. Movement is subject to a curfew (21:00
- 5:00)

* May 4: First stage of re-opening, labeled "smart quarantine". The first phase of re-opening is to last until May 25. During this phase, most closed manufacturing industries can re-open, as can vehicle repair shops and certain construction activities. Services can begin functioning in the client's residence or premises. Individual sport activity is permitted. The public is to stay at home except to purchase essential goods or go to work. In the former case, a system of alternate vehicle circulation is in place based on plate numbers. Movement to purchase essential goods is subject to a curfew (21:00
- 5:00).

* March 20: The country implemented a total quarantine.

* March 16: A health emergency is declared and preventive isolation is ordered by Decree 3456/2020

* March 12: Exceptional working hours of government institutions

* March 9: Implementation of preventive actions against coronavirus according to the National Plan for respiratory viruses 2020
column14:
* March 24: Paraguay announced the full closure of borders. This measure does not affect cargo aircraft, or commercial transport from foreign countries.

* March 15: incoming travellers subject to 14 day quarantine

* March 14. Commercial flights were gradually suspended from this date.
column16:
* June 15: In-person teaching remains closed but examinations and laboratory practice require for graduation are allowed if they respect social distancing and do not gather more than 10 people

* March 19: The Ministry of Education and Science (MEC), in agreement with the Microsoft Paraguay firm, launched the platform "Tu escuela en casa". This platform will allow students to have virtual classes as part of the contingency plan adopted to mitigate the spread of COVID-19. Approximately more than 1,500,000 students and 80,000 teachers will have free access to the learning platform from a computer or a cell phone.

* March 10: the government has decided to suspend all educational activities at all levels of education in coordination with the Ministry of Education and Science, universities and other training institutions
column18:
* 15 June: as part of the third stage of "smart quarantine" outdoor public spaces and gatherings are permitted subject to registration and santiary protocols. Public places (food courts, playgrounds, waiting areas) remain closed.

* March 10: suspension of all activities that involve groups of people, as well as public and private events (resolution 90/2020 of Ministry of Public Health and Social Welfare)
column20:
* June 15 (until 19 July, extended on 5 July): Third phase of gradual opening of the economy (Decree 3706): most industry and factories allowed to function, and non-essential trade allowed to open at reduced opening times (10:00
- 19:00) and subject to sanitary protocols. Premises where the public stays over 30 minutes have to deliver services with prior reservation and registration of clients. Restaurants are allowed to open with registration and reservation and subject to specific sanitary protocols. Offices are allowed to open at 50% of capacity. Cultural activities can function without public. Bars, hotels, casinos and public recreational events cannot operate.

* May 25: Second phase of gradual opening of the economy: most industry and factories allowed to function, and non-essential trade allowed to open at reduced opening times and subject to sanitary protocols. Services are allowed to operate on a home delivery basis and food and drink establishments operate for take away or delivery only. Offices are allowed to open at 50% of capacity.
*May 4: Gradual opening of the economy, most industry and factories allowed to open under enhanced sanitary standards, as well as vehicle repair shops. Public works allowed to operate as well as some private construction. Services are allowed to operate on a home delivery basis.
*April 13: Extension of quarantine and restriction of exceptions. Most activities remain closed, with a positive list of exceptions including essential services (health, maintenance of health equipment, public security forces, meteorological services, fire squad, air traffic control), media, public works (at half capacity), supermarkets and essential shops (pharmacies, gas stations), agriculture and food production and distribution channels, waste management, utilities (only as necessary to mantain service), home delivery of essential goods (subject to the curfew), security and cleaning services, essential financial services, logistics and funeral services. Public transport is heavily restricted and inter-urban public transport not operating since April 9.

* March 20: Most activities ordered to close, with a positive list of exceptions including essential services (health, maintenance of health equipment, public security forces, meteorological services, fire squad, air traffic control), media, public works, supermarkets and essential shops (pharmacies, distributors of cooking gas, gas stations, DIY stores), industrial and trade activities for essential goods, agriculture and food production and distribution channels, telecommunication and call centres, waste management, utilities, public transport, home delivery of essential goods, security and cleaning services. essential financial services, logistics and funeral services.
column22:
* June 29: Announcement of a USD 2 513.6 million plan financed in part by a futher increase in debt of USD 350 million, including 1 372.3 USD million in public investment (within 2020), 676 USD million in credit facilities (including direct credit and guarantees), and 465.3 USD million in social protection benefits and other support projects

* April 23: Paraguay emits USD 1 000 million in sovereign bonds (10 year maturity at 4.95% interest rate)

* April, 2: By Decree No. 3506, which regulates Law declaring a State of Emergency throughout the national territory in the face of the coronavirus pandemic, the Executive authorized the Ministry of Finance to sign loan agreements on behalf of Paraguay and to establish the issuance and placement of Treasury Bonds, either in the domestic or international market, for a total of USD 1.6 billion. Expenditure has been repurposed to respond to the epidemic in particular through temporary reductions in wages, bonuses and travel budgets amounting to around 52 USD million.

* March 26: An emergency package amounting to USD 945 million (2.5 percent of GDP) has been approved by the congress. The government has asked Congress to authorize additional borrowing of up to USD 1.6 billion (4 percent of GDP) from IFIs and through bond issuances.
*
column25:
* March 26: The emergency package includes health-related spending for doubling beds for intensive care, investment in hospital supplies, acquisition of more reagents to increase testing, a bonus for health professionals and the provision of care centers for affected patients. The planned envelope for the health system is 514 USD million and the constitution of a specific Emergency Health Fund in planned to channel resources

* March, 25: The government has lowered VAT on medical supplies to 5% and eliminated import tariffs on them

* March 19: The government has put all sanitary response to the Covid-19 epidemic in the public sector under the coordination of the Ministry of Health
*March 16: Through presidential decree 3456/2020, a state of health emergency was declared.
column28:
* 29 June 2020: announcement of funding of USD 250 million to support a new social protection programme (Pytyv 2.0) aiming to assist and formalise 770 000 beneficiaries.

* 29 June 2020: announcement of funding of 215.3 USD million to increase coverage of social assistance programmes (social pensions, conditional cash transfers and childhood integration)

* 30 March 2020: Creation of food security programme (angareko) which makes a single PYG 500 000 transfer for food purchases to vulnerable households not covered by social assistance (it is expected the transfer will reach 300 000 households for a total outlay of 165 000 million PYG or 25 million USD). Transfers are made by electornic wallet in most cases and as food baskets in more remote areas.

* An additional half installment was granted to 167 000 households receiving the conditional cash transfer Tekoporã. The estimated cost is 31 378 million PYG (about 4.8 million USD) with payments starting on May 13.

* Workers with active contributions to the social security institute (IPS) whose activity was closed or contracts suspended are eligible for a transfer of up to 50% of minimum wage paid once (100 USD million have been made availalbe to finance this allowance).

* March 26th: Through the emergency package, the governement took measures to safeguard the income of workers in situations of informality (priority was given to those whose income is equal or inferior to a legal minimum wage, who do and not receive other social transfers). The established allowance is equivalent to 25% of the minimum wage. The Ministry of Finance estimates that this benefit could reach approximately 1,500,000 people, and for this it will have a fund of USD 300 million. The subsidy has been operationalised as the Pytyv programme.

* Utility bills for the months of March, April and May (Electricity, Phone services, water supply) are waived for vulnerable households (identified on the basis of past consumption). Others can defer payment and make it in 18 installments with 0 % interest .

* Government invested USD 10 million to acquire 300,000 food kits.(Fiscal incidence estimate on the basis of available funds)
column31: * 25 March: Temporary reduced VAT rate on medical supplies (until 30 June 2020)
column34: Information not available
column37:
* March 26: The tax authority (Undersecretariat of State for Taxation (SET)), by means of General Resolution No. 49/20, exceptionally extends the term for the presentation of the tax returns and the payment of tax obligations

* Payment facility for VAT extended over 4 months with initial instalment of 20%, for Personal Income Tax payments and arrears (up to 5 months with initial payment of 20%), and for Corporate Income tax (the Income Tax from Agricultural Activities (IRAGRO) and the Commercial, Industrial or Services Income Tax (IRACIS)) (payment july 2020, extended 14 April).
column40:
* 29 June: (announcement) Establishment of a Long Term Fund for Private investment (through the National Development Bank (BNF)) worth 361 milllion USD.

* 13 April: The trust fund established in the Development Finance Agency (AFD) is to receive additional capital of 650 000 million PYG (100 million USD) on top of the 60 000 million PYG planned in March.

* 26 March: The Development Finance Agency (AFD) has made available a fund with up to 20% of the National Development Bank (BNF) uncapitalized net profits to support Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises. Likewise, the AFD will receive USD 18.5 million from the Ministry of Finance in order to grant credits to Micro, Small and Medium-sized Businesses.

* 26 March: The Agricultural Habilitation Credit (CAH) organisation is to receive additional capital of 120 000 million PYG (18.6 million USD) for granting credit to households and MSMEs.
column43:
* 29 June (announcement): creation of a housing credit guarantee fund of 80 million USD.

* 13 April: The Guarantee Fund for Micro, Small and Medium-sized enterprises (FOGAPY) is to receive addition capital of 100 million USD (approximately 650 000 million PYG), which would allow it to guarantee up to 3 250 000 million PYG in loans (or 500 million USD). FOGAPY can guarantee loans up to 1 000 million PYG with a coverage rate of up to 70% per operation.

* 26 March:The Guarantee Fund for Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises will receive USD 4.6 million from the Ministry of Finance (Law of National Emergency, No. 6524).
column46:
* 21 June: Rection of the policy rate to 0.75%

* April 22: Reduction of the policy rate to 1.25%.

* April 20: Creation of a new liquidity window for repo operations on collateralised loans with rate 150 basis points above the zero coupon curve and maturity of up to 1 year.

* March 30: Reduction of the interest rate by 100 basis points to 2.25%.

* March 30: Liberation of the Legal Reserve in National and Foreign Currency, which represents making funds available to financial entities for an equivalent value of USD 959 million.(minimum reserve requirements have been lowered 3 times during the period, the latest on 16 April)

* March 30: Creation of a liquidity window for entities for a term of up to 12 months, for a value equivalent to USD 760 million.
column47: * 2 April: Financial institutions are allowed not to hold reserves agaisnt new loans to MSMEs granted during the Covid-19 crisis for 18 months (individual loans up to 51 000 USD)
column54: * March 30: Paraguay is cutting wages and other benefits in the public sector for at least three months as part of measures to mitigate coronavirus. The government will cap monthly public sector wages at 37 million Paraguayan Guarani (around US USD 5,700), which matches the amount of the president's salary. It is also implementing wage cuts of 10% and 20% for public employees whose salaries exceed five and 10 times the minimum wage, all of which will save a total of about  USD 52 million. The President of the Chamber of Deputies, authorized the Executive Branch to temporarily deduct 20% of the salaries of all legislators in the Lower House and redirect those funds to strengthen the fight against the COVID-19 coronavirus pandemic (for 3 months).

column12:
*August 16: Publication of Supreme Decree No. 116-2020-PCM which expands quarantine measures to combat the spread of COVID-19 in Peru. Quarantine measures are now in effect in 19 regions. Mandatory nightly curfew from 22h to 4h remains in effect from Monday to Saturday for non-quarantine areas. The nightly curfew for quarantine areas is in effect from 22h to 4h Monday through Saturday. The all-day Sunday curfew will resume throughout the entire country beginning August 16.

*June 30: Sixth extension of the state of emergency until July 31 (Decreto Supremo No 116-2020-PCM). The lockdown is lifted in most of the country, except for the regions of Arequipa, Ica, Junín, Huánuco, San Martín, Madre de Dios and ncash.

*May 23: Fifth extension of the state of emergency until June 30 (Decreto Supremo No 094-2020-PCM). Curfew times remain and economic activities deemed essential such as dentistry, ophthalmology, rehabilitation services, and veterinary medicine will be allowed to resume. Certain professional services such as plumbing, gardening, domestic appliance maintenance and repair, hairdressing and cosmetology will be allowed as long as these services are provided to the home.

*May 10: Publication of Decreto Legislativo No 083-2020-PCM which allows children under 14 years of age, who are not presenting COVID-19 symptoms, to leave their residence accompanied by an adult for a daily 30-minute walk as of 18 May. Children must stay within 500 meters of their residence and comply with all other health norms such as maintaining social distance and wearing a facemask.

*May 8: Fourth extension of the state of emergency until May 24 (Decreto Supremo No 044-2020-PCM). The decree modifies the starting time of curfew in Lima and most of Peru from 8pm to 4am for Lima and most of Peru.
