Curfew times in the rest of the country remain the same: 4pm to 4am in La Libertad, Lambayeque, Loreto, Piura, and Tumbes regions.

*April 23: Third extension of the state of emergency until May 10 (Decreto Supremo No 075-2020-PCM).

*April 11: Second extension of the state of emergency until April 26 (Decreto Supremo No 064-2020-PCM). The decree provides the mandatory use of facemasks and establishes that for the acquisition of food, pharmaceuticals and banking activities, only one person per family unit (regardless of gender) is allowed from Monday to Saturday.

*March 26: First extension of the state of emergency Decreto Supremo No 051-2020-PCM until April 12.
column14:
*July 15: As per Ministerial Resolution 0384-2020-MTC, domestic travel resumes throughout Peru except for Ancash, Arequipa, Huánuco, Ica, Junín, Madre de Dios, and San Martín. Travel is prohibited to and from these seven regions where quarantine is still in effect.

*May 8: The national emergency decree (Decreto Supremo No 044-2020-PCM) modifies curfew hours for Lima and most of Peru: from 8pm to 4am for Lima and most of Peru. Curfew times in the rest of the country remain the same: 4pm to 4am in La Libertad, Lambayeque, Loreto, Piura, and Tumbes regions.


* March 15: The decree of national emergency (Decreto Supremo No 044-2020-PCM) involves the closing of national borders, restrictions to interprovincial movement, and daily curfews from 6pm to 5 am.
column16:
*June 24: Publication of Vice-Ministerial Resolution No. 116-2020-MINEDU, which approves the "Protocol for the start of the face-to-face educational service of the 2020 school year". Starting July 1, COVID-19 free regions, schools will have a maximum of two shifts and the capacity of the classrooms must not exceed 50% of their maximum capacity.

*April 18: Publication of Legislative Decree 1465 which authorises the Ministry of Education to buy 719,000 mini tablets with mobile internet for primary and secondary education schools in rural areas.

*April 6: Establishment of distance learning platform (television and radio) Aprendo en Casa for early childhood, primary, secondary and alternative education students.

*March 15: all schools closed following the decree of national emergency.
column18: * March 15: all public events and public places closed following the decree of national emergency, until further notice
column20:
*June 2: Publication of Decreto Supremo No 094-2020-PCM which sets out Phase 2 of the reopening of the economy. Specific sectors will resume economic activities, inter alia acquisition, production and supply of food, which includes its storage and distribution for sale to the public; acquisition, production and supply of pharmaceutical and basic necessity products; Assistance to health centres, services and establishments, as well as diagnostic centres.

*May 4: Publication of Decreto Supremo No 080-2020-PCM to initiate a gradual reactivation of the economy. This foresees four phases: Phase 1 involves a progressive resumption of 27 economic activities in the sectors of mining and industry, construction, services/tourism and retail, subject to compliance with certain sanitary measures.

*Since March 15, and until further notice, all non-essential business operations are forbidden-excluding health facilities, food vendors, pharmacies, and financial institutions.
column22:
*April 16: Debt issuance by the Ministry of Economy and Finance of two bonds (Bono Global 2026 and Bono Global 2030) for a quantity of USD 3,000 million
- Resolución Ministerial No 136-2020-EF/52.

*April 12: Publication of Legislative Decree 1457 which sets the temporary and extraordinary suspension of the fiscal rules for 2020 and 2021.

*March 28: The government announced an overall package of around PEN 90,000 million (USD 26 billion), equivalent to 12% of GDP, including two main areas of intervention: 1) contain the impact of the shock, supporting the most vulnerable and protecting payment chains, worth 8% of GDP (including the joint action with the BCRP to guarantee loans to SMEs, worth 4% of GDP); 2) a second phase aimed at supporting the recovery after the shock.
column25:
*July 8: Arrival of 476 ventilators to expand the capacity of ICUs.

*June 10: Under the Temporary Hospital Expansion Plan, the government will construct by end June, 10 temporary hospitals in Lima and nine in other heavily affected regions, providing additional 4504 beds and 232 ICU beds.

*June 3: Peru received 85 doctors and medical professionals from Cuba to join local health workers.

*May 3: Publication of Legislative Decree N° 1474 which strengthens preventive mechanisms and actions, care and protection of elderly adults during the duration of the state of emergency, in particular those in vulnerable situations, such as poverty or extreme poverty.

*April 4: transfer of PEN 720 (USD 215) to workers in the medical sector supporting the COVID-19 emergency.

*March 22: approval of around USD 260 million package for health-related measures, including the support for health services, disinfection efforts in transport and educational sector, and the suspension of tariffs for imports of medicines.

*March 12: Temporary reduction to 0% tariff importation of medical equipment and pharmaceuticals for the duration of the national emergency state -Decreto Supremo No° 051-2020-EF.
column28:
*May 10: Announcement of “Bono Familiar Universal”, an unconditional cash transfer of PEN 760 (USD 227) to 6 million families (75% of the total population in the country). This includes previous monetary transfers, namely the “Bono yo me quedo en casa” and “Bono independiente”, and adds to them the “Bono Rural” and the transfer that will be given to the remaining 2.3 million households that are estimated to have no formal dependency labour relationship.

*May 1: Enactment of Law 31017 which provides AFP affiliates to withdraw, voluntarily and extraordinarily, up to 25% of the total of their accumulated funds in their individual accounts (with a maximum of PEN 12,000 (USD 3,539) and a minimum of PEN 4,300 (USD 1,278))

*April 27: Approval of a transfer of PEN 311 million (USD 90 million) to municipalities, to support the provision of public services and payroll expenditures.

*April 16: PEN 760 bonus (around USD 696) to more than 1 million households in rural areas.

* Second PEN 380 bonus (around USD 110) to support around 3 million vulnerable families

*March 26: In-kind support of package worth PEN 200 million (around USD 60 million) of transfers to 1,874 municipalities to support most vulnerable locals with basic products
*Right to withdraw individual savings from the CTS up to a level of PEN 2400 (USD 700) and suspension of 10% social security contribution to AFP (private administrators of pension funds).

*March 21: Advance payments in the Contigo and Pension 65 pension programmes, which benefit people with severe disabilities and those over 65 in situations of poverty.

*March 18: First PEN 380 bonus (around USD 110) to support around 3 million vulnerable families and independent workers.
column31:
*May 27: Changes to Plan Reactívate Peru by Supreme Decree 124-2020-EF, with particular emphasis in supporting micro and small-sized enterprises. Changes include increasing the maximum loan amounts for micro-sized enterprises from 1 to 3 months of average monthly sales. In the case of micro-sized enterprises that cannot document a level of sales that reflects their actual transactions, they will be able to access a Reactiva Peru Program financing -based on their credit history
- of up to S/40,000 (around USD 11,751)

*May 10: Expansion (Decreto Legislativo No 1486) of Plan Reactívate Peru by PEN 30000 million (USD 9000 million) for a total of PEN 60000 million.

*April 9: Support with the payment of 35% of payrolls of workers earning up to PEN 1500 (USD 443) a month.

*April 4: Approval of the Plan Reactívate Peru, to support access to credit for SMEs with guarantees up to PEN 30000 million. (USD 9000 million) to access credit to sustain the payments chains and payrolls. Liquidity will be injected through the Central Bank to commercial banks, and credits will be guaranteed by the State.

*March 28: Creation of the "Fondo de Ayuda Empresarial" to support SMEs to secure working capital and/or refinance debts, worth PEN 300 million (USD 87 million)

*March 24: Approval of three-month extension for income tax declaration for SMEs and greater flexibility to enterprises in the repayment of tax liabilities.
column34:
*April 27: Expansion of the Fondo de Ayuda Empresarial fund to support SMEs by PEN 500 million (around USD 150 million), which now amounts to a total of PEN 800 million (around USD 236 million). This will support credit guarantees up to a total of PEN 4000 million. The guarantee has been expanded to 98% to all SMEs, and with a grace period of 12 months

*March 28: Creation of the "Fondo de Ayuda Empresarial" to support SMEs to secure working capital and/or refinance debts, worth PEN 300 million (USD 87 million).

*March 13: 90% expansion of Fondo Crecer to allow SMEs to access capital: measures have been taken to speed up the expansion of the Crecer Fund, which has USD 225 million allocated to allow SMEs to access capital.
column37:
*March 26: Suspension of the 10% social security contribution to AFP (private administrators of pension funds).

*March 24: The government has approved a three-month extension for the income tax declaration for SMEs and is granting flexibility to enterprises in the repayment of tax liabilities.

*March 13: The government is granting flexibility to households in the repayment of tax liabilities
- Resolución de Superintendencia N° 054-2020/SUNAT.
column40: Information not available
column43: *May 12: Publication of Decreto Legislativo No. 1508 approving the creation of a Government guarantee programme for loans to companies in the financial system for up to PEN 7 million (USD 2 million), with the aim of increasing its capacity to face scenarios of greater demand for liquidity.
column46:
*August 13: The Central Bank of Peru maintained unchanged the policy rate at 0.25 per cent.


*July 9: The Central Bank of Peru maintained unchanged the policy rate at 0.25 per cent.

*June 11: The Central Bank of Peru maintained unchanged the policy rate at 0.25 per cent.

*April 9: The Central Bank of Peru (BCRP) cut the policy rate from to 1.25 to 0.25 per cent, further to a previous cut in March from 2.25 to 1.25 per cent. BCRP has provided liquidity to the financial system through repo operations. BCRP also reduced the interest rates of operations in national currency with the financial system, under the modality of window, such as overnight deposits to 0.15% per year and operations of direct reporting of securities and currency, and loans of monetary regulation at 0.5% per year. Reserve requirements for commercial banks have been reduced, both in domestic and foreign currency, to release around PEN 2000 million (USD 600 million).
column47: Information not available
column48:
*April 4: Publication of decree (Decreto de Urgencia 035-2020) for the deferral of payment, or payment in instalments, of utility bills on water, electricity, gas, and telecommunications.

*March 28: The Superintendency of Banks and Insurances authorises financial institutions to defer the payments of credits by individuals and businesses
column51:
* March 28: The Superintendency of Banks and Insurances authorises financial instutions to defer the payments of credits by individuals and businesses

* Support with the payment of 35% of payrolls of workers earning up to PEN 1500 a month.
* Possibility for firms that cannot implement teleworking modalities or are in a particularly tough situation to suspend employment temporarily, for a maximum period of 90 days, without breaking the contract and without having to pay compensations to workers
column54:
*July 1: Opening of Machu Picchu at 15% of its capacity. Only 657 people allowed per day in lieu of approximately 4,000.

*June 15: The Government announces the launch of the programme “Arranca Per” worth USD 1.800 mn. which encompasses public works in transportation and communications and housing, among others to spur economic activity and job creation. The government aims to create more than 1 mn jobs.

*May 13: Publication of Decreto Legislativo No. 1491 authorising the Instituto Tecnológico de la Producción of the Ministry of Production to provide free tech services and support to over 16,000 SMEs until end 2020.

*May 12: Publication of Decreto Legislativo No. 1507 giving free access to public servants, children and elder people, national and foreign, to archaeological sites, museums, and natural protected areas from 1 July to 31 December.

*May 10: Announcement by the Ministry of Production to establish a virtual platform under the SUNAT to allow informal firms to become formal.

column12: On March 8, the President signed a bill on extraordinary measures to contain the spread of the virus, including easier conditions to telework for persons subject to quarantine or epidemiological surveillance and additional powers for provincial governors to take containment measures at the local level. On March 13, the state of epidemic emergency was declared and a fine of PLN 5000 for violating quaranteen was introduced. On March 20, fines for violating quarantine rules were increase from PLN 5,000 to PLN 30,000. On March 24, the Prime Minister announced strict lockdown measures that considerably restricted people's movement and gatherings. It became forbidden to leaving home unless absolutely necessary. People could only go out to buy food and medicine, go to work, consult a physician or walk their pets. Gatherings of three or more persons became prohibited unless they are family members. The maximum number of persons taking part in religious ceremonies and funerals was cut to five. For means of public transportation, the limit of passengers was defined at half of seats. The lockdown was expected to remain in force until 11 April. On 31 March, the lockdown measures were tightened further, notably by closing hotels, temporary accommodation services, hairdressers and public parks, by reducing the number of allowed customers in shops, and by dedicating specific hours for the shopping of older persons. Wearing protective gloves became mandatory for all customers in shops. A ban on operations of home improvement retailers on weekends was introduced. Persons below 18 years old were not allowed go out unless accompanied by an adult. Pedestrians had to keep at least 2-metres distance from each other, even when walking together. On April 9, it became compulsory to cover nose and mouth in public using masks and the strict lockdown measures were prolonged. On May 4, the first measures to ease the lockdown came into force: shopping centres, hotels and other accommodation facilities were allowed to reopen. The number of customers in such centres was limited to one customer per 15 square metres and social distancing rules still applied. Restaurants and other type of businesses (e.g. fitness clubs, hair and beauty salons, cinemas and travel agents) remained closed. On May 6, nurseries and preschools were allowed to reopen again, as well as cultural institutions (libraries, museums, art galleries) and physiotherapy centres. On March 18, lockdown measures were eased again. Restaurants, hairdresser's, and beauty parlours were allowed to open under a strict a sanitary regime. So did open-air cinemas, art schools and recording studios. The permitted number of people on football pitches and in stadiums was increased and it became possible to organise sport activities indoors. More travellers (30% of the maximum number) were allowed aboard public transport. On May 25, the youngest children (grades 1-3) were able to go back to schools and teachers started to organise consultations for eighth-graders and A-level pupils. At the same time the child care allowance was kept, so that parents could choose whether to send their kids to school or not. On May 30, lockdown measures were eased again. Wearing face masks in public spaces was no longer mandatory if maintaining two metre distance is possible. Wearing masks was still be obligatory in shops, churches, cinemas, on public transport and during social interaction at distances shorter than two metres. The limit on the number of customers entering shops, restaurants and bars was also abolished. However, in small retail and catering premises customers still had to wear face masks. Similar rules applied to churches. Public gatherings of up to 150 persons were permitted again. Participants were required to maintain two metre distance from each other or wear masks. On June 6, cinemas, theatres, philharmonic halls, sports and recreation facilities were allowed to reopen. Weddings and other family events were also allowed to take place, with the number of guests limited to 150.
column14: On March 6, bilateral parlamentary journeys to other countries were suspended. On March 10, as a reaction to the expected rapid growth in the number of confirmed cases, sanitary inspections were introduced at four border crossings with Germany and one with the Czech Republic. The inspections mainly concerned passengers of buses and coaches. Inspections were also planned for railway traffic in borderland areas. Starting March 13, all passengers flying into Poland had to undergo border checks involving measurement of body temperature. During the night of the 13-14 March, Poland also introduced full checks on its border crossings with Schengen zone until the 24 of March. Restrictions on border traffic between Poland and Russia, Poland and Ukraine and Poland and Belarus were introduced until further notice. Right to enter the country has been limited to Polish citizens and some foreign citizens, including spouses and dependants of Polish citizens, foreign citizens with temporary and permanent residence permits and work permits. On April 9, the government also suspended international passenger air traffic and international railway traffic. On May 4, the government lifted the compulsory 14-day quarantine for citizens crossing the border with neighbouring EU countries for professional, business and learning purposes. All other restrictions and bans remained in place. On May 13, border controls with other EU states were extended until June 12. Controls were also extended for seaports and airports. On June 13, Poland restored full border traffic with EU member states. As a result, Poles returning from abroad are no longer placed under 14-day quarantine. Border checks are still performed at random, like before the lockdown. On June 16, international flights resumed. However, Poles were still not able to travel freely to all countries. Poland was still not included on the list of safe countries in Slovenia, Slovakia or Austria. On July 1st, travelling within the EU borders became possible again. The EU re-opened its borders to 15 non-EU countries. The list of non-EU countries will be updated every two weeks.
column16: On March 10, the Prime Minister announced that the decision of school closures was left to local governments. On March 12, the Prime Minister finally announced that all nurseries, kindergartens, schools and higher education institutions would remain closed for two weeks starting from Monday 16 of March. On March 16, the Ministry of Education published a guide for organising online classes, but those remained voluntary since there was no regulations to enforce it. The grading of online classes was not regulated either. On March 20, the President announced that schools closure would be extended until Easter. On April 8, the government announced that schools would remain closed until May. On April 9, the government announced that final and junior high-school exams would be rescheduled. On May 6, nurseries and preschools were allowed to reopen again. On May 25, the youngest children (grades 1-3) were able to go back to schools and teachers started to organise consultations for eighth-graders and A-level pupils. At the same time the child care allowance was kept, so that parents could choose whether to send their kids to school or not.
column18: On March 8, the Chief Sanitary Inspector recommended to put on hold any public gatherings of more than 1,000 people due to the threat of transmission of the novel coronavirus. On March 10, all mass events were cancelled, including large sports events. On March 12, Culture Minister Piotr Glinski informed that cultural institutions such as theatres, museums and cinemas would close for two weeks.On March 24, the Prime Minister announced strict lockdown measures that considerably restricted people's movement and gatherings. Gatherings of three or more persons became prohibited unless they are family members. The maximum number of persons taking part in religious ceremonies and funerals was cut to five. For means of public transportation, the limit of passengers was defined at half of seats. The lockdown was expected to remain in force until 11 April. On April 9, the government announced that the strict lockdown measures were prolonged. On May 4, the first measures to ease the lockdown came into force: shopping centres, hotels and other accommodation facilities were allowed to reopen. The number of customers in such centres was limited to one customer per 15 square metres and social distancing rules still applied. Restaurants and other type of businesses (e.g. fitness clubs, hair and beauty salons, cinemas and travel agents) remained closed. On May 6, cultural institutions (libraries, museums, art galleries) and physiotherapy centres were allowed to reopen. On March 18, lockdown measures were eased again. Restaurants, hairdresser's, and beauty parlours were allowed to open under a strict a sanitary regime. So did open-air cinemas, art schools and recording studios. The permitted number of people on football pitches and in stadiums was increased and it became possible to organise sport activities indoors. More travellers (30% of the maximum number) were allowed aboard public transport. On May 22, the Presidential election, originally planned for May 10, was rescheduled to June 28. On May 30, lockdown measures were eased again. Wearing face masks in public spaces was no longer mandatory if maintaining two metre distance is possible. Wearing masks was still be obligatory in shops, churches, cinemas, on public transport and during social interaction at distances shorter than two metres. The limit on the number of customers entering shops, restaurants and bars was also abolished. However, in small retail and catering premises customers still had to wear face masks. Similar rules applied to churches. Public gatherings of up to 150 persons were permitted again. Participants were required to maintain two metre distance from each other or wear masks.
column20: On March 8, the President signed a bill allowing the suspension of the public procurement law and construction law in extraordinary situations related to the spread of the virus. On March 12, Culture Minister Piotr Glinski informed that cultural institutions such as theatres, museums and cinemas would close for two weeks. On March 24, strict lockdown measures were implemented. The maximum number of persons taking part in religious ceremonies and funerals was cut to five. For means of public transportation, the limit of passengers was defined at half of seats. Shopping malls and restaurants were closed. Shopping activities were severely limited since people were only allowed to go out to buy food and medicine, go to work, consult a physician or walk their pets. On 31 March, the lockdown measures were tightened further, notably by closing hotels, temporary accommodation services, hairdressers and public parks, by reducing the number of allowed customers in shops, and by dedicating specific hours for the shopping of older persons. Wearing protective gloves became mandatory for all customers in shops. A ban on operations of home improvement retailers on weekends was introduced. Persons below 18 years old were not allowed go out unless accompanied by an adult. Pedestrians had to keep at least 2-metres distance from each other, even when walking together. On May 4, the first measures to ease the lockdown came into force: shopping centres, hotels and other accommodation facilities were allowed to reopen. The number of customers in such centres was limited to one customer per 15 square metres and social distancing rules still applied. Restaurants and other type of businesses (e.g. fitness clubs, hair and beauty salons, cinemas and travel agents) remained closed. On May 6, cultural institutions (libraries, museums, art galleries) and physiotherapy centres were allowed to reopen. On March 18, lockdown measures were eased again. Restaurants, hairdresser's, and beauty parlours were allowed to open under a strict a sanitary regime. So did open-air cinemas, art schools and recording studios. The permitted number of people on football pitches and in stadiums was increased and it became possible to organise sport activities indoors. More travellers (30% of the maximum number) were allowed aboard public transport. On May 30, lockdown measures were eased again. Wearing face masks in public spaces was no longer mandatory if maintaining two metre distance is possible. Wearing masks was still be obligatory in shops, churches, cinemas, on public transport and during social interaction at distances shorter than two metres. The limit on the number of customers entering shops, restaurants and bars was also abolished. However, in small retail and catering premises customers still had to wear face masks. Similar rules applied to churches. Public gatherings of up to 150 persons were permitted again. Participants were required to maintain two metre distance from each other or wear masks. On June 8, the government  decided in favour of a temporary suspension of production in two of JSW's coal mines and 10 mines owned by PGG, citing a rise in the number of new coronavirus infections among miners. Miners received 100 percent of downtime pay.
column22: On March 8, the President signed a bill on extraordinary measures to contain the spread of coronavirus. Measures included the attribution of care allowance for parents whose children would be affected by closures of nurseries and schools. On March 11, a support fund of PLN 1 billion was announced for firms whose revenues would shrink by at least 15 percent due to the coronavirus outbreak. On March 12, the Prime Minister announcd that PLN 470 million from reserves had been allocated to fight the coronavirus. On March 19, the government passed a fiscal package, including the establishment of a public infrastructure investment fund, with approximately PLN 67 billion (3 percent of GDP) from the state budget, in addition to PLN 75 billion (3.2 percent of GDP) in guarantees and micro loans for firms and entrepreneurs (up to the amount of PLN 5,000). On April 8, the government announced an extension of its anti-crisis package. The cost of that expansion was estimated at nearly PLN 18.5 billion, including PLN 11.5 billion in new spending and PLN 6.9 billion in revenue losses. On June 24, the fourth extension of the anti-crisis package was signed by the president. The legislation states that entrepreneurs who received micro-loans of PLN 5,000 will not have to reimburse them if the company operates for 3 months after receiving it. The new legislation introduces subsidies to interest on loans for firms put in a difficult position by the pandemic. The new regulation is also supposed to prevent hostile takeovers of Polish companies by foreign enterprises from the outside of the EU, with such transactions to be audited by the Office for Competition and Consumer Protection (UOKiK). Furthermore, local governments will be allowed to have higher debts in order to counteract the pandemic. Richer local governments will be exempt from paying the Robin Hood tax in June and July. The extension of the anti-crisis package also introduces regulations on credit holidays, allowing people to suspend repayment for up to three months. On July 20, the government launched a PLN-500-worth tourist voucher programme to support the tourism industry. Vouchers, entitled to all families with at least one children, will be valid until March 2022 and can be used to pay for accommodation, agritourism, summer camps, among others, provided they are located in Poland.
column25: On March 8, the authorities unlocked 23.3 million EUR (98 million PLN) additional funding for hospitals. In cases when patients' health was at risk, qualified pharmacists were allowed to issue prescriptions for pharmaceuticals directly. On March 13, 19 hospitals in Poland were transformed into dedicated centres for patients infected with coronavirus. On March 19, the Government announced an additional 7,5 billion PLN package for the health sector. On April 8, the government announced that further investments would be made in the health care sector, drawing from available EU Funds. Poland dedicated PLN 550 million from the Infrastructure and Development Programme for the purchase of health care equipment. Extra funds for personal protection equipment were also made available to rescue services, fire services, police and the railway sector.
column28: On March 8, the President signed a bill on extraordinary measures to contain the spread of coronavirus. Measures included the attribution of care allowance for parents whose children would be affected by closures of nurseries and schools. On March 11, the President promised additional reliefs for people having financial problems because of the coronavirus, possibly through loan rescheduling. On March 19, the government announced the details of its rescue package. The government commited to subsidise the employees' salaries, for firms meeting some criteria related to recorded losses and fall in turnover, by up to 40% of the average wage. Employers had to pay the same share of the employees' salaries, and employees had to agree to decrease their salaries by one fifth. The subsidy was provided under the condition that benefiting firms would not dismiss any employee. The government also subsidised the income of the self-employed, service employees, sole traders or those employed on the basis of a contract of mandate or contract for specific work, among other forms of temporary and atypical employment contracts, by up to 80% of the statutory minimum wage. Such subsidy was exempted from social security contributions and taxes. To be eligible, individuals would have to prove that they experienced a significant drop in activity at least 30 days prior to the application for the benefit, that their revenues in the preceding month was 300-percent lower than their average monthly gross pay, that their revenue dropped by at least 15 percent compared to the previous calendar month, and that they started their economic activity prior to March 1st this year and have not suspended it since. On April 8, as part of the extension of the anti-crisis package, the government announced that the above subsidy for self-employed and atypical workers, originally planned as a one-off payment, could be demanded three times. The government also announced that farmers would obtain a benefit of 50 percent the statutory minimum wage if they could not work due to the coronavirus. After the mandated closure of mines on June 8, miners received 100 percent of downtime pay. On June 22, the government introduced a solidarity benefit of PLN 1,400 per month for people who lost their jobs after 15 March 2020. The subsidy can be received for up to three months. On July 20, the government launched a PLN-500-worth tourist voucher programme to support the tourism industry. Vouchers, entitled to all families with at least one children, will be valid until March 2022 and can be used to pay for accommodation, agritourism, summer camps, among others, provided they are located in Poland.
column31: On March 19, the government announced the details of its rescue package. It included the deduction of 2020's losses for firms' and self-employed 2021 tax settlement. On June 24, the fourth ammendment to the anti-crisis package was signed by the president. Richer local governments will be exempt from paying the Robin Hood tax in June and July 2020. On July 1st, the government announced that payers of PIT, CIT, VAT and excise duties may benefit from prolonged deadlines in the payment of these taxes. Local authorities were also allowed to defer the payment of property tax instalments.
column34: On March 11, a support fund of PLN1bn was announced for firms whose revenues would shrink by at least 15 percent due to the coronavirus outbreak. On March 19, the government announced the details of its rescue package. The government commited to subsidise the employees' salaries, for firms meeting some criteria related to recorded losses and fall in turnover, by up to 40% of the average wage. Employers had to pay the same share of the employees' salaries, and employees had to agree to decrease their salaries by one fifth. The subsidy was provided under the condition that benefiting firms would not dismiss any employee. The government also subsidised the income of the self-employed, service employees, sole traders or those employed on the basis of a contract of mandate or contract for specific work, among other forms of temporary and atypical employment contracts, by up to 80% of the statutory minimum wage. Such subsidy was exempted from social security contributions and taxes. To be eligible, individuals would have to prove that they experienced a significant drop in activity at least 30 days prior to the application for the benefit, that their revenues in the preceding month was 300-percent lower than their average monthly gross pay, that their revenue dropped by at least 15 percent compared to the previous calendar month, and that they started their economic activity prior to March 1st this year and have not suspended it since. On April 8, as part of the extension of the anti-crisis package, the government announced that the above subsidy for self-employed and atypical workers, originally planned as a one-off payment, could be demanded three times. The government also announced that farmers would obtain a benefit of 50 percent the statutory minimum wage if they could not work due to the coronavirus. The government also announced an unprecedented loan scheme worth PLN 100 billion. The funds were made available directly to enterprises in the form of loans to help them maintain liquidity and protect jobs. PLN75bn were offered to SMEs, while PLN25bn were made available to large enterprises which pay taxes in Poland. In order to apply for the funds, firms were required to show a 25 percent drop in their revenues. Micro-firms could apply for loans up to PLN324,000, small and medium companies could receive up to PLN3.5m, while large enterprises could be granted up to PLN1bn. The loans were awarded for three years, with zero interests, and repayments will start in the second year. Up to 75 percent of the value of the loans can be disbursed in the form of grants, provided firms keep their employees during the entire loan period. On June 24, the fourth extension of the anti-crisis package was signed by the president. The new regulation states that entrepreneurs who received micro-loans of PLN 5,000 will not have to reimburse them if the company operates for 3 months after receiving it. The new legislation also introduces subsidies to interest on loans for firms put in a difficult position by the pandemic.
column37: On March 11, the government announced the details of its rescue package. It included the postponement of social contributions and the possible deferral, cancellation or payment in installments for taxes. Self-employed and micro-firms who experienced at least a 50-percent drop in revenues since February were eligible for exemption from payment of social insurance premiums for three months, provided that their revenues in March did not exceed 300 percent of the average pay. The budget cost of this remittal is estimated at PLN 14bn. On April 8, as part of the extension for the anti-crisis package, firms with between 10 and 49 employees were also allowed to seek the cancellation of their social security contributions for three months. On May 4, the Sejm passed third revision to the anti-crisis package. The bill provided for wider availability of social insurance contribution remittal for self-employed persons.
column40: From April 1st onwards and under the anti-crisis legislation, investments and financing on preferential conditions by the Polish Development Fund (PFR) were facilitated. The Fund had the possibility of investing in subscription warrants, shares, bonds and credits. Companies in financial trouble could ask for PFR to purchase their shares in order to increase their capital base. However, PFR committed not to take over companies. The aim was to make it a support programme and not to use the difficult condition of firms for acquisitions. On April 8, as part of the government's extension to the anti-crisis package, the government announced an unprecedented loan scheme worth PLN 100 billion. The funds were made available directly to enterprises in the form of loans to help them maintain liquidity and protect jobs. PLN75bn were offered to SMEs, while PLN25bn were made available to large enterprises which pay taxes in Poland. In order to apply for the funds, firms were required to show a 25 percent drop in their revenues. Micro-firms could apply for loans up to PLN324,000, small and medium companies could receive up to PLN3.5m, while large enterprises could be granted up to PLN1bn. The loans were awarded for three years, with zero interests, and repayments will start in the second year. Up to 75 percent of the value of the loans can be disbursed in the form of grants, provided firms keep their employees during the entire loan period. The government also announced that further capital injections would be financed by drawing on available EU Funds: PLN 500 million from the Eastern Poland programme were dedicated to provide working capital to enterprises in the Lubelskie, Podkarpackie, Podlaskie, Swietokrzyskie and Warminsko-Mazurskie provinces.
column43: On March 19, the government announced the details of its rescue package, which included PLN 75 billion in government liquidity support to firms, including micro firms. The State Development Bank (BGK) also increased its loan guarantees for private-sector firms by PLN 22 billion. The State Development Bank (BGK) will guarantee loans and current investments of medium sized and big companies to ensure their liquidity. These public guarantees will be extended until the end of 2020 and will cover a maximum period of 2 years. The fees and interest rates are not to exceed the limits set in the temporary state aid framework. On April 28, the government announced that Poland had tapped into PLN 400 million in funds from the EU to be used for the anti-crisis loan fund for companies. The plan is being carried out in cooperation with state-controlled development bank BGK.
column46: On March 17, the National Bank of Poland (NBP) reduced its policy interest rate 50 bps to 1%, its lombard rate by 100bps to 1.5%, while the deposit rate was left unchanged at 0.5%. Regarding non-conventional monetary policy, the NBP re-introduced repo operations to provide liquidity to the banking sector and announced the purchase of Polish Treasury securities in the secondary market in the value of PLN 8.3 billion (0.4 percent of GDP). The NBP also announced the introduction of a program to provide funding for bank lending to the non-financial private enterprises (similar to the ECB's TLTRO). On March 19, the NBP announced an additional PLN 70 billion package in liquidity support for private sector firms. On April 8, the Monetary Policy Council (RPP) reduced interest rates again by 50 base points. The reference rate was set to 0.5 percent per annum; the Lombard rate was set at 1 percent per annum; deposit rate at 0 percent per annum; the promissory note rediscount rate to 0.55 percent per annum; and the promissory note discount rate at 0.6 percent per annum. These interest rates are the lowest in history. The National Bank of Poland (NBP) reiterated its comittment to supply the banking sector with liquidity through repo transactions. On April 28, the Polish Development Fund (PFR) managed to raise PLN 16.3 billion via the issue of “coronavirus bonds” to finance the government's rescue package. The four-year bonds with a 1.375 percent coupon rate were oversubscribed. The bonds are guaranteed by the State Treasury and were all claimed by banks. The government initially wanted the NBP to directly purchase the bonds, but that would be against Polish and EU regulations. The NBP may still buy the bonds from the subscribing banks in the secondary market. On May 11, the Polish Development Fund (PFR) issued five-year bonds worth PLN18.5bn, as part of the bond issuance programme with the total value up to PLN100bn. The bonds have the interest rate of 1.625 percent per annum and their term of maturity is 31 March 2025. The nominal value of a single bond is PLN1m and the issue price is PLN995,870. On May 28, the Monetary Policy Council (RPP) decided to reduce most interest rates. The reference rate was cut from 0.5 to 0.1 percent per annum, which is the lowest value it has ever reached. The lombard rate was reduced from 1 to 0.5 percent, whereas the rediscount rate was slashed from 0.55 to 0.11 percent, and the discount rate on bills of exchange was capped from 0.6 to 0.12 percent. The deposit rate remained at 0 percent per annum.
column47:
On March 17, the National Bank of Poland (NBP) lowered the reserve requirement from 3.5% to 0.5%, while raising the interest on mandatory reserves from 0.5% to 1%. The Ministry of Finance, following the recommendation by the Financial Stability Committee, repealed the 3 percent systemic risk buffer for bank capital requirements. The Polish Financial Supervisory Authority (PFSA) also announced a package of measures (SSP
- Supervisory Stimulus Package) related to provisions and the reclassification of loans to existing SMEs/micro enterprises. This included measures to enable the smoothing of credit losses over a longer period, to allow some flexibility in how banks meet capital requirements, and more flexible bank liquidity requirements. The PFSA also announced a flexible approach to valuation under Solvency II for the insurance sector. Additionally, the Polish Banking Association recommended the voluntary deferral of loan repayments for affected borrowers for up to three months.
column48: On March 17, the head of the Association of Polish Banks (ZBP) announced that in the face of the coronavirus pandemic, banks operating in Poland would make it possible for clients to take a three-month mortgage payment holiday, with possibility of further extension if needed. Applications for postponed payment were free of charge and involved minimum procedures. This solution was available to both companies and individual customers with mortgages and cash loans. On June 24, the President signed the fourth extension to the anti-crisis package. The extension of the anti-crisis package introduces regulations on credit holidays, allowing people to suspend repayment for up to three months.
column51: On March 17, the head of the Association of Polish Banks (ZBP) announced that in the face of the coronavirus pandemic, banks operating in Poland would make it possible for clients to take a three-month mortgage payment holiday, with possibility of further extension if needed. Applications for postponed payment were free of charge and involved minimum procedures. This solution was available to both companies and individual customers with mortgages and cash loans.
column54:
On March 19, the government announced that the introduction of the tax on retail sales turnover, planned for 2020, would be postponed until the end of the year. On April 9, additional measures in support of farming activities were introduced: funds allocated for the promotion of agri-food products could finally be used for market-recovery measures; flexible working hours for farmers; prolongation of expired visas and residence permits of migrant workers in the agrifood sector
- they became able to stay in Poland up to 30 days after the epidemic measures were lifted. On May 4, the Sejm approved the third revision of the anti-crisis package. Among the new measures: VoD platforms shall pay a new levy, set at 1.5 percent of their revenues; hiring foreigners is to be easier, as work permits shall be prolonged automatically during the pandemic; the capital of the Industrial Development Agency shall be raised by PLN900m; railway and road passenger carriers shall be offered compensations, if they provide public service; and finally, the list of administrative procedures that can be handled online shall be expanded. On May 6, the Climate ministry announced that the government was willing to delay some requirements concerning the development of electric car charging stations, which were included in the bill on electro mobility and alternative fuels. On May 15, the government announced that two important reforms of the pension insurance system
- the extension of the Employee Capital Plans (PPK) scheme onto new groups of enterprises and the abolition of open pension funds (OFE)
- would be delayed due to the coronavirus pandemic. On May 18, the PM Mateusz Morawiecki announced that the monthly unemployment benefit would be increased from the current level of PLN860 to PLN1,200 and PLN942.3 after 3 months. Moreover, he added that there would be another temporary benefit for 3 months at the level of PLN1,300. On May 27, the Polish government adopted a draft amendment of the Public Finance Act which enables suspension of application of the stabilising spending rule during the time of the epidemic. The measure enables Poland to provide additional financial support to the economy if necessary. The spending rule will be reintroduced in the next two to four years. Without these modifications, the expenses incurred as a result of the adoption of the anti-crisis shield would have had to be compensated by means of restricting other expenses within bodies subject to the spending rule. On June 17, the PM Mateusz Morawiecki announced the introduction of the so-called Estonian CIT in Poland: enterprises with a turnover of up to PLN50m (97 percent of businesses operating in Poland) will be exempt from CIT as long as they refrain from paying dividends. This is to encourage enterprises to develop and invest. The PM hopes that the Estonian CIT will strengthen Polish capital but also attract foreign entrepreneurs to the country. On June 22, the government announced that the new VAT matrix would not be delayed any further and be implemented on July 1st.

column12:
Public containment has been implemented on the 19/03 after the announcement of the State of Emergency on the 18/03. It was extended on the 03/04 and again on the 16/04 and lasted until 2/5. From 4/5, confinement measures have been eased.

- General rules from 4/5: mandatory usage of masks in public transports, schools and closed spaces; and disinfectant gel. Regular sanitization of public spaces. Max capacity of 5 people/100m2 and 2/3 in public transports. Social distancing (2m). Prohibition of crowds (more than 10 people).

- On 4/5: keeping mandatory telework; conditioned access to beaches; funerals limited to family.

- Lifting confinement measures, on 4/5: small commerce; hairdressers, barber shops, beauticians; public services (assistance counters); dentists; auto stands; bookstores, libraries; individual sports; gardens.

- On 18/5: kindergartens (optional); 11/12 grads in high school; restaurants, cafés, pastries and esplanades (50% capacity limitation and other rules); camping; stores until 400m2; museums and monuments; social institutions.

- On 30/5: football (closed doors) and religious ceremonies.

- On 1/6: teleworking by shifts; kindergartens; administrative service centres (loja do cidadão); larger stores and malls (exception in Lisbon); cinemas, stage theatre, auditoria (following specific recommendations); restaurants with maximum capacity (idem); gyms (idem); teleworking. Specific restrictions apply to Lisbon.

- On 6/6: start of the bathing season (beaches and swimming pools with specific rules).

- On 15/6: school recreational centres (not in school facilities); summer camps.

- On 23/6: prohibition of gatherings of more than 10 people restored in some municipalities in the Lisbon region

- On 25/06: the government approved the transition to a state of alert starting from 01/07 except for the Lisbon metropolitan area, in which more restrictions are imposed.
- On 01/07: A civic duty of home confinement is in place in 19 parishes in the Lisbon region. Public gatherings are limited to 10 persons in the Lisbon metropolitan area (5 in the 19 parishes under lockdown). Lisbon's partial reconfinement to control outbreaks of the new coronavirus was extended until at least the end of July.

- COVID-19 contact tracing apps (CovidApp in 11 countries), including one for Portugal (StayAway) in June.
column14:
Border control with Spain through mutual agreement started on 17/3and ended on 01/07. Suspended air, rail and river connections until 14/05.
-Movement of goods and authorized persons at only 9 border points, including nationals and residents returning home, family reunion and cases of access to health units in bilateral health care agreements. Boat traffic on both Minho and Guadiana rivers and train traffic is only allowed for circulation of goods.

- Flights to and from Italy are also suspended from 11/04 until 06/05.

- Suspension of flights from/to extra-EU on 19th of March. Exceptions: flights to countries with strong presence of PT communities (CA, US, UK, ZA), with all PT-speaking countries, EEA (NO, IS, LI, CH).

- Restrictions eased on 01/07 with flights allowed to and from European Union, Schengen Area, the United Kingdom, Algeria, Canada, South Korea, Morocco, Tunisia and China.

- 14-day isolation period for all passengers on flights to the Azores and Madeira, since 14/03.

- Temperature control sensors in airports (Lisbon, Porto, Faro, Madeira, Ponta Delgada), 20/03.

- COVID-19 support telephone line for consular emergencies (Portuguese abroad), 13/03.
column16:
Suspension of all face-to-face school activities (teaching and non-teaching) from 16/03. It was re-assessed on 9/4: 1) classes restarted on 14/04 for high school exam-takers (exam period 6-23 July) while distance teaching remains at place for primary schools.

- TV-schooling for primary level education through RTP Memória, starting on 20/4.

- Establishment of exceptional and temporary measures regarding the organization of the school year 2020/2021, 20/7.

- Schools are expected to operate fully by mid-September
column18:
Closure of all national monuments and places of cultural activities (both public and private).
Suspension of religious and cult celebrations.
On 04/05, the practice of individual sports in the open air is authorized
On 04/05, libraries and zoos can open
On 18/05, museums and art galleries can open

- On 31/7: bars & clubs can open but with restrictions.
column20:
Closure of non-essential shops (i.e. nightclubs, bars, and restaurants) is progressively eased.

- On 04/05 small commerce; hairdressers, barber shops, beauticians; public services (assistance counters); dentists; auto stands; bookstores, libraries; individual sports; gardens, zoos, oceanariums and the like can open, maximum 2 occupied seats per taxi/ridesharing vehicle from and maximum of 2/3 passenger capacity for airplanes (exceptions for repatriations) from 4/5

- On 18/5: restaurants, cafés, pastries and esplanades (50% capacity limitation and other rules); camping; stores until 400m2; museums and monuments; social institutions.

- On 30/5: football (closed doors).

- On 1/6: larger stores and malls (exception in Lisbon); cinemas, stage theatre, auditoria (following specific recommendations); restaurants with maximum capacity (idem); gyms (idem)

- On 23/6: shops and other commercial establishments (except restaurants) close at 8 pm in some municipalities in the Lisbon Metropolitan area.
column22: On March 13th, the government announced a package of measures, including an initially 200 million EUR credit line to support firms' liquidity (which increased to 400 million EUR by 02/04), a 60 million EUR credit line to support micro-companies in the tourism sector, and the deferral on fulfilment of fiscal obligations and reporting requirements regarding CIT and payment on account, additional payment on account and special payment on account. As of 20/04, a €13 billion liquidity scheme, approved by European Commission, is available to provide direct grants and public guarantee loans to companies. Key fiscal measures include: i) €600 million per month (0.5% GDP) in financial support for those temporarily furloughed by their employer followed by additional support once businesses reopen (over €700 million); ii)  €13 billion (6.8% of GDP) of state-guaranteed credit lines for medium, small and micro enterprises in affected sectors, operated through the banking system (initially €3 billion)  iii) €7.9 billion (3.7% GDP) of (within-year) tax and social security contribution deferrals for companies and employees.
column25:
On March 12th, the authorities unlocked 296 million EUR to increase the capacity of the health sector. Other health-related measures include: a) suspension of overtime limits; b) simplifying the hiring of workers; c) worker mobility; d) hiring retired doctors without being subject to age limits.

- Exceptional regime for public procurement and expenditures in the health sector, allowing swifter procedures and more transparency in public spending (including ventilators, protective equipment, diagnostic support material).

- Special protection regime for professionals in the health sector directly involved in the diagnosis and specialized laboratory response. Exceptional regime for composition of medical boards to assess needs of people with disabilities. Special duty of protection to risk group (+70 year-old / severe disease) with call for limited mobility.

- Mandatory curfew to all tested positive or in active surveillance (in hospital, or at home).

- General call to avoid unnecessary displacements and to promote social distancing.

- National Contingency and Response Plan for Disease.

- Extensive testing implemented across the country, and proactive tracing of potential positives.

- Specific programme for nursing homes testing since 30/3. Two new diagnostic centres have been established since 30/3.

- Measures to support mental health and tackle domestic violence including public campaigns, support lines and extension of two more emergency facilities.

- Research 4 COVID-19: support to innovative solutions of rapid implementation in the NHS in response to the pandemic (1.5 million EUR).

- AI 4 COVID: Data Science and Artificial Intelligence in Public Administration (3 million EUR).

- Science 4 COVID-19 platform launched on 4/4, with ideas, publications and initiatives from the scientific community for cooperative work to tackle COVID-19.

- University labs developing prototypes for test kits and innovation centres developing ventilators and textile equipment to cope with country's needs and capacitate the industry

- The Portuguese government has been developing three areas of action, the commitment with the Joint Procurement Agreements developed by the European Commission, the purchase of protective equiment on international markets and the use of the national capacity and availability in production of protective equipment and medical equipment to support the breathing of patients.

- Immunity testing plan involving 17 hospitals nationwide by the National Health Institute on 13/5

- VAT and customs duties on vital medical equipment has been waived (protective equipment, testing kits or medical devices such as ventilators) and lasts until 31/7.

- Reduced VAT rate on masks and disinfectant gel from 22/4 onwards.

- Simplified temporary system of industrial licensing, applicable to changes in industrial establishments, for the manufacture of medical devices, personal protective equipment, ethyl alcohol and disinfectant biocidal products from 15/07 onwards
column28:
-'“Temporary lay-off scheme” for firms with activity severely affected by the epidemic. Severely affected firms are those who show a decline in turnover of 40% compared to the previous three months or those that started their business less than 12 months ago. Workers will receive 2/3 of their gross income, up to 1905€ per month. Firms pay 30% of that sum while the social security pays the remaining 70%. This can last up to 6 months maximum. The social security is fully covering the costs of workers who are under a 14 days quarantine, i.e. exempting companies from paying salaries.

- Parents who need to stay home to take care of their kids (up to 12 years old) and who cannot telework cannot be laid-off for unjustified leave but will receive 2/3 of their salary during that period. These 2/3 of salary will be paid half-half by the employer and the social security. Thus, the employer pays 1/3, the social security pays 1/3, and the individual pays 1/3.

- Justified absences scheme for families.

- Training subsidy of 50% of prior earnings, up to minimum wage, plus the cost of training, for workers without occupation as a result of the Covid-19 crisis.

- The equivalent of 14 days sick absence leave for workers who have to self-isolate or isolate their children or grandchildren, as a prophylactic measure with 100% renumeration.

- Extraordinary extension of unemployment benefits and all benefits of the Social Security system which lasts until the end of containment measures.

- Extraordinary support to maintain jobs after the end of lay-off or closure of the establishment by Health Authority (first-month wages supported, up to limit of one min wage per worker).

- Companies are exempted from Social Security contributions in lay-off or closure determined by the Health Authority, as well as on the first month after the resumption of activity.

- Social benefits for those supporting social and health entities (re-insertion social programmes).

- Reinforced powers of Authority for Labour Conditions (ACT) to act against irregular dismissals.

- Suspension of social security lien foreclosures for 3 months.

- Emergency support financing to artists and cultural entities most affected (€1 million).

- Temperature control allowed in workplace (safeguarding data protection) from 1/5.

- Health Authority guidelines for restaurants reopening from 8/5, amongst other prevention areas.

- Clean and safe stamp for tourism companies and restaurants complying with health measures from 5/5.

- From 01/08 onwards, a new simplified layoff scheme is at place. This is aimed for companies that are not yet able to return to normality but whose activity is no longer suspended due to legal imposition imposed by Ministry of Health. Companies have the choice between an one-off support (paid at once) in the amount of 635 euros, per worker removed from the simplified working scheme or in the form of a support amounting to 1,270 euros, per employee paid in a phased manner over six months. As in the simplified lay-off, employers who adhere to this incentive cannot terminate employment contracts by collective dismissal. Employers can end contract with individuals but are required to make new hires within 30 days in order to restore the level of employment.
column31: Information not available
column34: Information not available
column37:
Postponing the payments of social security contributions and taxes, granting guaranteed treasury loans of 400 million EUR for SMEs, 60 million for micro enterprises in the tourism sector and encouraging the use of short-time work schemes (by shortening procedures and a higher public coverage of firms' costs).
-Flexible tax payments for companies and the self-employed from Q2 2020 onwards, regarding VAT payments, PIT and CIT which looks as follows: 1) payment in three instalments with no late payment interest being charged; or 2) payment in six instalments with late payment interest being due only over the last three instalments. Automatic eligibility for all companies regarding CIT. The VAT is applicable to self-employed workers and companies with turnover up to €10M in 2018 or starting on January 1, 2019, companies and SMEs having closed by decision of the Health Authority, and companies and SMEs whose turnover decreases more than 20%.

- For self-employed and companies with a turnover of up to EUR 10 million in fiscal year 2018 or that have started the activity after 1 January 2019, it will be possible to defer the withholding tax payment.

- Extraordinary support to maintain jobs after the end of lay-off. Companies that are closed or whose activity is reduced by the Health authorities are exempt from social security contributions, as well as on the first month after the resumption of activity. Reduction of social contributions on Q2 2020 to 1/3; deferral of remainder 2/3 to Q3 2020 (fractional payments) for firms with up to 50 employees. Larger companies are eligible if they have seen a drop in turnover of 20% or more and operating in tourism sector, civil aviation or others closed to the public.

- Suspension of tax or contributory enforcement proceedings for 3 months
column40: Information not available
column43:
13 billion state-backed credit guarantees are provided by firms in total out of which:

- €400 million are direct state guaranteed credit support to companies that are most affected: (increased from initially €200 million): microenterprises in the tourism sector (€60 million) and companies operating in the social economy sector (€165 million),

- State guaranteed credit through the banking system (6.2 billion): for restaurants (€600 million, €270 million for SMEs), travel agencies (€200 million), tourism accommodation (€900 million, €300 million for SME), industry (€ 4.5 billion), fishing and aquiculture sectors (€20 million).

- Increased ceilings for export credit insurance schemes for metallurgic, mould, metal and mechanical industries (€100 million), construction abroad (€100 million), short-term exports (€50 million).

- Suspension of termination of rental contracts and possible moratorium in case of income loss.

- Suspension of termination of essential services (water, electricity, natural gas, telecom).

- €25 million fiscal package to support the entrepreneurship ecosystem

- Review of the Internationalization 2030 programme to foster exports and FDI from 7/5 onwards.
column46: Information not available
column47:
The Portuguese government has approved a six-month moratorium on bank loan repayments for families and companies affected by the coronavirus outbreak. The Banco de Portugal (BdP) has relaxed some aspects of its macroprudential measures for consumer credit . In addition, BdP has announced a series of measures directed to less significant banks under its supervision, in line with the initiatives undertaken by the ECB and the EBA. These include the possibility to temporary operate below selected capital and liquidity requirements; a recommendation to restrict dividend distributions; extension of deadlines of some reporting obligations; and rescheduling of on-site inspections and the stress test exercise.

- New consumer credit (maturities up to 2 years), granted between 1/4-30/9 to mitigate households' temporary liquidity shortages will not have to comply with the DSTI ratio threshold and are exempted from the recommendation of regular principal and interest payments.

- BdP implemented EBA Guidelines on legislative and non-legislative moratoria on loan repayments, with conditions not to trigger default of obligor and assessment of distressed restructuring.

- Exceptional regime for insurance contracts (flexible payments, adapted premia to de-risking) from 7/5 onwards
column48:
On 26th of March, the Portuguese government announced that people who are repaying a housing loan/mortgage can delay their repayments until September 30 2020 without consequences.
-The Lisbon Town Hall is suspending the payment of all social housing rents until 30 June 2020. After that, households will have 18 months to repay the rents that were suspended progressively, without any penalty or interest being charged.

- On 15th of April, the government implemented the rent repayment scheme. Households with a 20% drop in income and rents more than 35% of income can apply for an interest-free credit from the Housing and Urban Rehabilitation Institute to pay their rents. Landlords can also apply for that financial support if tenants stop paying their rent. For that, landlords need to show that they have lost 20% or more of their household income with the loss of rents. Landlords' income also needs to be lower than the minimum social income (438.91€). Landlords will also need to repay that loan as soon as tenants re-start paying the rent. Coordinated response to tackle needs of Roma population with Migrations Authority (ACM). Financial support to artists and entities most affected (€1 M). Reinforced to €1.7 M, 13/5.
column54: Information not available

column12: The state of emergency ended on 14 May and has been replaced by a state of alert. Lockdown measures have been progressively eased,but the state of alert was extended on 15 July due to a rise in cases. Since 15 June, Romanians who travel to or return from countries with a low number of new cases do not have to stay in quarantine or in self-isolation. Restrictions on public gatherings remain in place. Facial masks are mandatory in indoor public spaces, including public transports. Since 29 July, they are also compulsory in crowed outdoor public places at certain hours.
column14: Travel restrictions are progressively eased during the state of alert, but remain in place from and to high risk countries. International road and rail transport has resumed since 1 June. Borders are closed for non-EU foreign citizens and stateless persons (with exceptions, for instance for those transiting Romania over designated transit corridors).
column16: Schools and kindergartens have been closed on 11 March. Schools will remain closed until the end of the school year, except for students having national exams. Kindergartens and after-school activities have reopened since 15 June.
column18: Outdoor sports competitions without spectators and cultural events with the participation of up to 500 spectators wearing protective masks and with seats at a distance of minimum 2 meters are allowed since 1 June.
column20: Small shops, hairdressers, dental offices, and museums reopened on 15 May, outdoor restaurants and beaches on 1 June, shopping malls and gyms on 15 June, restaurants on 1 September. Bars and night clubs remain closed. Since 29 July, outdoor restaurants and gambling halls have to close between 11pm and 6 am.
column22:
Afiscal stimulus package has been announced on 18 March. New measures were introduced on 26 March, including tax deductions on the corporate income tax and VAT exemptions on imports of medical and sanitary devices that can be used to prevent, limit and combat COVID-19.
On 1 July, the government has released a National Plan of Investments and Economic Recovery, worth over EUR 100 billion. It mainly includes public investment in transport and energy infrastructure, health, and education.
column25:
On 6 April, the government endorsed some new support measures to be financed from European funds, including risk bonuses of EUR 500 per month for the medical staff in direct contact with the coronavirus (EUR 100 million), financial support to quarantine centers (EUR 30 million) and the purchase of medical and protective equipment (EUR 350 million).
Between 24 March and 15 May, the hospitalizations and consultations in outpatient structures of public and private hospitals that are not urgent have been suspended.
The budgets of the Ministry of Health and the Ministry of Internal Affairs have increased by RON 392 million and RON 100 million respectively. A loan of maximum RON 1.15 billion will be allocated to the state-owned company UNIFARM for the emergency purchase of sanitary equipment. A mobile hospital was built near Bucharest to accommodate potential COVID-19 patients and the ministry of Defence launched a recruitment campaign of medical staff.
column28:
The State finances 75% of the gross salary of employees in technical unemployment (up to 75% of the average gross wage) in firms affected by the outbreak, i.e. firms that either stopped their activity completely or partially due to the state of emergency and hold a certificate issued by the Ministry of Economy (available online as of April 2020) or have reduced their revenues by at least 25% (compared to the average level of Jan-Febr 2020).

One parent can receive paid leave (75% of the gross salary, up to 75% of the standard gross average salary) when a child's educational institution is temporarily shut down by authorities due to extreme circumstances (for children up to 12 years old or up to 18 years old for children with disabilities and when working from home is not possible).

Since 1 June, employers whose employees had their individual employment agreements suspended for at least 15 days and who received the technical unemployment allowance, can benefit, for a period of three months, of a wage subsidy amounting to 41.5% of the basic salary (up to 41.5% of the average gross earnings and conditionned to maintaining the employment relationship until 31 December 2020).

Employers hiring jobseekers over 50 or below 30 or Romanian citizens returning to the country after losing their jobs abroad, between 1 June and 31 December 2020, can receive a monthly allowance of 50% of the gross salary (up to RON 2500) during one year. This measure is condionned to maintaining the employment relationship for one additional year after the end of the hiring support measure.
column31: Bonus for the payment of the corporate income tax in April for all companies (reduction of 5% for large companies, 10% for medium businesses and microenterprises) and VAT exemptions on imports of medical and sanitary devices that can be used to prevent, limit and combat COVID-19 have been introduced on 26 March. The bonus was extended for payments due in July and October on 16 June.
column34: Information not available
column37:
The payment deadlines for local taxes (cars, building, land) have been postponed to end of June.
Interest and penalties on outstanding corporate tax debt will not be charged for companies paying debt principal arrears by 15 December.
The government also announced tax relief measures, including the acceleration of VAT refunds, the suspension of most tax audits and of foreclosures on overdue debtors, amendments of the tax debt restructuring programme and of the calculation of the corporate income tax base.
column40: Information not available
column43:
The State guarantee scheme has been expanded and subsidised interest rates for small and microenterprises will be temporarily allocated (up to RON 15 billion).
As of 10 April, EximBank, acting on behalf and for the account of the State, can provide short-term export credit insurance to cover the temporarily non-marketable risks of buyers from EU and OECD countries.
column46:
The National Bank of Romania cut policy rate by 0.25 percentage point on 2 June (from 2% to 1.75%) and on 6 August (to 1.5%). It maintained that it will continue injecting liquidity to the market and purchase local currency denominated government securities on the secondary market.
A first package of measures was announced on 20 March 20 (implemented on 23 March):

- cut in the policy rate by 0.50 percentage points (to 2%)

- cut in the lending (Lombard) facility rate by 1 percentage point (to 2.5%, the deposit facility rate is maintained at 1.5%).

- provision of liquidity to credit institutions through REPO operations (reversible securities transactions)

- purchase of government securities denominated in national currency on the secondary market
column47:
The EU regulatory framework will be applied in the prudential and accounting fields. Banks are allowed to use capital buffers and operate with lower liquidity ratio.
Credit institutions are allowed to temporarily reduce or suspend loan amortisation payments without applying the regulatory provisions on the level of indebtedness, the loan-to-value limit, and the maximum maturity of consumer credit.
column48: Loan payments can be suspended for 9 months for individuals and firms affected by the outbreak.
column51: SMEs obtaining an emergency certificate can benefit from an extension of the payment deadlines for utility services (electricity, natural gas, water, telephone and internet services) and rents.
column54: Information not available

column12: Further easing of restrictions, but sweeping fines for not wearing masks in closed buildings
column14: Self-isolation of arrivals no longer required
column16: Schools and universities reopen but many keep distance learning
column18: All gatherings of more than 50 people prohibited
column20: Resorts, sanatories
column22: Anti-crisis fund of 500bn roubles
column25: Measures of July 13 still in place
column28:
Sickness benefit increased to the level of the minimum wage. Unemployment benefits set at the maximum level (12,130 roubles/month) through July.
Child benefit of 3,000 rubles ($40) per month for each child in the family. Simplified/expedited procedures for payment of “maternal capital” and other benefits to families with children.
Automatic extension of social benefits and entitlements over the next six months
In Moscow, citizens above 55 receive additional sickness benefits (4000 roubles) if they self-isolate
column31: 13% tax on investment income above 1m roubles; permanent tax reduction for IT firms; tax exemption for medical and pharmaceutical products
column34: SMEs get a subsidy of 12'130 roubles per employee. Compensation for the tourism and aviation sector.
column37: Deferral of tax payments to firms in the most affected sectors. No insolvency/bankruptcy procedures until september for the most affected sectors
column40: Forgivable loans for all enterprises in affected industries to pay minimum wages for 6 months
column43: Loan guarantees can be provided to secure firms' loan agreements
column46: Key rate remains at 4,5%
column47: Banks may value securities at their price at March 1. FX operations can also be valued at the exchange rate of March 1, except for open forex positions. The Deposit Insurance Fund contribution will be reduced from 0.15 percent to 0.1 percent through end-2020. The Bank eased liquidity regulations for systemically important credit institutions.
column48: Price regulation: In the case of a 30% increase in drug prices within one month, the government can set a 90-day price ceiling
column51: In Moscow and other regions late payment of uitlity bills is not sanctioned.
column54: Forced eviction from residential premises for non-payment of rent is prohibited
column55: Information provided by Central Bank, Russia-OECD Center at Presidential Academy (RANEPA), Moscow Times, Wikipedia and other

column12:
*August 26: Amidst the growing number of cases of Covid-19, the Government has directed that curfew hours be brought ahead to start at 7 pm (instead of 9 pm) across the country. Movements are now prohibited from 7 pm to 5 am.
*July 20: the Ministry of Local Governments announced the lockdown of Tetero, Indamutsa, and Intiganda villages in Tetero cell, Muhima sector, Nyarugenge district. The lockdown will last for at least 15 days.

* July 14: the Ministry of Local Governments announced the lockdown of Kigeme cell in Gasaka sector and Ruhunga cell in Kibirizi sector in Nyamagabe district, and Mubuga, Butare, Gitwas, and Jarama cells in Gihombo sector in Nyamasheke district. The lockdown will last for at least 15 days.
*June 30: the Government of Rwanda announced that movements to and from Rubavu district may resume. Rusizi and parts of Kigali remain locked down.
*June 25: the Ministry of Local Governments announced the lockdown of Kamabuye, Zuba, Nyenyeri, and Rugano villages in Kicukiro district, and Kadobogo and Gisenga villages in Nyarugenge district. The lockdown will last for at least 15 days.
*May 1: From May 4th Rwanda eases lockdown measures by restricting movement only between 8:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m.
*April 2: Lockdown measures are extended until April 19.
*April 17: Lockdown measures extended until April 30.
*March 21: Lockdown of the country for an initial period of 2 weeks. Unnecessary movements and visits outside the home are not permitted. All employees shall work from home except for those providing essential resources.
column14:
* August 2: Rwanda National Police spokesperson, CP John Bosco Kabera, announced that effective August 3 all residents of Rwanda, going or coming from Kigali International Airport after 9 pm will be required to produce a movement clearance pass to present to Police officers enforcing the curfew. For outgoing passengers, the pass should be obtained by applying on a newly established online platform. For those arriving, their applications will be processed by hotels where they will be accommodated.
*July 27: Following the reopening of domestic tourism and international charter flights on 17 June, Rwanda Development Board has announced that commercial flights will be welcomed back into the East African country from 1 August and the protocol that passengers will have to follow. All travelers, including those in transit through Rwanda, will therefore be required to show proof of a negative COVID-19 test from a certified laboratory, taken within 72 hours of arriving in Rwanda. For passengers staying in Rwanda, a second test will be conducted upon arrival, with results delivered within 24 hours during which time travelers will be required to self-quarantine in designated accommodation. To facilitate their transit, the government has negotiated rates at a 17 city hotels where they will remain until their results are out at their own costs. Tests will be administered at $50 with an additional $10 medical service fee. Tests results will be relayed to guests via email or text message.
*July 6 Commercial flights are expected to resume on August 1, with a requirement for all passengers to test negative for COVID-19 within 72h prior to arrival and again upon arrival.
*June 16: Domestic and international tourism is permitted only for visitors traveling on charter flights. The Kigali Airport remains closed to commercial air traffic.Transport between provinces in permitted, except to and from Rusizi and Rubavu districts. Borders remain closed, except for cargo, goods and returning?Rwandans and?Rwandan permanent residents.?Members of both of these groups returning to the country are subject to a mandatory seven day quarantine at designated locations at their own expense.
*May 1: Borders will also remain closed except for cargo as well as returning Rwandans and legal citizens, who will be subject to a mandatory 14-day quarantine.
