The Industrial Development Corporation has put a package together with the Department of Trade, Industry and Competition of more than R3bn for industrial funding to address the situation of vulnerable firms and to fast-track financing for companies critical to the efforts to fight the virus and its economic impact.
column43:
A) A R200 billion loan guarantee scheme in partnership with the major banks, the National Treasury and the South African Reserve Bank will be introduced. This will assist enterprises with operational costs, such as salaries, rent and the payment of suppliers.
o The IDC facility to support companies to procure or manufacture personal protective equipment has been utilised in the past few weeks, with finance of R162 million approved to date.
o In the initial phase, companies with a turnover of less than R300 million a year will be eligible.
o It is expected that the scheme will support over 700,000 firms and more than 3 million employees through this difficult period.
3. The Department of Small Business Development is setting up two funds amounting to R500 million to help firms. The precise scope, size and sectors concerned are not finalised yet.
a. A Debt Relief Fund to help alleviate the economic impact of the coronavirus on small businesses in South Africa is due to come into operation on Tuesday 24 March 2020.
b. The Business Growth/Resilience Facility is being established to enable continued participation of SMMEs in supply value chains
- particularly those small businesses which manufacture locally or supply items which are in demand due to the pandemic. This facility will offer working capital, stock, bridging finance, order finance and equipment finance, and the amount provided will be based on the funding needs of the business.
column46:
On the 23rd of July the Reserve Bank decided to further cut the repurshasing rate by 25 basis points to 3.50%. ///On the 21st of May the Reserve Bank decided to further cut the repurshasing rate by 50 basis points to 3.75% // i. On the 14 of April, the Reserve Bank decided a further cut of 100 basis points to 4.25% of the repo rate. // ii. Monetary policy rates: On the 19th of March the Reserve Bank decided to cut the repo rate from 6.25 to 5.25%.
iii. liquidity injections: On March 20, the Reserve Bank announced three measures to ease money market liquidity:
1. Intraday Overnight Supplementary Repurchase Operations: The SARB will, through its Open Market Operations Desk, conduct Intraday Overnight Supplementary Repurchase Operations (IOSROs) to provide intraday liquidity support to clearing banks, except on Wednesdays, when the main repurchase transaction is conducted. IOSROs will be carried out through a fixed-rate auction with a pro-rata allotment, with an interest rate that is equal to the repurchase (repo) rate.
2. Weekly Main Refinancing Operations: The additional money market liquidity provided to clearing banks via the IOSROs will result in the current money market shortage (MMS) declining below the current target level of R56 billion. The size of the Main Refinancing Operations (MROs) will be kept at R56 billion and increased if necessary.
3. Standing Facilities: The Standing Facilities (SF) borrowing rate
- the rate at which the SARB absorbs liquidity
- will be adjusted to the repo rate less 200 basis points, from the current repo rate less 100 basis points. The SARB deems this change necessary in order to encourage the flow of money market liquidity. The SF lending rate
- the rate at which the SARB provides liquidity to the commercial banks
- will be adjusted lower to the repo rate, from the prevailing rate of the repo rate plus 100 basis points. This will support banks to facilitate their flow of money market liquidity without being penalised.
column47: 1) The liquidity coverage ratio (LCR) of banks has been reduced from 100% to 80% (Directive 1 of 2020); 2) Temporary capital relief is provided in a manner which still complies with international standards. The Regulations provide that banks shall have in place robust policies, processes and procedures to ensure that the bank continuously maintains, in addition to the base minimum capital requirement of eight per cent of risk weighted assets, a systemic risk capital requirement (Pillar 2A), an idiosyncratic risk capital requirement (Pillar 2b), a capital conservation buffer, a countercyclical buffer (CCyB) and a domestic systemically important bank (D-SIB) buffer. Both the CCyB and D-SIB buffers, when imposed, are an extension of the capital conservation buffer. The relief provided is that the Pillar 2A requirement is reduced to zero. South Africa has not implemented the countercyclical capital buffers as there has not been an excess aggregate credit extension thus banks are not required to maintain capital for systemic risk. Banks have built up a capital conservation buffer of 2.5 per cent stipulated in terms of Regulation 38(8)(e)(D) hence banks are permitted to draw down from this buffer in this period of financial distress. the relief in response to the Covid-19 pandemic for banks to extend credit in the real economy and not for banks to distribute dividends. The Pillar 2A capital requirement will be re-imposed on banks after the financial stress period as will be directed by the PA. (Directive 2 of 2020). 3) The PA issued Directive 3 of 2020, which signals approval of the actions taken by banks to assist borrowers. This includes selected short-term payment holidays and loan restructures. The PA is providing credit risk capital relief to banks. Loans had to be up to date on 29 February 2020 in order to qualify for the relief. Retail (which include residential mortgage advances, retail revolving credit, SME retail and retail other) and corporate (which include corporate, SME corporate and the various specialised lending asset classes) would be able to qualify. A)Prudential authority issued a proposal on March 26 effective from April 1st, which includes dropping minimum capital requirements and compulsory reserve funds for lenders, reducing the liquidity coverage ratio to 80% from 100% and relaxing accounting standards when determining potential losses.

column12:
No lockdown has been imposed on any city or region. Instead, the government urged citizens to comply with distance measures and encouraged employees to work from home.
On 22 March, the authorities started the strong distancing campaign for four weeks (e.g. staying at home and avoiding mass congregations).
On 20 April, the government started to phase out some stringent physical distancing measures while the basic distancing campaign was extended to 5 May.
On 6 May, Korea eased distancing measures and switched to 'everyday life quaranteine'.

Meanwhile, the government supported most infected region with special quarantine measure and public resources at the inital stage.
-The government designated Daegu and the neighbouring region as "special management zone" on 23 February and as “special disaster zones” to allow the release of subsidies on 15 March.
On 16 August, the authorities raised the Level Two of distancing guidlines in the greater Seoul area and raised on 22 August the Level Twoo around the country as a preemptive measure.
On 30 August, the government raised the Level to strengthened level 2, Leve 2.5 until 13 August leading to the shutdown of indoor sports facilities and to the reduced operation at restaurant, bars and cafes.
column14:
In early February Korea banned the entry of those coming from Wuhan city and Hubei provice, China. The country also has strengthened quarantine measures for entrants. The government, however, did not ban the entry of travellers from other countries except for the Hubei povince until now.
Since 19 March, special quarantine procedures have been applied to all travelers arriving in Korea. Quarantine measures include temperature checks, filing out health declarations at airports and downloading a self-check application to report any changes in health.
On 22 March, all arrivals for a long-term stay undergo a mandatory Covid-19 test. All entrants have a 14 days self-quarantine at home or government designated facilities.
On 1 April, Korea expanded the mandatory isolation policy to almost all entrants, including short-term stays.
On 5 April Korea enforced penalty to those people who violate the isolation measure with up to a year in prison or up to KRW 10 million (USD 8 000) in fines.
On 13 April, all Koreans and long-term travelers of a foreign nationality ariving from the US should get tested for the virus within the first three days regardless of any symtoms.
On 10 August, the government lifted entry restrictions on arrivals from the Chinese province of Hubei due to the no reported cases.
column16:
The new spring semester for schools and kindergartens, which were supposed to start on 2 March, has been postponed to 8 April.
From 9 April. The new academic year opened gradually with online class

- Middle and high school started online classes on 9 April or 16 April.

- Elementary schools was open online class on 20 April.

As the country eased social distancing on 6 May, schools reopened gradually from 20 May to 8 June.

Meanwhile, universities, which opened online class on 9 March, have extended to their non-face-to-face class to the end of spring semester.

On 25 August, the Education Ministry made announcemnt of online lerning in greater Seoul until 11 September amid virus resurgence. Most schools are originally scheduled to open from the 26 August in phases.
column18:
On 22 March, the government urged people to avoid religious meetings, indoor sports and entertainment facilities.
On 20 April, the government decided to permit religious meetings and some social activities as far as people abide by the hygine guidelines.
On 22 April, the government unveiled a set of guidelines that communities and individuals to balance their daily lives and quarantine activities.
On 6 May, the government ended 6 weeks strong social distancing campaign and shifted so-called everyday life quarantine scheme. In early May,the Korea Baseball Organisation began the baseball season without audience.
From 26 July, the government will gradually permit spectators to attend major sports events such as baseball and football.
column20: Information not available
column22:
The Korean government has so far announced a total of over KRW 277 trillion (USD 14.4% of GDP) support measures to mitigate the impact of the Covid-19 virus including liquidity provisions and credit guarantees.
In February, the government announced emergency support of KRW 20 trillion for households and damaged industries, such as tourism and export industries.
On 17 March, the national Assembly approved the supplementary budget of KRW 11.7 trillion (USD 10 billion, 0.6% of GDP), consisting of KRW 10.9 trillion for new expenditure and KRW 0.8 trillion for revenue adjustment. New spending includes disease control and epidemic prevention (KRW 2.1 trillion), SME support (KRW 4.1 trillion), public welfare support such as consumption coupons, employment retention support (KRW 3.5 trillion).
On 24 March, the government announced an additional financial support package of KRW 100 trillion (later extended to nearly KRW 200 trillion) to boost local business and ease the financial burden on households and businesses:

* Expansion of financial loans and guarantees

* Creation of a bond market stabilisation fund

* Creation of a stock market stabilisation fund

* Rolling over debt of SMEs and self-employed people to financial institutions.
On 22 April, the government announced a KRW 75 trillion (4.0% of GDP) support plan for strategic industries and additional financing for SMEs and households:

* Establishment of a Key Industry Relief Fund guaranteed by the government to provide liquidity and purchase corporate debt and equity for the country's seven backbone industries(KRW 40 trillion). Large corporate recipients must retain at least 90% of their employees for six months and some conditions are imposed on management, such as a ban on dividend payments and stock buybacks.

* Additional financing for SMEs and households with low credit ratings (KRW 35 trillion)
On 30 April, the National Assembly passed a second supplementary budget of KRW 12.2 trillion (USD 10 billion) for emergency relief grants. A total of KRW 14.3 trillion (0.6% of GDP) including KRW 1.2 trillion of local government funds is allocated to the relief programme. The emergency relief payments are offered in the form of coupons and cash to encourage private consumption. Regarding cash out, some local governments introduced similar relief support schemes for people
On 4 June Korea submitted a third supplementary budget of KRW 35.3 trillion (1.8% of GDP). This extra budget focuses on:
-Creating 550 000 jobs in public programmes and strengthening social safety nets (KRW 9.4 trillion)
-Providing emegency loans to struggling SMEs and large businesses (KRW 5 trillion)
-Spending KRW 5.1 trillion on big data platforms, AI and 5G telecommunication services, so called "New Deal projects", on which the government pledged to invest KRW 76 trillion by 2025.
On 3 July the National Assembly passed a third supplementary budget of KRW 35.1 trillion(1.8% of GDP). With the third supplementary budget, the total added supplementary budget in 2020 is KRW 59 trillion.
On 14 July, the government announced the Korean New Deal projects in detail in which the country plans to create 1.9 million new jobs and invest KRW 160 trillion (USD 133 billion) by 2025, focusing on digital projects and eco-friendly projects.
column24:
The 1st supplementary budget of KRW 11.7 trillion (USD 10billion, 0.6% of GDP) was approved in National Assembly in March.

The 2nd supplementary budget of KRW 12.2 trillion was be passed by National Assembly on April 30.

The 3rd supplementary budget of KRW 35.1 trillion was be passed by the Parliament on 3 July.
column25:
Korea's containment strategy was based on testing, tracing and treating:

* Testing: innovative methods, such as drive-through and walk-through testing facilities, along with the rapid development of tests, allowed extensive testing. As of 8 June, almost 982 000 had been tested, among which 1.2% proved positive.

* Tracing: rigorous epidemiological investigations are conducted, using credit card transactions, CCTV recordings and GPS data on mobile phones when necessary. Anonymised information on contacts is disclosed to the public and close contacts of positive cases are put under self-quarantine, with their health condition monitored remotely.

* Treatment: patients are classified according to severity and directed towards appropriate treatment paths at hospitals for severe cases and living and treatment support centres for milder cases. Health care resources and organisation were adjusted in response to the pandemic.
column28:
The central government plans to pay relief checks to all housholds up to KRW 1 million (USD 820) per household.
-Regarding cash out, some local governments introduced similar cash support programmes
column31:

* VAT payable by small businesses with less than KRW 80 million in annual sales will be reduced until the end of 2020.

* VAT exemption threshold is raised temporarily until the end of 2020 (KRW 30 million to KRW 48 million)
February package:

* Increase of tax deduction for individuals for the use of debit and credit cards for the period from March to June 2020.

* Temporary individual consumption tax cut for auto purchases
