On 27 February, the Bank of Korea (BOK) increased the ceiling of the Bank Intermediated Lending Support Facility by KRW 5 trillion to KRW 30 trillion (further increased to KRW 35 trillion on 13 May) to support SMEs and small merchants.
On 16 March, the Bank of Korea cut the policy rate by 50 basis points to 0.75%. It also lowered the interest rate on the Bank Intermediated Lending Support Facility from 0.50%-0.75% to 0.25% to encourage bank lending to small businesses. The BOK broadened the eligible collateral for open market operations to inject more liquidity in the financial markets.
On 19 March, to ease the stress on the bond market, the Bank of Korea purchased KRW 1.5 trillion (USD 1.2 billion) of treasury bonds.
On 19 March, the BOK signed a USD 60 billion bilateral currency swap agreement with the US Federal Reserve, for 6 months. On 26 March, the Ministry of Economy and Finance, the Financial Services Commission and the Bank of Korea eased the foreign exchange market stability rules to expand foreign currency liquidity:

* Raising ceilings on the foreign exchange derivatives positions of local banks (from 40% to 50% of their equity capital) and foreign bank branches in Korea (from 200% to 250% of their equity capital).

* Temporarily lifting the levy on non-deposit foreign exchange liabilities of financial institutions.

* Temporarily lowering the foreign exchange liquidity coverage ratio by 10 percentage points to 70%.
On 14 April the BOK decided to provide loans of KRW 10 trillion to bank and non-bank financial institutions, such as securities companies and insurance companies, for three months.
On 28 May, the Bank of Korea cut the policy rate by 25 basis points to 0.50%.
column47: On 13 March, the financial authority introduced a six-month ban on short-selling in the stock market to contain volatility.
column51:
On 9 April package:
-The government announced a KRW 36 trillion (USD 29.4 billion) financial support for exporters.

* Extension of export insurance and guarantees (KRW 30 trillion)

* Offering emergency liquidity (KRW 1 trillion)

* Preemptive trade finance support (KRW 5 trillion)
-The public sector plans to spend KRW 3.3 trillion on advanced purchases and payments.

On 22 April package;
-The government announced a KRW 40 trillion fund helping key industries such as aviation, shipping, shipbuilding, autovehicle companies. For this, the Korea Development Bank will issue bonds with state guarantee.

- The Parliament passed a relevant bill for a KRW 40 trillion fund on 30 April.
column54: Information not available

column12: * The state of emergency has ended on June 21. Regions will make decisions on the management of the crisis. Since July 3, some localised restrictions on movements or activities have been implemented.
column14:
* July 1: Open borders with Portugal. Reopen borders for the residents of 12 nonEU-countries, in line with the recommendation of the EU Council of June 30.

* June 21: Movement across regions allowed and travelers from other European Union countries, including the United Kingdom, and those coming from the Schengen area allowed (except for Portugal, with which borders will open on July 1).
column16:
* August 27: Schools will open throughout September, with some differences across regions and education levels in terms of timing and rules. Some basic rules have been agreed on by all regions (e.g. students aged 6 and above will be obliged to wear a mask).

* June 10: The government published guidelines on safe return to schools in September, including class size, social distancing measures (agreed on by most regions).
column18: * There remain some rules on large events, but they vary by region.
column20:
* Closure of nightclubs and night bars (August 13).

* There remain some rules on capacity requirements in establishments and large events, but they vary by region.

* The government approved social distancing requirements and hygiene measures in workplaces on June 9, including mandatory use of masks in closed spaces and on streets when a safety distance of 1.5 meters cannot be maintained.
column22:
* July 9: Plan to strengthen the Science, Technology and Innovation System (EUR 1 billion investment in 2020-21, with EUR 396 million in 2020; EUR 508 million loans to innovative companies)

* July 7: Measures to support the transport sector (EUR 663 million and EUR 1 billion to increase RENFE's borrowing capacity, EUR 110 million to meet ongoing public work commitments).

* July 3: Program of public support for solvency and business investment (EUR 40 billion of loan guarantees and a Solvency Suppport Fund of EUR 10 billion to be invested in strategic companies).

* June 18: Tourism Sector Promotion Plan, (EUR 4.25 billion): These include investment to improve competitiveness for the sustainability and digitalisation of the sector and liquidity measures (ICO guarantees of EUR 2.5 billion).

* June 16: Creation of COVID-19 fund of EUR 16 billion for the regions (EUR 9 billion for healthcare, EUR 2 billion for education and EUR 5 billion to offset the fall in revenues).

* June 15: Plan to Promote the value chain of the Automotive Industry the Automotive, towards a Sustainable and Connected mobility (EUR 3.725 billion): 2020: EUR 1.5 billion. Short and medium-term measures to facilitate the adaptation of the industry to technological change, as well as direct aid for the acquisition of plug-in electric or hybrid vehicles (e.g. subsidy for vehicle renewal under the MOVE II program ( EUR 100 million)

* Main packages of reforms in March, April: EUR 138.2 billion (of which EUR 104.4 billion is liquidity measures). Main items: Health (EUR 4.3 billion), support to workers (EUR 23.2 billion), support to firms (EUR 5.2 billion), social measures (EUR 1 billion).
column25:
* Ban on smoking in public if social distancing can't be maintained (August 13).

* EUR 9 billion of the COVID-19 Fund earmarked for health expenditures (June 16).

* The use of masks mandatory on public transport from May 11, and in closed spaces and public roads where social distancing can't be observed from May 20. The use of masks made mandatory in all public places in some regions since mid July.

* Making public and private clinical diagnostic laboratories available to regions for extensive covid19 testing and introducing the possibility of adopting the necessary measures to regulate the prices of these tests. (April13)

* Exemption of fees in procedures for authorisation of clinical trials for research for medicines related to Covid19. (April 7)

* EUR 46 million for R&D for the development of drugs and vaccines for COVID-19. (March 17)

* EUR 1.4 billion for the Ministry of Health to cover expenditures related to healthcare needs. (March 12)

* EUR 2.8 billion advance payment to the regions to meet increased healthcare needs. (March 12)

* Price intervention: possibility for the government to set, in an exceptional public health situation, a maximum price for medicines and certain products. (March 12)

* Easing of public procurement and hiring rules in the health field and centralisation of the purchase of relevant medical goods.
column28:
June 26:

* Extension to September 30 of the temporary employment adjustment schemes (with conditions defined based on firm size, whether it is partial or total force majeure and benefits declining with time) and the extraordinary benefit to the self-employed (self-employed workers who were collecting the extraordinary benefit, which included financial aid equivalent to 70% of the regulatory base and an exemption from contributions, will not pay the July and will have an exemption of 50% in August and 25% in September).

* New extraordinary benefit for seasonal freelancers of up to 70% of the minimum contribution base (from June, max duration of 4 months).

* In the event of new COVID-19 outbreaks, companies could resort to a new ERTE of force majeure, with exemptions of around 80% for companies with less than 50 workers and the 60% for those with a larger workforce.

* May 26: Classification of benefits for health workers affected by COVID-19 as derived from an accident at work, which means greater coverage in cases where the illness causes permanent disability or death.

* May 12: Extension of the use of temporary employment adjustment schemes (ERTEs) until June 30 for firms who can't resume activity and the introduction of a new partial ERTE category for firms who can partially resume activities (combination of active and suspended workers), with different % of SSC exemptions depending on firm size and worker status.

* May 6: Extraordinary access to unemployment benefit to workers in the cultural sector.

April 21 package:

* Increase in the scope of the use of temporary employment adjustment schemes (ERTEs) due to force majeure to be applicable in sectors considered essential but having nevertheless suffered a reduction in revenues due to confinement measures.

* Extension of the unemployment benefit to cover workers whose contracts under trial period have been terminated since March 9th, and for workers who voluntarily terminated their contract since March 1st because they had a firm job offer that has been withdrawn. (EUR 42 million)

April 7: Temporary flexibility measures in hiring of temporary workers in the agriculture sector during the state of emergency (extended until September 30 on May 26).

March 31 package:

* A temporary allowance for temporary workers whose contracts (with at least two months duration) expires during the state of emergency and have not reached the minimum contribution period to receive UB (around EUR 430). (EUR 17.6 million)

* A temporary subsidy for household employees affected by the crisis (70% of the regulatory base). (EUR 3.1 million)

* Extension of the temporary contracts of university teachers and research staff during the state of emergency. (EUR 3.8 million)

* Specific program for victims of gender violence, homeless people and others who are especially vulnerable to provide them with an immediate housing solution. (EUR 50 million)

* Rental assistance programs for vulnerable renters and additional state contribution to the State Housing Plan 2018-21. ( EUR 400 million)

* March 30: Workers affected by the suspension of all non-essential activities will receive their full salary during the suspension, and will be required to compensate the lost working hours before December 31, 2020.

* March 27: Dismissals for reasons related to Covid19 will not be considered justified from March 27 until the end of the health crisis. Temporary contracts can not be cancelled (they can be interrupted during the crisis but must be resumed after the end of the lockdown).

March 17 package:

* Changes in the temporary employment adjustment schemes (ERTEs) in order to avoid outright dismissal: simplification, extension of access conditions, entitlement of unemployment benefit for workers affected by ERTE, with no requirement for prior minimum contribution or reduction of accumulated entitlement. (EUR 17.8 billion)

* An extraordinary allowance is provided for self-employed workers affected by the suspension of economic activity (70% of the SSC base, at least for one month). (EUR 3.8 billion)

* Additional budgetary funds of EUR 300 million to ensure the provision of assistance to dependent persons.

* Automatic extension of the social benefit for energy provision ('bono social') until September 15 (expanded on March 31).

* Broadened scope for protected families in the supply of water and energy. Telecommunication services are also guaranteed. (expanded on March 31).

* Increased flexibility of working conditions, encouragement of telework and adjustment of working times. Reduced working times are permitted for workers having to take care of children, elderly or dependent persons (extension to 2 months after the end of state of emergency on April 21).

* March 12: Supplemental credit of EUR 25 million to cover meal allowances to ensure the basic access to food for vulnerable children affected by the suspension of educational activity in schools.

* March 10: Increased sick pay for coronavirus infected workers or those quarantined, from 60 to 75 percent of the regulatory base, paid by the social security budget. (EUR 1.4 billion)
column31:
April 21 package:

* Measures to align the tax bases to the current situation: the use of the 'direct estimation method' by self-employed workers for the calculation of certain personal income tax and VAT payments, which will allow to adjust these payments during the state of alarm to the real income received; the adjustment of advance corporate tax payments to the estimated revenues in 2020. (EUR 1.1 billion)

* Reduction of VAT applicable to the supply of medical equipment from national producers to public entities, non-profit organizations and hospital centres to 0%, in line with the EU until July 31. (EUR 1 billion)

* Reduction the VAT on electronic books, newspapers to align them with that on paper ones. (EUR 24 million)

* Reduction of the contributions for certain agricultural workers during periods of inactivity in 2020 and simplification of the procedure for deferring Social Security debt. (EUR 43 million)

* March 17: Exemption of social security contributions by impacted firms that maintain employment under ERTE: 100% for SMEs, 75% of employer's social security contributions for other companies (EUR 2.2 billion). Exemption from the payment of contributions for self-employed persons affected by the declaration of the state of emergency (EUR 980 million).

* March 12: 50% exemption from employers social security contributions, from February to June 2020, for workers with permanent discontinuous contracts in the tourism sector and related activities. (EUR 45 million)
column34: * March 17: Support to the digitalisation of small and medium companies through grants and loans to finance investment in digital equipment or solutions for remote working conditions (programme ACELERA PYME). (EUR 250 million)
column37:
* May 26: The possible interest free postponement period of tax payment deferrals for SMEs and self-employed workers (announced on March 12) increased to four months.

* April 21:The possibility to suspend the enforcement periods for payment of certain tax debts if companies are financing their payment through the State Guarantee Line.

* April 14: Extension of deadlines for filing tax returns in April to 20 May for SMEs and the self-employed .

March 31 package:

* Budget flexibility to enable transfers between budget lines and for local governments to use budget surplus from the previous years for supporting measures in the area of housing.

* Give Social Security the power to grant moratoriums on the payment of SSC of companies and the self-employed.

* 6-month suspension of social security contributions for the self-employed (for the period May-July) and companies (for the period April-June) without interest. (EUR 359 million)

* Deferral of SSC debts for the self-employed and companies. (EUR 350 million)

* For the self-employed who get the allowance for cessation of activity, the possibility to postpone without any charge March's Social Security quota for the days worked.

* Suspension of interest and repayment of loans granted by the Secretariat of State for Tourism for one year with no need for prior request.

March 17 package:

* Additional flexibility for local authorities to use their 2019 budgetary surplus to fund social services and primary assistance to dependent persons (EUR 300 million)

* Facilitation of procedural and administrative requirements for companies. Extension of deadlines for tax filing, insolvency declaration, preparation of financial statements.

* Introduction of a special regime for the suspension of public contracts, foreseeing compensation in certain cases.

* March 12: Possibility for SMEs and self-employed workers to defer tax payments for maximum six months and benefit from interest rate subsidies (EUR 8.9 million).
column40:
* July 3: Fund to support the solvency of strategic firms, managed by the Ministry of Finance (granting of participative loans, acquisition of subordinated debt or subscription of shares or other instruments of capital) (EUR 10 billion).

* May 6: To guarantee the liquidity of companies in the culture sector, inject EUR 20 million to CREA to guarantee loans of up to EUR 880 million.

* March 17: Allow ICO to increase its funding by EUR 10 billion to extend its existing lines of credit to companies and self-employed workers.

March 12 package:

* Specific ICO (Instituto de Crédito Oficial) financing facility amounting to EUR 400 million to support, through liquidity provision, firms and self-employed workers in the tourism sector affected by COVID-19.

* Deferral of the repayment of principal and/or interest of loans received from the Ministry of Industry, Trade and Tourism.
column43:
* July 3: A line of guarantees through ICO (EUR 40 billion). First tranche of EUR 8 billion, of which EUR 5 billion goes to self-employed and SMEs (June 28): gurantee of 80% of the new loans for the self-employed and SMEs, and 70% for other companies.

April 21 package:

* A line of guarantees to provide financial assistance on housing expenses for vulnerable households (announced on March 31) (EUR 1.2 billion).

* Expand the coverage of the previously announced guarantee line to Alternative Fixed Income Market commercial paper.

* Strengthen counter-guarantees granted by CERSA to increase the capacity of regional mutual guarantee entities.

* Authorise the Insurance Compensation Consortium to act as a reinsurer of credit insurance risks to strengthen the channelling of resources to commercial credit.

March 31:

* A microcredit guarantee scheme for 0% interest loans for an amount up to 6 months rent (repayment period of up to 10 years), or direct aid (EUR 900/month) to help pay rent.

* Additional loan guarantees for SMEs and self-employed through the Compaía Espaola de Reafianzamiento (EUR 1 billion).

March 17 package:

* A new line of guarantees via the national development bank (ICO) of up to EUR 100 billion. The first tranche of guarantees (EUR 20 billion): 50% of the tranche will cover loans to SMEs and self-employed workers, for whom the guarantee will cover 80% of new loans and loan renewals. For the rest of firms, the guarantee will cover 70% of new loans and 60% of loan renewals (made available on April 6). The second tranche of guarantees (EUR 20 billion) for SMEs and self-employed only, for whom the guarantee will cover 80% of new loans and renewals (made available on April 10). Third tranche (EUR 24.5 billion): EUR 10 billion for SMEs and self-employed, EUR 10 billion for other companies, EUR 4 billion for the issue of promissory notes of NFCs in fixed income markets, EUR 0.5 billion for CERSA (made available on May 5). Fourth tranche (EUR 20 billion) for SMEs and the self-employed only, for whom the guarantee will cover 80% of new loans and renewals (made available on May 19).

* Additional guarantees of up to EUR 2 billion through the Spanish Export Insurance Credit Company (CESCE) for exporting firms.

* Guarantees for loan maturity extensions to farmers using credit lines under the special 2017 drought credit line. (EUR 2.5 million)
column46: Monetary policy set by the ECB.
column47:
No macroprudential measures taken at the national level.

Other related measures:
The National Securities Market Commission (CNMV) issued a ban on transactions which might constitute or increase net short positions in shares admitted to trading to Spanish trading venues for which the CNMV is the competent authority until April 17th, which was then extended to May 18.
column48:
* July 7: Extension of some policies announced in March (moratorium on mortgages, consumer loans; moratorium of rent payment of vulnerable households, guarantee of utilities) to the end of September

* June 1: The introduction of a minimum income guarantee scheme (estimated to cost EUR 3 billion/year).

* April 21: Reduction of notary fees associated with changes in non-mortgage credits.

March 31 package:

* The suspension of rent for vulnerable groups for 6 months, the extension of current rental housing contracts due to expire for 6 months, automatic moratorium of rent payments (up to 4 months) for vulnerable groups with “large” (10 or more properties) landlords.

* A three-month credit moratorium on the payment non-mortgage loans and credits, including consumer credits, by vulnerable groups.

* More flexibility for workers to access savings from their pension plans.

* Three-month credit postponement on mortgage payments for the most vulnerable. (initially introduced for 1 month on March 17).
column51:
* April 21: Establishment of a mechanism for reducing the costs of renegotiating and deferring rent payments for businesses to large owners or public companies. For other owners, deposits will be facilitated as payment mechanism.

* March 31: A three-month moratorium on mortgage payments to the self-employed affected by the crisis.
column54:
March 17 package:

* Acceleration of custom procedures for imports and exports in the industrial sector for six months.

* Prior government authorisation for third country FDI in strategic sectors (reinforced on March 31 to ensure the coverage of all foreign investment effectively controlled by third country companies).

* March 12: Measures to support the aviation sector: EU Commission has been requested to provide urgently flexibility for airport slots.

column12:
- From 1 April, a ban on visiting elderly care institutions is imposed.

- On 16 March, the health authority (Folkhälsomyndigheten) recommended as much as possible isolating people over 70 and working from home.

- On 13 March, many hospital introduced a ban on external visitors.

- Since 10 March, everyone with symptoms of respiratory infection, even mild ones, was urged to avoid social contacts, both at work and in private, and throughout the country. Relatives should avoid "unnecessary visits" to hospitals.
column14:
- On 27 August, the entry ban from outside the EU and the exemption list of countries was extended until 31 October. The advice against non-essential travel was lifted for Bulgaria, the Netherlands and Romania (in addition to Andorra, Austria, Belgium, Croatia, Czechia, Denmark, France, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Iceland, Italy, Liechtenstein, Luxembourg, Monaco, Norway, Poland, Portugal, San Marino, Spain, Switzerland and the Vatican City). For other countries in the EU, the EEA, the Schengen area, and the United Kingdom, the advice against non-essential travel is extended until 9 September. For countries outside the EU, the EEA, the Schengen area and the United Kingdom, the advice against non-essential travel is extended until 15 November.

- Since 15 August, residents from Morocco are no longer generally exempted from entry ban (however, other exemptions from the entry ban may continue to apply to them).

- On 13 August, advice against non-essential travel was lifted for Liechtenstein and Austria.

- Since 5 August, residents from Algeria are no longer generally exempted from entry ban (however, other exemptions from the entry ban may continue to apply to them).

- From 30 July, recommendation against non-essential travel were lifted for Denmark, Norway, Switzerland and the Czech Republic.

- From 19 July, residents from the following countries are allowed freely travel to Sweden: Algeria, Australia, Canada, Georgia, Japan, Morocco, New Zealand, Rwanda, South Korea, Thailand, Tunisia, Uruguay. Travellers from other non-EU/EEA countries will remain banned from entry until 31 August. Residents of Serbia and Montenegro are no longer generally exempted from the entry ban (however, other exemptions from the entry ban may continue to apply to them).

- On 30 June, recommendation against non-essential travel were lifted for Belgium, France, Greece, Iceland, Italy, Croatia, Luxembourg, Portugal, Switzerland and Spain. The recommendation remains until 15 July for other countries in the EU, EEA and Schengen and is extended until 31 August for the remaining countries.

- On 17 March, in response to the European Council's and the European Commission's call for travel restrictions, the government decided to temporarily stop non-essential travel to Sweden from countries outside the EEA and Switzerland, so as to mitigate the effects of the outbreak of the COVID-19 virus and reduce the spread of the disease. The decision takes effect on 19 March and will initially apply for 30 days.

- On 14 March, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs advised against non-essential travel to all countries.
column16:
- On 15 June, high schools re-open for on-site education.

- Many higher secondary schools (children aged over 16) and all universities have switched to distance learning as of 18 March. Schools for younger children are still open at this stage.
column18:
- Events with more than 50 persons are banned since 27 March.

- Events with more than 500 persons are banned since 12 March.
column20:
- From 13 June, public transport where a place cannot be booked should be avoided.

- From 1 April, shops must limit the number of customers in the shop at the same time. If possible, sport associations must hold training sessions outside and postpone matches and competition. Public transport must limit the number of passengers.

- From 25 March, in restaurants, bars, nightclubs and cafés, only seated table service is allowed and tables must be placed far enough apart.
column22: Total government support in 2020 amounts to a total of SEK 805bn (16% of GDP), including SEK 240bn (4.8% of GDP) in budget measures, SEK 335bn (6.6% of GDP) in liquidity measures and SEK 230bn (4.6% of GDP) in guarantees (assuming these are used to the maximum).
column25:
- 11 May: New measures to strengthen health elderly care (SEK 5bn).

- 7 May: Extended reimbursement for the first day of sickness (cost SEK 3.2bn), continued suspension of medical certificate requirement for the first 14 days of leave (cost SEK 1.1bn).

- The central government will compensate municipalities and regions for extraordinary measures and extra costs in health and medical care associated with the COVID-19 virus. On 2 April, the amount was raised to SEK 3bn from SEK 2bn.

- On 2 April, the government announced that grants to municipalities and regions will increase by SEK 20bn in 2020, up from SEK 5bn previously planned, of which SEK 12.5bn will be permanent.

- From 11 March until 11 May, sickness benefit will be paid for the first day of sickness.
column28:
- 7 May: Increase in the ceiling for income-related benefits from unemployment insurance funds from SEK 760 to SEK 1 000 per day from benefit day 101 and onwards, from 29 June 2020 until 3 January 2021 (cost SEK 1.1bn).

- On 14 April, the Ministry of Finance announced a further reinforcement of its short-term layoffs scheme. From 1 May 2020 and for three months, employers will be able to reduce their employees' working hours by up to 80% (instead of 60%) and the government will bear most of the cost. The wage costs will be reduced by over 70% (previously 50%), while workers will retain almost 90% of their original wage. Combined with the reduced employers' social security contributions, employer costs can be reduced by up to 86% per cent during May and June. Control mechanisms will be enhanced.

- On 30 March, the government announced a new crisis package for jobs and transition
o Temporary reinforcement of unemployment insurance: eligibility conditions (length of employment and membership of a fund) will be temporarily relaxed; both the highest and the lowest amounts paid out by an unemployment insurance fund will be raised temporarily; the six initial qualifying days will be removed; the unemployment insurance funds will receive funding for administration.
o More active labour market policy: increased funding for the public employment service and labour market policy programmes; the period during which a person may have a subsidised job (extra job, new start job or introductory job) will be extended by an additional year for those who already have such jobs; the maximum time for support for starting a business will be extended from six to twelve months; municipalities will receive grants for more summer jobs for young people and funding for green jobs.
o More places and more distance learning at higher education institutions to benefit unemployed and people who are given notice of the termination of their contract.
o More opportunities for vocational education and training throughout the country.
o Removal of the income ceiling for student aid: the income ceiling for all those receiving student aid will be temporarily removed so that health and medical care students can help out in the health care sector without their student aid being reduced.

- On 16 March, the short-term layoffs scheme was introduced. Employees receive more than 90 per cent of their wages, but employers' wage costs can be halved, thanks to the government subsidy. The subsidy level is significantly higher than in the previous short-time work scheme (estimated cost: SEK 20 billion). Sickness benefit qualifying day is temporarily discontinued and the government will assume the entire cost of all sick pay during April and May. Self-employed persons will be entitled to receive standardised sick pay for 14 days.

- From 11 March until 11 May, sickness benefit will be paid for the first day of sickness.
column31:
On 25 March, the government announced another crisis package for small enterprises:
o Measures targeting small enterprises: 100% of the taxable profits of sole proprietors and partners in Swedish partnerships for 2019, up to SEK 1 million, can be set aside in the tax allocation reserve, which can then be set off against possible future losses. VAT reported by sole proprietors annually from 27 December 2019 to 17 January 2021 will be eligible to deferral, with interest. These measures will provide a maximum liquidity reinforcement of more than SEK 20 billion.
column34:
- On 4 September, the government announced the extension of the conversion support to companies affected by the COVID-19 crisis, mainly in the hospitality industry (cost SEK 9 billion). The support initially applied for March and April 2020 and will also apply to May, June and July 2020. Eligible firms for May 2020 must have lost more than 40% of their sales from 2019. Eligible firms for June and July 2020 must have lost more than 50% of their sales from 2019. The amount of the support is 75% of the fixed costs fo May-July 2020. In May, the maximum amount is SEK 75 million per company, in June and July a maximum of SEK 150 million.

- 7 May: Extension of the the state aid to cover businesses' sick pay costs (cost SEK 9bn) and of the financial support to sick self-employed (cost SEK 250mn).

- On 30 April, the government announced a SEK 39bn (0.8% of GDP) package to support businesses based on loss of turnover. The amount may vary between 22.5% and 75% of the fixed costs excluding wage costs for March and April 2020. Eligible firms are those with a turnover of at least SEK 250 000 during the past financial year and a loss of turnover of at least 30%. Almost 180 000 businesses may be entitled.

- Announced on 25 March: Temporary discount for rental costs in vulnerable sectors, such as durable consumer goods, hotels, restaurants and certain other activities, with the government covering 50% of the rental reduction up to 50% of the fixed rent (estimated cost: SEK 5 billion).

- On 20 March, the government announced support amounting to SEK 500 million (EUR 45 million ; 0.01% of GDP) for cultural activities that lose revenue as a result of the restriction on public events and the same amount for sports.
column37:
- On 25 March, the government announced another crisis package for small enterprises:
o Temporary reduction of employers' social security contributions to the old age pension contribution only for the period 1 March to 30 June 2020, up to 30 employees and on the portion of the employee's wage that does not exceed SEK 25 000 per month. This entails tax relief of up to SEK 5 300 per employee per month. An equivalent relief applies to sole proprietors (estimated cost: SEK 33 billion).

- On 16 March, liquidity reinforcement is given via tax accounts: companies can defer three months payment of employer social security contributions, preliminary tax on salaries and value added tax that are reported monthly or quarterly for up to 12 months, with interest. The new regulations take effect on 30 April, but can be retroactively applied from 1 January 2020. If companies use this opportunity to the same extent as in 2009, this would amount to SEK 27 billion. If all companies would use it to the maximum, this would amount to SEK 315 billion. To support SMEs, it will also be allowed to defer the value-added tax reported annually. Hence, companies can defer the payment of last year's VAT that is due shortly. If this is used to the maximum, it can amount to SEK 7 billion. In addition, SMEs can claim back the preliminary tax paid in 2019 and either pay it later or set it off against future losses (the maximum liquidity reinforcement could amount to SEK 13 billion).
column40:
On 20 March, the government announced a new support package for small businesses:
o Almi, a state agency which offers loans to companies with growth potential and assists in their business development, will get a new capital grant of SEK 3 billion (about EUR 270 million, 0.06% of GDP) to allow it to lend more to SMEs.
o The Swedish Export Credit Agency's loan limit is extended to SEK 200 billion (about EUR 18 billion, 3.8% of GDP) from SEK 125 billion.
o The ceiling for credit guarantees from the agency which insures export companies and banks against the risk of non-payment in export transactions (EKN) is increased to SEK 500 billion (about EUR 45bn, 9.6% of GDP) from SEK 450 billion, the same amount as during the 2008 financial crisis, and the coverage is extended to encompass sea shipping.
column43:
- On 25 March, the government announced another crisis package for small enterprises:
o Government guarantee on 70% of new bank loans to companies experiencing financial difficulty due to the COVID-19 virus but otherwise robust, up to SEK 75 million (with possible exceptions).

- On 19 March, the Swedish Parliament has allowed the Government to issue credit guarantees of up to SEK 5 billion in 2020 for loans to airlines that on 1 January this year had a Swedish permit to operate commercial aviation and who have their main operations or headquarters in Sweden.
column46:
- On 5 August, the Riksbank decided to extend the swap agreement with the US Federal Reserve until 31 March 2021.

- On 1 July, the Riksbank decided to extend its asset purchases plans from SEK 300 billion to SEK 500 billion and to the end of June 2021. The Riksbank will continue to purchase government bonds, municipal bonds and mortgage bonds for SEK 100 billion between 1 October and 31 December. The Riksbank will offer weekly purchases of commercial paper up to holdings of a maximum of SEK 32 billion and representing less than 70% of an individual issuer's total outstanding volume of commercial paper in SEK. In September, the Riksbank will begin purchasing corporate bonds for SEK 10 billion up to 30 June 2021.

- On 19 March, the Riksbank and the US Federal Reserve agreed on a swap facility of 60 billion USD. The agreement will be in place for at least six months.

- On 16 March, the Riksbank decided to increase purchases of securities by up to SEK 300 billion in 2020. Given relative scarcity of government bonds, purchases can include municipal and mortgage bonds (in the Nordics, there is a deep and liquid market for the latter) as well as non-financial corporate bonds and commercial papers.
column47:
- On 1 July, the Riksbank decided cut in interest rates and extended maturities on lending to banks:
o The interest rate on the standing loan facility was cut from the repo rate plus 0.2 percentage points to the repo rate plus 0.1 percentage points
o The interest rate on the weekly extraordinary loans to banks was cut from the repo rate plus 0.2 percentage points to the repo rate. Loans have been offered at maturities of three months and six months.
o The maturity on loans to banks for onward lending to companies was extended from two to up to four years.
o The interest supplement that applies if the requirement for onward lending to Swedish companies is not met was cut from 0.20 percentage points to 0.10 percentage points.

- On 24 March, the FSA stressed that it expects credit institutions to stop this year's dividend payments and use the earnings to further strengthen their capital.

- On 16 March, FSA announced that it considers the loss of income associated with COVID-19 to qualify as a special reason that allows the bank and borrower to reach an agreement to reduce or suspend loan amortisation payments for a limited period of time. FSA also clarified that it will temporarily allow banks to fall below the liquidity coverage ratio requirements for individual currencies and total currencies. This measure relieves liquidity constraints.

- On 16 March, the Riksbank decided to reduce the lending rate for overnight loans to banks from 0.75 to 0.20 percentage points above the repo rate, while keeping the repo rate at zero per cent. Banks will be allowed to borrow an unlimited amount at 3-month's maturity on a weekly basis against collateral at an interest rate of 20 bp above the repo rate. Flexibility will be increased on collateral requirements for banks when they borrow money from the Riksbank.

- On 13 March, the Riksbank decided to lend up to SEK 500 billion (about 10% of GDP) (about €46 billion) to companies via the banks, to avoid robust companies being knocked out as a result of the spread of the coronavirus.

- On 13 March, Finansinspektionen (FSA) lowered its countercyclical capital buffer from 2.5% percentage points to 0%. This amounts to SEK 45 bn and should create a capacity of around SEK 900 billion (about 18% of GDP) for new lending. The FSA also announced that it will postpone all new investigations and on sight supervisory activities, in order to free up resources at the banks.
column54: Information not available

column12: Wearing a mask is compulsory on planes from August 15 for scheduled and charter flights from or to Switzerland. This measure applies regardless of the airline.
column14: The Federal Council has issued restrictions on entry into Swiss territory for tourist purposes for nationals of countries outside the Schengen Area, i.e. 160 countries. 20 countries are exempt from these restrictions, including 5 EU members (Bulgaria, Cyprus, Croatia, Ireland and Romania).
column16: On May 11, mandatory schools have reopened  and on June 8, all non-mandatory schools
column18: On June 22, The Federal Council has decided to authorize gatherings of up to 1000 people provided that tracing of contacts is guaranteed and people can be separated into groups of 300 people maximum. Gatherings of more than 1,000 people should be allowed from September.
column20: On June 22,  the Federal Council puts an end to its recommendation for teleworking and to the instructions for the protection of fragile people. The state leaves it up to employers to decide on measures to protect their employees.
column22: The federal executive transmits to Parliament the draft additional funding of up to CHF 770 million to finance screening for the coronavirus and support to the air and rail sectors.
column25: The hospitals will again be able to perform all procedures. The medical cabinets will reopen.
column28: As of September 1, 2020, the majority of extraordinary measures are abolished (extension of the group of beneficiaries, additional financial relief for companies) and the original system of compensation in the event of a reduction in working hours applies again. The maximum authorized duration for the reduction of the working hours is again three months. The new maximum duration of receipt of compensation in the event of a reduction in working hours is 18 months (and not more than 12). The simplified procedure for the notice and the summary procedure for the counting of reduction of the working hours continue to apply until the end of December 2020.
column31: Information not available
column34: In May, the Parliament voted 65 million Swiss francs to support crèches in difficulty, 65 million for the media and 40 million for the tourism in order to finance a marketing campaign for the sector for 2020-2022. The Federal Council has decided to allocate 500 million francs to the world of sport to compensate for the losses linked to the stopping of competitions.
column37: Information not available
column40: The Confederation strengthen its support by waiving the repayment of the remainder of the additional loan granted to the Swiss Hotel Credit Corporation (SCH), which expired at the end of 2019. The SCH thus has an additional 5.5 million francs available to devote to loans for the retroactive financing of investments in accommodation establishments, which the latter have financed through their cash flow over the past two years. Within the framework of regional policy, Confederation loans for projects (60% of which are in the field of tourism) currently amount to around 530 million francs. The law provides that the management of these loans is delegated to the cantons. In order to make more liquidity available to borrowers, the Confederation allows the cantons more flexibility in managing the possibilities of deferral of payment.
column43: Information not available
column46: In its quarterly report, the Swiss National Bank (SNB) indicates that it maintains its expansionary monetary policy (key rate at -0.75%) and be prepared to intervene widely on the foreign exchange market (40% of foreign currency reserves are in euros, compared to 36% in dollars)
column47: Information not available
column48: Parliament passed motion to allow commercial tenants to pay only 40% of their rent during the period when the establishments were closed by decision of the Council federal (for rents below CHF 20,000 per month).
column51: The Federal Council adopted an ordinance on April 16 with several measures to prevent bankruptcies, including a delay for SMEs and independents for being declared bankrupt due to the covid-19 crisis.
column54: Information not available

column12: Information not available
column14:
*August 1: authorities announced requirements for all travelers entering Tanzania amid the ongoing coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreak. Commercial flights are operating to and from Tanzania and individuals are no longer required to quarantine for 14-days on arrival. All travelers entering the country are required to provide proof of a negative COVID-19 test which has been performed up to 72 hours prior to boarding. All international passengers will also be subject to temperature screening on arrival, and if passengers show symptoms of COVID-19 they will be subject to further testing and may be required to quarantine at a government-designated facility at their own costs. International travelers will also be required to complete a health form on arrival. Face masks, social distancing measures, and hygiene protocols should continue to be observed by all travelers.
*May 18: Effective on May 18, the authorities lifted the suspension of international flights into and out of Tanzania and said those entering the country would no longer need to undergo mandatory quarantine.

* May 11: Tanzanian government has relaxed some restrictions on international flights to allow some categories of flight movements amid growing demand for the service, authorities say. The relaxation touches repatriation flights, operations related to humanitarian aid, medical and relief flights, technical landings where passengers do not disembark and other safety-related operations.
*April 12: Tanzanian authorities have suspended all flights to and from Tanzanian International Airports effective immediately.
*April 1: formulated plans to shut down all tourist hotels
*March 25: suspension of international flights by Air Tanzania.
*March 25: travel bans to and from Zanzibar
*March 23: All travelers whether foreigners or returning residents arriving from COVID-19 most affected countries, will be subjected to mandatory isolation for 14 days at their own cost at designated facilities identified by the Government.
column16:
*June 29: All other educational institutions reopened on this day.
*May 18: Effective June 1, 2020, the authorities allowed the opening of upper-secondary and tertiary schools and the resumption of sport activities and events. On June 29, 2020 all other educational institutions will reopen.
*April 14: Tanzanian Prime Minister Kassim Majaliwa announced indefinite extension of closure of schools and universities as part of measures aimed at fighting against the COVID-19 pandemic.
*March 17: schools are closed for 30 days.
column18:
*August 1: The government of Tanzania has reportedly begun relaxing the ban on public gatherings and sporting competitions. The majority of bars, restaurants, and hotels closed voluntarily and remain closed, although many restaurants are offering takeaway services. Social distancing measures and hygiene protocols should be observed.
*April 15: President John Magufuli has cancelled celebrations to mark Union Day on April 26 and May Day on May 1 to avoid spread of the virus.
*March 17: Government has banned all forms of public gatherings for 30 days
column20: Information not available
column22:
*June 18: Thus far, the government spent $8.4 million specifically related to deal with the effects of COVID-19.
*March 20: A 2.5 billion TND emergency plan ($0.8 billion or 2 percent of GDP) was announced.
column25:
*June 18: the government has received grants and will use contingency reserve of US$3.2 million to fund additional health spending to mitigate the risks of the pandemic.
*May 7: the government released USD 302 million for health spending. The funds come from cancelling and postponing some budgeted spending such as foreign travel and training; national ceremonies; and procurement of vehicles. The government has granted VAT and customs exemptions to additional medical items requested by the Ministry of Health.
column28: Information not available
column31: *June 18: The government has expanded social security schemes by US$32.1 million to meet the increase in withdrawals benefits for the newly unemployed due to COVID-19.
column34: Information not available
column37: Information not available
column40: Information not available
column43: Information not available
column46:
*May 21: The daily transactions limit for mobile money operators was raised from about USD 1,300 to USD 2,170 and the daily balance limit was raised from USD 2,170 to USD 4,340.
*May 13: To mitigate the economic impact of Covid-19, the Bank of Tanzania (BoT) cut its discount rate from 7.0% to 5.0% (reflecting a 200-bps reduction) and committed to implementing the following measures: i) lowering the statutory minimum reserve requirement from 7.0% to 6.0% to support financial sector stability; ii) reducing the haircuts on government securities from 10.0% to 5.0% for treasury bills, and from 40% to 20% for treasury bonds; iii) providing commercial banks with regulatory flexibility to restructure loans to borrowers who experience distress due to the crisis.
column47: Information not available
column51: *May 7: the government has expedited the payment of verified expenditure arrears giving priority to affected SMEs, paying USD 376 million in March.
column54: *August 7: East African Community (EAC) partner states have agreed to start launching a regional electronic cargo and driver tracking system as one of the measures aimed at preventing further spread of the Coronavirus disease, and minimize loss of lives. The Regional Electronic Cargo and Driver Tracking System (RECDTS) will be launched at five border points. After Rusumo on August 12 next will be the Mutukula border between Tanzania and Uganda on August 14; the Malaba border between Kenya and Uganda on August 21; Namanga border between Tanzania and Kenya on August 28 and finally, Kobero border between Burundi and Tanzania on August 31.The launch will run from August 12 to 31 at the various border points. It will start at the Rusumo border between Rwanda with Tanzania.

column12:
- On 25 August 2020, the state of emergency has been extended for another month to 30 September 2020.

- On 22 July 2020, the state of emergency has been extended for another month to 31 August in order to enforce travel restriction, tracking and quarantine system, surveillance of suspected cases, integration of police and military personne

- On 30 June 2020, the government extended the nationwide state of emergency for another month until 31 July 2020.

- On 15 June 2020, the government decided to lift the night time curfew, but the state of emergency and ban on entry remain in effect.

- On 26 May 2020, the state of emergency including the night curfew was extended until 30 June 2020.

- On 17 May 2020, the night-time curfew was shortened, starting at 23:00 to 4:00, instead of 22:00 to 4:00.

- On 28 April 2020, the government extended the period of the state of emergency including the night curfew until 31 May 2020.

- A National state of emergency was declared on 26 March 2020 until 30 April, limiting cross provincial movements of the population. The elderly over 70 year of age, person with previous health conditions and children under five years are advised to stay at their home.

- Following the declarion of the state of emergency, the government tightened measures to contain the spread of COVID-19 by imposing a nationwide curfew on 3 April, banning people from leaving their residences from 22h00 to 4h00.
column14:
- On 22 July, the Centre for Covid-19 Situation Administration (CCSA) approved the list of foreigners that can entry Thailand, subject to compulsory state quarantine at their arrival. The list consists of 4 groups: 1) international business representatives and specilaists; 2) diplomats; 3) migrant workers with work permits and 4) migrant workers without existing work permit for the construction and the food production sectors.
On 1 July, the Civil Aviation Authority of Thailand (CAAT) lifted the ban on international flights under some conditions. Aircrafts and passengers entering Thailand must comply with the conditions, time limits and rules of the authorised person under the Immigration Act, communicable diseases laws, air naviation law and the Emergency decree. In addtion to Thai nationals, some foreign travellers are allowed to enter the country including business travellers, spouses, parent and children of Thai nationals, foreigners with work permits or residency, foreigners in need of medical treatment in Thailand, foreign students and members of diplomatic missions and international organisations.

- On 16 May, the Ministry of Public Health removed China, Hong Kong(China), Macau(China) and South Korea from Thailand's list of “dangerous disease zones”, in which the countries and territories were listed since early March.

- On 16 May, the Civil Aviation Authority of Thailand (CAAT) extended the temporary ban on international passenger flights for another month until 30 June, with the exception made for state and military aircraft, emergency landing, technical landing without disembarkation, humanitarian aid, medical and relief flights, repatriation flights and cargo flights.

- Since 1 May, several airlines have resumed their operation for domestic flights in the major airports in Thailand, except Phuket International airport, where the closure has been extended until 15 May. The airports and airlines must comply with strict hygiene and preventive guidelines. The international flights are still banned.
column16:
- Under the fifth phase of the lockdown relaxation measure, announced on 29 June, all schools will be reopened on 1 July.

- On 12 June 2020, the government allowed international schools, universities with international courses, informal schools and small schools to reopen, while other schools will reopen on 1 July 2020.

- All schools have been closed since 18 March. All schools will reopen for the new semester on 1st July, postponed from 16 May.
column18:
- From 15 June, meetings and seminars, exhibition, convention and event halls can resume activities, along with theatres, but social distancing must be respected. Pubs, bars, karaoke shops and entertainment venues will remain closed.

- On 17 May, the second phase of lockdown relaxation took into effect. Several public places resumed their activities including libraries, galleries and museums.

- On 30 April, the government announced the first phase of the lockdown relaxation allowing 6 types of businesses to resume their activies including public parks and outdoor sport venues.

- In accordance with the state of emergency declared on 26 March, sports complex including boxing stadiums, sports stadiums, sports arenas, playgrounds, horse racetracks have been ordered to close in all provinces throughout Thailand. Natural tourist attractions, museums, public libraries, religious sites, public transport terminals and stations may be considered for closure.
column20:
- On 29 June 2020, the fifth phase of the lockdown relaxation was introduced. It allows pubs, bars, karaoke shops and entertainment venues to reopen with strict hygienic measures.

- On 15 June 2020, the fourth phase of the lockdown relaxation has been taken into effect. Most of economic activities are allowed to resume their businesses, except pubs, bars, karaoke shops and entertainment venues.

- On 1 June, the government introduced the third phase of the lockdown relaxation, allowing the reopening of several activities such as theaters, cinemas, massage salons, zoo, boxing stadiums and gymnasiums.

- On 17 May, the second phase of lockdown relaxation took into effect. More businesses are allowed to resume their activities, including shopping malls, restaurants, day-care nursing homes for elderly, meeting rooms, hotels and conference centres with a maximum of 50 participants from the same organisation, beauty and wellness salons, fitness centres, public swimming pools, parks and libraries. Cinemas, amusement parks, boxing stadiums and gymnasiums remain closed.

- On 30 April, the government announced a relaxation of some restrictive measures by allowing 6 types of businesses to resume their activies from 3 May including 1)restaurants 2)markets 3). dine-in area in supermarkets or grocery stores 4)public parks and outdoor sport venues 5) hair salons and 6) pet grooming services. These businesses must respect social distancing rules and carry out preventive measures includinghaving health and temperature screening at the entries, providing hand sanitizers and facial masks wearing.

- In accordance with the state of emergency declared on 26 March, locations that are risk-prone to the transmission of the Covid-19 have been ordered to temporarily close down in Bangkok and its vicinity., including pubs, spas, fitness centres; and wellness and beauty salons. Any other places such as restaurants, markets and shopping malls may be considered for closure in whole or in part.
column22:
- On 7 April, the third stimulus package worth THB 1.9 trillion (about 9% of GDP) was approved by the Cabinet aiming to help people and businesses as well as providing financial aid to farmers. Of this amount, the Ministry of Finance through bond issuance will finance THB 1 trillion, while THB 900 billion will be disbursed from the Bank of Thailand.

- The Government approved the Phase two stimulus package of THB 117 billion on 24 March. The package aims to financially support those in the informal sector and outside of the social security system; and MSMEs.

- The "phase one" package was announced on 11 March. It includes tax cuts, the reduction of social security contribution payments, among others.
column25:
- On 25 August, the Cabinet approved THB 1 billion to support the development and production of Covid-19 vaccines.

- On 12 May, the Thai Cabinet approved an additional recruitment of 38,105 public health-related posts, in response to the Covid-19 pandemic. The frontline medical and public health personnels to the Covid-19 pandemic will receive an additional monthly allowance between THB 1,000-1,500 for seven months.

- On 17 March, the cabinet approved the budget of 6.3 billion THB from central funds reserved for emergencies to ease and response to the impact of Covid-19. The budget will be allocated to seven line ministries and 14 government agencies.

- The Ministry of Public Health distributed 1,000,000 surgical masks per day to the hospitals. Additional 1.5 million N95 masks and 1.9 million personal protective equipment (PPE) will also be allocated. In addition, the Ministry will supply 40,000 pills of Favipiravir and 220 doses of Remdesivir for the Covid-19 treatment.
column28:
- Monthly cash handout of THB 5,000 for nine million workers from April to June, with possible extension for three additional months until September.

- Cash handouts of THB 5,000 per month to three million workers who are not covered by the social security fund (SSF) for three months, starting from April to June. Employees covered by the SSF are eligible for an increased unemployment compensation of up to 50% of their salary.

- The government provides emergency loans of THB 10,000 per person at a monthly interest rate of 0.1% and a special loan of THB 50,000 per person at a monthly interest rate of 0.35%.
column31:
- On 2 June, the cabinet approved a royal decree on the cut of the tax on land and buildings by 90% of the amount due for the 2020 tax year. The royal decree also covers a tax examption for the first home buyers for owners of both land and house.

- On 13 April, the Board of Investment of Thailand (BOI) approved a measure to accelerate investments in the medical sector. This measure introduced a reduction of 50 % of corporate income tax for an additional 3 years will be given to qualified investments in the medical sector, including the production of medical devices and parts, non-woven fabric used as raw materials in the production of medical supplies, diagnostic test kits, drugs, and active pharmaceutical ingredients.

- Tax exemption on risk compensation for medical workers involved in the treatment and prevention of COVID-19

- Tax relief schemes include:
1) Lowering the payment of withholding tax to boost liquidity
2) Allowing SMEs to deduct employee salaries from 1 April to 1 July
3) Extending the deadline for filing of corporate income tax to August and September and that of other revenue taxes for three months, speeding up VAT refunds for local businesses.
4) Extending the deadline for the filing of excise tax in the service sector and oil products operators.
column34: On 30 April, the State Enterprise Policy Committee (SEPC) meeting approved in principle the proposal to rehabilitate Thai airways international, the national carrier, with a loan worth THB 50 billion.
column37:
- The deadline for personal income tax declaration has been extended to August 2020.

- Tax deduction on health insurance was increased from THB 15,000 to THB 25,000.
column40: The Bank of Thailand (BOT) will allocate THB 500 billion for soft loans to SMEs.  SMEs willl be able to borrow a maximum of THB 500 million at an annual interest of 2% and interest-free for the first six months.
column43: Information not available
column46:
- On 20 May, the Monetary Policy Committee cut the policy rate by 0.25% point from 0.75 to 0.50%, the lowest rate on record.

- The Bank of Thailand (BOT) reduced its policy rate from 1.25% to 1.00% on 5 February, and further to 0.75% on 20 March, the latter of which was off-cycle.

- The BOT will halve the annual rate of contribution from financial institutions to the FIDF from 0.46% of deposit base to 0.23% per annum for a period of two years. This measure is intended to allow financial institutions to immediately pass on such cost savings to businesses and households by further reducing the interest rates.
column47: On 29 April, the Bank of Thailand injected THB 400 billion into Thailand's corporate bond market by establishing a bridge-financing fund called the Corporate Bond Liquidity Stabilisation Fund.
column48:
- On 5 May, the Thai cabinet approved the Metropolitan Waterworks Authority (MWA) and Provincial Waterworks Authority (PWA) proposals to provide 20% discount on water bills to the private consumers until the end of June.

- On 30 April, the Bank for Agriculture and Agricultural Cooperatives (BAAC) has announced the debt moratorium of one year from April 2020 to March 2021. 3.3 million farmers will benefit from this moratorium worths THB 1.2 trillion.

- On 21 April, the cabinet approved the energy authorities' decision to either waive or cut electricity fees for 22 million households for three months from March to May.

- Free electricity for households with a power meter of less than 5 amps.

- Households with power meters over 5 amps, will pay the same rate as their February bill if the consumption does not exceed 800 kWh. The amount over 800 kWh will be subject to a 50% discount.

- Households with consumption over 3,000 kWh will obtain a 30% discount.
column51: On 13 April, the Board of Investment of Thailand (BOI) approved a series of measures to mitigate the impact of the COVID-19 outbreak on businesses, including steps to encourage rapid investment in the manufacturing of medical equipment. The measures include a temporary relaxation of investment conditions. BOI agreed to extend deadlines and relax investment conditions for certain businesses,for instance, an extension of the duration for the duty-free importation of machinery, an extension for an application for license and standard approval; and waivers for temporary cessations of operations for a period of more than two months.
column54:
- On 8 September, the Thai Cabinet approved THB 23.48 billion measures to create jobs for 260,000 graduates from universities and vocational schools.

- On 30 June, the Thai Cabinet approved two stimulus package worth THB 22.4billion to revitalise domestic tourism, which will start as of 1 July until 31 October. The first package includes subsidies for domestic transport fares, accomodations, food and other services provided at tourist destination. the other THB 2.4 billion package will fund holiday travel for health volunteers and officials.

- On 25 May, National Economic and Social Development Council (NESDC) approved for THB 400 billion allocated for economic and social rehabilitation projects
to be spent on four sectors: 1). Future sustainable growth (smart agriculture, large-scale farming, food processing, bio-economy, tourism); 2). Local economic development
- (community businesses and community tourism); 3) Household and private consumption stimulus; and 40. Small scale infrastructure development

column12:
*Extension of the state of health emergency until August 16.
*June 9: Lifting of the closure/quarantine of the concerned cities.
*June 9: Lifting of the curfew.
*May 9: Lifting of curfew, from 9pm to 5am, starting May 10.
*April 20: Obligation to wear masks for the public health staff.
*April 1: State of emergency for three months.
*April 1: Curfew from 8 pm to 6 am, beginning April 2.
*March 20: Closure/quarantine of Lomé, Tsévié, Kpalimé and Sokodé beginning 21 March
column14:
*April 4: Limitation on public transport (limit of number of passengers in vehicles, city taxis, buses, ban on tricycles). These measures were suspended on April 5 until April 11.
*March 20: Closure of land borders (excluding circulation of goods) for 2 weeks.
*March 16: Suspension of all flights coming from affected countries.
*March 16: Mandatory quarantine for all people coming from affected countries.
*March 16: Ban on official travel to risky countries [Italy, France, Spain and Germany]; suspension of all international events taking place in Togo and all non-essential official missions to high risk countries.
column16:
*June 5: Reopening of schools for examinations classes, starting June 8.
*March 20: Closure of schools and universities.
column18:
*March 20: Ban on gatherings of more than 15 people (for religious ceremonies); closure of public spaces (beaches, nightclubs, etc.) and suspension of sporting and cultural events; closure of places of worship (beginning March 21).
*March 20: Mandatory use of masks for market vendors.
*March 16: Ban on gatherings of more than 100 people beginning March 19.
column20: *May 9: Establishment of the working hours from 8am to 4pm.
column22:
*The Heads of States of the West-African Economic and Monetary Union (UEMOA) have declared a temporary suspension of the UEMOA growth and stability pact (setting six convergence criteria, including a 3% of GDP fiscal deficit limit) to help member-countries cope with the fallout of the Covid-19 pandemic. As a result, member countries are allowed to raise their overall fiscal deficit temporarily and use any additional external support provided by donors in response to the Covid-19 crisis.

*April 1: Creation of a National and Economic Solidarity Fund of XOF 400 billion (11.8% of GDP) to be financed by the government, international partners, and private citizens.
*March 20: The authorities have announced an action plan heavily reliant on development partner financing. The overall financing needed is estimated at XOF 70 billion (about USD 130 million or 2% of GDP).
column25:
*April 1: Creation of a Joint Pandemic Task Force, consisting of 5 000 defence and security force officers; establishment of mobile laboratories for screening and testing throughout the country; equipment of treatment centres, improvement of drug availability and launch of a vast program to rehabilitate hospitals and provide health centres with standard infrastructure to screen and treat people with Covid-19. Imports of medical equipment and other products used exclusively in the fight against Covid-10 have been exonerated from taxes and duties.
The estimated costs of a total multi-phase health plan are XOF 110 billion (USD187 million; 3.3% of GDP), of which XOF 20.8 billion (USD34 million, 0.6% of GDP) for the immediate Covid-19 response and the remainder for the strengthening of the health system.
*March 21: The Central Bank for West African States (BCEAO) has announced measures to promote the use of electronic payments.
column28: *April 3: The National Solidarity and Recovery Fund includes free electricity and water bills for three months for the poorest households. The subsidy paid by the central government per month is XOF 1.7 billion (USD 2.9 million) for the electricity utility and XOF 481 million (USD 0.8 million) for the water utility.
column31:
* The government announced a series of fiscal measures for businesses:

- the reduction of VAT rate from 18% to 10% for the hotel and catering sectors;

- the suspension of tax audits and penalties for the fiscal year;

- a waiver for the submission of financial statements and postponement of tax payments for selected businesses;

- granting instalments in tax payments for SMEs.
column34: *The government is also preparing an agriculture response plan to ensure food security, increase income of farmers and support growth in the sector.
column37: *April 3: Tax recoveries are suspended in the same way as tax adjustments. Tax exemption and the suspension of customs duties on medical equipment and medicine for the duration of the crisis.
column40: *The government is also preparing an agriculture response plan to ensure food security, increase income of farmers and support growth in the sector.
column43: Information not available
column46:
*June 22: The Monetary Policy Committee cut by 50 basis points the ceiling and the floor of the monetary policy corridor, to 4 and 2% respectively.
*The Central Bank for West African States (BCEAO) launched a special 3-month refinancing window at a fixed rate of 2.5% for limited amounts of 3-month “Covid-19 T-Bills” to be issued by each UEMOA sovereign to help meet immediate funding needs related to the current pandemic. The amount of such special T-Bills issued by Togo amounted to 3.2% of GDP.
*March 25: The West African Development Bank (BOAD) decided to grant to the WAEMU (UEMOA) members countries XOF 120 billion in concessional loans (XOF 15 billion per country) to be disbursed immediately; such loans are softened though the interest subsidy mechanism replenished by BCEAO and the WAEMU Commission for XOF 25 billion and XOF 15 billion, respectively.
*March 23: The Central Bank for West African States (BCEAO) first raised the liquidity made available to banks at its weekly and monthly auctions of March 23, allowing average refinancing rates to remain relatively close to the floor of the monetary policy corridor of 2.5%. This was followed, starting with the weekly refinancing auction of March 30, by the adoption of a full allotment strategy at a fixed rate of 2.5% thereby allowing banks to satisfy their liquidity needs fully at a lower rate.
column47:
*The WAEMU (UEMOA) authorities have extended by one year the five-year period initiated in 2018 for the transition to Basle II/III bank prudential requirements. In particular, the regulatory capital adequacy ratio will remain unchanged at end-2020 from its 2019 level of 9.2%, before gradually increasing to 11.5% by 2023 instead of 2022 as initially planned.
*March 21: The BCEAO has announced: i) the extension of the collateral framework to access central bank refinancing to include bank loans to prequalified 1,700 privates companies; ii) a framework inviting banks to accommodate demands from firms with COVID-19-related repayment difficulties to postpone for a 3 month renewable period debt service falling due, without the need to classify such postponed claims as NPL.
column48: *April 3: The National Solidarity and Economic Fund includes to provide mobile-based cash transfer programme for informal workers who will receive directly through mobile enrolment a state grant of at least 30% of the minimum wage, with payouts ranging from XOF 10 500 million (USD 18 million) to XOF 20 000 million (USD 34 million). As of May 5, 1.3 million individuals has registered, of whom 500.000 received a NOVISSI payment. Based on program data, 65% of the beneficiaries are women. The cash transfer program is expected to last 3 months at a cost of XOF 36 billion (USD 61 million; 1.1% of GDP). The NOVISSI program was have been revised in late June with eligibility limited to workers in specific districts recording a high contagion rate. In total, 1.4 million individuals have registered and close to 600.000 have received a NOVISSI payment at a total cost of XOF 11.4 billion (USD 19 million; 0.3% of GDP) so far.
column54:
*April 29: The World Bank has approved USD 8.1 million in financing from the International Development Association (IDA) to help Togo combat Covid-19 and better respond to public health emergencies.

*April 28: World Bank has approved USD273 million in International Development Association (IDA) financing for Togo, Benin, Burkina Faso and Niger to facilitate access to services for vulnerable people (especially women and the poorest segments of society), through the West Africa Unique Identification for Regional Integration and Inclusion (WURI) Program.

*April 15: The Association Professionnelle des Banques et tablissements Financiers du Togo (APBEF) mobilised XOF 100 million in the fight against Covid-19.

*April 3: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) authorised an immediate disbursement of USD 131.1 million to Togo in line with the completion of the 6th and final review of the country's economic performance under the programme supported by the Extended Credit Facility (ECF) agreement. The disbursement is four times greater than what was initially planned (USD 35 million) due to the human and economic implications of Covid-19.

*April 3: The National Solidarity and Economic Fund includes the adjustment of the working hours of civil servants from 9 am to 4 pm; a decree freeing 1 048 detainees was signed.

column12:
- March 17: a night curfew (from 18 hr in the evening until 6 hr in the morning) is announced starting on March 18.

- March 21: A 2-week nationwide lockdown is announced.

- March 31: Extension of the lockdown has been announced until April 20.

- April 17: The government adopts a decree-law to fix fines in case of violation of the curfew or confinement. This fine is TND 50 (around 16 EUR) but could increase to TND 100 in the event of recurrence and should be paid within a period not exceeding ten days. The same legislative decree will also make it possible to take additional measures concerning the movement of people and putting them under surveillance in the event of contamination or suspected contamination. Fines for not respecting these provisions are between TND 1,000 and 5,000 and could double in the case of recurrence.

- April 19: The government announces an extension of the lockdown until May 03. The head of the government announces that the hours of the night curfew will be eased during the holy month of Ramadan (from 20 hr in the evening until 6 hr in the morning).

- April 22: The government makes an announcement that period of deconfinement will be spread over several phases from starting from May 04 until the end of June 2020. The procedure of deconfinement will revolve around 5 axes: The application of health measures and preventive standards; The adaptation of the transport system; The application of prior authorizations; The strengthening of control mechanisms; The revision of working hours to avoid congestion in workplaces and transport.

- April 29: The government announces that the deconfinement will be done gradually in three stages. The government's targeted containment plan stipulates the obligation to wear masks and social distancing. In first instance, deconfinement will exclude persons aged 65 and above, children below 15 years, pregnant women, persons with a fragile health condition and chronically ill people.

- May 02: The government adopts a decree-law which specifies different population groups that are required to remain in confinement during the deconfinement period (after May 04). These include elderly people, children below 15 years and chronically ill people.

- May 04: Start of the deconfinement period.

- May 13: The hours of the night curfew are further eased from 23 hr in the evening until 5 hr in the morning.

- May 14: The government announces that deconfinement will also include elderly people (aged 65 and above) and children below 15 years starting on May 18.

- June 08: The government announces the end of the night curfew.

- June 14: End of the third (and final) phase of deconfinement.
column14:
- March 13: Maritime borders are closed. 14 days of quarantine for travellers coming from specific countries (e.g., China, Italy, Iran, France and several other countries).

- March 16: Aerial and land borders are closed. Borders remain open for repatriation of Tunisian citizens and trade in goods.

- April 08: Further confinement measures are adopted by the government: These measures will improve the process of granting traffic circulation permits during the confinement period; In addition, all travelling between governorates is prohibited.

- April 30: The Minister of Transport announces new provisions concerning (public) transport including taxis starting when the deconfinement period starts on May 04. Drivers and passengers will have the obligation to wear a protective mask. Individual taxis will be allowed to transport two people, but only placed in the back side (this was one person during the confinement period). Collective and hire taxis will also be authorized to resume their operations, with only half of the passengers and an tariff revised upwards. This rising tariffs are in place to share the burden between taxi owners and their clients. The Tunisian Transport Company (Transtu) announced new preventive measures that will be in place as of May 04 in the different governorates of Greater Tunis to reduce transport capacity by 50%.

- May 14: The government announces that travelling between governorates is prohibited during the celebrations of the end of the holy month of Ramadan (Eid al-Fitr).

- May 21: The government announces that the mandatory quarantine period for people entering the country from abroad (e.g., repatriated Tunisian citizens) will be reduced from 2 weeks to 1 week. The costs to cover the expenses of quarantine stays in modified hotels will soon be in charge of the persons themselves. All persons from abroad will be subjected, at the beginning of their quarantine, to a medical analysis, then to a second medical analysis at the end of confinement. If the test results are negative, the person can leave from the quarantine.

- June 01: The national commission in charge to combat the Covid-19 has decided to open the land, air and sea borders on June 27.

- June 04: Start of the third phase of the progressive deconfinement period (until June 14). The government announces that that wearing protective masks is compulsory in public transport which will work at 50% of its capacity. Travelling between governorates is allowed again without prior authorisation request. The government also announces that people coming into Tunisia from abroad need to show proof of payment of the hotel where they will go into a one-week mandatory quarantine. In addition, people need to show the negative test result of a Covid-19 test (from a test taken maximum 72 hours before) and fill in a questionnaire about their health status.

- June 08: The Ministry of Transport announces that public transport, such as trains and buses, operating within governorates and urban areas are allowed to carry again 100% of the number of passengers of original capacity. The 50% increase in the tariffs of collective and hire taxis, put in place in beginning of the deconfinement period, is cancelled again.

- June 09: The Ministry of Health announces that babies, children under ten and their parents, as well as people with a fragile health are exempt from compulsory confinement when entering Tunisia from abroad, but have to show negative test results to proof that they are not carriers of the virus.

- June 12: The Ministry of Transport and Logistics allows the resuming of internal flights.

- June 18: The compulsory one-week quarantine procedure for Tunisians returning from abroad and the self payment of the hotel is abolished and replaced by self-quarantine for a period of 14 days. People coming from abroad must show negative Covid-19 test results from a test taken maximum 72 hours before.

- June 24: The government publishes the sanitary and hygiene measures for people entering the country when the borders reopen on June 27. Countries of origin are classified by colour according to the status of the Covid-19 crisis in these countries and updated weekly according to the development of the epidemic situation. People coming from countries with a low contamination rate (green category) will not be required to undergo any health measure.
